Filippenko (UCB) report on behalf of the KAIT GRB team:\n\n\nThe 0.76-m Katzman Automatic Imaging Telescope (KAIT), located at\n\nLick Observatory, automatically responded to the EP-WXT trigger\n\n(ID= 01709065118; Zhou et al., GCN 37715) starting at 05:49 UT,\n\nOct. 05th, ~8 minutes after the trigger. A set of images with 20s\n\nexposure time were obtained in B, V, R I and clear (roughly R)\n\nfilters. Observations lasted for about 5 hours. The flare star\n\n1RXS J225817.2-110434, reported by Zhou et al. (GCN 37715) to be\n\nwithin EP-FXT error circle, was covered by KAIT images. Photometry\n\nof the star show that its brightness decreased from the start of\n\nour observation in all filters, especially in B band which\n\ndecreased by 0.6 mag. The light curves became flat after about 1.5\n\nhours after trigger in all bands. We therefore confirm that this\n\nEP-WXT trigger event is truly associated with this stellar flare.\n","createdOn":1728360888394}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 240910A","submitter":"Andrea Rossi at INAF <andrea.rossi@inaf.it>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 240910A: LBT optical observations ","circularId":37734,"format":"text/plain","body":"A. GCN 37445; Ripa et al. GCN 37450; Godwin, GCN 37464) with the LBC camera mounted on LBT (Mt. Graham, AZ, USA) in r’ and z’ bands (15 min exposure time per filter) approximately at midtime 06:20:00 UT on 2024-09-26 (16.1 days after the burst). Veres at Ruhr University Bochum <veres@astro.ruhr-uni-bochum.de>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"Fermi-LAT Gamma-ray Observations of NuEm-240926A","circularId":37735,"format":"text/plain","body":"P. M. Veres (Ruhr-Universitaet Bochum), C. Bartolini (INFN Bari), S. Buson (DESY, Univ. of Wuerzburg), S. Garrappa (Weizmann Institute of Science), L. Pfeiffer (Univ. of Wuerzburg) and J. Sinapius (DESY)  on behalf of the Fermi-LAT collaboration:\n\nWe report an analysis of observations of the vicinity of the IceCube-HAWC coincidence alert (GCN#37614) with all-sky survey data from the Large Area Telescope (LAT), on board the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope. The HAWC event was detected in a 6.06 hours interval from  2024-09-26 at 13:12:19 UT (T0)  to 2024-09-26 at 19:01:26 UT with J2000 position RA = 149.97  deg, Decl. = 46.22 deg  and a 90% PSF containment of 0.41 deg. One cataloged >100 MeV gamma-ray source is located within the 90% NuEm-240926A localization error, at a distance of roughly 0.12 deg (Fourth Fermi-LAT catalog, 4FGL-DR4, The Fermi-LAT collaboration 2023, arXiv:2307.12546). This is the object 4FGL J0959.6+4606 likely associated with the narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxy SDSS J095909.51+460014.3 (Li et al. 2023, A&A, 676, A9). Based on a preliminary analysis of the LAT data over the-timescales of 6.06 hours, 1-day and 1-month prior to T0, this object is not significantly detected at gamma-rays.\n\nWe searched for short (hours to month) timescale emission from a new gamma-ray transient source. Preliminary analysis indicates no significant (> 5 sigma) new excess emission (> 100 MeV) at the NuEm-240926A best-fit position. Assuming a power-law spectrum (photon index = 2.0 fixed) for a point source at the NuEm-240926A best-fit position, the >100 MeV flux upper limit (95% confidence) is < 2.8e-7 ph cm^-2 s^-1 for ~6.06 hours, < 1.0e-7  ph cm^-2 s^-1 for a 1-day and < 4.6e-9 ph cm^-2 s^-1 for a 1-month integration time before T0.\n\nSince Fermi normally operates in an all-sky scanning mode, regular monitoring of this source will continue. For these observations, the Fermi-LAT contact person is Patrik M. Veres (veres at astro.ruhr-uni-bochum.de). The Fermi LAT is a pair conversion telescope designed to cover the energy band from 20 MeV to greater than 300 GeV. It is the product of an international collaboration between NASA and DOE in the U.S. and many scientific institutions across France, Italy, Japan and Sweden.","createdOn":1728394191288}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241002B","submitter":"Joe Durbak at UMD <gcn.joedurbak@gmail.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241002B: PRIME near-infrared detection in 3rd epoch","circularId":37736,"format":"text/markdown","body":"O. {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"IceCube-241006A","submitter":"Jannis Necker at DESY <jannis.necker@desy.de>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"IceCube-241006A: No candidates from the Zwicky Transient Facility","circularId":37739,"format":"text/plain","body":"Jannis Necker (DESY), Robert Stein (Caltech), Simeon Reusch (DESY), Sven Weimann (Ruhr University Bochum), and Anna Franckowiak (DESY/Ruhr University Bochum) report:\n\nOn behalf of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) and Global Relay of Observatories Watching Transients Happen (GROWTH) collaborations: \n\nAs part of the ZTF neutrino follow up program (Stein et al. 2023), we observed the localization region of the neutrino event IceCube-241006A (Zegarelli et. al, GCN 37723) with the Palomar 48-inch telescope, equipped with the 47 square degree ZTF camera (Bellm et al. 2019, Graham et al. 2019). We started observations in the g- and r-band beginning at 2024-10-08 07:00 UTC, approximately 32.4 hours after event time. We covered 76.0% (1.3 sq deg) of the reported localization region. This estimate accounts for chip gaps. Each exposure was 300s with a typical depth of 21.0 mag. \n \nThe images were processed in real-time through the ZTF reduction and image subtraction pipelines at IPAC to search for potential counterparts (Masci et al. 2019). AMPEL (Nordin et al. 2019, Stein et al. 2021) was used to search the alerts database for candidates. We reject stellar sources (Tachibana and Miller 2018) and moving objects, and apply machine learning algorithms (Mahabal et al. 2019). We are left with the following high-significance transient candidates by our pipeline, all lying within the 90.0% localization of the skymap.\n\n+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+\n| ZTF Name     | IAU Name  | RA (deg)    | DEC (deg)   | Filter | Mag   | MagErr |\n+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+\n| ZTF19accjndb |  -------  | 058.6439041 | +08.5812604 | g      | 20.59 | 0.12    \n| ZTF24ablklut |  -------  | 058.2043689 | +08.6628184 | r      | 21.69 | 0.18   |  \n+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------+\n \n\nAmongst our candidates, \n\nZTF19accjndb was first detected on 2019-09-09, and has a crossmatched detection as WISEA J035434.54+083452.2 at a distance of 0.35\". This source is also listed in milliquas (Flesch 2023) as a likely QSO (p=98%). This AGN has been detected previously by ZTF, and does not appear to currently be in an elevated optical state. It had been gradually fading in difference image detections for the past 60 days, and these represent minor fluctations relative to the archival PS1 magnitude of g=18.6 (Chambers et al. 2016). \n\nZTF24ablklut was first detected on 2024-10-08. It has a cross-matched detection as WISEA J035249.06+083946.1 at a distance of  0.19\". Based on the archival MIR colours of this source (W1-W2=1.0), this object is very likely to be an AGN (Stern et al. 2012). The recent optical detection is very faint in difference imaging, representing a small increase relative to the archival detection in PS1 at r=20.5 (Chambers et al. 2016).\n\nWe therefore find no reason to suggest that either ZTF19accjndb/WISEA J035434.54+083452.2 or ZTF24ablklut/WISEA J035249.06+083946.1 are related to the neutrino.\n\nObservations of this field will continue as part of our standard ToO cadence for high-energy neutrinos (Stein et al 2023.).\n\nZTF and GROWTH are worldwide collaborations comprising Caltech, USA; IPAC, USA; WIS, Israel; OKC, Sweden; JSI/UMd, USA; DESY, Germany; TANGO, Taiwan; UW Milwaukee, USA; LANL, USA; TCD, Ireland; IN2P3, France.\n\nGROWTH acknowledges generous support of the NSF under PIRE Grant No 1545949.\nAlert distribution service provided by DIRAC@UW (Patterson et al. 2019).\nAlert database searches are done by AMPEL (Nordin et al. 2019).\nAlert filtering is performed with the nuztf (Stein et al. 2021, The candidate was found by the GstLAL [1] and MBTA [2] analysis pipelines.\n\nS241009l is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 3.3e-08 Hz, or about one in 11 months. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S241009l\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (98%), Terrestrial (2%), NSBH (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [3] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [3] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state for maximum neutron star mass. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [4], distributed via GCN notice about 27 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,2, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [4], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,2. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,2 sky map, the 90% credible region is 2544 deg2. Marginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 6642 +/- 2029 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/.\n\n [1] Tsukada et al. The candidate was found by the GstLAL [1], MBTA [2], PyCBC Live [3], and SPIIR [4] analysis pipelines.\n\nS241009an is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.9e-12 Hz, or about one in 1e4 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S241009an\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), NSBH (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [5] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [5] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state for maximum neutron star mass. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is 2%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 37 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,1 sky map, the 90% credible region is 542 deg2. Salvaggio (INAF-OAB) and\nP.A. Evans (U. Leicester) reports on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nSwift-XRT has conducted further observations of the field of the\nFermi/GBM-detected burst GRB 241002B (GCN Circs. 37668 and 37711), also\ndetected by Swift-BAT GUANO (GCN Circ. 37704). The observations now\nextend from T0+134.5 ks to T0+600.2 ks. The source previously reported,\n\"Source 4\", is fading with 2.8 sigma significance and thus is believed\nto be the GRB afterglow. Using 2711 s of PC mode data and 3 UVOT\nimages, we find an enhanced XRT position (using the XRT-UVOT alignment\nand matching UVOT field sources to the USNO-B1 catalogue): RA, Dec =\n328.32006, -58.94706 which is equivalent to:\n\nRA (J2000): 21h 53m 16.81s\nDec(J2000): -58d 56' 49.4\"\n\nwith an uncertainty of 3.2 arcsec (radius, 90% confidence). This\nposition is 3.2 arcsec from the position of candidate optical\ncounterpart GOTO24gpc/AT 2024xbg (GCN Circs. 37676  and 37694).\n\nThe light curve can be modelled with a power-law decay with a decay\nindex of alpha=0.9 (+0.6, -0.4).\n\nA spectrum formed from the PC mode data can be fitted with an absorbed\npower-law with a photon spectral index of 1.7 (+0.9, -0.7). The\nbest-fitting absorption column is  1.3 (+2.8, -0.9) x 10^21 cm^-2,\nconsistent with the Galactic value of 3.0 x 10^20 cm^-2 (Willingale et\nal. 2013). The counts to observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux\nconversion factor deduced from this spectrum  is 4.6 x 10^-11 (5.3 x\n10^-11) erg cm^-2 count^-1. \n\nA summary of the PC-mode spectrum is thus:\nTotal column:\t     1.3 (+2.8, -0.9) x 10^21 cm^-2\nGalactic foreground: 3.0 x 10^20 cm^-2\nExcess significance: <1.6 sigma\nPhoton index:\t     1.7 (+0.9, -0.7)\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/00021721.\nThe results of the full analysis of the XRT observations are available\nat https://www.swift.ac.uk/ToO_GRBs/00021721.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n\n","createdOn":1728467512239}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241008A","submitter":"Rahul Gupta at NASA GSFC <rahul.gupta@nasa.gov>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241008A: Fermi-LAT detection","circularId":37747,"format":"text/plain","body":"R. Gupta (NASA GSFC), C. Bartolini (UniTrento e INFN Bari), and J. Racusin (NASA GSFC) report on behalf of the Fermi-LAT Collaboration:\n\nOn Oct 08, 2024, Fermi-LAT detected high-energy emission from GRB 241008A, which was also detected by Fermi-GBM (trigger 750117609/ 241008917, GCN 37740).\n\nThe best LAT on-ground location is found to be:\n\nRA, Dec = 112.84, -9.40 (J2000)\n\nwith an error radius of 0.23 deg (90 % containment, statistical error only).\n\nThis was 82 deg from the LAT boresight at the time of the GBM trigger: T0 = 22:00:04 UT.\n\nThe data from the Fermi-LAT show a significant increase in the event rate that is spatially and temporally correlated with the GBM emission with high significance. The photon flux above 100 MeV in the time interval 0-2050 s after the GBM trigger is (2.1 +/- 0.7) E-6 ph/cm2/s. The estimated photon index above 100 MeV is -2.0 +/- 0.3.\n\nThe highest-energy photon is a 1.8 GeV event which is observed ~1667 seconds after the GBM trigger.\n\nThe Fermi-LAT point of contact for this burst is Rahul Gupta (rahul.gupta@nasa.gov).\n\nThe Fermi-LAT is a pair conversion telescope designed to cover the energy band from 20 MeV to greater than 300 GeV. Myers (NPP/GSFC) reports on behalf of the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\"At 22:00:04.35 UT on 08 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB 241008A (trigger 750117609/241008917).\nwhich was also detected by Fermi-LAT (Gupta et al. 2024, GCN 37747).\nThe Fermi GBM on-ground location is consistent with the Fermi-LAT position.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 75 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of two peaks with a duration (T90)\nof about 53 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0 to T0+53.2 s is best fit by\na power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff.\nThe power law index is -1.01 +/- 0.03 and the cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 720 +/- 70 keV.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(2.46 +/- 0.05)E-05 erg/cm^2. (NAOC), Li-Ping Xin (NAOC), Bing Zhang (UNLV)\n\nReport on behalf of the SVOM team:\n\nDuring the commissioning phase, the SVOM/ECLAIRs telescope triggered and located GRB 241009A (sb24100915) at 2024-10-09T19:17:29 UT (Tb).\n\nThe following trigger information was received on the ground with low-latency by the SVOM VHF Alert Network.\nThe burst was detected by both the on-board Count-Rate Trigger (CRT) and Image Trigger (IMT) and 12 Alerts were received. The detection with the best signal-to-noise ratio of 15.3 sigma is obtained by CRT in the 8-50 keV energy band over a time window of 10.24 s starting at Tb.\n\nThis is a clear long duration GRB.\n\nThe median location of the event on all 12 Alerts is RA, Dec = 325.11, -35.63 (J2000).\nThe statistical uncertainty on this position is 5.6 arcminutes, to which we recommend adding 10 arcminutes of systematic uncertainty in quadrature.\n\nThe SVOM satellite did not slew onto this burst.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA), French Space Agency (CNES), and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. The candidate was found by the cWB BBH [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], and PyCBC Live [4] analysis pipelines.\n\nS241009em is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 2.8e-09 Hz, or about one in 11 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S241009em\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), NSBH (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nThere was a noise transient (glitch) in the LIGO Livingston detector near the event time which may affect the localization of the candidate.\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [5] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [5] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state for maximum neutron star mass. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 27 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. Garrappa (Weizmann Institute of Science), C. Bartolini (INFN Bari), S. Buson (DESY, Univ. of Wuerzburg), L. Pfeiffer (Univ. of Wuerzburg), J. Sinapius (DESY) and P. M. Veres (Ruhr University Bochum) on behalf of the Fermi-LAT collaboration:\n\nWe report an analysis of observations of the vicinity of the high-energy IC241006A neutrino event (GCN 37723) with all-sky survey data from the Large Area Telescope (LAT), on board the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope. The IceCube event was detected on 2024-10-06  22:38:14.30 UTC (T0) with J2000 position RA = 58.36 (+0.94, -0.84) deg, Decl. = +8.35 (+0.47, -0.49) deg 90% PSF containment. No Fermi 4FGL catalog gamma-ray source is located within the 90% IC-240929A localization error (Fourth Fermi-LAT catalog, 4FGL-DR4, The Fermi-LAT collaboration 2023, arXiv:2307.12546). \n\nWe searched for the existence of intermediate (days to years) timescale emission from a new gamma-ray transient source. Preliminary analysis indicates no significant (>5sigma) new excess emission (>100 MeV) within the IC241006A 90% confidence localization. Assuming a power-law spectrum (photon index = 2.0 fixed) for a point source at the IceCube best-fit position, the >100 MeV flux upper limit (95% confidence) is <1.8e-10 ph cm^-2 s^-1 for ~16-years (2008-08-04 / T0), <8.6e-9 (< 1.1e-7) ph cm^-2 s^-1 for a 1-month (1-day) integration time before T0.\n\nSince Fermi normally operates in an all-sky scanning mode, regular monitoring of this source will continue. For these observations, the Fermi-LAT contact person is S. Garrappa (simone.garrappa at weizmann.ac.il). The Fermi LAT is a pair conversion telescope designed to cover the energy band from 20 MeV to greater than 300 GeV. It is the product of an international collaboration between NASA and DOE in the U.S. and many scientific institutions across France, Italy, Japan and Sweden.","createdOn":1728552657141}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241010A","submitter":"David Palmer at LANL <palmer@lanl.gov>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241010A: Swift detection of a burst with an optical counterpart","circularId":37755,"body":"S. Sbarufatti (INAF-OAB) report on behalf of the Neil Gehrels Swift\nObservatory Team:\n\nAt 10:05:14 UT, the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) triggered and\nlocated GRB 241010A (trigger=1259578).  Swift slewed immediately to the burst.\nThe BAT on-board calculated location is \nRA, Dec 153.365, +11.544 which is \n   RA(J2000) = 10h 13m 28s\n   Dec(J2000) = +11d 32' 38\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3 arcmin (radius, 90% containment, including \nsystematic uncertainty).  The BAT light curve showed a complex\nstructure with a duration of about 40 sec.  The peak count rate\nwas ~10000 counts/sec (15-350 keV), at ~0 sec after the trigger.\n\nThe XRT began observing the field at 10:06:56.3 UT, 102.0 seconds after\nthe BAT trigger. Using promptly downlinked data we find an uncatalogued\nX-ray source located at RA, Dec 153.38152, 11.53521 which is equivalent\nto:\n   RA(J2000)  = 10h 13m 31.56s\n   Dec(J2000) = +11d 32' 06.8\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3.8 arcseconds (radius, 90% containment). This\nlocation is 66 arcseconds from the BAT onboard position, within the BAT\nerror circle. This position may be improved as more data are received;\nthe latest position is available at https://www.swift.ac.uk/sper.  We\ncannot determine whether the source is fading at the present time. \n\nA power-law fit to a spectrum formed from promptly downlinked event\ndata gives a column density in excess of the Galactic value (3.87 x\n10^20 cm^-2, Willingale et al. 2013), with an excess column of 5.8\n(+3.64/-2.97) x 10^21 cm^-2 (90% confidence).\n\nUVOT took a finding chart exposure of 150 seconds with the White filter\nstarting 105 seconds after the BAT trigger. There is a candidate afterglow in\nthe rapidly available 2.7'x2.7' sub-image at\n  RA(J2000)  =\t10:13:31.54 = 153.38141\n  DEC(J2000) = +11:32:03.4  =  11.53429\nwith a 90%-confidence error radius of about 0.77 arc sec. This position is 4.4\narc sec. from the center of the XRT error circle. The estimated magnitude is\n18.33 with a 1-sigma error of about  0.15. Excluding the event that prompted the alert, zero track-like events are found within the 90% containment region of IceCube-241006A. The IceCube sensitivity to neutrino point sources with an E^-2.5 spectrum (E^2 dN/dE at 1 TeV) within the locations spanned by the 90% spatial containment region of IceCube-241006A is 1.3e-01 GeV cm^-2 in a 1000 second time window. 90% of events IceCube would detect from a source at this declination with an E^-2.5 spectrum have energies in the approximate energy range between 2e+02 GeV and 1e+05 GeV.\n\nA subsequent search was performed including 2 days of data centered on the alert event time (2024-10-05 22:38:14.300 UTC to 2024-10-07 22:38:14.300 UTC). In this case, we report a p-value of 1.00, consistent with no significant excess of track events. The IceCube sensitivity to neutrino point sources with an E^-2.5 spectrum (E^2 dN/dE at 1 TeV) within the locations spanned by the 90% spatial containment region of IceCube-241006A is 1.5e-01 GeV cm^-2 in a 2 day time window.\n\nThe IceCube Neutrino Observatory is a cubic-kilometer neutrino detector operating at the geographic South Pole, Antarctica. S241007bw: Updated Sky localization","circularId":37768,"format":"text/plain","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further offline analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1), LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1), and Virgo Observatory (V1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S241007bw (GCN Circular 37727). Parameter estimation has been performed using Bilby [1] and a new sky map, Bilby.multiorder.fits,3, distributed via GCN Notice, is available for retrieval from the GraceDB event page:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S241007bw\n\nFor the Bilby.multiorder.fits,3 sky map, the 90% credible region is 823 deg2. Marginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 3923 +/- 1251 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/.\n\n [1] Ashton et al. PRD 108, 123040 (2023) doi:10.1103/PhysRevD.108.123040","createdOn":1728634008537}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241010A","submitter":"Phil Evans at U of Leicester <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241010A: Swift-XRT refined Analysis","circularId":37769,"body":"S. Dichiara (PSU), J.A. Kennea (PSU), K.L. Page (U. Leicester), A.P.\nBeardmore (U. Leicester), M. Ferro (INAF-OAB), R. Brivio (INAF-OAB), A.\nD'Ai (INAF-IASFPA), D.N. Burrows (PSU) and P.A. Evans report on behalf\nof the Swift-XRT team:\n\nWe have analysed 8.7 ks of XRT data for GRB 241010A, from 86 s to 68.0\nks after the  BAT trigger. The data comprise 9 s in Windowed Timing\n(WT) mode (taken while Swift was slewing), with the remainder in Photon\nCounting (PC) mode. \n\nThe light curve can be modelled with a series of power-law decays. The\ninitial decay index is alpha=3.3 (+4.0, -0.9). At T+154 s  the decay\nflattens to an alpha of 0.1 (+0.3, -0.4). The light curve breaks again\nat T+535 s to a decay with alpha=5.2 (+2.8, -3.4),  and  again at T+677\ns s to alpha=-0.6 (+0.4, -0.9),  before a final break at T+3672 s s\nafter which the decay index is 0.92 (+0.14, -0.05).\n\nA spectrum formed from the PC mode data can be fitted with an absorbed\npower-law with a photon spectral index of 1.91 (+/-0.13). The\nbest-fitting absorption column is  2.0 (+/-0.5) x 10^21 cm^-2, in\nexcess of the Galactic value of 3.9 x 10^20 cm^-2 (Willingale et al.\n2013). The counts to observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux conversion\nfactor deduced from this spectrum  is 3.8 x 10^-11 (5.0 x 10^-11) erg\ncm^-2 count^-1. \n\nA summary of the PC-mode spectrum is thus:\nTotal column:\t     2.0 (+/-0.5) x 10^21 cm^-2\nGalactic foreground: 3.9 x 10^20 cm^-2\nExcess significance: 6.0 sigma\nPhoton index:\t     1.91 (+/-0.13)\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/01259578.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n","createdOn":1728638554308}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241006A","submitter":"agul8829@uni.sydney.edu.au","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241006A: ATCA Radio Upper Limits","circularId":37770,"format":"text/plain","body":"A. Gulati (USyd), G. E. Anderson (Curtin), S. Chastain (UNM), J. K. Leung (UofT/HUJI), S. D. Ryder (Macquarie), A. J. van der Horst (GWU), and L. Rhodes (Oxford) on behalf of the ATCA PanRadio GRB collaboration\n\nWe observed GRB 241006A (Gupta et al., GCN 37722) as part of the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) \"PanRadio GRB\" Large Project C3542 (PI: G. Anderson) at 5.5 and 9 GHz, 5.2 hours post-merger on 2024-10-07 (03:03-14:32 UT) and 2.25 days post-merger on 2024-10-09 (04:30-08:30 UT). \n\nNo radio sources were detected near the Swift/XRT enhanced position (A.P. Beardmore et al., GCN 37724) in either observation epoch. The 3-sigma upper limits for the 9 GHz observations are 27 and 39 uJy respectively.\n\nWe thank the CSIRO Space and Astronomy staff for supporting these observations.\nWe acknowledge the Gomeroi people as the traditional owners of the Observatory site. The Australia Telescope Compact Array is part of the Australia Telescope National Facility (https://ror.org/05qajvd42) which is funded by the Australian Government for operation as a National Facility managed by CSIRO.","createdOn":1728646990485}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241010A","submitter":"Dong Xu at NAOC/CAS <dxu@nao.cas.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241010A: JinShan optical observations and potential host galaxy","circularId":37771,"format":"text/plain","body":"S.Q. Jiang, S.Y. Fu, X. Liu, J. An, Z.P. Zhu, D. Xu (NAOC), J.Z. Liu (XAO) report on behalf of a large collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 241010A detected by Swift (Dichiara et al. GCN 37755) using the 100C telescope of the JinShan project located at Altay, Xinjiang, China. A series of 300 s frames are obtained in the Sloan r-band, starting at 22:02:29.24 on 2024-10-10, i.e. 11.95 hr after the BAT trigger.\n\nThe optical afterglow (Dichiara et al. GCN 37755; Izzo et al. GCN 37756) of the burst is clearly detected in our stacked image. We measured a preliminary magnitude of r = 20.46 +/- 0.08 (AB), calibrated with nearby PanSTARRS stars. The magnitude is not corrected for Galactic extinction.\n\nWe also note that there exists a known source at the JinShan position in the Legacy Survey at coordinates R.A. (J2000) = 10:13:31.5317, Dec.(J2000) = +11:32:03.116, which is ~ 0.4 arcsec from the center of the UVOT position. The source has g = 23.0 +/- 0.05, r = 22.83 +/- 0.06, z = 22.13 +/- 0.09, a photometric redshfit of z = 0.87 +/- 0.11, and could be the host galaxy of the burst.\n\nWe acknowledge the excellent support from X. Yao, S.W. Luo, and Z.K. Feng for enabling these observations.","createdOn":1728647736480}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241009A","submitter":"Phil Evans at U of Leicester <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241009A: Swift-XRT afterglow detection","circularId":37772,"body":"M. A. Williams (PSU), S. Dichiara (PSU), J.A. Kennea (PSU), J.P.\nOsborne (U. Leicester), K.L. Page (U. Leicester), A.P. Beardmore (U.\nLeicester), C. Salvaggio (INAF-OAB), M. Ferro (INAF-OAB), R. Brivio\n(INAF-OAB) and P.A. Evans (U. Leicester) reports on behalf of the\nSwift-XRT team:\n\nSwift-XRT has performed follow-up observations of the\nSVOM/ECLAIRs-detected burst GRB 241009A, collecting 2.1 ks of Photon\nCounting (PC) mode data between T0+14.7 ks and T0+106.0 ks. \n\nSeven uncatalogued X-ray sources are detected, of which one (\"Source\n1\") is believed to be the afterglow. Using 433 s of PC mode data and 1\nUVOT image, we find an enhanced XRT position (using the XRT-UVOT\nalignment and matching UVOT field sources to the USNO-B1 catalogue):\nRA, Dec = 325.00866, -35.65944 which is equivalent to:\n\nRA (J2000): 21h 40m 02.08s\nDec(J2000): -35d 39' 34.0\"\n\nwith an uncertainty of 4.2 arcsec (radius, 90% confidence). This\nposition is 6.3 arcmin from the SVOM/ECLAIRs position. The source has\nfaded from a count rate of 0.0441 [+0.013, -0.011] ct s^-1 at T0+14.9\nks to an upper limit of 0.0132 ct s^-1 at T0+100.9 ks.\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/00021722.\nThe results of the full analysis of the XRT observations are available\nat https://www.swift.ac.uk/ToO_GRBs/00021722.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n\n","createdOn":1728661660796}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241009A","submitter":"Thomas Hussenot-Desenonges at IJCLab <thomas.hussenot@ijclab.in2p3.fr>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241009A: GRANDMA optical upper limits","circularId":37773,"format":"text/plain","body":"T. St-Gelais (KNC)\non behalf of the GRANDMA collaboration.\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 241009A, detected by SVOM/ECLAIRs (GCN 37749) with the GRANDMA network and its citizen science project Kilonova-catcher (KNC). Laurier | 41x60s | R | 19.1 (Vega) |\n\nIn particular, within these upperlimits, we do not detect any optical counterpart of the Swift-XRT afterglow position candidate (RA 21h 40m 02.08s DEC -35° 39′ 34.0″) (GCN 37772).\n\nImages obtained in Johnson Cousin filters were calibrated using the Gaia DR3 Synphot catalog. Images obtained with Sloan filters were calibrated using the SkyMapper DR4 catalog. The unfiltered image taken by TAROT-TRE was calibrated as a Gaia G image using the Gaia eDR3 catalogue.\n\nAll the data have been reduced by a single data processing pipeline, STDPipe (Karpov et al., 2022). The candidate was found by the GstLAL [1] analysis pipeline.\n\nS241011k is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 2.5e-34 Hz, or about one in 1e26 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S241011k\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), Terrestrial (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [2] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [2] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state for maximum neutron star mass. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is 3%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 28 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,1 sky map, the 90% credible region is 76 deg2. Marginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 232 +/- 51 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/.\n\n [1] Tsukada et al. We find 507 galaxies within the 90% containment volume, and we list here the top 20 galaxies sorted by the joint probability of the 3D localization and the WISE W1 luminosity (an observable proxy for stellar mass). For the full or top 20 list of galaxies in the 90% volume go either to the NED Gravitational Wave Followup service at https://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/uri/NED::GWF/ or click on the following links:\n\nFull List Download: https://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/uri/NED::GWFglist/fits/S241011k/3                       \nTop 20 List Download: https://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/uri/NED::GWFglist/fits/S241011k/3/20\n\nThe NED-GWF service provides downloadable galaxy lists and visualizations for candidate host galaxies. For each GW alert, these products are automatically generated and made available within minutes to expedite efficient electromagnetic follow-up observations. galaxies in NED-LVS that fall in the 90% probability volume for S241011k sorted by the joint probability of 3D position and WISE W1 luminosity (P_3D * P_LumW1). Galaxy is the NED preferred name. RA and Dec are the Equatorial coordinates in degrees (J2000). Objtype is the object type of the galaxy candidate. Distance is the distance to the galaxy in Mpc. m_NUV and mErr_NUV are the apparent magnitude and error from GALEX. m_Ks and mErr_Ks are the apparent magnitude and error from 2MASS. m_W1 and mErr_W1 are the apparent magnitude and error from AllWISE. (2017) in the redshift range [1,5], to the volume of the nearby universe enclosed within z = 0.151.\n\n- Assuming a constant GRB formation rate, we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~130 yr.\n- Assuming the GRB formation rate of Palmerio & Daigne (2021), we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~520 yr.\n\nWe conclude that there is a ~10% probability to observe an event like GRB 221009A about 50 years after the discovery of the first GRB.\n\nBibliography :\n- Cenko, S. GCNC 32660 -���������� Eiso = 8e53 ergs in [75 keV 1 MeV] ;\nFrederiks et al. GCNC 32668 - Eiso = 3e54 ergs in [20 keV - 10 MeV ?] ;\nKann et al. GCNC 32686), considering the rate of such extremely energetic GRBs observed at higher redshifts.\n\nConsidering a flat cosmology with H0 = 67.4 km/s/Mpc and Omegam = 0.315 (Planck Collaboration et al. 2020), we extrapolate the rate of ���4 extremely energetic GRBs per year derived by Atteia et al. (2017) in the redshift range [1,5], to the volume of the nearby universe enclosed within z = 0.151.\n\n- Assuming a constant GRB formation rate, we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~130 yr.\n- Assuming the GRB formation rate of Palmerio & Daigne (2021), we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~520 yr.\n\nWe conclude that there is a ~10% probability to observe an event like GRB 221009A about 50 years after the discovery of the first GRB.\n\nBibliography :\n- Cenko, S. Hjorth, M. I. Andersen, H. Pedersen, A. O. Jaunsen on behalf of the NOT \nGRB team and E. Costa & E. Palazzi on behalf of the SAX GRB team report:\n\nOn June 13.9 UT and June 17.9 UT we obtained R band images (600 sec each, \nseeing FWHM=0.7\") of the BeppoSAX error circle of GRB 980613 (Piro & Costa, \nGCN #99) with the 2.5-m Nordic Optical Telescope. We have discovered a faint \npoint source in our June 13.9 image which is not detected in our June 17.9 \nimage (which reaches a similar limiting magnitude). The source is located at \n(+- 0.5\"):\n\nRA(J2000)  =  10 17 57.64\nDec(J2000) = +71 27 26.4\n\nPreliminary photometry (Cousins R) of the source yields:\n\nJune 13.8897 UT: R = 22.9+-0.2\nJune 17.9088 UT: R > 24.0 (formal 10-sigma limit)\n\nThese numbers assume R=19.11 for USNO catalogue entry U1575-03105992 located at \nRA(J2000)=10 17 54.83, Dec(2000)=+71 27 39.8, consistent with the photometry \nof the isolated star 4_r of Odewahn et al. (GCN #105) (assuming r-R=0.35).\n\nThe location of the source is consistent with the BeppoSAX WFC error circle\nof GRB 980613 (GCN #99) and the BeppoSAX MECS error circle for source A\n(Piro, GCN #104; Costa et al., IAUC 6939). \n\nThe photometry is consistent with previously reported upper limits for\noptically variable objects in the field (R > 20.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado \net al., GCN #102; I>21.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado et al., GCN #103; \nr>21.0 on June 16.0, Odewahn et al., GCN #105; I>22.3 on June 14.2, Halpern\net al., GCN #106, I>20.6 on June 14.0 and I>21.5 on June 14.4, Diercks et \nal., GCN #108).\n\nGiven the consistency with the BeppoSAX error circles of GRB 980613 and\nthe rapidly fading nature of the source we suggest that the detected object\nis the optical afterglow of GRB 980613.\n\nFinding charts and updates of these preliminary results will be posted at \nhttp://www.nordita.dk/~jens/grb980613/\n\nThis report may be cited.","createdOn":898186684000,"email":"jens@nordita.dk"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Chryssa Kouveliotou at MSFC  <kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"Discovery of a new SGR source, SGR1627-41","circularId":107,"bibcode":"1998GCN...107....1K","body":"C. Kouveliotou, Universities Space Research Association, M. Kippen, P.\nWoods, G. Richardson, University of Alabama in Huntsville, V.\nConnaughton, National Research Council, report on behalf of the BATSE\nteam at NASA/Marshall Space Flight Center:\n\nBATSE has detected repeated soft gamma-ray bursts consistent with the\nsame (previously unknown) location. We recorded three bursts on June\n15.109, 15.296, 15.411 UT (BATSE triggers 6825, 6826, 6827,\nrespectively) with an average duration of ~ 200 milliseconds.\nPreliminary spectral analysis of the data indicates that the events\nare very soft, with power law spectral indices varying between -3.0\nand -7.0. BATSE triggered 5 more times, on June 17.873, 17.901,\n18.004, 18.035, and 18.071 UT (BATSE trigger numbers 6833, 6834, 6835,\n6836 and 6837, respectively). The last trigger had a peak count rate\nof over 300000 counts/sec above background (integrated over 4\ndetectors between 20-1000 keV, in 1 second interval) and a duration of\n~ 3 seconds. Due to its very high peak intensity, deadtime effects\nprevent us from using it for localization, until we receive more data\ntypes. The weighted location of the 7 remaining triggers is centered\non R.A. = 16h27m12.0s and dec = -41d06.0' with an error radius of\nabout 2 degrees.  This location does not correspond to any previously\nknown SGR source; we conclude that we have discovered a new source,\nSGR1627-41. We have initiated an RXTE ToO and we strongly encourage\nwide field observations at other wavelengths.","createdOn":898140980000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Filippo Frontera at ITESRE CNR  <filippo@tesre.bo.cnr.it>","subject":"Giant flare from SGR1900+14","circularId":1041,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1041....1G","body":"C.Guidorzi, E.Montanari and F.Frontera, University of Ferrara, Italy;  E.\nCosta, G.Gandolfi, M.Feroci and L.Piro, IAS-CNR, Roma;  L.Amati, TESRE,\nCNR, Bologna; J.J.M. in 't Zand, SRON and Astronomical Institute, Utrecht,\nNL; G. Belardinelli at INFN (Rome ToV) <belardinelli@roma2.infn.it>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231226av: Identification of a GW compact binary merger candidate","circularId":35428,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35428....1L","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe identified the compact binary merger candidate S231226av during real-time processing of data from LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) and LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1) at 2023-12-26 10:15:20.306 UTC (GPS time: 1387620938.306). The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], and PyCBC Live [4] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231226av is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.1e-50 Hz, or about one in 1e42 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231226av\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), BNS (<1%), or Terrestrial (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [5] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [5] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 30 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,1 sky map, the 90% credible region is 244 deg2. Marginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 1041 +/- 235 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/userguide/.\n\n [1] Klimenko et al. Henden (USRA/USNO) reports on behalf of the USNO GRB team:\n\nWe have obtained a second night of photometry with the\nNOFS 1.0m telescope for the field of GRB010324.  The\nrevised BVRcIc photometry file can be found at\nftp://ftp.nofs.navy.mil/pub/outgoing/aah/grb/grb010324.dat\nThe quality of this file is still below our normal\nstandards, but is good to about 0.03mag for all\nmagnitudes and colors. (GCN1024)\nlies just to the south of this calibration field and\nso is not included in the file.\nArne","createdOn":985967038000,"email":"aah@nofs.navy.mil"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Tianrui Sun at Purple Mountain Obs,CAS  <trsun@pmo.ac.cn>","subject":"GRB 220527A: AST3-3 Yaoan Optical Observation","circularId":32146,"bibcode":"2022GCN.32146....1S","body":"Tianrui Sun (Purple Mountain Observatory), Lei Hu, Maokai Hu, Xuefeng Wu, Lei Liu, Kelai Meng, Xiaoyan Li (Nanjing Institute of Astronomical Observation Technology),\nZhengyang Li, Xiangyan Yuan, Lifan Wang (TAMU), Xiaofeng Wang (Tsinghua University), report on behalf the AST3 Team:\n    \nFollowing the detection of GRB 220527A detected by AGILE (Ursi et al., GCN \n32129), Fermi (Fermi GBM team, GCN 32130; Bissaldi et al., GCN 32131), CALET (Yamaoka et la., GCN 32139), and AstroSat (Gopalakrishnan et al., \nGCN 32140), we use Antarctic Survey Telescope 3-3 at Yaoan Astronomy Observation (China, Yunnan) to follow up for the afterglow (Sbarufatti et\nal., GCN 32135; Tohuvavohu, GCN 32136; Imai et al., GCN 32138; Xu et al.,\nGCN 32141; Simon et al. 32143; D'Avanzo et al., 32145).\n\n\n\n\nWe observed the target position with 14 x 60s exposure in g-band starting from 27 May 2022, UTC 21:11:36.003, \n\nabout 11.9 hours after the burst.\n\nThe magnitude detection at the Swift UVOT position (GCN 32136) on the combined images for the GRB afterglow :\ng=19.3 +/- 0.06\n\n\nWe used the PS1 catalogue as the magnitude reference for calibration.","createdOn":1653751211000,"email":"trsun@pmo.ac.cn"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andrew S. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 980326: Late-time HST/STIS observations","circularId":1029,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1029....1F","body":"Andrew Fruchter (STScI), Paul Vreeswijk (University of Amsterdam) and\nPeter Nugent (LBNL) report on behalf of a larger HST GRB collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 980326 with HST/STIS on 31 December 2000,\njust over 1000 days after the burst. The total exposure time was 7080\nseconds in the 50CCD aperture. The images were reduced by the standard\nHST pipeline, and drizzled to a combined image with a pixelscale of\n0.\"0254.\n\nWe projected the location of the early afterglow from a KeckII/LRIS R\nband image, taken by Filippenko, Leonard and Riess on March 27, 1998\n(see GCN 33).  We estimate the 1-sigma error radius to be less than 1.5\ndrizzled HST pixels, which includes both the scatter in the\ntransformation (0.9 pixels, using 6 reference stars) and the\nmeasurement error of the transient in the Keck image (0.8 pixels).\n\nWithin one pixel of the estimated position, there was evidence of a\nsmall source.  We therefore convolved the image with a gaussian with a\nFWHM equal to that of the PSF (3.5 drizzled pixels).  This procedure\nuses the PSF as a matched filter to enhance the the signal-to-noise\nratio of unresolved sources.  In the convolved image an object is\nfound, again offset by one pixel from the expected position with a\nsignificance of ~4.5 sigma.  We estimate a magnitude (in the broad STIS\n50ccd filter) of V = 29.25 +/- 0.25.\n\nBloom et al., (1999, Nature, 401, 453) have suggested that the unusual\nlight curve of this GRB might be explained by an underlying supernova,\nand on the basis of this estimated a redshift of about z~1.   A\nsupernova at this redshift (which in this model peaks around a\nmagnitude of 25) would be expected to be significantly fainter than\nV=29 by now (as would the rapidly decaying GRB afterglow).  Therefore,\nwe may be detecting a faint host galaxy.  Deep HST images have in all\nother cases detected a host underlying the GRB, when good astrometry\nwas available for the GRB.  If we are observing a host galaxy, then the\nabove magnitude could underestimate its brightness by as much as a few\ntenths of a magnitude, due to extended emission missed in this\nmeasurement.  A galaxy at a z~1 with this observed magnitude would lie\na rather remarkable 7 magnitudes below L*, the knee of the of the\ngalaxy luminosity function at that redshift.\n\nGiven the apparent point-source nature of the detected object, and the\nlack of color information, we cannot exclude the possibility (which we\nconsider remote) that we are observing a light echo, from either the\nGRB or the supernova.\n\nImages of the field can be found at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/980326","createdOn":985809183000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Sylvia Biscoveanu at MIT <sylvia.biscoveanu@ligo.org>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231206ca: Updated Sky localization","circularId":35305,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35305....1L","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) and LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S231206ca (GCN Circular 35297). Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 010222: HST observations -- host galaxy and late-time decay","circularId":1087,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1087....1F","body":"A. Fruchter, I. Burud, J. Rhoads and A. Levan (STScI) report:\n\nWe have reduced the now public archival HST images of GRB 010222, taken\non 28 February, 17 and 18 March, 5 and 6 April, and 4 and 5 May of \nthis year using the F606W (V/R) and F814W (I) filters on WFPC2.   Using\nthe most recent data, we find that OT of GRB 010222 is clearly superposed\non a host galaxy.  \n\nIn order to accurately determine the decay of the OT and the magnitude\nof the host, we have drizzled the images onto an output grid that\nallows interlacing of these 2-point dithered images.  We have then fit\nfor the decay of the OT and the host galaxy flux using a small (~0.\"2)\naperture, which provides the best estimate of the OT as a function of\ntime, as well as using a larger aperture (~0.\"5), which is more\nappropriate for determining the host galaxy magnitude.\n\nWe find that the late-time decay of the OT is significantly steeper\nthan previously reported.  We find a power-law decay between 28 February\n(day 6) and 5 May (day 71) of -1.7 +/- 0.05.  Formally, we find\na slightly steeper decay (-1.73 +/- 0.02) in F606W than in F814W \n(-1.64 +/- 0.04), but this discrepancy may indicate the level of\nsystematic error in the slope measurement rather than true color\nevolution of the OT.\n\nWe find that the host galaxy is dominated by a compact core (FWHM ~ 0.\"15)\nlocated directly under the OT.  The magnitude of the host is \nF606W(AB) = 26.0 +/- 0.1, F814W(AB) = 25.8 +/- 0.15.  \n\nImages of the host, as well as a plot of the coninuing decline of the OT,\nare available at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/010222","createdOn":997814700000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"SGR1900+14","circularId":1053,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10053....1X","body":"K. Twelve dithered exposures were\ncombined to produce a final image with an exposure time of 7031s.\n\nNo source is immediately visible at the position of the GRB. The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], PyCBC Live [4], and SPIIR [5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231206cc is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.9e-35 Hz, or about one in 1e27 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231206cc\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), BNS (<1%), or Terrestrial (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [6] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [6] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 30 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,2, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,2. The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], PyCBC Live [4], and SPIIR [5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231206ca is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 3.2e-10 Hz, or about one in 1e2 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231206ca\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), or NSBH (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [6] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [6] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 25 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome), J.J.M. in 't Zand (Astronomical Institute,\nUtrecht University and SRON), P. Soffitta (IAS/CNR, Rome), K. Hurley\n(UCB, California), F. Frontera (Univ. Ferrara and TESRE/CNR, Bologna)\nand E. Mazets (IOFFE, S. Petersburg), report:\n\n\"A high-time resolution analysis has been performed of the BeppoSAX\nWide Field Camera data of SGR 1900+14 taken on April 18, 2001, when\nthe most recent giant flare was detected (Guidorzi et al., GCN 1041\nand IAUC 7611). The data cover a short intermediate pointing of Wide\nField Camera unit 1 between two scheduled targets. The observation\nstarted 2780 s before the giant flare and ended with the automatic\nswitch off due to that flare. The observation was interrupted when\nBeppoSAX traversed the SAA, from 2282 till 1052 s before the\ngiant flare. The analysis revealed the presence of 3 short X-ray\nprecursors, occurring 2537, 755, and 444 s before the giant flare\n(respectively, 25975, 27757 and 28068 s UT), with durations of 100,\n125 and 55 ms, peak fluxes in excess of 20 Crab units (2-28 keV),\nand 9-28/2-9 keV spectral hardness ratios that are consistent with\npower laws with photon indices between roughly 0.5 and 1.2. None of the\nprecursors was detected in the gamma-ray data from the BeppoSAX/GRBM,\nthe gamma-ray burst detector on Ulysses, and from Konus on Wind.\"","createdOn":988997172000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010612","circularId":1065,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10065....1C","body":"K. The burst occurred \nat 18950.56 SOD {05:15:50.56} UT on 21 September.  The burst is seen \nin the WXM X detector and is therefore well-localized in the X \ndirection; the burst was apparently outside the coded FOV of the WXM \nY detector, which therefore gives limited information about the Y \ndirection of the burst.\n\nThe X-detector data gives a good (+/-10 arcmin) localization in the X\ndirection and crude limits on Y, resulting in a localization that is a\nthin, long strip.\n\nTwo points along one side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h52m36s.7, Dec. =  39o35'13\"\nR.A. = 23h10m22s.8, Dec. =  48o57'43\"\n\nTwo points along the other side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h54m04s.0, Dec. =  39o34'23\"\nR.A. = 23h11m52s.5, Dec. =  48o57'00\"\n\nOur estimate is that the strip is  ~10  degrees in the long direction.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~12 s. Frail at NRAO  <dfrail@nrao.edu>","subject":"SGR 1900+14, Chandra observations","circularId":1047,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10047....1M","body":"D. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report on behalf of a larger\ncollaboration\"\n\n\"In response to the 18 April 2001 flare of SGR 1900+14 (GCN 1041) the\nChandra X-ray Observatory has undertaken a sequence of two public\n20-ksec observations of this source, on 22 and 30 April 2001.\n\nThe first observation began at 04:58 UT on 22 April and was taken in\ncontinuous-clocking mode (see also GCN 1046).  Examination of the\nlight curve reveals that at least one burst was observed, 9081 s after\nthe start of the observation.  Assuming the best-fit spectral\nparameters for the observation (see below), the peak 1-s flux of this\nburst was of order 5e-10 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (0.5-10 keV).\n\nSpectral fits to the full background-subtracted data set allow for at\nleast two emission models.  A power-law plus absorption model has\nbest-fit parameters of N_H = 3.18(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha =\n2.70(1), and unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of 4.20(4)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1.\nA power-law plus blackbody and absorption model has best-fit\nparameters of N_H = 2.56(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha = 1.88(1),\nblackbody temperature kT = 0.532(3) keV, unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of\n2.17(3)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1, and flux fraction for the blackbody\ncomponent of 29% (0.5-10 keV).  The addition of the blackbody\ncomponent is not supported by an F-test (65% confidence level) but is\nconsistent with models in the literature (Perna et al. 2001,\nastro-ph/0103273).  Analysis of the RXTE PCA data may help to clarify\nthe presence or absence of the blackbody component, as the PCA count\nrates inferred from the two models given above differ by 50%.\n\nNo narrow spectral features are apparent.  The two-sigma upper limit\nto the flux of a persistent 0.2-keV FWHM emission line in the 5-7 keV\nrange is 1e-5 photons cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThis message may be cited.\"","createdOn":988083484000,"email":"dfrail@nrao.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1055,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1055....1F","body":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14\n\nM. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Roma) and S. Mereghetti (IFC/CNR, Milano),\non behalf of a larger SGR collaboration, and G. Gandolfi, L. Piro\nand E. Costa (IAS/CNR, Roma), on behalf of the BeppoSAX Team,\nreport:\n\n\"A ToO observation of SGR1900+14 was carried out with the\nBeppoSAX Narrow Field Instruments starting on April 18, 15:10 UT,\nless than 8 hours after the large flare reported in GCN #1041.\nIntense bursting activity is present during the 28 hr long\nobservation.  After removing the numerous short bursts, a significant\nflux decay is visible in the MECS and LECS light curves.\nBy using our data and the Chandra 2-10 keV flux (GCN #1046)\nwe find that the decay can be reasonably well described by a power\nlaw with index ~-0.6.  There is also evidence for a spectral softening\ncorrelated with the intensity decrease.\n\nThe average spectrum (after removal of the bursts) can be fit by a\npower law with photon index 2.6+/-0.1 and NH=(4.3 +/-0.3)x10^22 cm^-2.\nThe average 2-10 keV flux during the whole BeppoSAX observation is\n2.9x10^-11 erg/cm^2/s (unabsorbed). The bursts have a significantly\nharder spectrum (power law photon index ~0 in the 2-10 keV range).\n\nPulsations,  with a nearly sinusoidal light curve and a modulation of\nabout 21%, are clearly detected at the barycentered period  P=5.17277(1) s.\nWhen compared with the value measured with Chandra about 3 days later\n(GCN #1049), this yields a dP/dt ~ (4.1 +/- 1.9)x10^-10 s/s.\n\nAn additional BeppoSAX/NFI observation will start on April 29, 20:30 UT.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988388763000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Francesco Longo at U of Trieste,INFN Trieste  <franzlongo1969@gmail.com>","subject":"GRB 221119A: Fermi-LAT detection","circularId":32952,"bibcode":"2022GCN.32952....1F","body":"Longo F. (University and INFN Trieste), Pillera R. (Politecnico and INFN, Bari)\nand Palatiello M. The individual exposures were combined using Drizzle for a total\nexposure time of 5120 s.\n\nWhen this image is subtracted from that obtained by HST on 2000 June\n4.17 a small residual of magnitude R~28 is found at the position of the\ncompact galaxy believed to be the host galaxy (GCN 669); however, the\nresidual is sufficiently faint to be consistent with no detection at\nabout the 2 sigma level. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi,\nF. Frontera, and M. Feroci, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM team, report:\n\nWe have identified a likely precursor to the giant flare from\nSGR1900+14 (GCN 1041, 1043) in the Ulysses data.  This event\noccurred on April 17, 2001, ~42184 s at Ulysses, and if it was\nindeed from SGR1900+14, its Earth-crossing time would have\nbeen ~42332 s.  This burst was ~50 s long, and its time history\nresembles that of the April 18 event, although it is considerably\nless intense.  Its 25-100 keV fluence was ~2.3x10^-5 erg/cm^2,\nand its peak flux over 0.5 s was ~1.5x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s.  Due to\na high solar proton background, these numbers are subject to more\nthan the usual uncertainties.  As SGR1900+14 was Earth-blocked\nat BeppoSAX, it did not observe this event, and there is no\nlocalization data available.\n\nThe time history has been posted at ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010417.\nAlso, we note that the time history of the April 18 event, posted\nat ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010418, was incorrectly labelled \"Counts/\n0.5 s\".  The label should have read \"Counts/Second\". This event is the second burst localized \nfrom this source in the past week, indicating that it may have \nresumed an active state. (The first burst was reported in GCN \nCircular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 27 June burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.947 (19h07m47s.2)\n\nDec. = +9.362 (+9:21:41)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.6 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <200 ms. A total of 1084 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~2 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >3 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >100 x Crab flux).\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993698624000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010629","circularId":1076,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10076....1K","body":"K. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome), J.J.M. in 't Zand (Astronomical Institute,\nUtrecht University and SRON), P. Soffitta (IAS/CNR, Rome), K. Hurley\n(UCB, California), F. Frontera (Univ. Ferrara and TESRE/CNR, Bologna)\nand E. Mazets (IOFFE, S. Petersburg), report:\n\n\"A high-time resolution analysis has been performed of the BeppoSAX\nWide Field Camera data of SGR 1900+14 taken on April 18, 2001, when\nthe most recent giant flare was detected (Guidorzi et al., GCN 1041\nand IAUC 7611). The data cover a short intermediate pointing of Wide\nField Camera unit 1 between two scheduled targets. The observation\nstarted 2780 s before the giant flare and ended with the automatic\nswitch off due to that flare. The observation was interrupted when\nBeppoSAX traversed the SAA, from 2282 till 1052 s before the\ngiant flare. The analysis revealed the presence of 3 short X-ray\nprecursors, occurring 2537, 755, and 444 s before the giant flare\n(respectively, 25975, 27757 and 28068 s UT), with durations of 100,\n125 and 55 ms, peak fluxes in excess of 20 Crab units (2-28 keV),\nand 9-28/2-9 keV spectral hardness ratios that are consistent with\npower laws with photon indices between roughly 0.5 and 1.2. None of the\nprecursors was detected in the gamma-ray data from the BeppoSAX/GRBM,\nthe gamma-ray burst detector on Ulysses, and from Konus on Wind.\"","createdOn":988997172000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Dale A. Frail at NRAO  <dfrail@nrao.edu>","subject":"SGR 1900+14, Chandra observations","circularId":1047,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1047....1F","body":"D. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report on behalf of a larger\ncollaboration\"\n\n\"In response to the 18 April 2001 flare of SGR 1900+14 (GCN 1041) the\nChandra X-ray Observatory has undertaken a sequence of two public\n20-ksec observations of this source, on 22 and 30 April 2001.\n\nThe first observation began at 04:58 UT on 22 April and was taken in\ncontinuous-clocking mode (see also GCN 1046).  Examination of the\nlight curve reveals that at least one burst was observed, 9081 s after\nthe start of the observation.  Assuming the best-fit spectral\nparameters for the observation (see below), the peak 1-s flux of this\nburst was of order 5e-10 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (0.5-10 keV).\n\nSpectral fits to the full background-subtracted data set allow for at\nleast two emission models.  A power-law plus absorption model has\nbest-fit parameters of N_H = 3.18(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha =\n2.70(1), and unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of 4.20(4)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1.\nA power-law plus blackbody and absorption model has best-fit\nparameters of N_H = 2.56(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha = 1.88(1),\nblackbody temperature kT = 0.532(3) keV, unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of\n2.17(3)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1, and flux fraction for the blackbody\ncomponent of 29% (0.5-10 keV).  The addition of the blackbody\ncomponent is not supported by an F-test (65% confidence level) but is\nconsistent with models in the literature (Perna et al. 2001,\nastro-ph/0103273).  Analysis of the RXTE PCA data may help to clarify\nthe presence or absence of the blackbody component, as the PCA count\nrates inferred from the two models given above differ by 50%.\n\nNo narrow spectral features are apparent.  The two-sigma upper limit\nto the flux of a persistent 0.2-keV FWHM emission line in the 5-7 keV\nrange is 1e-5 photons cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThis message may be cited.\"","createdOn":988083484000,"email":"dfrail@nrao.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. Woods (USRA/NSSTC), C. Kouveliotou (NASA/MSFC), and E. Gogus\n(UAH/NSSTC) report on behalf of a larger collaboration.\n\nToO observations of SGR 1900+14 with the Rossi XTE were initiated on\nApril 19, 2001 and have continued through April 28.  Thus far, more\nthan 60 bursts have been detected in ~110 ks of exposure time. \nCoincidentally, a short (~10 ks) observation of SGR 1900+14 was\nperformed on April 14 (4 days prior to the flare) as part of our\nongoing monitoring campaign.  We find no burst activity within this\nobservation.  For the latest observation on April 28, 4 bursts were\nrecorded in one RXTE orbit, thus the source remains burst active.\n\nSelecting a 6 day subset of these observations for which we have\nspacecraft ephemeris information, we have phase connected the data and\nmeasured both a period and period derivative.  We chose our epoch (MJD\n52021.3 TDB) to coincide with the first Chandra observation.  We\nmeasure a barycentric period of 5.1728219(14) s where the number given\nin the parentheses marks the 1 sigma error in the least significant\ndigits.  The period derivative is found to be +1.58(22) X 10E-10 s/s. \nThe ephemeris we find agrees well with the measured periods reported\nfor both the Chandra (GCN #1049) and BeppoSAX (GCN #1055)\nobservations.  Furthermore, the magnitude of the spindown found here\nis well within the range of historical spindown rates measured for\nthis SGR.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988650865000,"email":"peter.woods@msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Evert Rol at U.Amsterdam  <evert@astro.uva.nl>","subject":"GRB010214, optical observations","circularId":1059,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1059....1R","body":"E. Rol, I. Salamanca, L. Kaper, P. Vreeswijk (University of\nAmsterdam), N. Tanvir (University of Hertfordshire), report on behalf\nof a larger collaboration:\n\n\nIn order to verify the possible counterpart to GRB010214 (Rol et al.,\nGCN 955), we obtained another set of images with the Isaac Newton\nTelescope on February 21, 2001. Examination and comparison of these\nimages with those obtained at the INT on February 17 shows no evidence\nfor a further fading of the possible counterpart, as already suggested\nin other reports (Gorosabel et al., GCN 972; Klose et al., GCN 997;\nFynbo, private comm.). Instead, the source has the same magnitude as\nmeasured in the images obtained at the William Herschel Telescope on\nFebruary 16, R = 22.9 (Rol et al, GCN 955). We therefore conclude that\nthe optical counterpart of GRB010214 has not been detected, with upper\nlimits R ~ 23.5, R ~ 24.2 and R ~ 23.8 on Feb. 15.26, Feb. 17.25 and\nFeb. 22.22 respectively (using the calibration of Henden, GCN\n988). Since the decrease in intensity on Feb. 17 does not appear to be\nan artifact in the images, the detected source likely is a variable\nstar.\n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":988972984000,"email":"evert@astro.uva.nl"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"SG Bhargavi at Indian Inst of Astrophysics  <bhargavi@iiap.ernet.in>","subject":"GRB 010222 /corrections to VBT data","circularId":1051,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1051....1C","body":"R Cowsik and SG Bhargavi (IIA Bangalore, India) report:\n\n\nResults of  observations of afterglow of GRB 010222\nobtained from 2.34-m VBT are as follows:\n\nFeb 24.977    600s  I 20.8 +- 0.2  **\nFeb 24.9924   600s  R 21.405 +/- 0.17\nFeb 25.9816   900s  I 21.42 +/-0.18\nFeb 25.9955   900s  R 21.99  +/-0.13\n \nFeb 28.9014   1200s  R  >22.1\nFeb 28.9257   2400s  R  >22.1\nMar 1.9319    1800s  R  >21.9\n \n \n** It may be noted that some of these are the final numbers and\nthose quoted in Table.1 in astroph/0104363 (Cowsik et al.)\nwere priliminary. \nFurther details on measurements on these data may  be obtained from Bhargavi\n(2001; Ph D thesis).\n\nWe acknowledge S Ambika and K Jayakumar for observations.\n \nThis messge may be cited.","createdOn":988363411000,"email":"bhargavi@iiap.ernet.in"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paul Price at RSAA, ANU at CIT  <pap@srl.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB 010326B: Optical observations","circularId":1020,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1020....1P","body":"P.A. Afanasiev, T. Fatkhullin, S. Dodonov, V. Sokolov, (SAO RAS),\nA. Castro-Tirado (IAA-CSIC Granada; LAEFF-INTA, Madrid), V. Komarova,\nA. Moiseev (SAO RAS), A. Cherepashchuk, K. Postnov (SAI-MSU Moscow)\nreport:\n\n\"On July 24, 2001 UT, we observed the field of GRB 001109 (Gandolfi, GCNs #878,\n#879). The photometric conditions were good with a seeing of about 1.3 arcsec. \nWe have obtained three 180-s R-band images with the SCORPIO instrument\n(http://www.sao.ru/~moisav/scorpio/scorpio.html) at the 6-m telescope of SAO\nRAS. At the position of the VLA radiosource (Taylor et al. GCN #880) which\nis presumably a radio afteglow (Rol et al. GCN #889) we detected an extended\nobject as already reported by Vreeswijk et al. (GCN #886) and Greiner et al. \n(GCN#887), most likely double. Spectroscopic observations (12 x 600-s \nexposures) were obtained with the 300 lines/mm grating giving a spectral \nresolution (FWHM) of about 20 A and an effective wavelength coverage of \n3500 - 9500 A. The slit was placed along the extended object. The analysis \nrevealed that the object is double with a spectra showing the continua\nwith clearly detected Balmer break. The redshift for each component is:\n\nObject A:  z = 0.398 +/- 0.002, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           O[III] 4959,5007AA emission lines (brighter component)\n\n\nObject B:  z = 0.3399 +/- 0.0005, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           Hbeta 4861AA, emission lines (fainter component)\n\nIf the radio transient is related to GRB 001109 indeed, then this is the\nnearest host galaxy detected so far.\n\nThe R-band image can be seen at:\nhttp://www.sao.ru/~sokolov/GRB/HOSTS/GRB001109/GRB001109.html\n\nThis message may be cited\".\n\n-Vladimir Sokolov, on behalf of the RAS Special Astrophysical Observatory\nGRB followup team.","createdOn":999934127000,"email":"sokolov@sao.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Ana Nicuesa at TLS Tautenburg  <ana@tls-tautenburg.de>","subject":"ZTF21aaeyldq: GROND observations","circularId":29330,"bibcode":"2021GCN.29330....1N","body":"A. Kouveliotou, A. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on behalf\nof a larger SGR collaboration:\n\nWe have examined our overlapping Chandra/RXTE observations of SGR 1900+14\n(RXTE TOO, P. Woods, PI). We cannot verify the burst reported in GCN #1047. \nThe source was occulted by the earth at the time in question.\n\nWe confirm the burst in the Chandra data at approximately 7:15:25 UT. The burst \nduration appeared to be 0.35 seconds during which 14 counts were recorded \n(ignoring pile-up). Thus the peak count rate was 65 times the quiescent rate.\nAdopting the quiescent source spectrum (GCN # 1046), we estimate the peak flux \nin the 2-10 keV band to be 7.2 x 10^-10 ergs/cm^2 s (2.9 x 10^-9 ergs/cm^2 s in \n0.5-10.0 keV).\n\nWe would like to add a clarification regarding the persistent source flux  \nvalues in the two GCNs (1046, 1047). Our flux estimates are for the 2-10  \nkeV band to facilitate comparison with data from other satellites; when we  \nexpand the energy range to 0.5-10 keV (as in GCN 1047) we find similar  \nvalues for the quiescent flux.\n\nThis message can be cited.\n\n_____________________________________________\nChryssa Kouveliotou\nNSSTC, SD-50, Rm 2057\n320 Sparkman Drive,\nHuntsville, AL 35805\ntel: 256 961 7604 fax: 256 961 7215","createdOn":988150068000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN Triangulation of the Giant Flare from SGR1900+14","circularId":1043,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10043....1D","body":"K.
