Hjorth, M. I. Andersen, H. Pedersen, A. O. Jaunsen on behalf of the NOT \nGRB team and E. Costa & E. Palazzi on behalf of the SAX GRB team report:\n\nOn June 13.9 UT and June 17.9 UT we obtained R band images (600 sec each, \nseeing FWHM=0.7\") of the BeppoSAX error circle of GRB 980613 (Piro & Costa, \nGCN #99) with the 2.5-m Nordic Optical Telescope. We have discovered a faint \npoint source in our June 13.9 image which is not detected in our June 17.9 \nimage (which reaches a similar limiting magnitude). The source is located at \n(+- 0.5\"):\n\nRA(J2000)  =  10 17 57.64\nDec(J2000) = +71 27 26.4\n\nPreliminary photometry (Cousins R) of the source yields:\n\nJune 13.8897 UT: R = 22.9+-0.2\nJune 17.9088 UT: R > 24.0 (formal 10-sigma limit)\n\nThese numbers assume R=19.11 for USNO catalogue entry U1575-03105992 located at \nRA(J2000)=10 17 54.83, Dec(2000)=+71 27 39.8, consistent with the photometry \nof the isolated star 4_r of Odewahn et al. (GCN #105) (assuming r-R=0.35).\n\nThe location of the source is consistent with the BeppoSAX WFC error circle\nof GRB 980613 (GCN #99) and the BeppoSAX MECS error circle for source A\n(Piro, GCN #104; Costa et al., IAUC 6939). \n\nThe photometry is consistent with previously reported upper limits for\noptically variable objects in the field (R > 20.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado \net al., GCN #102; I>21.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado et al., GCN #103; \nr>21.0 on June 16.0, Odewahn et al., GCN #105; I>22.3 on June 14.2, Halpern\net al., GCN #106, I>20.6 on June 14.0 and I>21.5 on June 14.4, Diercks et \nal., GCN #108).\n\nGiven the consistency with the BeppoSAX error circles of GRB 980613 and\nthe rapidly fading nature of the source we suggest that the detected object\nis the optical afterglow of GRB 980613.\n\nFinding charts and updates of these preliminary results will be posted at \nhttp://www.nordita.dk/~jens/grb980613/\n\nThis report may be cited.","createdOn":898186684000,"email":"jens@nordita.dk"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Chryssa Kouveliotou at MSFC  <kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"Chandra Observations of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1046,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1046....1K","body":"C.Kouveliotou, A. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on\nbehalf of a large SGR collaboration:\n\nChandra observed the newly active (GCN #1041) Soft Gamma Repeater,\nSGR 1900+14, on April 22, 2001 starting at 4:45 UT, for 20,000 seconds.\nThe ACIS S3 observation mode was Continuous Clocking (CC). We have fitted a\nspectrum to the whole data set; we find the best fit to be a single power law\nwith spectral (photon) index of 2.9 +/- 0.1 and a hydrogen column density (NH)\nof (3.4 +/- 0.1)x10^22 cm^-2. We detect no black body contribution in \nthe spectrum.  The source (unabsorbed) flux is 1.1x10^-11 ergs/cm^2 s\n(2-10 keV), nearly identical to the quiescent source flux level.\nThe pulse period is 5.1725 s (barycenter corrected); the pulse profile\nappears sinusoidal.\n\nMore detailed analysis and comparison with RXTE simultaneous \nobservations is underway.","createdOn":988070436000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Josh Bloom at CIT  <jsb@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"HETE Trigger #1760 (GRB 010920B?): new optical source = asteroid","circularId":1095,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10095....1C","body":"HETE Trigger #1760 (GRB 010920B?): new optical source = asteroid\n\nJ. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 03:34:06.53 UTC (12846.53 s UT) on 2 July, the HETE FREGATE and \nWXM instruments detected and localized an intense burst from \nSGR1900+14, a soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the highest \nfluence burst yet detected by HETE from SGR1900+14 during its current \nepisode of activity. (The first burst in the current series was \nreported in GCN Circular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 2 \nJuly burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.846 (19h07m23s.1)\n\nDec. =  +9.344 (+9o20'40\")\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~4 s. A total of 44000 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >7 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >200 x Crab flux) over a duration of \n10 ms.\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":994051790000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010921 (=H1761)","circularId":1097,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10097....1G","body":"K. Saracco, G. Chincarini, S. Covino, G. Ghisellini, M. Longhetti, F.\nZerbi\n(Osservatorio Astronomico di Brera, Merate, Italy)\nD. Lazzati (Institute of Astronomy,Cambridge, UK)\nP. Severgnini (Osservatorio Astronomico di Arcetri, Firenze, Italy)\n\nWe have obtained twelve 540-second dithered images in the Rc (Bessell)\nband centered on the position of  GRB 990705. These images have been\nobtained  from  20th to 28th December 2000 at the ESO-VLT UT1 telescope\nwith FORS1 as a part of a survey of host galaxies (Saracco et al. 2000;\nProg. ID: 66.B-0539(A)).\n\nObservations have been carried out under seeing conditions of 0.6-0.7\narcsec.\nThe limiting magnitude reached on the final coadded image is Rc=26.6\n(3 sigmas within the seeing disk).\nWe confirm the presence of a late-type (Sc) galaxy located at the\nposition of\nGRB 990705 as previously found by Holland et al. (2000; GCN #753).\n\nWe measure a magnitude Rc=22.2(+-0.1) (galactic extinction A(R)=0.2)\nwithin an aperture radius of 2 arcsec.\nConsidering the V-band aperture magnitude obtained by Holland et al.\n(GCN #753) we estimate for the host galaxy a color V-Rc=0.6(+-0.2).\nGiven the large uncertainty in this estimate, such a color is\nconsistent with that of an Sc galaxy  at redshift z<1.3.\n\nThis message can be cited.\n\n\n--\nPaolo Saracco\nOsservatorio Astronomico di Brera\nVia E. The candidate was found by the GstLAL [1] analysis pipeline.\n\nS231231ag is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 8.4e-15 Hz, or about one in 1e7 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231231ag\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), NSBH (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [2] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [2] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 27 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. The slit was placed along the extended object. The analysis \nrevealed that the object is double with a spectra showing the continua\nwith clearly detected Balmer break. The redshift for each component is:\n\nObject A:  z = 0.398 +/- 0.002, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           O[III] 4959,5007AA emission lines (brighter component)\n\n\nObject B:  z = 0.3399 +/- 0.0005, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           Hbeta 4861AA, emission lines (fainter component)\n\nIf the radio transient is related to GRB 001109 indeed, then this is the\nnearest host galaxy detected so far.\n\nThe R-band image can be seen at:\nhttp://www.sao.ru/~sokolov/GRB/HOSTS/GRB001109/GRB001109.html\n\nThis message may be cited\".\n\n-Vladimir Sokolov, on behalf of the RAS Special Astrophysical Observatory\nGRB followup team.","createdOn":999934127000,"email":"sokolov@sao.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Charlie Hoy at University of Portsmouth <charlie.hoy@port.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231206cc: Updated Sky localization and Source Classification","circularId":35301,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35301....1H","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) and LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S231206cc (GCN Circular 35298). Piro and G.\nGandolfi, Istituto di Astrofisica Spaziale del CNR, Rome.\n\n\"The BeppoSAX Gamma Ray Burst Monitor (GRBM) and the Wide Field Camera\n(WFC) unit 2 observed the GRB 010518 on May 18.280046 UT. The burst, that\nwas very faint and detected only by ground trigger logic, required a\ncareful off-line analysis.\nThe event detected by the GRBM shows an irregular single pulse profile\nwith a time duration of 25 s and a peak count rate of 210+- 40 c/s\ncorresponding to (1.3 +- 0.3)x10^-7 erg/cm^2 s in the 40-700 keV energy\nband. In the WFC, the duration is about 30 s and the peak flux\nis 0.7 Crab (2-26 keV). Klose, B. Stecklum, and U. Laux (Thueringer Landessternwarte\n   Tautenburg) on behalf of a larger collaboration\n\nreport:\n\nWe observed the field towards SGR 1900+14 in the I-band using the \nTautenburg Schmidt telescope equipped with the Schmidt focus CCD camera\n(14 frames, 2 min exposure time each). Observations were performed on\nApril 19, 1:12 UT - 2:19 UT, i.e., about 18 hours after the giant \ngamma-ray flare discovered by BeppoSAX and Ulysses (Guidorzi et al., GCN\n#1041; Hurley et al., GCN #1043). Of the 14 frames obtained we finally\nadded 8 to construct an image. The other frames are affected by a cloudy\nsky.\n\nAt the position of the fading radio source discovered after the strong \noutburst in 1998 (Frail et al. 1999, Nature 398, 127; see also Fig. 1 in\nVrba et al. 2000, ApJ 533, L17) we detect no object down to a limiting\nmagnitude of about I=21.\n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":987683715000,"email":"klose@tls-tautenburg.de"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paul Price at RSAA, ANU at CIT  <pap@srl.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB010412: Optical observations","circularId":1038,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1038....1P","body":"P.A. (+9:20:22)\n\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 24 arcmin in radius.\nSGR1900+14 lies 6.2 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~400 ms. A total of 4700\ncounts above background were detected during that interval,\ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux\nwas ~4 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >150 x Crab flux) during a 5 ms interval.\n\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993745828000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paul Price at RSAA, ANU at CIT  <pap@srl.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB010412: Optical observations","circularId":1039,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1039....1P","body":"P.A. This event may indicate the \nonset of a new period of activity by this source. [Another galactic \nX-ray source, GX9+1, lies 100 arcmin from the HETE position.]\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <300 ms. A total of 864 \ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a flux \nof >10 times Crab.\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":992900745000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Valerie Connaughton at MSFC  <valerie@nasa.gov>","subject":"GRB 090902B: Fermi LAT and GBM refined analysis.","circularId":9872,"bibcode":"2009GCN..9872....1B","body":"F. de Palma (Universit� e INFN Bari), E. Bissaldi (MPE), H. Tajima (SLAC),\nS. Guiriec (UAH),  N. Omodei (INFN Pisa), V. Vasileiou (NASA GSFC/UMBC)\nand V. Connaughton (UAH) report for the Fermi LAT and GBM teams:\n\nFurther analysis of GRB 090902B (Bissaldi et al. GCN 9866, de Palma et al.\n GCN 9867, Kennea et al. GCN 9868) reveals it is detected in the Fermi\nLarge Area Telescope (LAT) at least until 300 s after the Fermi\nGamma-Ray Burst Monitor (GBM) trigger time, T0=11:05:08.31 UT.\n\nSpectral analysis of the main emission episode, from T0 to T0+25 s, shows a\ndeviation from the Band function obtained from fitting GBM data between\n50 keV and 40 MeV (GCN 9866). This deviation is apparent both below 50\nkeV in the GBM and above 100 MeV in the LAT. It is well-fit by a single\npower-law, with a well-constrained index that is retrieved from a fit of \nthe\nGBM data alone, the LAT data alone, and when jointly fitting the entire\ndata set.\n\nThe parameters for this multi-component fit are Band_alpha =\n0.61 � 0.01, Band_beta = 3.87 � 0.16, Band_EPeak = 798 � 7 keV,\nand a power-law index of 1.94 � 0.01 that shows no evidence for a\nspectral cut-off below 100 GeV. The fluence between 8 keV and 30\nGeV is 4.86 � 0.06 x 10-4 ergs/cm2.\n\nThe points of contact for this burst are:\n\nFrancesco de Palma (francesco.depalma@ba.infn.it) and\nElisabetta Bissaldi (ebs@mpe.mpg.de).\n\nThe Fermi LAT is a pair conversion telescope designed to cover the\nenergy band from 20 MeV to greater than 300 GeV.\nIt is the product of an international collaboration between NASA and DOE\nin the U.S. and many scientific institutions across France, Italy, Japan\nand Sweden.\n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":1251963402000,"email":"valerie@nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"Dramatic Increase in the Rate of X-ray Bursts Reported by HETE","circularId":1084,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10084....1E","body":"Dramatic Increase in the Rate of X-ray Bursts Reported by HETE\n\nG. Ricker (MIT), on behalf of the HETE Team, reports:\n\nOver the past few weeks, the number of X-ray bursts (XRBs) reported \nby HETE has been gradually increasing, reaching ~10 per day during \nthe past 2-3 days. This seeming storm of XRBs is being produced by an \nensemble of ~10 distinct XRB sources, which are optimally placed in \nthe HETE field-of-view (FOV) for detectability.\n\nThis dramatic overall increase is due to two factors: 1) Improvements \nin the on-board detection algorithm, resulting from lowered trigger \nthresholds and increased numbers of trigger time scales being \nactivated; 2) Sco X-1 has moved out of the HETE instruments' FOV, \ngreatly reducing the overall background, thus improving the \ninstruments' burst detection efficiency.\n\n(NB: Despite the flurry of XRBs, soft gamma repeaters [SGR] and \ngamma-ray bursts [GRB] positions are now being, and will continue to \nbe, reported for events which trigger the high energy bands of the \nFREGATE instrument directly.)\n\nMany of the faint XRB detections are near threshold, and thus their \nonboard localization is unreliable. In order not to saturate rapid \nresponse telescopes and observing programs which primarily target \nSGRs and GRBs, these XRB events are being reported to the GCN with no \npositions. (In fact, reliable positions are subsequently established \nby the WXM ground software for a large fraction of these XRB events.) \nA  refined reporting algorithm, which will more clearly distinguish \nfainter, poorly-localized XRBs from brighter, well-localized XRBs \nwill be implemented in the near future. In the meantime, the XRB \n\"alert only\" reports will continue.  Beginning in late August, when \nthe Galactic Bulge Region moves out of HETE's FOV, we anticipate a \nprecipitous drop in the reported XRB rate.","createdOn":996527165000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"D. Kouveliotou (USRA at MSFC-NASA) report:\n\nWe observed the BeppoSAX error box of GRB 980613 on June 14.35 UT and\nJune 15.35 UT in Kron-Cousins I with the APO 3.5m telescope.\nConditions were mostly clear with ~2.0 arcsec seeing.\n\nPhotometry on a 30 min series of I-band (Kron-Cousins) images centered\naround June 14.35 UT (28 hr after the burst) yields the following\npreliminary magnitudes and relative uncertainties for several\nreference stars:\n\nID  I mag  Rel Err     RA   (J2000)   DEC\n--  -----  ------   ------------------------\n1   17.28    0.02   10 17 47.48  +71 27  0.6\n2   18.74    0.02   10 17 54.83  +71 27 40.2\n3   18.70    0.03   10 18  6.55  +71 27  5.1\n4   18.58    0.02   10 17 55.29  +71 28 16.5\n5   18.25    0.02   10 17 41.45  +71 28  9.3\n\nAbsolute calibration is based on a single observation of the PG\n2213-006 standard field (Landolt 1992) and a previously determined\nairmass correction for this filter and instrument. We have fitted a\nspectrum to the whole data set; we find the best fit to be a single power law\nwith spectral (photon) index of 2.9 +/- 0.1 and a hydrogen column density (NH)\nof (3.4 +/- 0.1)x10^22 cm^-2. Simcoe report on behalf of the larger\nCaltech-NRAO-CARA GRB collaboration:\n\n\"A follow-up image to those reported in GCN #1094 obtained at Palomar\nshows that the 'new optical source' moved by ~29 arcsec in 66 min,\nprimarily westwardly. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Analysis of data from the 22 April 2001 Chandra observation (GCN\n1046, 1047), barycenter-corrected with the preliminary CXC ephemeris,\nreveals that the source emission is pulsed at a period of P =\n5.17288(5) s with a pulse strength of 14.3(2)% RMS that remains\nconstant (within errors) throughout the observation.  Separation of\nthe source photons into \"on-pulse\" and \"off-pulse\" components of 1/3\ncycle each reveals that the off-pulse spatial distribution is\nsignificantly broader than the on-pulse distribution.  Since the\nobservation is taken in continuous-clocking mode, we can only make\nthis determination in one dimension.  Nonetheless, the sigma-widths of\nthe one-dimensional Gaussian PSFs are 0.98(1) arcsec for on-pulse\nphotons and 1.08(2) arcsec for off-pulse photons, different at\n>5-sigma level.  We attribute this difference in widths to the\npresence of an underlying X-ray nebula.\"","createdOn":988243520000,"email":"derekfox@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"Probable SGR or Short Duration GRB Detected by HETE","circularId":1089,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1089....1R","body":"Probable SGR or Short Duration GRB Detected by HETE\n\nG. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor, N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. Morgan, G. \nPrigozhin, J. Braga, R. Manchanda, and G. Pizzichini, on behalf of \nthe HETE Operations and HETE Optical-SXC Teams;\n\nN. Kawai, M. Matsuoka, Y. Shirasaki, T. Tamagawa, K. Torii, T.\nSakamoto, A. Yoshida, E. Fenimore, M. Galassi, T. Donaghy, and  C. Graziani, on\nbehalf of the HETE WXM Team;\n\nJ-L Atteia, M. Boer, J-F Olive, J-P Dezalay, and K. Hurley on behalf\nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 05:06:30.61 UTC (18390.61 s UT) on 22 August, the HETE FREGATE \ninstrument detected a short, intense burst from a probable soft \ngamma-ray repeater or (less likely) a short duration GRB. This event \nwas promptly distributed as a GCN Notice (HETE BID_1715). No signal \nwas detected in the WXM, indicating that the event was likely to \nbe >40 degrees from the anti-sun direction. For the current HETE \npointing direction, SGR1900+14 is about 48 degrees off the boresight, \nwhile SGR1806-20 is about 56 degrees off the boresight, so that \neither could be a candidate.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~200 ms. A total of 500\ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence\nof ~9 x 10-8 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux was >2 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >50 x Crab flux) over a duration of 30 ms.\n\nA search for this event in the archives of other GRB instruments is \nencouraged. This message is citeable.","createdOn":998516933000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Derek Fox at CIT  <derekfox@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"SGR 1900+14: Correction to GCN 1049","circularId":1052,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10052....1G","body":"D. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"The PSF parameters quoted in GCN 1049 for the 22 April 2001 Chandra\nobservation of SGR 1900+14 are in units of ACIS pixels, not arcseconds\nas reported.  The correct on- and off-pulse PSF sigma values for the\nbest-fit Gaussians are 0.98(1) and 1.08(2) pixels, or 0.480(5) and\n0.53(1) arcseconds, respectively.\"","createdOn":988364660000,"email":"derekfox@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Filippo Frontera at ITESRE CNR  <filippo@tesre.bo.cnr.it>","subject":"Giant flare from SGR1900+14","circularId":1041,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10041....1L","body":"C.Guidorzi, E.Montanari and F.Frontera, University of Ferrara, Italy;  E.\nCosta, G.Gandolfi, M.Feroci and L.Piro, IAS-CNR, Roma;  L.Amati, TESRE,\nCNR, Bologna; J.J.M. in 't Zand, SRON and Astronomical Institute, Utrecht,\nNL; G. D'Andreta, R. Kaptein, L. Reboa, BeppoSAX Science Operation Center,\nreport:  \nA giant flare of SGR1900+14 was detected by BeppoSAX at 7:55:12 UT of\nApril 18, 2001. The peak flux measured by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor, \nafter background subtraction and no dead time correction, is around 15400\nc/s. The flare has an approximate duration of 40 s. The 5s pulsation is\napparent.  The Wide Field Camera #1 was switched off by rate protection at\na level of 1300 c/s before the flare peak.  A BeppoSAX TOO is in\nprogress. \n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":987599842000,"email":"filippo@tesre.bo.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN detection of SGR1900+14","circularId":1071,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1071....1H","body":"K. Mazets and S.\nGolenetskii, on behalf of the Konus-Wind GRB team, report:\n\nUlysses and Konus observed a burst on 2001 June 25 at 51801 s UT (Earth\ncrossing time) whose origin is probably SGR1900+14.  It had a duration\nof ~2 s, a 25-100 keV fluence of 2.8 x 10^-6 erg/cm^2, and a peak flux\nover 0.25 s of 3.9x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s.  Triangulation gives an annulus\ncentered at RA(2000), Decl(2000) = 17.530 deg, +33.050 deg, with radius\n85.548 +/- 0.027 deg.  The center line of this annulus passes ~0.018\ndeg from SGR1900+14. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi,\nF. Frontera, and M. Feroci, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM team, report:\n\nWe have identified a likely precursor to the giant flare from\nSGR1900+14 (GCN 1041, 1043) in the Ulysses data.  This event\noccurred on April 17, 2001, ~42184 s at Ulysses, and if it was\nindeed from SGR1900+14, its Earth-crossing time would have\nbeen ~42332 s.  This burst was ~50 s long, and its time history\nresembles that of the April 18 event, although it is considerably\nless intense.  Its 25-100 keV fluence was ~2.3x10^-5 erg/cm^2,\nand its peak flux over 0.5 s was ~1.5x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s. Vreeswijk report for a larger collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000301c was reobserved by the Hubble Space Telescope\nusing the STIS camera in open (50CCD) mode on the 25 Feb 2001, or\nnearly one year after outburst.   Twelve dithered exposures were\ncombined to produce a final image with an exposure time of 7031s.\n\nNo source is immediately visible at the position of the GRB.  However,\nwhen the image is convolved with gaussians or boxcars with\ncharacteristic sizes from that of the PSF, 0.\"08, to 0.\"2, an extended\nobject appears to be visible under the position of the GRB and to its\nNE. Burst Monitor (GBM) triggered and located GRB 190609A (trigger 581758450.25943 / 190609315).\n\nThe on-ground calculated location, using the Fermi GBM trigger data, is RA = 165.8, Dec = -50.8 (J2000 degrees, equivalent to J2000 11h 03m, -50d 47'), with a statistical uncertainty of 1.9 degrees.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 30.0 degrees.\n\nThe skymap can be found gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Filippo Frontera at U. of Ferrara, Physics Dept  <frontera@fe.infn.it>","subject":"SGR1900+14 burst seen by HETE: BeppoSAX data","circularId":1081,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1081....1M","body":"E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi and F. Frontera, Physics Dept., University of\nFerrara, Italy; F. Calura, Astronomy Dept., University of Trieste; M.\nFeroci, IAS, CNR, Rome, Italy, report:\n\nThe short burst from SGR1900+14 detected by HETE (GCN # 1078) was also\ndetected by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor aboard BeppoSAX. The burst\ntriggered the GRBM on board logic at 03:34:07.15 UT of July 2, 2001. The\nevent duration was about 2 s.\n\nThe event showed significant flux only in the 40-100 keV energy band. The\ntotal counts above the background level in this range were 400 +/- 50. \nAssuming a power law spectral shape, from our data we can set a lower\nlimit to the photon index of 3.5. With a photon index of 4.0, the derived\nfluence is (1.2+/- 0.2) x 10-6 erg cm-2 in the band from 40 to 100 keV. \nUsing the high time resolution data only available in the 40-700 keV band,\nthe peak flux obtained from 125 ms bins corresponds to (1.4 +/- 0.4)x10-6\nerg cm-2 s-1. \n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":994267010000,"email":"frontera@fe.infn.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Scott Barthelmy at NASA/GSFC  <scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"GCN and HETE status","circularId":1085,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10085....1E","body":"INTRO:\nThere have been a lot of HETE triggers in the last week.  Many people\nare wondering what is going on.  This announcement attempts to explain\nthe recent developments.\n\nTRIGGERS:\nStarting about a week ago, the HETE Operations team resumed sending\nthe HETE messages from the s/c to GCN -- there were gaps due to HETE and due\nto GCN (the network problems).  And since the Galactic Center\nis still in the HETE FOV, this has caused a marked step increase\nin the amount of HETE Notices (from zero to several per day).\nThis increase has been further enhanced by the fact that Sco X-1 has left\nthe FOV of the HETE instruments two weeks ago.  The decrease in the background\ndue to the loss of Sco X-1 has increased the sensitivity to the the XRB\nsources in the Galactic Center.\n\nPOSITIONS:\nSince a larger fraction of these triggers is caused by X-ray Burst sources\nwhich are very weak, they produce poor image detections and therefore\nlocations with large uncertainites.  The HETE Operations team\nhas commanded the s/c to suppress the positions if the \"source\"\nin the image is not significant enough.  This results in the large\nnumber of Notices with no positions.\n\nFILTERING:\nI have changed the GCN filtering system to compensate for this change\nin the Notice content.  If there is no position in the S/C_Update,\nS/C_Last, or even the Gnd_Analysis messages, then they are NOT distributed\nthe sites requesting HETE Notices.  The reasoning is that with no position\ninformation in the Notice, what possible use could a follow-up observer\nmake of the notification.  This change was made Saturday, 28 Jul 01.\n\nTOO MANY ALERTS?\nHowever, the S/C_Alerts never were intended to have position information\n(except for rare instances (~10%)), so they are still being distributed\nto those sites that have requested the HETE S/C_Alert subtype.\nEven with the filtering of the U/L/GA's that have no positions, there are\nstill a large number of Alert Notices being distributed to sites.  If you feel\nthat you are receiving too many Alerts (that subsequently have no U/L/GA\nfollow-ups), then you might consider requesting that the Alert subtype\nbe disabled for your site.  (Or you might consider \"toughing it out\"\nfor another 4-6 weeks until the Galactic Center is no longer in the HETE FOV \nin which case the trigger rate should drop dramatically.)\n\nACTION ITEM:\nSites can:\n1) keep their current configurations,   or\n2) request that S/C_Alerts be disabled,   or\n3) request that S/C_Alerts/Updates/Lasts be disabled (say for the next month\nor so, and then request they be turned back on),   or\n4) request that all HETE subtypes (A/U/L/GA) be disabled (again for the next\nmonth or so).\nGiven the no-positions-filtering incorporated last Saturday, choice \"2\"\nseems like a reasonable approach if a site has any concern about \"too many\nNotices\".\n\nSincerely,\n\nScott Barthelmy\nNASA-GSFC\n301-286-3106\nscott@lheamail.gsfs.nasa.gov","createdOn":996530269000,"email":"scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN Triangulation of GRB010412","circularId":1036,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10036....1S","body":"K. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, G. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 08:33:12 UTC (=30792s UT), a soft spectrum, high \nenergy transient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized \nby HETE.\n(NB: This is the second GRB detected by HETE on 26 March 2001.)\n\nBoth the WXM and the FREGATE instruments detected the event. The \nburst triggered FREGATE in the 6-120 keV band, at the 160ms timescale.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h24m23.36s, \nDec. = -11o09'57\", derived from combining data from the WXM and \nBoresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the WXM \nlocalization is 18 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we estimate \na systematic error radius at present of 10 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 30 \narcsec (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~4 Crab; with WXM \n(2-25 keV), ~2 Crab. The burst duration was about 4 seconds.\n\nThe high galactic latitude of the source, well away from the Galactic \nBulge, and the shape of its spectrum suggest that it is a gamma-ray \nburst similar to those reported for \"X-ray rich\" GRBs by Heise et al \n(2001) from BeppoSAX observations.\n\nFollow-up observations of this unusual transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on the GRB010326B (including light curves), as \nwell as for the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985612698000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Aaron Zimmerman at U. of Texas at Austin <aaron.zimmerman@utexas.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231231ag: Updated Sky localization and Source Classification","circularId":35446,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35446....1Z","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S231231ag (GCN Circular 35445). A. Smith (Rice University) and R. P. J. Tilanus (Joint Astronomy Centre) \nreport on behalf of the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope (JCMT) GRB collaboration:\n \nWe used the SCUBA sub-millimeter continuum bolometer array on the JCMT to \nobserve the variable radio source VLA J0702+3850 proposed by Taylor et al. \n(GCN #40) as the radio afterglow to GRB 980329.\n \nOn UT 1998 April 5.2 we detected a source at 850 microns with a preliminary \nflux density of 5 +/- 1.5 mJy.  This source was confirmed on April 6.2 with \na flux density of 4 +/- 1.2 mJy, resulting in an average of 4.5 +/- 1 mJy \nover the two days. (-18o43'24\")\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 15 arcmin in radius.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~20 s, with two peaks \nseparated by ~12 s. Ricker (MIT), on behalf of the HETE Team, reports:\n\nOver the past few weeks, the number of X-ray bursts (XRBs) reported \nby HETE has been gradually increasing, reaching ~10 per day during \nthe past 2-3 days. This seeming storm of XRBs is being produced by an \nensemble of ~10 distinct XRB sources, which are optimally placed in \nthe HETE field-of-view (FOV) for detectability.\n\nThis dramatic overall increase is due to two factors: 1) Improvements \nin the on-board detection algorithm, resulting from lowered trigger \nthresholds and increased numbers of trigger time scales being \nactivated; 2) Sco X-1 has moved out of the HETE instruments' FOV, \ngreatly reducing the overall background, thus improving the \ninstruments' burst detection efficiency.\n\n(NB: Despite the flurry of XRBs, soft gamma repeaters [SGR] and \ngamma-ray bursts [GRB] positions are now being, and will continue to \nbe, reported for events which trigger the high energy bands of the \nFREGATE instrument directly.)\n\nMany of the faint XRB detections are near threshold, and thus their \nonboard localization is unreliable. In order not to saturate rapid \nresponse telescopes and observing programs which primarily target \nSGRs and GRBs, these XRB events are being reported to the GCN with no \npositions. (In fact, reliable positions are subsequently established \nby the WXM ground software for a large fraction of these XRB events.) \nA  refined reporting algorithm, which will more clearly distinguish \nfainter, poorly-localized XRBs from brighter, well-localized XRBs \nwill be implemented in the near future. In the meantime, the XRB \n\"alert only\" reports will continue.  Beginning in late August, when \nthe Galactic Bulge Region moves out of HETE's FOV, we anticipate a \nprecipitous drop in the reported XRB rate.","createdOn":996527165000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Derek Fox at CIT  <derekfox@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB010921 Optical Observations","circularId":1099,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10099....1L","body":"D. (-20:21:56)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 6 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1806-20 lies 3.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~200 ms, comprised of two \npeaks each <100ms in duration. Metzger report for a larger HST GRB Collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000418 was re-observed by the Hubble Space Telescope\nstarting on UT 2001 Feb 11.64 using the STIS camera in open (50CCD)\nmode.  The individual exposures were combined using Drizzle for a total\nexposure time of 5120 s.\n\nWhen this image is subtracted from that obtained by HST on 2000 June\n4.17 a small residual of magnitude R~28 is found at the position of the\ncompact galaxy believed to be the host galaxy (GCN 669); however, the\nresidual is sufficiently faint to be consistent with no detection at\nabout the 2 sigma level.  Taking into account the varying brightness of\nthe host galaxy we find an upper limit to the brightness of the OT on\n2000 June 4.2 of R > 27.5.\n\nThis upper limit on the R-band flux implies that the decay of the\noptical transient steepened to at least t ^ -1.75 to -2 at late times,\nin agreement with the result obtainted primarily from radio data by\nBerger et al (20001, astro-ph/0102278).\n\nThe images of the STIS field, with transient location indicated, can be\nseen at http://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/000418.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":989703442000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Nello Ruocco at Osservatorio Nastro Verde - Sorrento (Naples) - Italy - MPC Code C82 <osservatorionastroverde@gmail.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 231215A: Osservatorio Astronomico Nastro Verde upper limit","circularId":35392,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35392....1R","body":"Nello Ruocco at Osservatorio Nastro Verde - Sorrento (Naples) - Italy\nin a large collaboration with:\nM.G. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 03:34:06.53 UTC (12846.53 s UT) on 2 July, the HETE FREGATE and \nWXM instruments detected and localized an intense burst from \nSGR1900+14, a soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the highest \nfluence burst yet detected by HETE from SGR1900+14 during its current \nepisode of activity. (The first burst in the current series was \nreported in GCN Circular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 2 \nJuly burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.846 (19h07m23s.1)\n\nDec. =  +9.344 (+9o20'40\")\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~4 s. A total of 44000 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >7 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >200 x Crab flux) over a duration of \n10 ms.\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":994051790000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Peter Shawhan at U of Maryland/LSC  <pshawhan@umd.edu>","subject":"LIGO/Virgo S190602aq: Identification of a GW compact binary merger candidate","circularId":24717,"bibcode":"2019GCN.24717....1T","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration and the Virgo Collaboration report:\n\nWe identified the compact binary merger candidate S190602aq during\nreal-time processing of data from LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1), LIGO\nLivingston Observatory (L1), and Virgo Observatory (V1) at 2019-06-02\n17:59:27.089 UTC (GPS time: 1243533585.089). The candidate was found\nby the PyCBC Live [1], CWB [2], SPIIR [3], GstLAL [4], and MBTAOnline\n[5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS190602aq is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as\nestimated by the online analysis, is 1.9e-09 Hz, or about one in 16\nyears. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S190602aq\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending\nprobability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), NSBH (<1%),\nor MassGap (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, there is strong\nevidence against the lighter compact object having a mass < 3 solar\nmasses (HasNS: <1%). A. Smith (Rice University) and R. P. J. Tilanus (Joint Astronomy Centre) \nreport on behalf of the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope (JCMT) GRB collaboration:\n \nWe used the SCUBA sub-millimeter continuum bolometer array on the JCMT to \nobserve the variable radio source VLA J0702+3850 proposed by Taylor et al. \n(GCN #40) as the radio afterglow to GRB 980329.\n \nOn UT 1998 April 5.2 we detected a source at 850 microns with a preliminary \nflux density of 5 +/- 1.5 mJy.  This source was confirmed on April 6.2 with \na flux density of 4 +/- 1.2 mJy, resulting in an average of 4.5 +/- 1 mJy \nover the two days.  The 850 micron source is present in all our separate \nintegrations making us confident it is real.  A hint of a fading trend \nappears to be confirmed by observations on April 7.2 when the (preliminary)\n850 micron flux density was 2 +/- 0.8 mJy. \n\nThe source was not detected at 450 microns with a preliminary rms of 10.0 \nmJy averaged over the first two days.\n\nAssuming these fluxes are due to the burst counterpart, they should represent\n\"clean\" measures of its intensity, unaffected by scintillation and extinction.  \nMonitoring with SCUBA is continuing.\n\nWe wish to thank Dr. L. Rol, I. Salamanca, L. Kaper, P. Vreeswijk (University of\nAmsterdam), N. Tanvir (University of Hertfordshire), report on behalf\nof a larger collaboration:\n\n\nIn order to verify the possible counterpart to GRB010214 (Rol et al.,\nGCN 955), we obtained another set of images with the Isaac Newton\nTelescope on February 21, 2001. Examination and comparison of these\nimages with those obtained at the INT on February 17 shows no evidence\nfor a further fading of the possible counterpart, as already suggested\nin other reports (Gorosabel et al., GCN 972; Klose et al., GCN 997;\nFynbo, private comm.). Instead, the source has the same magnitude as\nmeasured in the images obtained at the William Herschel Telescope on\nFebruary 16, R = 22.9 (Rol et al, GCN 955). We therefore conclude that\nthe optical counterpart of GRB010214 has not been detected, with upper\nlimits R ~ 23.5, R ~ 24.2 and R ~ 23.8 on Feb. 15.26, Feb. 17.25 and\nFeb. 22.22 respectively (using the calibration of Henden, GCN\n988). Woods (USRA/NSSTC), C. Kouveliotou (NASA/MSFC), and E. Gogus\n(UAH/NSSTC) report on behalf of a larger collaboration.\n\nToO observations of SGR 1900+14 with the Rossi XTE were initiated on\nApril 19, 2001 and have continued through April 28.  Thus far, more\nthan 60 bursts have been detected in ~110 ks of exposure time. \nCoincidentally, a short (~10 ks) observation of SGR 1900+14 was\nperformed on April 14 (4 days prior to the flare) as part of our\nongoing monitoring campaign.  We find no burst activity within this\nobservation.  For the latest observation on April 28, 4 bursts were\nrecorded in one RXTE orbit, thus the source remains burst active.\n\nSelecting a 6 day subset of these observations for which we have\nspacecraft ephemeris information, we have phase connected the data and\nmeasured both a period and period derivative.  We chose our epoch (MJD\n52021.3 TDB) to coincide with the first Chandra observation.  We\nmeasure a barycentric period of 5.1728219(14) s where the number given\nin the parentheses marks the 1 sigma error in the least significant\ndigits.  The period derivative is found to be +1.58(22) X 10E-10 s/s. \nThe ephemeris we find agrees well with the measured periods reported\nfor both the Chandra (GCN #1049) and BeppoSAX (GCN #1055)\nobservations.  Furthermore, the magnitude of the spindown found here\nis well within the range of historical spindown rates measured for\nthis SGR.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988650865000,"email":"peter.woods@msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"GRB980611","circularId":100,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10000....1M","body":"K. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Roma) and S. Mereghetti (IFC/CNR, Milano),\non behalf of a larger SGR collaboration, and G. Gandolfi, L. Piro\nand E. Costa (IAS/CNR, Roma), on behalf of the BeppoSAX Team,\nreport:\n\n\"A ToO observation of SGR1900+14 was carried out with the\nBeppoSAX Narrow Field Instruments starting on April 18, 15:10 UT,\nless than 8 hours after the large flare reported in GCN #1041.\nIntense bursting activity is present during the 28 hr long\nobservation.  After removing the numerous short bursts, a significant\nflux decay is visible in the MECS and LECS light curves.\nBy using our data and the Chandra 2-10 keV flux (GCN #1046)\nwe find that the decay can be reasonably well described by a power\nlaw with index ~-0.6.  There is also evidence for a spectral softening\ncorrelated with the intensity decrease.\n\nThe average spectrum (after removal of the bursts) can be fit by a\npower law with photon index 2.6+/-0.1 and NH=(4.3 +/-0.3)x10^22 cm^-2.\nThe average 2-10 keV flux during the whole BeppoSAX observation is\n2.9x10^-11 erg/cm^2/s (unabsorbed). The bursts have a significantly\nharder spectrum (power law photon index ~0 in the 2-10 keV range).\n\nPulsations,  with a nearly sinusoidal light curve and a modulation of\nabout 21%, are clearly detected at the barycentered period  P=5.17277(1) s.\nWhen compared with the value measured with Chandra about 3 days later\n(GCN #1049), this yields a dP/dt ~ (4.1 +/- 1.9)x10^-10 s/s.\n\nAn additional BeppoSAX/NFI observation will start on April 29, 20:30 UT.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988388763000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andrew S. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 010222: HST observations -- host galaxy and late-time decay","circularId":1087,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10087....1C","body":"A. Fruchter, I. Burud, J. Rhoads and A. Levan (STScI) report:\n\nWe have reduced the now public archival HST images of GRB 010222, taken\non 28 February, 17 and 18 March, 5 and 6 April, and 4 and 5 May of \nthis year using the F606W (V/R) and F814W (I) filters on WFPC2.   Using\nthe most recent data, we find that OT of GRB 010222 is clearly superposed\non a host galaxy.  \n\nIn order to accurately determine the decay of the OT and the magnitude\nof the host, we have drizzled the images onto an output grid that\nallows interlacing of these 2-point dithered images.  We have then fit\nfor the decay of the OT and the host galaxy flux using a small (~0.\"2)\naperture, which provides the best estimate of the OT as a function of\ntime, as well as using a larger aperture (~0.\"5), which is more\nappropriate for determining the host galaxy magnitude.\n\nWe find that the late-time decay of the OT is significantly steeper\nthan previously reported.  We find a power-law decay between 28 February\n(day 6) and 5 May (day 71) of -1.7 +/- 0.05.  Formally, we find\na slightly steeper decay (-1.73 +/- 0.02) in F606W than in F814W \n(-1.64 +/- 0.04), but this discrepancy may indicate the level of\nsystematic error in the slope measurement rather than true color\nevolution of the OT.\n\nWe find that the host galaxy is dominated by a compact core (FWHM ~ 0.\"15)\nlocated directly under the OT.  The magnitude of the host is \nF606W(AB) = 26.0 +/- 0.1, F814W(AB) = 25.8 +/- 0.15.  \n\nImages of the host, as well as a plot of the coninuing decline of the OT,\nare available at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/010222","createdOn":997814700000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010612","circularId":1066,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1066....1H","body":"The previous message, GCN 1065, was truncated by the terminal.\nThe last paragraph should have read:\n\nThis error box has an area of approximately 1500 sq.\narcminutes, or a factor of about 2.7 smaller than the\nWXM error circle. Kouveliotou, Universities Space Research Association, M. Kippen, P.\nWoods, G. Richardson, University of Alabama in Huntsville, V.\nConnaughton, National Research Council, report on behalf of the BATSE\nteam at NASA/Marshall Space Flight Center:\n\nBATSE has detected repeated soft gamma-ray bursts consistent with the\nsame (previously unknown) location. We recorded three bursts on June\n15.109, 15.296, 15.411 UT (BATSE triggers 6825, 6826, 6827,\nrespectively) with an average duration of ~ 200 milliseconds.\nPreliminary spectral analysis of the data indicates that the events\nare very soft, with power law spectral indices varying between -3.0\nand -7.0. BATSE triggered 5 more times, on June 17.873, 17.901,\n18.004, 18.035, and 18.071 UT (BATSE trigger numbers 6833, 6834, 6835,\n6836 and 6837, respectively). The last trigger had a peak count rate\nof over 300000 counts/sec above background (integrated over 4\ndetectors between 20-1000 keV, in 1 second interval) and a duration of\n~ 3 seconds. Due to its very high peak intensity, deadtime effects\nprevent us from using it for localization, until we receive more data\ntypes. The weighted location of the 7 remaining triggers is centered\non R.A. = 16h27m12.0s and dec = -41d06.0' with an error radius of\nabout 2 degrees.  This location does not correspond to any previously\nknown SGR source; we conclude that we have discovered a new source,\nSGR1627-41. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB and HETE teams; T. Cline, on\nbehalf of the Ulysses, Konus-Wind, and HETE GRB teams; E. Mazets and\nS.  Golenetskii, on behalf of the Konus-Wind and Konus-A GRB teams; and\nG. Ricker, D. Lamb, C.  Graziani, E. Fenimore, N. Kawai, and J.-L.\nAtteia, on behalf of the HETE team report:\n\nUlysses, Konus-Wind and Konus-A observed GRB010326A. This burst had a\nduration of ~25 s, a 17 keV - 2.5 MeV fluence of ~4x10^-5 erg/cm2, and\na peak flux over 0.25 s of ~8x10^-6 erg/cm2 s. From a cross-correlation\nof the Ulysses and Konus-Wind time histories, we have triangulated the\nlocation of the burst to an annulus centered at RA(2000)=178.727 deg.,\nDecl(2000)=30.803 deg., and radius 81.702+/- 0.028 deg. (3 sigma confidence).\nThe triangulation based on the Konus-Wind and the Konus-A data resulted\nin an annulus centered at RA(2000)=94.662 deg., Decl(2000)=21.978 deg., and\nradius 69.7+/- 0.4 deg. (1 sigma confidence).  Combining these data, we\nare able to restrict the location of the burst to the following ~180\nsquare arcmin. error box.\n\n  RA(2000)       DEC(2000)\n132.9630 o     -38.3005 o (CENTER)\n132.3408 o     -38.5784 o (CORNER)\n132.3988 o     -38.5441 o (CORNER)\n131.5271 o     -38.0568 o (CORNER)\n131.5851 o     -38.0230 o (CORNER)\n\nThis location is consistent with the spectra and time history seen in \nthe four HETE FREGATE detectors. The above error box can be refined \nby further processing.\n\nOn this basis, we have concluded that the WXM location reported in GCN\n1014 for this burst is spurious.  This burst is distinct from the other \nGRBs (GRB010326B, GCN 1018; GRB010213, GCN 934) for which HETE WXM \nlocations have been reported, in that it has a very low \nsignal-to-noise excess count rate in the WXM, and our further \nanalysis suggests that it is this fact that accounts\nfor the spurious location. Kouveliotou, A. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on behalf\nof a larger SGR collaboration:\n\nWe have examined our overlapping Chandra/RXTE observations of SGR 1900+14\n(RXTE TOO, P. Woods, PI). We cannot verify the burst reported in GCN #1047. \nThe source was occulted by the earth at the time in question.\n\nWe confirm the burst in the Chandra data at approximately 7:15:25 UT. The burst \nduration appeared to be 0.35 seconds during which 14 counts were recorded \n(ignoring pile-up). Thus the peak count rate was 65 times the quiescent rate.\nAdopting the quiescent source spectrum (GCN # 1046), we estimate the peak flux \nin the 2-10 keV band to be 7.2 x 10^-10 ergs/cm^2 s (2.9 x 10^-9 ergs/cm^2 s in \n0.5-10.0 keV).\n\nWe would like to add a clarification regarding the persistent source flux  \nvalues in the two GCNs (1046, 1047). ID: 66.B-0539(A)).\n\nWe reach a limiting magnitude fainter than Rc=27.5 in the final co-added\nimage\n(S/N=3 within the seeing disk).\nWe clearly detect a galaxy at the position of  GRB 981226 as previously\nfound by Holland et al. (2000; GCN #749).\n\nWe measure a magnitude (Vega) Rc=24.8(+-0.1) (galactic extinction\nA(R)=0.06)\nwithin an aperture radius of 2 arcsec.\n\nThis message can be cited.\n\n\n\n--\nPaolo Saracco\nOsservatorio Astronomico di Brera\nVia E. (+39) 039 9991151    www.merate.mi.astro.it/~saracco","createdOn":986214402000,"email":"saracco@merate.mi.astro.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Israel Martinez-Castellanos at UMD/HAWC  <imc@umd.edu>","subject":"LIGO/Virgo S190602aq: No counterpart candidates in HAWC observations","circularId":24718,"bibcode":"2019GCN.24718....1H","body":"The HAWC Collaboration (https://www.hawc-observatory.org) reports:\n\nThe HAWC Collaboration performed a follow-up of the gravitational wave\ntrigger S190602aq. At the time of the trigger the HAWC\nlocal zenith was oriented towards (RA, Dec) = (63.2 deg, 18.9 deg).\n57% of the GW candidate sky location probability fell within our\nobservable field of view (0-45 deg zenith angle).\n\nWe performed a search for a short timescale emission using 6 sliding\ntime windows (dt = 0.3s, 1s, 3s, 10s, 30s and  100s), shifted forward\nin time by 20% of their width. We searched the 95% probability\ncontainment area in a timescale-dependent time period, from t0-5dt to\nt0+10dt, where t0 is the time of the GW trigger.\n\nNo significant gamma-ray detection above the background was observed.\n\nThe sensitivity of this analysis is greatly dependent on zenith angle,\nranging from 14.4 deg to 45 deg for the area searched in this\nanalysis. The 5sigma detection sensitivity to a 1s (100s) burst in the\n80-800GeV energy range goes from 1.6e-6 erg/cm^2 to 1.1e-4 erg/cm^2\n(8.6e-6 erg/cm^2 to 5.0e-4 erg/cm^2), depending on the zenith\nangle.\n\nHAWC is a TeV gamma ray water Cherenkov array located in the state of\nPuebla, Mexico. It is sensitive to the energy range ~0.1-100TeV, and\nmonitors 2/3 of the sky every day with an instantaneous field-of-view\nof ~2 sr.","createdOn":1559500672000,"email":"imc@umd.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Tianrui Sun at Purple Mountain Obs,CAS <trsun@pmo.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"GRB 231216A: AST3-3 YaoAn Optical Upper Limit","circularId":35390,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35390....1Y","body":"Tian-Rui Sun (Purple Mountain Observatory), Yan-Long Hua, Mao-Kai Hu, Xue-Feng Wu, Lei Liu, Ke-Lai Meng, Xiao-Yan Li (Nanjing Institute of Astronomical Observation Technology),\nXiang-Yan Yuan, Lifan Wang (TAMU), Xiao-Feng Wang (Tsinghua University), Lei Hu (CMU) report on behalf the AST3 Team:\n\nFollowing the detection of GRB 231216A by Swift (Sbarrato et al., GCNC 35378),\nwe use Antarctic Survey Telescope 3-3 at YaoAn Astronomy Observation Station (China, Yunnan) for follow-up.\nOur observation started on 2023-12-16T18:44:08 (about 506 seconds after the trigger of BAT (Sbarrato et al., GCNC 35378)). \nNo optical source was detected within the XRT error box down to 20.7 mag in the coadded image (total 600s, g-band).\n\n\nOur non-detection is consistent with the results from the UVOT (Sbarrato et al., GCN 35378), MASTER (Lipunov et al. The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], PyCBC Live [4], and SPIIR [5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231206ca is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 3.2e-10 Hz, or about one in 1e2 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231206ca\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), or NSBH (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [6] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [6] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 25 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,1 sky map, the 90% credible region is 1986 deg2. Marginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 3223 +/- 983 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/userguide/.\n\n [1] Klimenko et al. This event may indicate the \nonset of a new period of activity by this source. The coordinates \n(J2000) of the burst source were:\n\nR.A. = 272.0265 deg.\n\nDec. = -20.2743 deg\n\nThe error circle for the localization is 36 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1806-20 lies 11.8 arcmin from the HETE position. [Another galactic \nX-ray source, GX9+1, lies 100 arcmin from the HETE position.]\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <300 ms. A total of 864 \ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a flux \nof >10 times Crab.\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":992900745000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kira Simpson at PSU  <kira.simpson1984@gmail.com>","subject":"GRB 190531B: Swift/UVOT Upper Limits","circularId":24731,"bibcode":"2019GCN.24731....1S","body":"GRB 190531B: Swift/UVOT Upper Limits\n\nK. Dodonov, T. Fatkhullin, V. Sokolov (SAO RAS), Andrew Fruchter (STScI),\nV. Komarova, A. Moiseev (SAO RAS), A. Cherepashchuk, K. Postnov (SAI-MSU Moscow)\nreport:\n\n\"On July 24 and 25, 2001 UT, we have observed the field of the optical\ntransient of GRB 000926 (Fynbo et al., 2001, A&A, 373, 796).\nWe have obtained B, V, Rc, Ic images with the SCORPIO\n(http://www.sao.ru/~moisav/scorpio/scorpio.html) at the\n6-m telescope of SAO RAS. Photometric conditions were good and\nthe seeing was about 1.3 arcsec. Photometric calibration was\nperformed using Stetson standards in Landolt standard field PG1633.\n\nAt the position of the optical transient we have detected an object -\na host galaxy. At about 3\" to the East from the OT position an extended\nemission is clearly seen. This extended emission is most likely the galaxy\nseen in early HST image (see Price et al., 2001, ApJ, 549, L7) and its\nassociation with the host is unclear.\n\nThe exposure times and magnitudes of the object are:\n\n Filter  Exposure (sec.)  Magnitude         Aperture\n---------------------------------------------------------\n  B        2500             26.13 +/- 0.17   2.0 arcsec\n  V        1500             25.85 +/- 0.22   2.0 arcsec\n  Rc       1260             26.31+/-  0.25   2.0 arcsec\n  Ic       1800             24.7 +/-  0.4    2.0 arcsec\n---------------------------------------------------------\n\nThe faint R-band  magnitude can be explained by a graphite band\nas on the Galactic extinction curves. Indeed, for the redshift z=2.0369\n(Castro et al., GCN #851) this band (2200A) goes to the observed R-band.\nIf so, then this is the second case of direct observations of this\nfeature (see Sokolov et al., 2001, A&A, 372, 438, the case of the HG\nGRB 980703).\n\nWe also performed the photometry of entire system of the objects using\nan aperture of 4.5 arcsec. Below we present the obtained magnitudes:\n\n Filter  Exposure (sec.)     Magnitude        Aperture\n---------------------------------------------------------\n  B        2500             24.73 +/- 0.11   4.5 arcsec\n  V        1500             24.81 +/- 0.19   4.5 arcsec\n  Rc       1800*            24.38+/-  0.10   4.5 arcsec\n  Ic       1800             23.68 +/- 0.30   4.5 arcsec\n---------------------------------------------------------\n* The R-band data obtained on 25 Aug. are coadded.\n\nImages can be seen at\nhttp://www.sao.ru/~sokolov/GRB/HOSTS/GRB000926/GRB000926.html\n\nThis message may be cited\".\n\n-Vladimir Sokolov, on behalf of the RAS Special Astrophysical Observatory\nGRB followup team.","createdOn":999935125000,"email":"sokolov@sao.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX/GRBM detection of GRB 010801","circularId":1086,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10086....1S","body":"M. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome) and C. Guidorzi (University of Ferrara)\nreport on behalf of the BeppoSAX/GRBM team:\n\n\"The BeppoSAX Gamma Ray Burst Monitor (GRBM) was triggered by a gamma-ray\nburst on August 1st, 2001, 18:30:34.39 UT. This event is most likely the\nsame event detected by HETE-2 on the same day at 18:30:37.42 UT (HETE\nTrigger Number 1669). As seen in unit #2 of the GRBM, in the 40-700 keV\nenergy range, the event was bright (about 4,300 counts/s at peak)\nand long (approx. 33 s). It showed a main, structured pulse 10 s long,\nfollowed by a bunch of much shorter and weaker pulses starting about 4 s\nafter the end of the main pulse.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":996701872000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"Probable SGR or Short Duration GRB Detected by HETE","circularId":1089,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10089....1U","body":"Probable SGR or Short Duration GRB Detected by HETE\n\nG. Hurley on behalf\nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 05:06:30.61 UTC (18390.61 s UT) on 22 August, the HETE FREGATE \ninstrument detected a short, intense burst from a probable soft \ngamma-ray repeater or (less likely) a short duration GRB. This event \nwas promptly distributed as a GCN Notice (HETE BID_1715). No signal \nwas detected in the WXM, indicating that the event was likely to \nbe >40 degrees from the anti-sun direction. For the current HETE \npointing direction, SGR1900+14 is about 48 degrees off the boresight, \nwhile SGR1806-20 is about 56 degrees off the boresight, so that \neither could be a candidate.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~200 ms. A total of 500\ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence\nof ~9 x 10-8 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux was >2 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >50 x Crab flux) over a duration of 30 ms.\n\nA search for this event in the archives of other GRB instruments is \nencouraged. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 08:33:12 UTC (=30792s UT), a soft spectrum, high \nenergy transient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized \nby HETE.\n(NB: This is the second GRB detected by HETE on 26 March 2001.)\n\nBoth the WXM and the FREGATE instruments detected the event. The \nburst triggered FREGATE in the 6-120 keV band, at the 160ms timescale.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h24m23.36s, \nDec. = -11o09'57\", derived from combining data from the WXM and \nBoresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the WXM \nlocalization is 18 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we estimate \na systematic error radius at present of 10 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 30 \narcsec (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~4 Crab; with WXM \n(2-25 keV), ~2 Crab. The burst duration was about 4 seconds.\n\nThe high galactic latitude of the source, well away from the Galactic \nBulge, and the shape of its spectrum suggest that it is a gamma-ray \nburst similar to those reported for \"X-ray rich\" GRBs by Heise et al \n(2001) from BeppoSAX observations.\n\nFollow-up observations of this unusual transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on the GRB010326B (including light curves), as \nwell as for the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985612698000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Howard E Bond at STScI  <bond@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 010326 optical observations","circularId":1016,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10016....1L","body":"I have obtained CCD images centered on the position of GRB 010326,\n11:50:59.1 -23:32:44 (J2000), with the Cerro Tololo Interamerican\nObservatory 0.9-m reflector, on 2001 March 26 from 08:18 to 08:50 UT. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, G. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 03:15:00 UTC, a hard spectrum, high energy \ntransient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized by \nHETE. Both the FREGATE and the WXM instruments detected the event. \nThe burst triggered FREGATE in the 30-400 keV band.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h50m59.11s, \nDec. = -23�32'44\" (J2000), derived from combining data from the WXM \nand Boresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the \nWXM localization is 10 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we \nestimate a systematic error radius at present of 20 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 2 \narcmin (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe burst exhibited a multiple-peaked structure and lasted about 25 \nseconds. The peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~1 Crab. The \npeak flux was significantly less in the WXM.\n\nFollow-up observations of this GRB event are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on GRB010326 (including light curves and the \nWXM error box), as well as the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985591482000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Filippo Frontera at U. of Ferrara, Physics Dept  <frontera@fe.infn.it>","subject":"SGR1900+14 burst seen by HETE: BeppoSAX data","circularId":1081,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10081....1M","body":"E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi and F. Frontera, Physics Dept., University of\nFerrara, Italy; F. Calura, Astronomy Dept., University of Trieste; M.\nFeroci, IAS, CNR, Rome, Italy, report:\n\nThe short burst from SGR1900+14 detected by HETE (GCN # 1078) was also\ndetected by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor aboard BeppoSAX. The burst\ntriggered the GRBM on board logic at 03:34:07.15 UT of July 2, 2001. The\nevent duration was about 2 s.\n\nThe event showed significant flux only in the 40-100 keV energy band. The\ntotal counts above the background level in this range were 400 +/- 50. \nAssuming a power law spectral shape, from our data we can set a lower\nlimit to the photon index of 3.5. With a photon index of 4.0, the derived\nfluence is (1.2+/- 0.2) x 10-6 erg cm-2 in the band from 40 to 100 keV. \nUsing the high time resolution data only available in the 40-700 keV band,\nthe peak flux obtained from 125 ms bins corresponds to (1.4 +/- 0.4)x10-6\nerg cm-2 s-1. \n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":994267010000,"email":"frontera@fe.infn.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"INTEGRAL Shift Ops at INTEGRAL  <shift@isdcmail.unige.ch>","subject":"GRB021219: Correction to GCN 1766","circularId":1769,"bibcode":"2002GCN..1769....1I","body":"Due to a typing mistake the GRB declination in GCN 1766\nwas reported as  +31deg 52s.\nThe correct value is  +31deg 52min\nThere was also a spelling error in the name of J.Borkowski","createdOn":1040322241000,"email":"shift@isdcmail.unige.ch"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Josh Bloom at CIT  <jsb@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"Further Optical Observations of GRB 010324","circularId":1024,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1024....1B","body":"Further Optical Observations of GRB 010324\n\nJ. S. Bloom, P. A. Price, D. W. Fox, S. G. Djorgovski (CIT), and\nJ. M. Schombert (U. Oregon) report on behalf of the larger\nCaltech-NRAO-CARA GRB Collaboration:\n\n\"On 26.27 March 2001, we obtained a second night of exposures of the\nfield of GRB 010324 (GCN/RXTE ASM; Hurley et al., GCN #1011) using\nCOSMIC on the Palomar 200-inch atop Mt. Palomar.  Using the same\npattern as in the first epoch of imaging (GCN #1012), the entire XTE\nerror box was observed in V-band in two pointings with a total of 1800\nsec per pointing.\n\nBoth image differencing and differential aperture photometry between\nthe two epochs revealed no obviously varying source.  No absolute\nphotometry for the field is available at this time.  However, adopting\nV = 19.1 mag for a USNO A2.0 star at RA: 07:11:26.301, DEC:\n+19:58:30.32 (J2000) we estimate the absence of variation by more than\n0.3 mag down to V = 22.3 mag.\n\nSources brighter than V~18.5 mag were saturated however all such sources\nwere previously observed in DPOSS (see GCN #1012); therefore any GRB\nafterglow is now likely to be faint (V > 22.3 mag). One caveat to this\nconclusion is that the GRB field has a high stellar density and so it is\npossible to have missed a varying source near a bright star.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985713383000,"email":"jsb@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"Duration, ECT, peak flux and fluence of GRB010324","circularId":1013,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1013....1H","body":"K. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and C. Guidorzi,\nE. Montanari, and F. Frontera, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM\nteam, report:\n\nThis burst (RXTE/ASM and GCN 1011) had a duration of\napproximately 15 seconds in 25-150 keV gamma-rays.  Its\nEarth-crossing time was ~41558 s, and its 25-100 keV\nfluence was ~1.8x10^-6 erg/cm^2; over 0.25 s, its peak\nflux was ~4.3x10^-7 erg/cm^2 s.  The latter numbers are\nuncertain by about a factor of 2 at present, but can\nprobably be refined with further processing.","createdOn":985540932000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Scott Barthelmy at NASA/GSFC  <scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"GCN and HETE status","circularId":1085,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1085....1B","body":"INTRO:\nThere have been a lot of HETE triggers in the last week.  Many people\nare wondering what is going on.  This announcement attempts to explain\nthe recent developments.\n\nTRIGGERS:\nStarting about a week ago, the HETE Operations team resumed sending\nthe HETE messages from the s/c to GCN -- there were gaps due to HETE and due\nto GCN (the network problems).  And since the Galactic Center\nis still in the HETE FOV, this has caused a marked step increase\nin the amount of HETE Notices (from zero to several per day).\nThis increase has been further enhanced by the fact that Sco X-1 has left\nthe FOV of the HETE instruments two weeks ago.  The decrease in the background\ndue to the loss of Sco X-1 has increased the sensitivity to the the XRB\nsources in the Galactic Center.\n\nPOSITIONS:\nSince a larger fraction of these triggers is caused by X-ray Burst sources\nwhich are very weak, they produce poor image detections and therefore\nlocations with large uncertainites.  The HETE Operations team\nhas commanded the s/c to suppress the positions if the \"source\"\nin the image is not significant enough.  This results in the large\nnumber of Notices with no positions.\n\nFILTERING:\nI have changed the GCN filtering system to compensate for this change\nin the Notice content.  If there is no position in the S/C_Update,\nS/C_Last, or even the Gnd_Analysis messages, then they are NOT distributed\nthe sites requesting HETE Notices.  The reasoning is that with no position\ninformation in the Notice, what possible use could a follow-up observer\nmake of the notification.  This change was made Saturday, 28 Jul 01.\n\nTOO MANY ALERTS?\nHowever, the S/C_Alerts never were intended to have position information\n(except for rare instances (~10%)), so they are still being distributed\nto those sites that have requested the HETE S/C_Alert subtype.\nEven with the filtering of the U/L/GA's that have no positions, there are\nstill a large number of Alert Notices being distributed to sites.  If you feel\nthat you are receiving too many Alerts (that subsequently have no U/L/GA\nfollow-ups), then you might consider requesting that the Alert subtype\nbe disabled for your site.  (Or you might consider \"toughing it out\"\nfor another 4-6 weeks until the Galactic Center is no longer in the HETE FOV \nin which case the trigger rate should drop dramatically.)\n\nACTION ITEM:\nSites can:\n1) keep their current configurations,   or\n2) request that S/C_Alerts be disabled,   or\n3) request that S/C_Alerts/Updates/Lasts be disabled (say for the next month\nor so, and then request they be turned back on),   or\n4) request that all HETE subtypes (A/U/L/GA) be disabled (again for the next\nmonth or so).\nGiven the no-positions-filtering incorporated last Saturday, choice \"2\"\nseems like a reasonable approach if a site has any concern about \"too many\nNotices\".\n\nSincerely,\n\nScott Barthelmy\nNASA-GSFC\n301-286-3106\nscott@lheamail.gsfs.nasa.gov","createdOn":996530269000,"email":"scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Lorenzo Amati at TESRE/CNR  <amati@tesre.bo.cnr.it>","subject":"GRB010412: BeppoSAX GRBM and WFC observations","circularId":1037,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1037....1P","body":"A.
