At the time of the trigger the HAWC\nlocal zenith was oriented towards (RA, Dec) = (63.2 deg, 18.9 deg).\n57% of the GW candidate sky location probability fell within our\nobservable field of view (0-45 deg zenith angle).\n\nWe performed a search for a short timescale emission using 6 sliding\ntime windows (dt = 0.3s, 1s, 3s, 10s, 30s and  100s), shifted forward\nin time by 20% of their width. We searched the 95% probability\ncontainment area in a timescale-dependent time period, from t0-5dt to\nt0+10dt, where t0 is the time of the GW trigger.\n\nNo significant gamma-ray detection above the background was observed.\n\nThe sensitivity of this analysis is greatly dependent on zenith angle,\nranging from 14.4 deg to 45 deg for the area searched in this\nanalysis. The 5sigma detection sensitivity to a 1s (100s) burst in the\n80-800GeV energy range goes from 1.6e-6 erg/cm^2 to 1.1e-4 erg/cm^2\n(8.6e-6 erg/cm^2 to 5.0e-4 erg/cm^2), depending on the zenith\nangle.\n\nHAWC is a TeV gamma ray water Cherenkov array located in the state of\nPuebla, Mexico. It is sensitive to the energy range ~0.1-100TeV, and\nmonitors 2/3 of the sky every day with an instantaneous field-of-view\nof ~2 sr.","createdOn":1559500672000,"email":"imc@umd.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"SGR1900+14 - correction","circularId":1054,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1054....1H","body":"In GCN 1053, the date should read 2001 April 17 and 18, not 2000 April 17 and 18.","createdOn":988386763000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andrew S. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 980326: Late-time HST/STIS observations","circularId":1029,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10029....1G","body":"Andrew Fruchter (STScI), Paul Vreeswijk (University of Amsterdam) and\nPeter Nugent (LBNL) report on behalf of a larger HST GRB collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 980326 with HST/STIS on 31 December 2000,\njust over 1000 days after the burst. The total exposure time was 7080\nseconds in the 50CCD aperture. The images were reduced by the standard\nHST pipeline, and drizzled to a combined image with a pixelscale of\n0.\"0254.\n\nWe projected the location of the early afterglow from a KeckII/LRIS R\nband image, taken by Filippenko, Leonard and Riess on March 27, 1998\n(see GCN 33).  We estimate the 1-sigma error radius to be less than 1.5\ndrizzled HST pixels, which includes both the scatter in the\ntransformation (0.9 pixels, using 6 reference stars) and the\nmeasurement error of the transient in the Keck image (0.8 pixels).\n\nWithin one pixel of the estimated position, there was evidence of a\nsmall source.  We therefore convolved the image with a gaussian with a\nFWHM equal to that of the PSF (3.5 drizzled pixels).  This procedure\nuses the PSF as a matched filter to enhance the the signal-to-noise\nratio of unresolved sources.  In the convolved image an object is\nfound, again offset by one pixel from the expected position with a\nsignificance of ~4.5 sigma.  We estimate a magnitude (in the broad STIS\n50ccd filter) of V = 29.25 +/- 0.25.\n\nBloom et al., (1999, Nature, 401, 453) have suggested that the unusual\nlight curve of this GRB might be explained by an underlying supernova,\nand on the basis of this estimated a redshift of about z~1.   A\nsupernova at this redshift (which in this model peaks around a\nmagnitude of 25) would be expected to be significantly fainter than\nV=29 by now (as would the rapidly decaying GRB afterglow).  Therefore,\nwe may be detecting a faint host galaxy.  Deep HST images have in all\nother cases detected a host underlying the GRB, when good astrometry\nwas available for the GRB.  If we are observing a host galaxy, then the\nabove magnitude could underestimate its brightness by as much as a few\ntenths of a magnitude, due to extended emission missed in this\nmeasurement.  A galaxy at a z~1 with this observed magnitude would lie\na rather remarkable 7 magnitudes below L*, the knee of the of the\ngalaxy luminosity function at that redshift.\n\nGiven the apparent point-source nature of the detected object, and the\nlack of color information, we cannot exclude the possibility (which we\nconsider remote) that we are observing a light echo, from either the\nGRB or the supernova.\n\nImages of the field can be found at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/980326","createdOn":985809183000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Valerie Connaughton at NASA/MSFC/USRA  <valerie@nasa.gov>","subject":"LIGO/Virgo G194575:  Fermi GBM Observations","circularId":18448,"bibcode":"2015GCN.18448....1B","body":"LIGO/Virgo G194575:  Fermi GBM Observations\n\nLindy Blackburn (CfA), Michael S. Both the FREGATE and the WXM instruments detected the event. \nThe burst triggered FREGATE in the 30-400 keV band.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h50m59.11s, \nDec. = -23�32'44\" (J2000), derived from combining data from the WXM \nand Boresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the \nWXM localization is 10 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we \nestimate a systematic error radius at present of 20 arcmin about this \nlocation. Frontera (on behalf of the BeppoSAX team)\n\nReport:\n\nNew images in the K'-band obtained on June 14.87-14.93 at the 3.5-m CAHA \ntelescope (+ OMEGA) indicate that the red object reported by us (GCN 102) \nis a slow-moving object, probably an asteroid, and therefore unrelated \nto GRB 980613. The candidate was found\nby the PyCBC Live [1], CWB [2], SPIIR [3], GstLAL [4], and MBTAOnline\n[5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS190602aq is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as\nestimated by the online analysis, is 1.9e-09 Hz, or about one in 16\nyears. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S190602aq\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending\nprobability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), NSBH (<1%),\nor MassGap (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, there is strong\nevidence against the lighter compact object having a mass < 3 solar\nmasses (HasNS: <1%). Using the masses and spins inferred from the\nsignal, there is strong evidence against matter outside the final\ncompact object (HasRemnant: <1%).\n\nOne skymap is available at this time and can be retrieved from the\nGraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.fits.gz, an updated localization generated by BAYESTAR\n[6], distributed via GCN notice about 6 minutes after the candidate\n\nFor the bayestar.fits.gz skymap, the 90% credible region is 1172 deg2.\nMarginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance\nestimate is 797 +/- 238 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard\ndeviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of\nthis alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo Public Alerts User Guide\n<https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/userguide/>.\n\n [1] Nitz et al. CZTI is a coded aperture mask instrument that has considerable effective area for about 29% of the entire sky, but is also sensitive to brighter transients from the entire sky. At the time of merger, Astrosat's nominal pointing is (RA=295.71, DEC=-10.36), which is 134.4 deg away from the maximum probability location. In a time interval of 100 sec around the event, 51% of sky locations are visible in the satellite's frame and the rest of 49% with the inclusion of maximum probability location for the event are occulted by earth. \n\nCZTI data were de-trended to remove orbit-wise background variation. We then searched data from three of the four independent, identical quadrants to look for coincident spikes in the count rates. Searches were undertaken by binning the data in 0.1s, 1s, and 10s respectively. Statistical fluctuations in count rates were estimated by using data from 10 (+-5) neighbouring orbits. We selected confidence levels such that the probability of a false trigger in a 1000 sec window is 10^-4.We do not find any evidence for any hard X-ray transient in this window, in the CZTI energy range of 20-200 keV.\n\nWe convert our count rates into flux by assuming that the source spectrum is a power law with alpha = -1.0. We use a detailed mass model of the satellite to calculate the instrument response for every htm grid point that fall in 90% LIGO localization region and calculate flux limit in that direction. We get the following upper limits for source flux in the 20-200 keV band by taking a probability weighted mean of flux limit and are reported here :  \n\n0.1 s: flux limit= 8.7 e-7 ergs/cm^2/s \n1.0 s: flux limit= 3.0 e-6 ergs/cm^2/s \n10.0 s: flux limit= 3.6 e-6 ergs/cm^2/s\n\nCZTI is built by a TIFR-led consortium of institutes across India, including VSSC, ISAC, IUCAA, SAC and PRL. As observed by SROSS C-2, it \nhad a duration (T90) of 1.20 +- 0.05 secs. Its fluence in the 20-100 keV \nband is equal to 1.41.10-7 +- 2.0.10-8 ergs cm-2 and in the 100-1024 keV \nband is equal to 5.59.10-5 +- 2.35. 10-6 ergs cm-2 respectively. The peak flux (256 ms) in the \n20-100 keV band is 4.73 photons cm-2 sec-1 and the peak flux (256 ms) in \nthe 100-1024 keV band is 6.29 photons cm-2 sec-1. The hardness ratio for \nthis burst (when the signal peaks in the 100-1024 keV channel) is equal \nto 0.56 +- 0.15. Our hardness ratio is defined as [counts(100-1024 \nkeV)/counts (20-100 keV)]. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Analysis of data from the 22 April 2001 Chandra observation (GCN\n1046, 1047), barycenter-corrected with the preliminary CXC ephemeris,\nreveals that the source emission is pulsed at a period of P =\n5.17288(5) s with a pulse strength of 14.3(2)% RMS that remains\nconstant (within errors) throughout the observation.  Separation of\nthe source photons into \"on-pulse\" and \"off-pulse\" components of 1/3\ncycle each reveals that the off-pulse spatial distribution is\nsignificantly broader than the on-pulse distribution.  Since the\nobservation is taken in continuous-clocking mode, we can only make\nthis determination in one dimension.  Nonetheless, the sigma-widths of\nthe one-dimensional Gaussian PSFs are 0.98(1) arcsec for on-pulse\nphotons and 1.08(2) arcsec for off-pulse photons, different at\n>5-sigma level. The burst occurred \nat 18950.56 SOD {05:15:50.56} UT on 21 September.  The burst is seen \nin the WXM X detector and is therefore well-localized in the X \ndirection; the burst was apparently outside the coded FOV of the WXM \nY detector, which therefore gives limited information about the Y \ndirection of the burst.\n\nThe X-detector data gives a good (+/-10 arcmin) localization in the X\ndirection and crude limits on Y, resulting in a localization that is a\nthin, long strip.\n\nTwo points along one side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h52m36s.7, Dec. =  39o35'13\"\nR.A. = 23h10m22s.8, Dec. =  48o57'43\"\n\nTwo points along the other side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h54m04s.0, Dec. =  39o34'23\"\nR.A. = 23h11m52s.5, Dec. =  48o57'00\"\n\nOur estimate is that the strip is  ~10  degrees in the long direction.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~12 s. A total of 5310 \ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence \nof ~1 x 10-6 ergs cm-2. Ferro, S. Campana, Y.-D. Hu, R. Brivio, P. D’Avanzo, S. Covino, and D. Fugazza (INAF-OAB) report on behalf of the REM team:\nWe observed the field of GRB 241013A, detected by Fermi GBM (Fermi GBM Team GCN 37780) and INTEGRAL (Gotz et al. GCN 37781), with the REM 60cm robotic telescope located at the ESO observatory of La Silla (Chile), for two consecutive nights. The observations were carried in the g, r, i, z, J, H bands, starting:\n(1) epoch 1 on 2024 October 13 at 01:23 UT (i.e. 24.4 minutes after the INTEGRAL trigger), and lasting for about 1 hours.\n(2) epoch 2 on 2024 October 14 at 00:57 UT (i.e. 1 day after the INTEGRAL trigger), and lasting for about 1 hours.\n\nWe note that the field is extremely crowded due to its localization near the Galactic plane, where the extinction is significantly high, with E(B-V) = 11.8 (https://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/workspace/TMP_QnYsQd_14990/DUST/18_20_57.1_-15_38_09.5.v0001/extinction.html)\n\nFrom preliminary photometry within the 90% c.l. INTEGRAL error region (2.5 arcmin) we detect a source that is not listed in the 2MASS catalog, in H band first epoch, at the following position (J2000):\nR.A. = 18:20:57.1 \nDEC. = -15:38:09.5\nwith a fiducial uncertainty of 3 arcsec. \nWith magnitude:\nepoch (1) H = 14.9+-0.3 (Vega; against 2MASS)\n\nThe source is not detected in the second epoch down to:\nepoch (2) H > 15.3 (Vega; against 2MASS)\n\nWe note however that two PS1 sources are consistent with the candidate position, and a third one is marginally consistent, with r-band magnitudes ~20.3, ~21.6, and ~20.4, respectively. From preliminary photometry at the H-band source position, on the two r-band observations, we find:\nepoch (1) r > 19.7 (AB; against PS1)\nepoch (2) r = 19.8+-0.3 (AB; against PS1)\n\nWe suggest that this could be the blending of the PS1 sources, only detected in the second epoch given our deeper magnitude limit with respect to the first night. Veres (UAH) and C. Meegan (UAH) report on behalf of\nthe Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\"At 00:58:34.36 UT on 13 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB 241013A (trigger 750473919/241013041).\nwhich was also detected by INTEGRAL (Gotz et al. 2024, GCN 37781).\nThe Fermi GBM on-ground location is consistent with the INTEGRAL position.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 29 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of a single emission episode with a duration (T90)\nof about 9 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0-6.1 to T0+3.6 s is best fit by\na simple power law function with index -1.26 +/- 0.06.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(1.4 +/- 0.1)E-06 erg/cm^2. The 1-sec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0+2.1 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 1 +/- 0.1 ph/s/cm^2.\n\nA power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff fits the spectrum equally well.\nThe power law index is -0.58 +/- 0.29 and the cutoff energy, parameterized as\nEpeak, is 550 +/- 200 keV.\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1729006478665}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241013B","submitter":"Jimmy DeLaunay at Penn State <delauj2@gmail.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241013B: Swift/BAT-GUANO localization skymap of a burst","circularId":37790,"format":"text/markdown","body":"James DeLaunay (PSU), Aaron Tohuvavohu (U Toronto), Samuele Ronchini (PSU), Gayathri Raman (PSU), Jamie A. Kennea (PSU), Tyler Parsotan (NASA GSFC) report: \n\nSwift/BAT did not localize GRB 241013B onboard (T0: 2024-10-13 22:27:42.03 UTC, Fermi trig 750551267, SVOM/GRM GCN 37785) \n\nThe Fermi notice, distributed in near real-time, triggered the Swift Mission Operations Center operated Gamma-ray Urgent Archiver for Novel Opportunities (GUANO; Tohuvavohu et al. 2020, ApJ, 900, 1). \n\nUpon trigger by this notice, GUANO sent a command to the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) to save 200 seconds of BAT event-mode data from [-50,+150] seconds around the time of the burst. All the requested event mode data was delivered to the ground. \n\nThe BAT likelihood search, NITRATES (DeLaunay + Tohuvavohu 2022, ApJ, 941, 169), performed on the temporal window [T0-20 s, T0+20 s], detects the burst with a sqrt(TS) of 8.5 in a 8.192 s analysis time bin, starting at T0 + 0.0 s. \n\nUsing the NITRATES analysis, parameter estimation was performed to obtain the localization of this burst in the form of a HEALPIX Multi-Order Coverage (MOC) skymap. This localization accounts for both statistical and systematic errors. More details in the creation and calibration of these maps will soon be published (DeLaunay et al. 2024. in prep)\n\nThe 90% credible area is 9,534 deg2 and the 50% credible area is 1,569 deg2.\nThe integrated probability inside the coded field of view is 8%. \n\nA plot of the probability skymap can be viewed here,\n[https://guano.swift.psu.edu/trigger_report?id=750551296/#:~:text=Probability%20Skymap](https://guano.swift.psu.edu/trigger_report?id=750551296/#:~:text=Probability%20Skymap)\n\nThe probability skymap file can be downloaded from the link here,\nhttps://guano.swift.psu.edu/files/750551296/0_n_PROBMAP\n\nInstructions on how to read and manipulate this map can be found here,\nhttps://guano.swift.psu.edu/documentation\n\nMore details about this burst can be found on the trigger report page here\nhttps://guano.swift.psu.edu/trigger_report?id=750551296\n\nGUANO is a fully autonomous, extremely low latency, spacecraft commanding pipeline designed for targeted recovery of BAT event mode data around the times of compelling astrophysical events to enable more sensitive GRB searches. \n\nA live reporting of Swift/BAT event data recovered by GUANO can be found at: https://www.swift.psu.edu/guano/","createdOn":1729021863295}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241013B","submitter":"sumanbala2210@gmail.com","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241013B: Fermi GBM Observation","circularId":37791,"format":"text/plain","body":"S. Bala (USRA), P. Veres (UAH) and C. Meegan (UAH) report on behalf of\nthe Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\"At 22:27:42.03 UT on 13 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB 241013B (trigger 750551267/241013936).\nwhich was also detected by Swift/BAT-GUANO(J. DeLaunay et al. 2024, GCN 37790) and\nSVOM/GRM (Y. Zhang et al. 2024, GCN 37785) .\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 69 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of a single peak with smooth decay with a duration (T90)\nof about 29 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0-6.8 to T0+37.2 s is best fit by\na power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff.\nThe power law index is -1.39 +/- 0.06 and the cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 280 +/- 60 keV.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(7.9 +/- 0.4)E-06 erg/cm^2. The 1-sec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0+0.77 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 6.1 +/- 0.3 ph/s/cm^2.\n\nA Band function fits the spectrum equally well with Epeak= 270 +/- 81 keV, \nalpha = -1.39 +/- 0.07 and beta = -2.31 +/- 0.56.\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1729036346730}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241010A","submitter":"Mike Moss at NASA GSFC <mikejmoss3@gmail.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241010A: Swift-BAT refined analysis","circularId":37792,"format":"text/plain","body":"D. Sadaula (GSFC/UMBC), S. D. Barthelmy (GSFC),\nS. Dichiara (PSU),  R. Gupta (GSFC),\nH. A. Krimm (NSF), S. Laha (GSFC/UMBC),\nA. Y. Lien (U Tampa), C. B. Markwardt (GSFC),\nM. J. Moss (GSFC), D. M. Sakamoto (AGU)\n(i.e. the Swift-BAT team):\n \nUsing the data set from T-240 to T+962 sec from the recent telemetry downlink,\nwe report further analysis of BAT GRB 241010A (trigger #1259578)\n(Dichiara, et al., GCN Circ. 37755).  The BAT ground-calculated position is\nRA, Dec = 153.367, 11.544 deg which is\n   RA(J2000)  =  10h 13m 28.1s\n   Dec(J2000) = +11d 32' 40.1\"\nwith an uncertainty of 1.1 arcmin, (radius, sys+stat, 90% containment).\nThe partial coding was 85%.\n \nThe mask-weighted light curve shows multiple emission periods. The first period\nlasts ~six seconds and displays three pulses, followed by a quiescent period, and\nthen a second emission period lasting ~15 seconds with two apparent pulses.\nT90 (15-350 keV) is 30.86 +- 1.36 sec (estimated error including systematics).\n \nThe time-averaged spectrum from T-0.04 to T+35.12 sec is best fit by a simple\npower-law model. Upon further examination by the IceCube collaboration, the event was found to clearly not be of astrophysical origin.  \n\nAt the time of this alert, the detector was operating with several portions of the detector removed from data taking.  Normally, these periods of operation are excluded from generating alerts.  We apologize for any confusion this error may have caused.\n\nThe IceCube Neutrino Observatory is a cubic-kilometer neutrino detector operating at the geographic South Pole, Antarctica. Trigger (IMT), which sent 1 Alert, with a signal-to-noise ratio of 6.9 in the 5-8 keV energy band over a time window of 40.96 s starting at Tb.\nThe excess was confirmed after reception of the full dataset on ground.\n\nThe localization of the burst is RA, Dec = 356.28, 15.72 (J2000).\n\nThe statistical uncertainty on this position is 12.4 arcminutes, to which we recommend adding 10 arcminutes of systematic uncertainty in quadrature.\n\nThe significance of the detection was too low to request an automatic slew of SVOM to the burst position.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA), French Space Agency (CNES), and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241017A","submitter":"Benjamin Schneider at MIT <bschn@mit.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241017A: J-band upper limit from WINTER","circularId":37805,"format":"text/plain","body":"Viraj Karambelkar (Caltech), Benjamin Schneider (MIT), Geoffrey Mo (MIT), Robert Stein (Caltech), Tomas Ahumada (Caltech), Nathan Lourie (MIT), Danielle Frostig (CFA), Robert Simcoe (MIT), and Mansi Kasliwal (Caltech) report:\n\nWe observed the field of the SVOM/ECLAIRs GRB 241017A (Le Provost et al, GCN 37799) in the near-infrared J-band with the Palomar 1-m telescope, equipped with the 1-square degree WINTER camera (Lourie et al. 2020, Frostig et al. 2024).\n\nOur observations began at 2024-10-17T07:40:52 UTC (~3.7 hours after the GRB trigger) and consisted of 30x120s exposures. The images were processed using the WINTER data reduction pipeline (https://github.com/winter-telescope/mirar, https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10888436), with image subtraction performed relative to J-band images from the UKIRT Hemisphere survey (Dye et al., 2017).\n\nOur observations covered 95% of the SVOM/ECLAIRs statistical error circle. In the stacked and subtracted images, we do not detect any new source down to a 5-sigma depth of J ~ 19.3 mag (AB).\n\nWINTER (Wide-field INfrared Transient ExploreR) is a partnership between MIT and Caltech, housed at Palomar Observatory, and funded by NSF MRI, NSF AAG, the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, and the MIT Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research.","createdOn":1729181767329}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241016B","submitter":"Jimmy DeLaunay at Penn State <delauj2@gmail.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241016B: Swift/BAT-GUANO localization skymap of a short burst","circularId":37806,"format":"text/markdown","body":"James DeLaunay (PSU), Aaron Tohuvavohu (U Toronto), Samuele Ronchini (PSU), Gayathri Raman (PSU), Jamie A. Kennea (PSU), Tyler Parsotan (NASA GSFC) report: \n\nSwift/BAT did not localize GRB 241016B onboard (T0: 2024-10-16 11:12:40.13 UTC, Fermi trig 750769965, GCN 37797, SVOM/GRM GCN 37803) \n\nThe Fermi notice, distributed in near real-time, triggered the Swift Mission Operations Center operated Gamma-ray Urgent Archiver for Novel Opportunities (GUANO; Tohuvavohu et al. 2020, ApJ, 900, 1). \n\nUpon trigger by this notice, GUANO sent a command to the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) to save 200 seconds of BAT event-mode data from [-50,+150] seconds around the time of the burst. All the requested event mode data was delivered to the ground. \n\nThe BAT likelihood search, NITRATES (DeLaunay + Tohuvavohu 2022, ApJ, 941, 169), performed on the temporal window [T0-20 s, T0+20 s], detects the burst with a sqrt(TS) of 7.2 in a 0.128 s analysis time bin, starting at T0 - 0.064 s. \n\nUsing the NITRATES analysis, parameter estimation was performed to obtain the localization of this burst in the form of a HEALPIX Multi-Order Coverage (MOC) skymap. This localization accounts for both statistical and systematic errors. More details in the creation and calibration of these maps will soon be published (DeLaunay et al. 2024. in prep)\n\nThe 90% credible area is 16,614 deg2 and the 50% credible area is 7,705 deg2.\nThe integrated probability inside the coded field of view is 2%. \n\nA plot of the probability skymap can be viewed here,\n[https://guano.swift.psu.edu/trigger_report?id=750769994/#:~:text=Probability%20Skymap](https://guano.swift.psu.edu/trigger_report?id=750769994/#:~:text=Probability%20Skymap)\n\nThe probability skymap file can be downloaded from the link here,\nhttps://guano.swift.psu.edu/files/750769994/0_n_PROBMAP\n\nInstructions on how to read and manipulate this map can be found here,\nhttps://guano.swift.psu.edu/documentation\n\nMore details about this burst can be found on the trigger report page here\nhttps://guano.swift.psu.edu/trigger_report?id=750769994\n\nGUANO is a fully autonomous, extremely low latency, spacecraft commanding pipeline designed for targeted recovery of BAT event mode data around the times of compelling astrophysical events to enable more sensitive GRB searches. \n\nA live reporting of Swift/BAT event data recovered by GUANO can be found at: https://www.swift.psu.edu/guano/\n","createdOn":1729193735412}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241017A","submitter":"Diego Gotz at CEA <diego.gotz@cea.fr>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB241017A: TOO Observations by SVOM/MXT","circularId":37807,"format":"text/plain","body":"SVOM/MXT Commissioning Team: D. Götz (CEA Irfu/DAp), A. Fort, J. Joubert, K. Mercier, S. Crepaldi (CNES), F. Robinet, N. Leroy (IJCLab), P. Ferrando, H. Goto, A. Meuris, M. Moita, C. Plasse, A. Sauvageon (CEA), P. Maggi, L. Michel (ObAS) \n\nSVOM JSWG: Jian-Yan Wei (NAOC), Bertrand Cordier (CEA), Shuang-Nan Zhang (IHEP), Stéphane Basa (LAM), Olivier Godet (IRAP), Arnaud Claret (CEA), Zi-Gao Dai (USTC), Frédéric Daigne (IAP), Jin-Song Deng (NAOC), Andrea Goldwurm (APC), Diego Götz (CEA), Xu-Hui Han (NAOC), Cyril Lachaud (APC), En-Wei Liang (GXU), Yu-Lei Qiu (NAOC), Susanna Vergani (Obs.Paris), Jing Wang (NAOC), Chao Wu (NAOC), Li-Ping Xin (NAOC), Shaolin Xiong (IHEP), Bing Zhang (UNLV)\n\nReport on behalf of the SVOM team:\n\nMXT observed the field of GRB241017A (Le Provost et al., GCN 37799) as a ToO from 2024 October 17th  at 18:05 UTC for about 4ks, about 14 hours after T0.\n\nOur preliminary analysis shows no obvious X-ray conterpart in the entire ECLAIRs error region down to a limit of about 1e-12 erg/cmsq/s in the 0.5-10 keV energy band.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA), French Space Agency (CNES), and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. Cordier (CEA) on behalf of the SVOM and Einstein Probe teams\n\nWe performed a follow-up observation of GRB 241001A (Dagoneau et al., GCN 37655)  with the Follow-up X-ray Telescope (FXT) on board the Einstein Probe (EP) mission. The observation started at 2024-10-10T02:43:51 (T-TGRB ~ 0.52 day) for about 6 ks of exposure in total. \n\nWe detected an uncatalogued x-ray source at a position consistent with the Swift/XRT afterglow (Osborne et al., GCN 37725). Compared to the first Swift/XRT epoch (Osborne et al., GCN 37670) the source had faded by about an order of magnitude to F_X =  5.1e-14 +/- 1.2e-14 erg.cm-2.s-1 in the 0.3-10 keV energy band.\n \nWe thus confirm that the Swift/XRT source #2 is the afterglow of GRB 241001A.\n \nThe above observation was made with the EP-FXT instrument. Launched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics). The best detection is obtained by CRT with a signal-to-noise ratio of 107.8 in the 8-120 keV energy band over a time window of 10.24 s starting at T0.\n\nThe burst location is RA, Dec = 67.990, 43.030 (J2000).\n\nThe statistical uncertainty on this position is 2 arcminutes, to which we recommend adding 2 arcminutes of systematic uncertainty in quadrature.\n\nSVOM did perform an automatic slew to the burst.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA), French Space Agency (CNES), and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. Bissaldi (Politecnico and INFN Bari) and C. Meegan (UAH) \nreport on behalf of the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\n\"At 11:12:40.13 UT on 16 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB 241016B (trigger 750769965/241016467),\nwhich was also detected by SVOM/GRM (Zhang et al. 2024, GCN 37803)\nand by Swift/BAT-GUANO (DeLaunay et al. 2024, GCN 37806).\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 86 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of two peaks with a duration (T90)\nof about 0.8 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0-0.6s to T0+0.7s is best fit by\na power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff.\nThe power law index is 0.0 +/- 0.5 and the cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 840 +/- 380 keV.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(4.1 +/- 0.5)E-07 erg/cm^2. The 64-msec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0-0.064 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 6.4 +/- 0.7 ph/s/cm^2.\n\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1729258364752}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241018A","submitter":"Damien Turpin at CEA-Saclay <dturpin-astro@hotmail.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241018A: X-ray afterglow candidate observed by MXT","circularId":37814,"format":"text/plain","body":"P. The VT conducted observations simultaneously in two channels: VT_B (400nm-650nm) and VT_R (650nm-1000nm).\n\nWith the VHF data started at 2024-10-18T12:00:28 UT, in which the cataloged source brighter than 21 mag is completed relative to the PS1 catalog. An uncatalogued source was found within the errorbox of Eclairs and has an angular distance of 1.8509 arcmin from the position of MXT (Maggi et al., 37814). \n\nThe position is RA=04:31:59, DEC=+43:01:12, error=1.0 arcsec, J2000.\n\nThe brightness of the source is fading rapidly in 10 min, from 20.9 mag to 22.2 mag for VT_B and from 18.7 mag to 20.5 mag for VT_R.\n\nWe proposed that this source might be the counterpart of the burst. More analysis is continuing with X-band data. \n\nFurther follow-ups are encouraged especially in red wavelength. \n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA, China), National Center for Space Studies (CNES, France) and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS, China), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. Malesani at IMAPP / Radboud University <d.malesani@astro.ru.nl>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241018A: NOT optical observations","circularId":37821,"format":"text/plain","body":"Daniele B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.), Antonio de Ugarte Postigo (OCA/LAM - CNRS), Ny Avo Rakotondrainibe (LAM), and Alba Casasbuenas Corral, report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of the SVOM GRB 241018A (Atteia et al., GCN 37812; Maggi et al., GCN 37814; Qiu et al., GCN 37814) using the Nordic Optical Telescope (NOT) equipped with the ALFOSC imager. Given the proximity of the bright Moon and the large foreground extinction affecting this field, observations were carried out in the z band filter only, and consisted of 12x200 s exposures, at a mean epoch of 2024 Oct 18.988 UT (10.28 hr after the SVOM trigger).\n\nFollowing inspection of a preliminary stack of the data, a faint source is marginally detected at a position consistent with the VT optical afterglow candidate (Qiu et al., GCN 37814). We measure a preliminary magnitude z = 22.1 +- 0.3 AB, calibrated against nearby Pan-STARRS objects.\n\nThe fading of the source, as well as the association with Swift XRT source #1 (Evans, GCN 37817), further confirm the identification of the VT object as the optical afterglow of GRB 241018A.\n\nWe thank the SVOM team, in particular Liping Xin on behalf of VT commissioning team, for providing improved coordinates of the VT source.","createdOn":1729299085147}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241018A","submitter":"Matteo Ferro at INAF-OAB <matteo.ferro@inaf.it>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241018A: REM optical/NIR upper limits","circularId":37822,"format":"text/plain","body":"\nM. The observations were initiated at 15:35:30 2024-10-17 UT (~11.6 hrs after SVOM/Eclairs trigger) and several frames were taken in uvgriz bands (although affected with high background due to the moon light). We did not find any uncatalogued source in the stacked images which is consistent with the results reported by Mohan et al. (GCN 37808), Bochenek et al. (GCN 37810) and Qiu et al. (GCN 37820). It provides real-time, high-quality colors of stellar objects. The on-site telescope assemblage and commissioning were carried out in September 2022. (NAOC), Li-Ping Xin (NAOC),  Shao-Lin Xiong (IHEP), Bing Zhang  (UNLV)\n\nreport on behalf of the SVOM team:\n\nDuring the commissioning phase, the SVOM/GRM was triggered in-flight by GRB 241018A (SVOM trigger reference: sb24101802) at 2024-10-18T11:54:37.500 UT (T0), which also triggered SVOM/ECLAIRs (Atteia et al., GCN 37812).\n\nThe real-time alert data and light curves of SVOM/GRM were downlinked to the ground through the VHF system with low latency. The light curves show that this burst consists of multi pulse with a duration (T90) of about 16 s.\n\nThe SVOM/GRM light curve can be found here:\nhttps://www.bursthub.cn//admin/static/svgrb241018A.png\n\nThe time-averaged spectrum from T0 to T0+14 s is best fit by a power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff. The power law index is -1.28 +/- 0.04 and the cutoff energy, parameterized as Epeak, is 117 +/- 5 keV. The event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is (1.11 +/- 0.02)E-05 erg/cm^2.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA, China), National Center for Space Studies (CNES, France) and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS, China), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. (2017) in the redshift range [1,5], to the volume of the nearby universe enclosed within z = 0.151.\n\n- Assuming a constant GRB formation rate, we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~130 yr.\n- Assuming the GRB formation rate of Palmerio & Daigne (2021), we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~520 yr.\n\nWe conclude that there is a ~10% probability to observe an event like GRB 221009A about 50 years after the discovery of the first GRB.\n\nBibliography :\n- Cenko, S. GCNC 32660 -���������� Eiso = 8e53 ergs in [75 keV 1 MeV] ;\nFrederiks et al. GCNC 32668 - Eiso = 3e54 ergs in [20 keV - 10 MeV ?] ;\nKann et al. The peak flux measured by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor, \nafter background subtraction and no dead time correction, is around 15400\nc/s. The flare has an approximate duration of 40 s. Kouveliotou, Universities Space Research Association, M. Kippen, P.\nWoods, G. Richardson, University of Alabama in Huntsville, V.\nConnaughton, National Research Council, report on behalf of the BATSE\nteam at NASA/Marshall Space Flight Center:\n\nBATSE has detected repeated soft gamma-ray bursts consistent with the\nsame (previously unknown) location. We recorded three bursts on June\n15.109, 15.296, 15.411 UT (BATSE triggers 6825, 6826, 6827,\nrespectively) with an average duration of ~ 200 milliseconds.\nPreliminary spectral analysis of the data indicates that the events\nare very soft, with power law spectral indices varying between -3.0\nand -7.0. BATSE triggered 5 more times, on June 17.873, 17.901,\n18.004, 18.035, and 18.071 UT (BATSE trigger numbers 6833, 6834, 6835,\n6836 and 6837, respectively). The last trigger had a peak count rate\nof over 300000 counts/sec above background (integrated over 4\ndetectors between 20-1000 keV, in 1 second interval) and a duration of\n~ 3 seconds. Due to its very high peak intensity, deadtime effects\nprevent us from using it for localization, until we receive more data\ntypes. The weighted location of the 7 remaining triggers is centered\non R.A. = 16h27m12.0s and dec = -41d06.0' with an error radius of\nabout 2 degrees.  This location does not correspond to any previously\nknown SGR source; we conclude that we have discovered a new source,\nSGR1627-41. We have initiated an RXTE ToO and we strongly encourage\nwide field observations at other wavelengths.","createdOn":898140980000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Jens Hjorth at NORDITA  <jens@nordita.dk>","subject":"GRB 980613 Optical Observations","circularId":109,"bibcode":"1998GCN...109....1H","body":"GRB 980613 Optical Observations\n\nJ. Hjorth, M. I. Andersen, H. Pedersen, A. O. Jaunsen on behalf of the NOT \nGRB team and E. Costa & E. Palazzi on behalf of the SAX GRB team report:\n\nOn June 13.9 UT and June 17.9 UT we obtained R band images (600 sec each, \nseeing FWHM=0.7\") of the BeppoSAX error circle of GRB 980613 (Piro & Costa, \nGCN #99) with the 2.5-m Nordic Optical Telescope. We have discovered a faint \npoint source in our June 13.9 image which is not detected in our June 17.9 \nimage (which reaches a similar limiting magnitude). The source is located at \n(+- 0.5\"):\n\nRA(J2000)  =  10 17 57.64\nDec(J2000) = +71 27 26.4\n\nPreliminary photometry (Cousins R) of the source yields:\n\nJune 13.8897 UT: R = 22.9+-0.2\nJune 17.9088 UT: R > 24.0 (formal 10-sigma limit)\n\nThese numbers assume R=19.11 for USNO catalogue entry U1575-03105992 located at \nRA(J2000)=10 17 54.83, Dec(2000)=+71 27 39.8, consistent with the photometry \nof the isolated star 4_r of Odewahn et al. (GCN #105) (assuming r-R=0.35).\n\nThe location of the source is consistent with the BeppoSAX WFC error circle\nof GRB 980613 (GCN #99) and the BeppoSAX MECS error circle for source A\n(Piro, GCN #104; Costa et al., IAUC 6939). \n\nThe photometry is consistent with previously reported upper limits for\noptically variable objects in the field (R > 20.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado \net al., GCN #102; I>21.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado et al., GCN #103; \nr>21.0 on June 16.0, Odewahn et al., GCN #105; I>22.3 on June 14.2, Halpern\net al., GCN #106, I>20.6 on June 14.0 and I>21.5 on June 14.4, Diercks et \nal., GCN #108).\n\nGiven the consistency with the BeppoSAX error circles of GRB 980613 and\nthe rapidly fading nature of the source we suggest that the detected object\nis the optical afterglow of GRB 980613.\n\nFinding charts and updates of these preliminary results will be posted at \nhttp://www.nordita.dk/~jens/grb980613/\n\nThis report may be cited.","createdOn":898186684000,"email":"jens@nordita.dk"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"D. Belardinelli at INFN (Rome ToV) <belardinelli@roma2.infn.it>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231226av: Identification of a GW compact binary merger candidate","circularId":35428,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35428....1L","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe identified the compact binary merger candidate S231226av during real-time processing of data from LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) and LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1) at 2023-12-26 10:15:20.306 UTC (GPS time: 1387620938.306). The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], and PyCBC Live [4] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231226av is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.1e-50 Hz, or about one in 1e42 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231226av\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), BNS (<1%), or Terrestrial (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [5] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [5] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 30 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. PRD 92, 023002 (2015)","createdOn":1701966973038}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andrew S. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 980326: Late-time HST/STIS observations","circularId":1029,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1029....1F","body":"Andrew Fruchter (STScI), Paul Vreeswijk (University of Amsterdam) and\nPeter Nugent (LBNL) report on behalf of a larger HST GRB collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 980326 with HST/STIS on 31 December 2000,\njust over 1000 days after the burst. The total exposure time was 7080\nseconds in the 50CCD aperture. The images were reduced by the standard\nHST pipeline, and drizzled to a combined image with a pixelscale of\n0.\"0254.\n\nWe projected the location of the early afterglow from a KeckII/LRIS R\nband image, taken by Filippenko, Leonard and Riess on March 27, 1998\n(see GCN 33).  We estimate the 1-sigma error radius to be less than 1.5\ndrizzled HST pixels, which includes both the scatter in the\ntransformation (0.9 pixels, using 6 reference stars) and the\nmeasurement error of the transient in the Keck image (0.8 pixels).\n\nWithin one pixel of the estimated position, there was evidence of a\nsmall source.  We therefore convolved the image with a gaussian with a\nFWHM equal to that of the PSF (3.5 drizzled pixels).  This procedure\nuses the PSF as a matched filter to enhance the the signal-to-noise\nratio of unresolved sources.  In the convolved image an object is\nfound, again offset by one pixel from the expected position with a\nsignificance of ~4.5 sigma.  We estimate a magnitude (in the broad STIS\n50ccd filter) of V = 29.25 +/- 0.25.\n\nBloom et al., (1999, Nature, 401, 453) have suggested that the unusual\nlight curve of this GRB might be explained by an underlying supernova,\nand on the basis of this estimated a redshift of about z~1.   A\nsupernova at this redshift (which in this model peaks around a\nmagnitude of 25) would be expected to be significantly fainter than\nV=29 by now (as would the rapidly decaying GRB afterglow).  Therefore,\nwe may be detecting a faint host galaxy.  Deep HST images have in all\nother cases detected a host underlying the GRB, when good astrometry\nwas available for the GRB.  If we are observing a host galaxy, then the\nabove magnitude could underestimate its brightness by as much as a few\ntenths of a magnitude, due to extended emission missed in this\nmeasurement.  A galaxy at a z~1 with this observed magnitude would lie\na rather remarkable 7 magnitudes below L*, the knee of the of the\ngalaxy luminosity function at that redshift.\n\nGiven the apparent point-source nature of the detected object, and the\nlack of color information, we cannot exclude the possibility (which we\nconsider remote) that we are observing a light echo, from either the\nGRB or the supernova.\n\nImages of the field can be found at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/980326","createdOn":985809183000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andrew S. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 010222: HST observations -- host galaxy and late-time decay","circularId":1087,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1087....1F","body":"A. Fruchter, I. Burud, J. Rhoads and A. Levan (STScI) report:\n\nWe have reduced the now public archival HST images of GRB 010222, taken\non 28 February, 17 and 18 March, 5 and 6 April, and 4 and 5 May of \nthis year using the F606W (V/R) and F814W (I) filters on WFPC2.   Using\nthe most recent data, we find that OT of GRB 010222 is clearly superposed\non a host galaxy.  \n\nIn order to accurately determine the decay of the OT and the magnitude\nof the host, we have drizzled the images onto an output grid that\nallows interlacing of these 2-point dithered images.  We have then fit\nfor the decay of the OT and the host galaxy flux using a small (~0.\"2)\naperture, which provides the best estimate of the OT as a function of\ntime, as well as using a larger aperture (~0.\"5), which is more\nappropriate for determining the host galaxy magnitude.\n\nWe find that the late-time decay of the OT is significantly steeper\nthan previously reported.  We find a power-law decay between 28 February\n(day 6) and 5 May (day 71) of -1.7 +/- 0.05.  Formally, we find\na slightly steeper decay (-1.73 +/- 0.02) in F606W than in F814W \n(-1.64 +/- 0.04), but this discrepancy may indicate the level of\nsystematic error in the slope measurement rather than true color\nevolution of the OT.\n\nWe find that the host galaxy is dominated by a compact core (FWHM ~ 0.\"15)\nlocated directly under the OT.  The magnitude of the host is \nF606W(AB) = 26.0 +/- 0.1, F814W(AB) = 25.8 +/- 0.15.  \n\nImages of the host, as well as a plot of the coninuing decline of the OT,\nare available at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/010222","createdOn":997814700000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Doug Welch at McMaster University  <welch@physics.mcmaster.ca>","subject":"GRB221009A: Ionospheric disturbance observed in India","circularId":32745,"bibcode":"2022GCN.32745....1W","body":"Authors: A. Guha (Centre for Lightning and Thunderstorm Studies (CeLTS), \nDepartment of Physics, Tripura University, India.), P. Nicholson \n(Todmorden, UK)\n\nWe report the observation of a sudden disturbance of radio propagation \nin the very low frequency (VLF) band between 18kHz and 23kHz coincident with\nGRB221009A. Affected were phase and amplitude of MSK (\"Minimum Shift \nKeying\") signals from naval transmitters monitored by the Indian \nLightning Detection Network.\n\nThe GRB221009A exceeded 70 degrees elevation at all receiver sites.\n\nhttps://ildn.in/gallery/ILDN-GRB221009A-VTX3.png\nhttps://ildn.in/gallery/ILDN-GRB221009A-NWC.png\nhttps://ildn.in/gallery/ILDN-GRB221009A-NDT.png\n\nThe Indian Lightning Detection Network (ILDN) is an experimental network \nof 10 VLF receivers operated by collaborating institutions for lightning \nlocation and observation of other VLF phenomena on the Indian subcontinent.","createdOn":1665697706000,"email":"welch@physics.mcmaster.ca"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"SGR1900+14","circularId":1053,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10053....1X","body":"K. GCN 9868) reveals it is detected in the Fermi\nLarge Area Telescope (LAT) at least until 300 s after the Fermi\nGamma-Ray Burst Monitor (GBM) trigger time, T0=11:05:08.31 UT.\n\nSpectral analysis of the main emission episode, from T0 to T0+25 s, shows a\ndeviation from the Band function obtained from fitting GBM data between\n50 keV and 40 MeV (GCN 9866). This deviation is apparent both below 50\nkeV in the GBM and above 100 MeV in the LAT. It is well-fit by a single\npower-law, with a well-constrained index that is retrieved from a fit of \nthe\nGBM data alone, the LAT data alone, and when jointly fitting the entire\ndata set.\n\nThe parameters for this multi-component fit are Band_alpha =\n0.61 � 0.01, Band_beta = 3.87 � 0.16, Band_EPeak = 798 � 7 keV,\nand a power-law index of 1.94 � 0.01 that shows no evidence for a\nspectral cut-off below 100 GeV. Vreeswijk report for a larger collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000301c was reobserved by the Hubble Space Telescope\nusing the STIS camera in open (50CCD) mode on the 25 Feb 2001, or\nnearly one year after outburst.   Twelve dithered exposures were\ncombined to produce a final image with an exposure time of 7031s.\n\nNo source is immediately visible at the position of the GRB.  However,\nwhen the image is convolved with gaussians or boxcars with\ncharacteristic sizes from that of the PSF, 0.\"08, to 0.\"2, an extended\nobject appears to be visible under the position of the GRB and to its\nNE.  Although extended light from both a nearby bright star, and the\nlarger galaxy to the NW of the GRB make an exact determination of the\nsignificance of this object difficult, we believe this is approximately\na 3-4 sigma detection.  The probable host has an estimated magnitude of\nR = 28.0 +/- 0.3.  This magnitude is just consistent with the estimates\nof an underlying host from our earlier imaging, GCN 627 and 701.  It\nis, furthermore, about two magnitudes brighter than we would expect the\nOT to have been at this time, had it continued to decline with a\ntemporal power-law steeper than -2 (c.f. GCN 701 and  Rhoads and\nFruchter, ApJ 2001, 546, 177).\n\nIf this is indeed a detection of a host, then in all cases where we\nhave obtained a deep HST image and an OT is well localized (to ~0.\"1),\na host has been found under the GRB. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome), J.J.M. in 't Zand (Astronomical Institute,\nUtrecht University and SRON), P. Soffitta (IAS/CNR, Rome), K. Hurley\n(UCB, California), F. Frontera (Univ. Ferrara and TESRE/CNR, Bologna)\nand E. Mazets (IOFFE, S. Petersburg), report:\n\n\"A high-time resolution analysis has been performed of the BeppoSAX\nWide Field Camera data of SGR 1900+14 taken on April 18, 2001, when\nthe most recent giant flare was detected (Guidorzi et al., GCN 1041\nand IAUC 7611). The data cover a short intermediate pointing of Wide\nField Camera unit 1 between two scheduled targets. The observation\nstarted 2780 s before the giant flare and ended with the automatic\nswitch off due to that flare. The observation was interrupted when\nBeppoSAX traversed the SAA, from 2282 till 1052 s before the\ngiant flare. The analysis revealed the presence of 3 short X-ray\nprecursors, occurring 2537, 755, and 444 s before the giant flare\n(respectively, 25975, 27757 and 28068 s UT), with durations of 100,\n125 and 55 ms, peak fluxes in excess of 20 Crab units (2-28 keV),\nand 9-28/2-9 keV spectral hardness ratios that are consistent with\npower laws with photon indices between roughly 0.5 and 1.2. None of the\nprecursors was detected in the gamma-ray data from the BeppoSAX/GRBM,\nthe gamma-ray burst detector on Ulysses, and from Konus on Wind.\"","createdOn":988997172000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010612","circularId":1065,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10065....1C","body":"K. Hurley on behalf\nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nThe HETE Fregate instrument has detected a bright (>40 sigma) GRB \nthat has been reported in a GCN Notice as H1761. The burst occurred \nat 18950.56 SOD {05:15:50.56} UT on 21 September.  The burst is seen \nin the WXM X detector and is therefore well-localized in the X \ndirection; the burst was apparently outside the coded FOV of the WXM \nY detector, which therefore gives limited information about the Y \ndirection of the burst.\n\nThe X-detector data gives a good (+/-10 arcmin) localization in the X\ndirection and crude limits on Y, resulting in a localization that is a\nthin, long strip.\n\nTwo points along one side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h52m36s.7, Dec. =  39o35'13\"\nR.A. = 23h10m22s.8, Dec. =  48o57'43\"\n\nTwo points along the other side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h54m04s.0, Dec. =  39o34'23\"\nR.A. = 23h11m52s.5, Dec. =  48o57'00\"\n\nOur estimate is that the strip is  ~10  degrees in the long direction.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~12 s. A total of 5310 \ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence \nof ~1 x 10-6 ergs cm-2. The peak flux was >3 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >8 x Crab flux).\n\nFurther refinement of the X localization is in progress; a further\nattempt is also being made to improve the coarse Y localization.","createdOn":1001067928000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Aaron Zimmerman at U. of Texas at Austin <aaron.zimmerman@utexas.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231226av: Updated Sky localization","circularId":35429,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35429....1L","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) and LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S231226av (GCN Circular 35428). Frail at NRAO  <dfrail@nrao.edu>","subject":"SGR 1900+14, Chandra observations","circularId":1047,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10047....1M","body":"D. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report on behalf of a larger\ncollaboration\"\n\n\"In response to the 18 April 2001 flare of SGR 1900+14 (GCN 1041) the\nChandra X-ray Observatory has undertaken a sequence of two public\n20-ksec observations of this source, on 22 and 30 April 2001.\n\nThe first observation began at 04:58 UT on 22 April and was taken in\ncontinuous-clocking mode (see also GCN 1046).  Examination of the\nlight curve reveals that at least one burst was observed, 9081 s after\nthe start of the observation.  Assuming the best-fit spectral\nparameters for the observation (see below), the peak 1-s flux of this\nburst was of order 5e-10 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (0.5-10 keV).\n\nSpectral fits to the full background-subtracted data set allow for at\nleast two emission models.  A power-law plus absorption model has\nbest-fit parameters of N_H = 3.18(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha =\n2.70(1), and unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of 4.20(4)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1.\nA power-law plus blackbody and absorption model has best-fit\nparameters of N_H = 2.56(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha = 1.88(1),\nblackbody temperature kT = 0.532(3) keV, unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of\n2.17(3)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1, and flux fraction for the blackbody\ncomponent of 29% (0.5-10 keV).  The addition of the blackbody\ncomponent is not supported by an F-test (65% confidence level) but is\nconsistent with models in the literature (Perna et al. 2001,\nastro-ph/0103273).  Analysis of the RXTE PCA data may help to clarify\nthe presence or absence of the blackbody component, as the PCA count\nrates inferred from the two models given above differ by 50%.\n\nNo narrow spectral features are apparent.  The two-sigma upper limit\nto the flux of a persistent 0.2-keV FWHM emission line in the 5-7 keV\nrange is 1e-5 photons cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThis message may be cited.\"","createdOn":988083484000,"email":"dfrail@nrao.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1055,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1055....1F","body":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14\n\nM. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Roma) and S. Mereghetti (IFC/CNR, Milano),\non behalf of a larger SGR collaboration, and G. Gandolfi, L. Piro\nand E. Costa (IAS/CNR, Roma), on behalf of the BeppoSAX Team,\nreport:\n\n\"A ToO observation of SGR1900+14 was carried out with the\nBeppoSAX Narrow Field Instruments starting on April 18, 15:10 UT,\nless than 8 hours after the large flare reported in GCN #1041.\nIntense bursting activity is present during the 28 hr long\nobservation.  After removing the numerous short bursts, a significant\nflux decay is visible in the MECS and LECS light curves.\nBy using our data and the Chandra 2-10 keV flux (GCN #1046)\nwe find that the decay can be reasonably well described by a power\nlaw with index ~-0.6.  There is also evidence for a spectral softening\ncorrelated with the intensity decrease.\n\nThe average spectrum (after removal of the bursts) can be fit by a\npower law with photon index 2.6+/-0.1 and NH=(4.3 +/-0.3)x10^22 cm^-2.\nThe average 2-10 keV flux during the whole BeppoSAX observation is\n2.9x10^-11 erg/cm^2/s (unabsorbed). The bursts have a significantly\nharder spectrum (power law photon index ~0 in the 2-10 keV range).\n\nPulsations,  with a nearly sinusoidal light curve and a modulation of\nabout 21%, are clearly detected at the barycentered period  P=5.17277(1) s.\nWhen compared with the value measured with Chandra about 3 days later\n(GCN #1049), this yields a dP/dt ~ (4.1 +/- 1.9)x10^-10 s/s.\n\nAn additional BeppoSAX/NFI observation will start on April 29, 20:30 UT.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988388763000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"D. Stars brighter than\nV=13.5 are saturated and should be used with care.\nWe have placed the photometric data on our anonymous ftp site:\nftp://ftp.nofs.navy.mil/pub/outgoing/aah/grb/grb010412.dat\nThe current photometry has a potential external zero-point\nerror of about two percent. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi,\nF. Frontera, and M. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi,\nF. Frontera, and M. Feroci, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM team, report:\n\nWe have identified a likely precursor to the giant flare from\nSGR1900+14 (GCN 1041, 1043) in the Ulysses data.  This event\noccurred on April 17, 2001, ~42184 s at Ulysses, and if it was\nindeed from SGR1900+14, its Earth-crossing time would have\nbeen ~42332 s.  This burst was ~50 s long, and its time history\nresembles that of the April 18 event, although it is considerably\nless intense.  Its 25-100 keV fluence was ~2.3x10^-5 erg/cm^2,\nand its peak flux over 0.5 s was ~1.5x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s.  Due to\na high solar proton background, these numbers are subject to more\nthan the usual uncertainties.  As SGR1900+14 was Earth-blocked\nat BeppoSAX, it did not observe this event, and there is no\nlocalization data available.\n\nThe time history has been posted at ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010417.\nAlso, we note that the time history of the April 18 event, posted\nat ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010418, was incorrectly labelled \"Counts/\n0.5 s\".  The label should have read \"Counts/Second\".  A corrected\nplot has been posted.\n\nSearches are underway through the Ulysses data for more possible\nevents from this source.","createdOn":987796101000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"SGR1900+14: A Burst Localized by HETE","circularId":1073,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1073....1R","body":"SGR1900+14: A Burst Localized by HETE\n\nG. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 23:24:18.3 UT (84253.3s UT) on 27 June, the HETE FREGATE and WXM \ninstruments detected and localized an intense burst from SGR1900+14, \na soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the second burst localized \nfrom this source in the past week, indicating that it may have \nresumed an active state. (The first burst was reported in GCN \nCircular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 27 June burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.947 (19h07m47s.2)\n\nDec. = +9.362 (+9:21:41)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.6 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <200 ms. A total of 1084 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~2 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >3 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >100 x Crab flux).\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993698624000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010629","circularId":1076,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10076....1K","body":"K. Kouveliotou, A. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on behalf\nof a larger SGR collaboration:\n\nWe have examined our overlapping Chandra/RXTE observations of SGR 1900+14\n(RXTE TOO, P. Woods, PI). We cannot verify the burst reported in GCN #1047. \nThe source was occulted by the earth at the time in question.\n\nWe confirm the burst in the Chandra data at approximately 7:15:25 UT. The burst \nduration appeared to be 0.35 seconds during which 14 counts were recorded \n(ignoring pile-up). Thus the peak count rate was 65 times the quiescent rate.\nAdopting the quiescent source spectrum (GCN # 1046), we estimate the peak flux \nin the 2-10 keV band to be 7.2 x 10^-10 ergs/cm^2 s (2.9 x 10^-9 ergs/cm^2 s in \n0.5-10.0 keV).\n\nWe would like to add a clarification regarding the persistent source flux  \nvalues in the two GCNs (1046, 1047). Rol, I. Salamanca, L. Kaper, P. Vreeswijk (University of\nAmsterdam), N. Tanvir (University of Hertfordshire), report on behalf\nof a larger collaboration:\n\n\nIn order to verify the possible counterpart to GRB010214 (Rol et al.,\nGCN 955), we obtained another set of images with the Isaac Newton\nTelescope on February 21, 2001. Examination and comparison of these\nimages with those obtained at the INT on February 17 shows no evidence\nfor a further fading of the possible counterpart, as already suggested\nin other reports (Gorosabel et al., GCN 972; Klose et al., GCN 997;\nFynbo, private comm.). Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome), J.J.M. in 't Zand (Astronomical Institute,\nUtrecht University and SRON), P. Soffitta (IAS/CNR, Rome), K. Hurley\n(UCB, California), F. Frontera (Univ. Ferrara and TESRE/CNR, Bologna)\nand E. Mazets (IOFFE, S. Petersburg), report:\n\n\"A high-time resolution analysis has been performed of the BeppoSAX\nWide Field Camera data of SGR 1900+14 taken on April 18, 2001, when\nthe most recent giant flare was detected (Guidorzi et al., GCN 1041\nand IAUC 7611). The data cover a short intermediate pointing of Wide\nField Camera unit 1 between two scheduled targets. The observation\nstarted 2780 s before the giant flare and ended with the automatic\nswitch off due to that flare. The observation was interrupted when\nBeppoSAX traversed the SAA, from 2282 till 1052 s before the\ngiant flare. The analysis revealed the presence of 3 short X-ray\nprecursors, occurring 2537, 755, and 444 s before the giant flare\n(respectively, 25975, 27757 and 28068 s UT), with durations of 100,\n125 and 55 ms, peak fluxes in excess of 20 Crab units (2-28 keV),\nand 9-28/2-9 keV spectral hardness ratios that are consistent with\npower laws with photon indices between roughly 0.5 and 1.2. None of the\nprecursors was detected in the gamma-ray data from the BeppoSAX/GRBM,\nthe gamma-ray burst detector on Ulysses, and from Konus on Wind.\"","createdOn":988997172000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Peter Woods at UAH/MSFC  <peter.woods@msfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"SGR 1900+14 : RXTE observations","circularId":1056,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1056....1W","body":"P. Woods (USRA/NSSTC), C. Kouveliotou (NASA/MSFC), and E. Gogus\n(UAH/NSSTC) report on behalf of a larger collaboration.\n\nToO observations of SGR 1900+14 with the Rossi XTE were initiated on\nApril 19, 2001 and have continued through April 28.  Thus far, more\nthan 60 bursts have been detected in ~110 ks of exposure time. \nCoincidentally, a short (~10 ks) observation of SGR 1900+14 was\nperformed on April 14 (4 days prior to the flare) as part of our\nongoing monitoring campaign.  We find no burst activity within this\nobservation.  For the latest observation on April 28, 4 bursts were\nrecorded in one RXTE orbit, thus the source remains burst active.\n\nSelecting a 6 day subset of these observations for which we have\nspacecraft ephemeris information, we have phase connected the data and\nmeasured both a period and period derivative.  We chose our epoch (MJD\n52021.3 TDB) to coincide with the first Chandra observation.  We\nmeasure a barycentric period of 5.1728219(14) s where the number given\nin the parentheses marks the 1 sigma error in the least significant\ndigits.  The period derivative is found to be +1.58(22) X 10E-10 s/s. \nThe ephemeris we find agrees well with the measured periods reported\nfor both the Chandra (GCN #1049) and BeppoSAX (GCN #1055)\nobservations.  Furthermore, the magnitude of the spindown found here\nis well within the range of historical spindown rates measured for\nthis SGR.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988650865000,"email":"peter.woods@msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Valerie Connaughton at NASA/MSFC/USRA  <valerie@nasa.gov>","subject":"LIGO/Virgo G194575:  Fermi GBM Observations","circularId":18448,"bibcode":"2015GCN.18448A...1G","body":"LIGO/Virgo G194575:  Fermi GBM Observations\n\nLindy Blackburn (CfA), Michael S. Postnov (SAI-MSU Moscow)\nreport:\n\n\"On July 24, 2001 UT, we observed the field of GRB 001109 (Gandolfi, GCNs #878,\n#879). The photometric conditions were good with a seeing of about 1.3 arcsec. \nWe have obtained three 180-s R-band images with the SCORPIO instrument\n(http://www.sao.ru/~moisav/scorpio/scorpio.html) at the 6-m telescope of SAO\nRAS. At the position of the VLA radiosource (Taylor et al. GCN #880) which\nis presumably a radio afteglow (Rol et al. GCN #889) we detected an extended\nobject as already reported by Vreeswijk et al. (GCN #886) and Greiner et al. \n(GCN#887), most likely double. Spectroscopic observations (12 x 600-s \nexposures) were obtained with the 300 lines/mm grating giving a spectral \nresolution (FWHM) of about 20 A and an effective wavelength coverage of \n3500 - 9500 A. The slit was placed along the extended object. The analysis \nrevealed that the object is double with a spectra showing the continua\nwith clearly detected Balmer break. The redshift for each component is:\n\nObject A:  z = 0.398 +/- 0.002, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           O[III] 4959,5007AA emission lines (brighter component)\n\n\nObject B:  z = 0.3399 +/- 0.0005, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           Hbeta 4861AA, emission lines (fainter component)\n\nIf the radio transient is related to GRB 001109 indeed, then this is the\nnearest host galaxy detected so far.\n\nThe R-band image can be seen at:\nhttp://www.sao.ru/~sokolov/GRB/HOSTS/GRB001109/GRB001109.html\n\nThis message may be cited\".\n\n-Vladimir Sokolov, on behalf of the RAS Special Astrophysical Observatory\nGRB followup team.","createdOn":999934127000,"email":"sokolov@sao.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Dale A. Frail at NRAO  <dfrail@nrao.edu>","subject":"SGR 1900+14, Chandra observations","circularId":1047,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1047....1F","body":"D. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report on behalf of a larger\ncollaboration\"\n\n\"In response to the 18 April 2001 flare of SGR 1900+14 (GCN 1041) the\nChandra X-ray Observatory has undertaken a sequence of two public\n20-ksec observations of this source, on 22 and 30 April 2001.\n\nThe first observation began at 04:58 UT on 22 April and was taken in\ncontinuous-clocking mode (see also GCN 1046).  Examination of the\nlight curve reveals that at least one burst was observed, 9081 s after\nthe start of the observation.  Assuming the best-fit spectral\nparameters for the observation (see below), the peak 1-s flux of this\nburst was of order 5e-10 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (0.5-10 keV).\n\nSpectral fits to the full background-subtracted data set allow for at\nleast two emission models.  A power-law plus absorption model has\nbest-fit parameters of N_H = 3.18(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha =\n2.70(1), and unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of 4.20(4)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1.\nA power-law plus blackbody and absorption model has best-fit\nparameters of N_H = 2.56(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha = 1.88(1),\nblackbody temperature kT = 0.532(3) keV, unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of\n2.17(3)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1, and flux fraction for the blackbody\ncomponent of 29% (0.5-10 keV).  The addition of the blackbody\ncomponent is not supported by an F-test (65% confidence level) but is\nconsistent with models in the literature (Perna et al. 2001,\nastro-ph/0103273).  Analysis of the RXTE PCA data may help to clarify\nthe presence or absence of the blackbody component, as the PCA count\nrates inferred from the two models given above differ by 50%.\n\nNo narrow spectral features are apparent.  The two-sigma upper limit\nto the flux of a persistent 0.2-keV FWHM emission line in the 5-7 keV\nrange is 1e-5 photons cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThis message may be cited.\"","createdOn":988083484000,"email":"dfrail@nrao.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Jens Hjorth at NORDITA  <jens@nordita.dk>","subject":"GRB 980613 Optical Observations","circularId":109,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10009....1C","body":"GRB 980613 Optical Observations\n\nJ. This event is the second burst localized \nfrom this source in the past week, indicating that it may have \nresumed an active state. (The first burst was reported in GCN \nCircular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 27 June burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.947 (19h07m47s.2)\n\nDec. = +9.362 (+9:21:41)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.6 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <200 ms. A total of 1084 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~2 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >3 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >100 x Crab flux).\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993698624000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Surojit Saha at Institute of Astronomy, National Tsing Hua University <surojitsaha@gapp.nthu.edu.tw>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231206cc: Identification of a GW compact binary merger candidate","circularId":35298,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35298....1S","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe identified the compact binary merger candidate S231206cc during real-time processing of data from LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) and LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1) at 2023-12-06 23:39:01.498 UTC (GPS time: 1385941159.498). The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], PyCBC Live [4], and SPIIR [5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231206cc is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.9e-35 Hz, or about one in 1e27 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231206cc\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), BNS (<1%), or Terrestrial (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [6] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [6] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 30 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,2, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,2. This event is the highest \nfluence burst yet detected by HETE from SGR1900+14 during its current \nepisode of activity. (The first burst in the current series was \nreported in GCN Circular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 2 \nJuly burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.846 (19h07m23s.1)\n\nDec. =  +9.344 (+9o20'40\")\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~4 s. A total of 44000 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >7 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >200 x Crab flux) over a duration of \n10 ms.\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":994051790000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paul Price at RSAA, ANU at CIT  <pap@srl.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB 010326A: Further optical observations","circularId":1022,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1022....1P","body":"P.A. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on\nbehalf of a large SGR collaboration:\n\nChandra observed the newly active (GCN #1041) Soft Gamma Repeater,\nSGR 1900+14, on April 22, 2001 starting at 4:45 UT, for 20,000 seconds.\nThe ACIS S3 observation mode was Continuous Clocking (CC). We have fitted a\nspectrum to the whole data set; we find the best fit to be a single power law\nwith spectral (photon) index of 2.9 +/- 0.1 and a hydrogen column density (NH)\nof (3.4 +/- 0.1)x10^22 cm^-2. We detect no black body contribution in \nthe spectrum.  The source (unabsorbed) flux is 1.1x10^-11 ergs/cm^2 s\n(2-10 keV), nearly identical to the quiescent source flux level.\nThe pulse period is 5.1725 s (barycenter corrected); the pulse
