The candidate was found by the GstLAL [1] analysis pipeline.\n\nS231231ag is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 8.4e-15 Hz, or about one in 1e7 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231231ag\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), NSBH (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [2] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [2] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 27 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. Afanasiev, T. Fatkhullin, S. Dodonov, V. Sokolov, (SAO RAS),\nA. Castro-Tirado (IAA-CSIC Granada; LAEFF-INTA, Madrid), V. Komarova,\nA. Moiseev (SAO RAS), A. Cherepashchuk, K. Postnov (SAI-MSU Moscow)\nreport:\n\n\"On July 24, 2001 UT, we observed the field of GRB 001109 (Gandolfi, GCNs #878,\n#879). The photometric conditions were good with a seeing of about 1.3 arcsec. \nWe have obtained three 180-s R-band images with the SCORPIO instrument\n(http://www.sao.ru/~moisav/scorpio/scorpio.html) at the 6-m telescope of SAO\nRAS. At the position of the VLA radiosource (Taylor et al. GCN #880) which\nis presumably a radio afteglow (Rol et al. GCN #889) we detected an extended\nobject as already reported by Vreeswijk et al. (GCN #886) and Greiner et al. \n(GCN#887), most likely double. Spectroscopic observations (12 x 600-s \nexposures) were obtained with the 300 lines/mm grating giving a spectral \nresolution (FWHM) of about 20 A and an effective wavelength coverage of \n3500 - 9500 A. The slit was placed along the extended object. The analysis \nrevealed that the object is double with a spectra showing the continua\nwith clearly detected Balmer break. The redshift for each component is:\n\nObject A:  z = 0.398 +/- 0.002, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           O[III] 4959,5007AA emission lines (brighter component)\n\n\nObject B:  z = 0.3399 +/- 0.0005, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           Hbeta 4861AA, emission lines (fainter component)\n\nIf the radio transient is related to GRB 001109 indeed, then this is the\nnearest host galaxy detected so far.\n\nThe R-band image can be seen at:\nhttp://www.sao.ru/~sokolov/GRB/HOSTS/GRB001109/GRB001109.html\n\nThis message may be cited\".\n\n-Vladimir Sokolov, on behalf of the RAS Special Astrophysical Observatory\nGRB followup team.","createdOn":999934127000,"email":"sokolov@sao.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Giangiacomo Gandolfi at IAS/CNR Frascati  <gandolfi@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"GRB010518: a faint BeppoSAX detection","circularId":1062,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10062....1M","body":"C. Ricker (MIT), on behalf of the HETE Team, reports:\n\nOver the past few weeks, the number of X-ray bursts (XRBs) reported \nby HETE has been gradually increasing, reaching ~10 per day during \nthe past 2-3 days. This seeming storm of XRBs is being produced by an \nensemble of ~10 distinct XRB sources, which are optimally placed in \nthe HETE field-of-view (FOV) for detectability.\n\nThis dramatic overall increase is due to two factors: 1) Improvements \nin the on-board detection algorithm, resulting from lowered trigger \nthresholds and increased numbers of trigger time scales being \nactivated; 2) Sco X-1 has moved out of the HETE instruments' FOV, \ngreatly reducing the overall background, thus improving the \ninstruments' burst detection efficiency.\n\n(NB: Despite the flurry of XRBs, soft gamma repeaters [SGR] and \ngamma-ray bursts [GRB] positions are now being, and will continue to \nbe, reported for events which trigger the high energy bands of the \nFREGATE instrument directly.)\n\nMany of the faint XRB detections are near threshold, and thus their \nonboard localization is unreliable. In order not to saturate rapid \nresponse telescopes and observing programs which primarily target \nSGRs and GRBs, these XRB events are being reported to the GCN with no \npositions. (In fact, reliable positions are subsequently established \nby the WXM ground software for a large fraction of these XRB events.) \nA  refined reporting algorithm, which will more clearly distinguish \nfainter, poorly-localized XRBs from brighter, well-localized XRBs \nwill be implemented in the near future. In the meantime, the XRB \n\"alert only\" reports will continue.  Beginning in late August, when \nthe Galactic Bulge Region moves out of HETE's FOV, we anticipate a \nprecipitous drop in the reported XRB rate.","createdOn":996527165000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paul Price at RSAA, ANU at CIT  <pap@srl.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB010412: Optical observations","circularId":1038,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1038....1P","body":"P.A. Price, T.S. Axelrod and B.P. Our 3x300 sec exposures\ncover the entire error box to a limiting magnitude of R ~ 20.0 mag,\nbased on common stars with the USNO-A2.0 catalogue. This event is the third burst reported \nfrom this source in the past week, and the second one reported by \nHETE on 28 June. (The previous HETE burst was reported in GCN \nCircular #1073.) The coordinates (J2000) of the burst localized by \nHETE are:\n\nR.A. = 286.803 deg. (19h07m12s.62)\n\nDec. =  +9.340 deg. (+9:20:22)\n\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 24 arcmin in radius.\nSGR1900+14 lies 6.2 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~400 ms. A total of 4700\ncounts above background were detected during that interval,\ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux\nwas ~4 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >150 x Crab flux) during a 5 ms interval.\n\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993745828000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"D. H. Ishwara Chandra (NCRA, Pune),\nD. Bhattacharya (RRI, Bangalore) and A.J. Castro-Tirado (IAA, Granada)\nreport on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nThe afterglow of GRB030329 (Peterson & Price, GCN 1985) was observed\nwith the GMRT for about 5 hours on May 31, 2003. The observations were at\n1288  MHz with a bandwidth of 12MHz and effective angular resolution of\n~3.5\". The flux density of the source seen at the position of the GRB on\n31 March and 01 April 2003 (Rao et al, GCN 2073) has increased to 1.1 mJy\nconfirming that the radio source is related to the GRB.\n\nThe details of the GMRT measurements of GRB030329 at 1288 MHz:\n\nDate                        Time               Flux Density\n\n31 May 2003                14-18 UT         1100+/-150 microJy\n31 March/01 April 2003     14-22 UT          330+/-100 microJy\n\nThe quoted error bars are 2-sigma, and include systematic errors of\ncalibration.\n\nNote that the flux density at 31 March/01 April epoch has been\nrevised upwards in comparison to that reported in GCN 2073,\nfollowing a better absolute flux density calibration.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":1054720826000,"email":"dipankar@rri.res.in"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Sylvio Klose at TLS Tautenburg  <klose@tls-tautenburg.de>","subject":"SGR1900+14, I-band observations","circularId":1044,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1044....1K","body":"S. Bissaldi (MPE), H. Tajima (SLAC),\nS. Guiriec (UAH),  N. Omodei (INFN Pisa), V. Vasileiou (NASA GSFC/UMBC)\nand V. Connaughton (UAH) report for the Fermi LAT and GBM teams:\n\nFurther analysis of GRB 090902B (Bissaldi et al. GCN 9866, de Palma et al.\n GCN 9867, Kennea et al. GCN 9868) reveals it is detected in the Fermi\nLarge Area Telescope (LAT) at least until 300 s after the Fermi\nGamma-Ray Burst Monitor (GBM) trigger time, T0=11:05:08.31 UT.\n\nSpectral analysis of the main emission episode, from T0 to T0+25 s, shows a\ndeviation from the Band function obtained from fitting GBM data between\n50 keV and 40 MeV (GCN 9866). This deviation is apparent both below 50\nkeV in the GBM and above 100 MeV in the LAT. It is well-fit by a single\npower-law, with a well-constrained index that is retrieved from a fit of \nthe\nGBM data alone, the LAT data alone, and when jointly fitting the entire\ndata set.\n\nThe parameters for this multi-component fit are Band_alpha =\n0.61 � 0.01, Band_beta = 3.87 � 0.16, Band_EPeak = 798 � 7 keV,\nand a power-law index of 1.94 � 0.01 that shows no evidence for a\nspectral cut-off below 100 GeV. The fluence between 8 keV and 30\nGeV is 4.86 � 0.06 x 10-4 ergs/cm2.\n\nThe points of contact for this burst are:\n\nFrancesco de Palma (francesco.depalma@ba.infn.it) and\nElisabetta Bissaldi (ebs@mpe.mpg.de).\n\nThe Fermi LAT is a pair conversion telescope designed to cover the\nenergy band from 20 MeV to greater than 300 GeV.\nIt is the product of an international collaboration between NASA and DOE\nin the U.S. and many scientific institutions across France, Italy, Japan\nand Sweden.\n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":1251963402000,"email":"valerie@nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paolo Saracco at Obs.Astro. di Brera  <saracco@merate.mi.astro.it>","subject":"GRB990705, VLT-FORS1 observations of the host galaxy","circularId":1010,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10010....1C","body":"VLT-FORS1 observations of the host galaxy of GRB 990705\n\nP. Saracco, G. Chincarini, S. Covino, G. Ghisellini, M. Longhetti, F.\nZerbi\n(Osservatorio Astronomico di Brera, Merate, Italy)\nD. Lazzati (Institute of Astronomy,Cambridge, UK)\nP. Severgnini (Osservatorio Astronomico di Arcetri, Firenze, Italy)\n\nWe have obtained twelve 540-second dithered images in the Rc (Bessell)\nband centered on the position of  GRB 990705. These images have been\nobtained  from  20th to 28th December 2000 at the ESO-VLT UT1 telescope\nwith FORS1 as a part of a survey of host galaxies (Saracco et al. 2000;\nProg. ID: 66.B-0539(A)).\n\nObservations have been carried out under seeing conditions of 0.6-0.7\narcsec.\nThe limiting magnitude reached on the final coadded image is Rc=26.6\n(3 sigmas within the seeing disk).\nWe confirm the presence of a late-type (Sc) galaxy located at the\nposition of\nGRB 990705 as previously found by Holland et al. (2000; GCN #753).\n\nWe measure a magnitude Rc=22.2(+-0.1) (galactic extinction A(R)=0.2)\nwithin an aperture radius of 2 arcsec.\nConsidering the V-band aperture magnitude obtained by Holland et al.\n(GCN #753) we estimate for the host galaxy a color V-Rc=0.6(+-0.2).\nGiven the large uncertainty in this estimate, such a color is\nconsistent with that of an Sc galaxy  at redshift z<1.3.\n\nThis message can be cited.\n\n\n--\nPaolo Saracco\nOsservatorio Astronomico di Brera\nVia E. Metzger report for a larger HST GRB Collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000418 was re-observed by the Hubble Space Telescope\nstarting on UT 2001 Feb 11.64 using the STIS camera in open (50CCD)\nmode.  The individual exposures were combined using Drizzle for a total\nexposure time of 5120 s.\n\nWhen this image is subtracted from that obtained by HST on 2000 June\n4.17 a small residual of magnitude R~28 is found at the position of the\ncompact galaxy believed to be the host galaxy (GCN 669); however, the\nresidual is sufficiently faint to be consistent with no detection at\nabout the 2 sigma level.  Taking into account the varying brightness of\nthe host galaxy we find an upper limit to the brightness of the OT on\n2000 June 4.2 of R > 27.5.\n\nThis upper limit on the R-band flux implies that the decay of the\noptical transient steepened to at least t ^ -1.75 to -2 at late times,\nin agreement with the result obtainted primarily from radio data by\nBerger et al (20001, astro-ph/0102278).\n\nThe images of the STIS field, with transient location indicated, can be\nseen at http://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/000418.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":989703442000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paul Price at RSAA, ANU at CIT  <pap@srl.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB010412: Optical observations","circularId":1039,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10039....1F","body":"P.A. Klose, B. Stecklum, and U. Laux (Thueringer Landessternwarte\n   Tautenburg) on behalf of a larger collaboration\n\nreport:\n\nWe observed the field towards SGR 1900+14 in the I-band using the \nTautenburg Schmidt telescope equipped with the Schmidt focus CCD camera\n(14 frames, 2 min exposure time each). Observations were performed on\nApril 19, 1:12 UT - 2:19 UT, i.e., about 18 hours after the giant \ngamma-ray flare discovered by BeppoSAX and Ulysses (Guidorzi et al., GCN\n#1041; Hurley et al., GCN #1043). The other frames are affected by a cloudy\nsky.\n\nAt the position of the fading radio source discovered after the strong \noutburst in 1998 (Frail et al. 1999, Nature 398, 127; see also Fig. 1 in\nVrba et al. 2000, ApJ 533, L17) we detect no object down to a limiting\nmagnitude of about I=21.\n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":987683715000,"email":"klose@tls-tautenburg.de"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"SGR1806-20: A Second, Intense Burst Localized by HETE","circularId":1070,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1070....1R","body":"SGR1806-20: A Second, Intense Burst Localized by HETE\n\nG. (-20:21:56)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 6 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1806-20 lies 3.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~200 ms, comprised of two \npeaks each <100ms in duration. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S190602aq\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending\nprobability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), NSBH (<1%),\nor MassGap (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, there is strong\nevidence against the lighter compact object having a mass < 3 solar\nmasses (HasNS: <1%). Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi,\nF. Frontera, and M. Feroci, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM team, report:\n\nWe have identified a likely precursor to the giant flare from\nSGR1900+14 (GCN 1041, 1043) in the Ulysses data.  This event\noccurred on April 17, 2001, ~42184 s at Ulysses, and if it was\nindeed from SGR1900+14, its Earth-crossing time would have\nbeen ~42332 s.  This burst was ~50 s long, and its time history\nresembles that of the April 18 event, although it is considerably\nless intense.  Its 25-100 keV fluence was ~2.3x10^-5 erg/cm^2,\nand its peak flux over 0.5 s was ~1.5x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s.  Due to\na high solar proton background, these numbers are subject to more\nthan the usual uncertainties.  As SGR1900+14 was Earth-blocked\nat BeppoSAX, it did not observe this event, and there is no\nlocalization data available.\n\nThe time history has been posted at ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010417.\nAlso, we note that the time history of the April 18 event, posted\nat ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010418, was incorrectly labelled \"Counts/\n0.5 s\".  The label should have read \"Counts/Second\".  A corrected\nplot has been posted.\n\nSearches are underway through the Ulysses data for more possible\nevents from this source.","createdOn":987796101000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Filippo Frontera at U. of Ferrara, Physics Dept  <frontera@fe.infn.it>","subject":"SGR1900+14 burst seen by HETE: BeppoSAX data","circularId":1081,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1081....1M","body":"E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi and F. Frontera, Physics Dept., University of\nFerrara, Italy; F. Calura, Astronomy Dept., University of Trieste; M.\nFeroci, IAS, CNR, Rome, Italy, report:\n\nThe short burst from SGR1900+14 detected by HETE (GCN # 1078) was also\ndetected by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor aboard BeppoSAX. The burst\ntriggered the GRBM on board logic at 03:34:07.15 UT of July 2, 2001. The\nevent duration was about 2 s.\n\nThe event showed significant flux only in the 40-100 keV energy band. The\ntotal counts above the background level in this range were 400 +/- 50. \nAssuming a power law spectral shape, from our data we can set a lower\nlimit to the photon index of 3.5. With a photon index of 4.0, the derived\nfluence is (1.2+/- 0.2) x 10-6 erg cm-2 in the band from 40 to 100 keV. \nUsing the high time resolution data only available in the 40-700 keV band,\nthe peak flux obtained from 125 ms bins corresponds to (1.4 +/- 0.4)x10-6\nerg cm-2 s-1. \n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":994267010000,"email":"frontera@fe.infn.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"Probable SGR or Short Duration GRB Detected by HETE","circularId":1089,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1089....1R","body":"Probable SGR or Short Duration GRB Detected by HETE\n\nG. Hurley on behalf\nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 05:06:30.61 UTC (18390.61 s UT) on 22 August, the HETE FREGATE \ninstrument detected a short, intense burst from a probable soft \ngamma-ray repeater or (less likely) a short duration GRB. This event \nwas promptly distributed as a GCN Notice (HETE BID_1715). No signal \nwas detected in the WXM, indicating that the event was likely to \nbe >40 degrees from the anti-sun direction. For the current HETE \npointing direction, SGR1900+14 is about 48 degrees off the boresight, \nwhile SGR1806-20 is about 56 degrees off the boresight, so that \neither could be a candidate.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~200 ms. A total of 500\ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence\nof ~9 x 10-8 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux was >2 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >50 x Crab flux) over a duration of 30 ms.\n\nA search for this event in the archives of other GRB instruments is \nencouraged. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Analysis of data from the 22 April 2001 Chandra observation (GCN\n1046, 1047), barycenter-corrected with the preliminary CXC ephemeris,\nreveals that the source emission is pulsed at a period of P =\n5.17288(5) s with a pulse strength of 14.3(2)% RMS that remains\nconstant (within errors) throughout the observation.  Separation of\nthe source photons into \"on-pulse\" and \"off-pulse\" components of 1/3\ncycle each reveals that the off-pulse spatial distribution is\nsignificantly broader than the on-pulse distribution.  Since the\nobservation is taken in continuous-clocking mode, we can only make\nthis determination in one dimension.  Nonetheless, the sigma-widths of\nthe one-dimensional Gaussian PSFs are 0.98(1) arcsec for on-pulse\nphotons and 1.08(2) arcsec for off-pulse photons, different at\n>5-sigma level.  We attribute this difference in widths to the\npresence of an underlying X-ray nebula.\"","createdOn":988243520000,"email":"derekfox@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"GRB010326B: Localization by HETE (2nd GRB for this date)","circularId":1018,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1018....1R","body":"G. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, G. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 08:33:12 UTC (=30792s UT), a soft spectrum, high \nenergy transient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized \nby HETE.\n(NB: This is the second GRB detected by HETE on 26 March 2001.)\n\nBoth the WXM and the FREGATE instruments detected the event. The \nburst triggered FREGATE in the 6-120 keV band, at the 160ms timescale.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h24m23.36s, \nDec. = -11o09'57\", derived from combining data from the WXM and \nBoresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the WXM \nlocalization is 18 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we estimate \na systematic error radius at present of 10 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 30 \narcsec (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~4 Crab; with WXM \n(2-25 keV), ~2 Crab. The burst duration was about 4 seconds.\n\nThe high galactic latitude of the source, well away from the Galactic \nBulge, and the shape of its spectrum suggest that it is a gamma-ray \nburst similar to those reported for \"X-ray rich\" GRBs by Heise et al \n(2001) from BeppoSAX observations.\n\nFollow-up observations of this unusual transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on the GRB010326B (including light curves), as \nwell as for the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985612698000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Josh Bloom at CIT  <jsb@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"HETE Trigger #1759 (GRB 010920?) optical observations","circularId":1093,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1093....1B","body":"HETE Trigger #1759 (GRB 010920?) optical observations\n\nJ. Postnov (SAI-MSU Moscow)\nreport:\n\n\"On July 24 and 25, 2001 UT, we have observed the field of the optical\ntransient of GRB 000926 (Fynbo et al., 2001, A&A, 373, 796).\nWe have obtained B, V, Rc, Ic images with the SCORPIO\n(http://www.sao.ru/~moisav/scorpio/scorpio.html) at the\n6-m telescope of SAO RAS. Photometric conditions were good and\nthe seeing was about 1.3 arcsec. Photometric calibration was\nperformed using Stetson standards in Landolt standard field PG1633.\n\nAt the position of the optical transient we have detected an object -\na host galaxy. At about 3\" to the East from the OT position an extended\nemission is clearly seen. This extended emission is most likely the galaxy\nseen in early HST image (see Price et al., 2001, ApJ, 549, L7) and its\nassociation with the host is unclear.\n\nThe exposure times and magnitudes of the object are:\n\n Filter  Exposure (sec.)  Magnitude         Aperture\n---------------------------------------------------------\n  B        2500             26.13 +/- 0.17   2.0 arcsec\n  V        1500             25.85 +/- 0.22   2.0 arcsec\n  Rc       1260             26.31+/-  0.25   2.0 arcsec\n  Ic       1800             24.7 +/-  0.4    2.0 arcsec\n---------------------------------------------------------\n\nThe faint R-band  magnitude can be explained by a graphite band\nas on the Galactic extinction curves. Indeed, for the redshift z=2.0369\n(Castro et al., GCN #851) this band (2200A) goes to the observed R-band.\nIf so, then this is the second case of direct observations of this\nfeature (see Sokolov et al., 2001, A&A, 372, 438, the case of the HG\nGRB 980703).\n\nWe also performed the photometry of entire system of the objects using\nan aperture of 4.5 arcsec. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on\nbehalf of a large SGR collaboration:\n\nChandra observed the newly active (GCN #1041) Soft Gamma Repeater,\nSGR 1900+14, on April 22, 2001 starting at 4:45 UT, for 20,000 seconds.\nThe ACIS S3 observation mode was Continuous Clocking (CC). We have fitted a\nspectrum to the whole data set; we find the best fit to be a single power law\nwith spectral (photon) index of 2.9 +/- 0.1 and a hydrogen column density (NH)\nof (3.4 +/- 0.1)x10^22 cm^-2. We detect no black body contribution in \nthe spectrum.  The source (unabsorbed) flux is 1.1x10^-11 ergs/cm^2 s\n(2-10 keV), nearly identical to the quiescent source flux level.\nThe pulse period is 5.1725 s (barycenter corrected); the pulse profile\nappears sinusoidal.\n\nMore detailed analysis and comparison with RXTE simultaneous \nobservations is underway.","createdOn":988070436000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Derek Fox at CIT  <derekfox@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"SGR 1900+14: Correction to GCN 1049","circularId":1052,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10052....1G","body":"D. Many people\nare wondering what is going on.  This announcement attempts to explain\nthe recent developments.\n\nTRIGGERS:\nStarting about a week ago, the HETE Operations team resumed sending\nthe HETE messages from the s/c to GCN -- there were gaps due to HETE and due\nto GCN (the network problems).  And since the Galactic Center\nis still in the HETE FOV, this has caused a marked step increase\nin the amount of HETE Notices (from zero to several per day).\nThis increase has been further enhanced by the fact that Sco X-1 has left\nthe FOV of the HETE instruments two weeks ago.  The decrease in the background\ndue to the loss of Sco X-1 has increased the sensitivity to the the XRB\nsources in the Galactic Center.\n\nPOSITIONS:\nSince a larger fraction of these triggers is caused by X-ray Burst sources\nwhich are very weak, they produce poor image detections and therefore\nlocations with large uncertainites.  The HETE Operations team\nhas commanded the s/c to suppress the positions if the \"source\"\nin the image is not significant enough.  This results in the large\nnumber of Notices with no positions.\n\nFILTERING:\nI have changed the GCN filtering system to compensate for this change\nin the Notice content.  If there is no position in the S/C_Update,\nS/C_Last, or even the Gnd_Analysis messages, then they are NOT distributed\nthe sites requesting HETE Notices.  The reasoning is that with no position\ninformation in the Notice, what possible use could a follow-up observer\nmake of the notification.  This change was made Saturday, 28 Jul 01.\n\nTOO MANY ALERTS?\nHowever, the S/C_Alerts never were intended to have position information\n(except for rare instances (~10%)), so they are still being distributed\nto those sites that have requested the HETE S/C_Alert subtype.\nEven with the filtering of the U/L/GA's that have no positions, there are\nstill a large number of Alert Notices being distributed to sites.  If you feel\nthat you are receiving too many Alerts (that subsequently have no U/L/GA\nfollow-ups), then you might consider requesting that the Alert subtype\nbe disabled for your site.  (Or you might consider \"toughing it out\"\nfor another 4-6 weeks until the Galactic Center is no longer in the HETE FOV \nin which case the trigger rate should drop dramatically.)\n\nACTION ITEM:\nSites can:\n1) keep their current configurations,   or\n2) request that S/C_Alerts be disabled,   or\n3) request that S/C_Alerts/Updates/Lasts be disabled (say for the next month\nor so, and then request they be turned back on),   or\n4) request that all HETE subtypes (A/U/L/GA) be disabled (again for the next\nmonth or so).\nGiven the no-positions-filtering incorporated last Saturday, choice \"2\"\nseems like a reasonable approach if a site has any concern about \"too many\nNotices\".\n\nSincerely,\n\nScott Barthelmy\nNASA-GSFC\n301-286-3106\nscott@lheamail.gsfs.nasa.gov","createdOn":996530269000,"email":"scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: (GCN\n987).\n\nNo host galaxy (or any other object) is detected at the position of\nthe optical afterglow of GRB010222\n(RA = 14:52:12.55, DEC =+43:01:06.2, J2000).\n\nVery close to the position of the GRB010222, we detect two objects,\nmost probably galaxies. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB000301C: Late-time HST/STIS observation","circularId":1063,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10063....1M","body":"A. Fruchter and P. Vreeswijk report for a larger collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000301c was reobserved by the Hubble Space Telescope\nusing the STIS camera in open (50CCD) mode on the 25 Feb 2001, or\nnearly one year after outburst.   Twelve dithered exposures were\ncombined to produce a final image with an exposure time of 7031s.\n\nNo source is immediately visible at the position of the GRB.  However,\nwhen the image is convolved with gaussians or boxcars with\ncharacteristic sizes from that of the PSF, 0.\"08, to 0.\"2, an extended\nobject appears to be visible under the position of the GRB and to its\nNE.  Although extended light from both a nearby bright star, and the\nlarger galaxy to the NW of the GRB make an exact determination of the\nsignificance of this object difficult, we believe this is approximately\na 3-4 sigma detection.  The probable host has an estimated magnitude of\nR = 28.0 +/- 0.3.  This magnitude is just consistent with the estimates\nof an underlying host from our earlier imaging, GCN 627 and 701.  It\nis, furthermore, about two magnitudes brighter than we would expect the\nOT to have been at this time, had it continued to decline with a\ntemporal power-law steeper than -2 (c.f. GCN 701 and  Rhoads and\nFruchter, ApJ 2001, 546, 177).\n\nIf this is indeed a detection of a host, then in all cases where we\nhave obtained a deep HST image and an OT is well localized (to ~0.\"1),\na host has been found under the GRB.   However, again, due to the\nscattered and extended light in this region of the image, the detection\nmust be considered tentative.\n\nThe image can be seen at http://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/000301C","createdOn":991165718000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Aaron Zimmerman at U. of Texas at Austin <aaron.zimmerman@utexas.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231231ag: Updated Sky localization and Source Classification","circularId":35446,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35446....1Z","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S231231ag (GCN Circular 35445). W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Our earlier report of a pulse phase-variable PSF width in Chandra\nobservations of SGR 1900+14 (GCN 1049) was in error.  Appropriate\ntreatment of the background counts relative to source counts reveals\nthat the one-dimensional PSF is consistent with a Gaussian of fixed\nstandard deviation equal to 0.41(1) arcseconds throughout the pulse\nphase. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\n\nAt 12:21:07.75 UTC (44467.75 s UT) on 29 June, the HETE FREGATE and \nWXM instruments detected and localized a bright GRB. The coordinates \n(J2000) of the 29 June burst are:\n\nR.A. = 248.158 deg. (16h32m38s.3)\n\nDec. =  -18.723 deg. (-18o43'24\")\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 15 arcmin in radius.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~20 s, with two peaks \nseparated by ~12 s. A total of ~11600 counts above background were \ndetected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence of ~2 x \n10-6 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux was >3 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >10 x \nCrab flux).\n\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993849476000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010629","circularId":1076,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1076....1H","body":"K. A. Smith (Rice University) and R. P. J. Tilanus (Joint Astronomy Centre) \nreport on behalf of the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope (JCMT) GRB collaboration:\n \nWe used the SCUBA sub-millimeter continuum bolometer array on the JCMT to \nobserve the variable radio source VLA J0702+3850 proposed by Taylor et al. \n(GCN #40) as the radio afterglow to GRB 980329.\n \nOn UT 1998 April 5.2 we detected a source at 850 microns with a preliminary \nflux density of 5 +/- 1.5 mJy.  This source was confirmed on April 6.2 with \na flux density of 4 +/- 1.2 mJy, resulting in an average of 4.5 +/- 1 mJy \nover the two days.  The 850 micron source is present in all our separate \nintegrations making us confident it is real.  A hint of a fading trend \nappears to be confirmed by observations on April 7.2 when the (preliminary)\n850 micron flux density was 2 +/- 0.8 mJy. \n\nThe source was not detected at 450 microns with a preliminary rms of 10.0 \nmJy averaged over the first two days.\n\nAssuming these fluxes are due to the burst counterpart, they should represent\n\"clean\" measures of its intensity, unaffected by scintillation and extinction.  \nMonitoring with SCUBA is continuing.\n\nWe wish to thank Dr. L. Ricker (MIT), on behalf of the HETE Team, reports:\n\nOver the past few weeks, the number of X-ray bursts (XRBs) reported \nby HETE has been gradually increasing, reaching ~10 per day during \nthe past 2-3 days. This seeming storm of XRBs is being produced by an \nensemble of ~10 distinct XRB sources, which are optimally placed in \nthe HETE field-of-view (FOV) for detectability.\n\nThis dramatic overall increase is due to two factors: 1) Improvements \nin the on-board detection algorithm, resulting from lowered trigger \nthresholds and increased numbers of trigger time scales being \nactivated; 2) Sco X-1 has moved out of the HETE instruments' FOV, \ngreatly reducing the overall background, thus improving the \ninstruments' burst detection efficiency.\n\n(NB: Despite the flurry of XRBs, soft gamma repeaters [SGR] and \ngamma-ray bursts [GRB] positions are now being, and will continue to \nbe, reported for events which trigger the high energy bands of the \nFREGATE instrument directly.)\n\nMany of the faint XRB detections are near threshold, and thus their \nonboard localization is unreliable. In order not to saturate rapid \nresponse telescopes and observing programs which primarily target \nSGRs and GRBs, these XRB events are being reported to the GCN with no \npositions. (In fact, reliable positions are subsequently established \nby the WXM ground software for a large fraction of these XRB events.) \nA  refined reporting algorithm, which will more clearly distinguish \nfainter, poorly-localized XRBs from brighter, well-localized XRBs \nwill be implemented in the near future. In the meantime, the XRB \n\"alert only\" reports will continue.  Beginning in late August, when \nthe Galactic Bulge Region moves out of HETE's FOV, we anticipate a \nprecipitous drop in the reported XRB rate.","createdOn":996527165000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Vijay Mohan at U.P.State Observatory Nainital  <vijay@upso.ernet.in>","subject":"GRB 010326b Optical Observations","circularId":1040,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1040....1P","body":"S.B.Pandey, C.S. As noted by \nHenden (GCN #1077) this field has a high Galactic extinction \n(A_I=1.18 according to Schlegel et al. 1998), making the search for \nan afterglow intrinsically less deep. P. Halpern & N. Mirabal (Columbia U.) report on behalf\nof the MDM Observatory GRB team:\n\n\"Using the MDM 1.3m telescope, we obtained R-band images\ncovering the error box of GRB 010629 as defined by the\noverlap of the HETE error circle (Ricker et al. GCN #1075)\nand the IPN annulus (Hurley et al. GCN #1076) beginning on\nJune 30 3:35 UT and ending at 7:50 UT.  These images are\ndeeper than the DSS.  We don't see any new object, but an\nasteroid passed through the error box.  Moving west at a\nrate of 27\"/hour, it was located at 16:32:17.9, -18:49:59\n(J2000) on June 30 4:34 UT.\n\nConcerning the possible high proper motion star reported by\nHenden (GCN #1077), we see both it and its neighbor 10\" to\nthe west.  Therefore, it is a `new' object, but one of many\nthat are near the limit of the DSS.\n\nThe proximity of the moon has prevented useful follow-up\ncoverage from being made.\"\n\nThis message may be cited, although we can't imagine why.","createdOn":994068147000,"email":"jules@astro.columbia.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Josh Bloom at CIT  <jsb@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"HETE Trigger #1760 (GRB 010920B?): a new optical source","circularId":1094,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1094....1B","body":"J. S. Bloom, D. Reichart, D. W. Fox, P. D. Nicholson, C. Dumas, S. R.\nKulkarni, P. A. Price, R. A. Simcoe report on behalf of the larger\nCaltech-NRAO-CARA GRB collaboration:\n\n\"P. Nicholson and C. Postnov (SAI-MSU Moscow)\nreport:\n\n\"On July 24 and 25, 2001 UT, we have observed the field of the optical\ntransient of GRB 000926 (Fynbo et al., 2001, A&A, 373, 796).\nWe have obtained B, V, Rc, Ic images with the SCORPIO\n(http://www.sao.ru/~moisav/scorpio/scorpio.html) at the\n6-m telescope of SAO RAS. Photometric calibration was\nperformed using Stetson standards in Landolt standard field PG1633.\n\nAt the position of the optical transient we have detected an object -\na host galaxy. At about 3\" to the East from the OT position an extended\nemission is clearly seen. This extended emission is most likely the galaxy\nseen in early HST image (see Price et al., 2001, ApJ, 549, L7) and its\nassociation with the host is unclear.\n\nThe exposure times and magnitudes of the object are:\n\n Filter  Exposure (sec.)  Magnitude         Aperture\n---------------------------------------------------------\n  B        2500             26.13 +/- 0.17   2.0 arcsec\n  V        1500             25.85 +/- 0.22   2.0 arcsec\n  Rc       1260             26.31+/-  0.25   2.0 arcsec\n  Ic       1800             24.7 +/-  0.4    2.0 arcsec\n---------------------------------------------------------\n\nThe faint R-band  magnitude can be explained by a graphite band\nas on the Galactic extinction curves. Indeed, for the redshift z=2.0369\n(Castro et al., GCN #851) this band (2200A) goes to the observed R-band.\nIf so, then this is the second case of direct observations of this\nfeature (see Sokolov et al., 2001, A&A, 372, 438, the case of the HG\nGRB 980703).\n\nWe also performed the photometry of entire system of the objects using\nan aperture of 4.5 arcsec. The candidate was found\nby the PyCBC Live [1], CWB [2], SPIIR [3], GstLAL [4], and MBTAOnline\n[5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS190602aq is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as\nestimated by the online analysis, is 1.9e-09 Hz, or about one in 16\nyears. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S190602aq\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending\nprobability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), NSBH (<1%),\nor MassGap (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, there is strong\nevidence against the lighter compact object having a mass < 3 solar\nmasses (HasNS: <1%). Using the masses and spins inferred from the\nsignal, there is strong evidence against matter outside the final\ncompact object (HasRemnant: <1%).\n\nOne skymap is available at this time and can be retrieved from the\nGraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.fits.gz, an updated localization generated by BAYESTAR\n[6], distributed via GCN notice about 6 minutes after the candidate\n\nFor the bayestar.fits.gz skymap, the 90% credible region is 1172 deg2.\nMarginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance\nestimate is 797 +/- 238 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard\ndeviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of\nthis alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo Public Alerts User Guide\n<https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/userguide/>.\n\n [1] Nitz et al. Woods, PI). We cannot verify the burst reported in GCN #1047. \nThe source was occulted by the earth at the time in question.\n\nWe confirm the burst in the Chandra data at approximately 7:15:25 UT. The burst \nduration appeared to be 0.35 seconds during which 14 counts were recorded \n(ignoring pile-up). Thus the peak count rate was 65 times the quiescent rate.\nAdopting the quiescent source spectrum (GCN # 1046), we estimate the peak flux \nin the 2-10 keV band to be 7.2 x 10^-10 ergs/cm^2 s (2.9 x 10^-9 ergs/cm^2 s in \n0.5-10.0 keV).\n\nWe would like to add a clarification regarding the persistent source flux  \nvalues in the two GCNs (1046, 1047). Our flux estimates are for the 2-10  \nkeV band to facilitate comparison with data from other satellites; when we  \nexpand the energy range to 0.5-10 keV (as in GCN 1047) we find similar  \nvalues for the quiescent flux.\n\nThis message can be cited.\n\n_____________________________________________\nChryssa Kouveliotou\nNSSTC, SD-50, Rm 2057\n320 Sparkman Drive,\nHuntsville, AL 35805\ntel: 256 961 7604 fax: 256 961 7215","createdOn":988150068000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX/GRBM detection of GRB 010801","circularId":1086,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1086....1F","body":"M. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Our earlier report of a pulse phase-variable PSF width in Chandra\nobservations of SGR 1900+14 (GCN 1049) was in error.  Appropriate\ntreatment of the background counts relative to source counts reveals\nthat the one-dimensional PSF is consistent with a Gaussian of fixed\nstandard deviation equal to 0.41(1) arcseconds throughout the pulse\nphase. CZTI is a coded aperture mask instrument that has considerable effective area for about 29% of the entire sky, but is also sensitive to brighter transients from the entire sky. At the time of merger, Astrosat's nominal pointing is (RA=295.71, DEC=-10.36), which is 134.4 deg away from the maximum probability location. In a time interval of 100 sec around the event, 51% of sky locations are visible in the satellite's frame and the rest of 49% with the inclusion of maximum probability location for the event are occulted by earth. \n\nCZTI data were de-trended to remove orbit-wise background variation. We then searched data from three of the four independent, identical quadrants to look for coincident spikes in the count rates. Searches were undertaken by binning the data in 0.1s, 1s, and 10s respectively. Statistical fluctuations in count rates were estimated by using data from 10 (+-5) neighbouring orbits. We selected confidence levels such that the probability of a false trigger in a 1000 sec window is 10^-4.We do not find any evidence for any hard X-ray transient in this window, in the CZTI energy range of 20-200 keV.\n\nWe convert our count rates into flux by assuming that the source spectrum is a power law with alpha = -1.0. We use a detailed mass model of the satellite to calculate the instrument response for every htm grid point that fall in 90% LIGO localization region and calculate flux limit in that direction. We get the following upper limits for source flux in the 20-200 keV band by taking a probability weighted mean of flux limit and are reported here :  \n\n0.1 s: flux limit= 8.7 e-7 ergs/cm^2/s \n1.0 s: flux limit= 3.0 e-6 ergs/cm^2/s \n10.0 s: flux limit= 3.6 e-6 ergs/cm^2/s\n\nCZTI is built by a TIFR-led consortium of institutes across India, including VSSC, ISAC, IUCAA, SAC and PRL. The Indian Space Research Organisation funded, managed and facilitated the project.","createdOn":1559625588000,"email":"varunb@iitb.ac.in"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"H1761: A Bright GRB Detected by HETE","circularId":1096,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10096....1B","body":"H1761: A Bright GRB Detected by HETE\n\nG. The burst occurred \nat 18950.56 SOD {05:15:50.56} UT on 21 September.  The burst is seen \nin the WXM X detector and is therefore well-localized in the X \ndirection; the burst was apparently outside the coded FOV of the WXM \nY detector, which therefore gives limited information about the Y \ndirection of the burst.\n\nThe X-detector data gives a good (+/-10 arcmin) localization in the X\ndirection and crude limits on Y, resulting in a localization that is a\nthin, long strip.\n\nTwo points along one side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h52m36s.7, Dec. =  39o35'13\"\nR.A. = 23h10m22s.8, Dec. =  48o57'43\"\n\nTwo points along the other side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h54m04s.0, Dec. =  39o34'23\"\nR.A. = 23h11m52s.5, Dec. =  48o57'00\"\n\nOur estimate is that the strip is  ~10  degrees in the long direction.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~12 s. As observed by SROSS C-2, it \nhad a duration (T90) of 1.20 +- 0.05 secs. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, T. Cline, on behalf\nof the Ulysses and Konus - Wind GRB teams, and E. Mazets and S.\nGolenetskii, on behalf of the Konus-Wind GRB team, report:\n\nUlysses and Konus observed a burst on 2001 June 25 at 51801 s UT (Earth\ncrossing time) whose origin is probably SGR1900+14.  It had a duration\nof ~2 s, a 25-100 keV fluence of 2.8 x 10^-6 erg/cm^2, and a peak flux\nover 0.25 s of 3.9x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s.  Triangulation gives an annulus\ncentered at RA(2000), Decl(2000) = 17.530 deg, +33.050 deg, with radius\n85.548 +/- 0.027 deg.  The center line of this annulus passes ~0.018\ndeg from SGR1900+14.  In addition, the Konus data indicate that the\nsource of this event is located in the north ecliptic hemisphere, which\nis consistent with the location of SGR1900+14, and the spectrum of the\nburst is soft.  This may signal a resurgence of activity from this\nSGR.","createdOn":993596072000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Varun Bhalerao at Indian Inst of Tech  <varunb@iitb.ac.in>","subject":"LIGO/Virgo S190602aq: AstroSat CZTI upper limits","circularId":24736,"bibcode":"2019GCN.24736....11","body":"We have carried a search for X-ray candidates in Astrosat CZTI data in a 100 sec window around the trigger time of the BBH merger event S190602aq (UTC 2019-06-02 17:59:27.00, GraceDB event). CZTI is a coded aperture mask instrument that has considerable effective area for about 29% of the entire sky, but is also sensitive to brighter transients from the entire sky. At the time of merger, Astrosat's nominal pointing is (RA=295.71, DEC=-10.36), which is 134.4 deg away from the maximum probability location. In a time interval of 100 sec around the event, 51% of sky locations are visible in the satellite's frame and the rest of 49% with the inclusion of maximum probability location for the event are occulted by earth. \n\nCZTI data were de-trended to remove orbit-wise background variation. We then searched data from three of the four independent, identical quadrants to look for coincident spikes in the count rates. Searches were undertaken by binning the data in 0.1s, 1s, and 10s respectively. Statistical fluctuations in count rates were estimated by using data from 10 (+-5) neighbouring orbits. We selected confidence levels such that the probability of a false trigger in a 1000 sec window is 10^-4.We do not find any evidence for any hard X-ray transient in this window, in the CZTI energy range of 20-200 keV.\n\nWe convert our count rates into flux by assuming that the source spectrum is a power law with alpha = -1.0. We use a detailed mass model of the satellite to calculate the instrument response for every htm grid point that fall in 90% LIGO localization region and calculate flux limit in that direction. We get the following upper limits for source flux in the 20-200 keV band by taking a probability weighted mean of flux limit and are reported here :  \n\n0.1 s: flux limit= 8.7 e-7 ergs/cm^2/s \n1.0 s: flux limit= 3.0 e-6 ergs/cm^2/s \n10.0 s: flux limit= 3.6 e-6 ergs/cm^2/s\n\nCZTI is built by a TIFR-led consortium of institutes across India, including VSSC, ISAC, IUCAA, SAC and PRL. The Indian Space Research Organisation funded, managed and facilitated the project.","createdOn":1559625588000,"email":"varunb@iitb.ac.in"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Richard McMahon at Inst.Astonomy, U Cambridge  <rgm@ast.cam.ac.uk>","subject":"GRB980613 Near Infra-Red Observations","circularId":101,"bibcode":"1998GCN...101....1M","body":"R. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Analysis of data from the 22 April 2001 Chandra observation (GCN\n1046, 1047), barycenter-corrected with the preliminary CXC ephemeris,\nreveals that the source emission is pulsed at a period of P =\n5.17288(5) s with a pulse strength of 14.3(2)% RMS that remains\nconstant (within errors) throughout the observation.  Separation of\nthe source photons into \"on-pulse\" and \"off-pulse\" components of 1/3\ncycle each reveals that the off-pulse spatial distribution is\nsignificantly broader than the on-pulse distribution.  Since the\nobservation is taken in continuous-clocking mode, we can only make\nthis determination in one dimension.  Nonetheless, the sigma-widths of\nthe one-dimensional Gaussian PSFs are 0.98(1) arcsec for on-pulse\nphotons and 1.08(2) arcsec for off-pulse photons, different at\n>5-sigma level. Kouveliotou, Universities Space Research Association, M. Kippen, P.\nWoods, G. Richardson, University of Alabama in Huntsville, V.\nConnaughton, National Research Council, report on behalf of the BATSE\nteam at NASA/Marshall Space Flight Center:\n\nBATSE has detected repeated soft gamma-ray bursts consistent with the\nsame (previously unknown) location. We recorded three bursts on June\n15.109, 15.296, 15.411 UT (BATSE triggers 6825, 6826, 6827,\nrespectively) with an average duration of ~ 200 milliseconds.\nPreliminary spectral analysis of the data indicates that the events\nare very soft, with power law spectral indices varying between -3.0\nand -7.0. BATSE triggered 5 more times, on June 17.873, 17.901,\n18.004, 18.035, and 18.071 UT (BATSE trigger numbers 6833, 6834, 6835,\n6836 and 6837, respectively). The last trigger had a peak count rate\nof over 300000 counts/sec above background (integrated over 4\ndetectors between 20-1000 keV, in 1 second interval) and a duration of\n~ 3 seconds. Due to its very high peak intensity, deadtime effects\nprevent us from using it for localization, until we receive more data\ntypes. Burud, J. Rhoads and A. Levan (STScI) report:\n\nWe have reduced the now public archival HST images of GRB 010222, taken\non 28 February, 17 and 18 March, 5 and 6 April, and 4 and 5 May of \nthis year using the F606W (V/R) and F814W (I) filters on WFPC2.   Using\nthe most recent data, we find that OT of GRB 010222 is clearly superposed\non a host galaxy.  \n\nIn order to accurately determine the decay of the OT and the magnitude\nof the host, we have drizzled the images onto an output grid that\nallows interlacing of these 2-point dithered images.  We have then fit\nfor the decay of the OT and the host galaxy flux using a small (~0.\"2)\naperture, which provides the best estimate of the OT as a function of\ntime, as well as using a larger aperture (~0.\"5), which is more\nappropriate for determining the host galaxy magnitude.\n\nWe find that the late-time decay of the OT is significantly steeper\nthan previously reported. Formally, we find\na slightly steeper decay (-1.73 +/- 0.02) in F606W than in F814W \n(-1.64 +/- 0.04), but this discrepancy may indicate the level of\nsystematic error in the slope measurement rather than true color\nevolution of the OT.\n\nWe find that the host galaxy is dominated by a compact core (FWHM ~ 0.\"15)\nlocated directly under the OT. Woods (USRA/NSSTC), C. Kouveliotou (NASA/MSFC), and E. Gogus\n(UAH/NSSTC) report on behalf of a larger collaboration.\n\nToO observations of SGR 1900+14 with the Rossi XTE were initiated on\nApril 19, 2001 and have continued through April 28.  Thus far, more\nthan 60 bursts have been detected in ~110 ks of exposure time. \nCoincidentally, a short (~10 ks) observation of SGR 1900+14 was\nperformed on April 14 (4 days prior to the flare) as part of our\nongoing monitoring campaign.  We find no burst activity within this\nobservation.  For the latest observation on April 28, 4 bursts were\nrecorded in one RXTE orbit, thus the source remains burst active.\n\nSelecting a 6 day subset of these observations for which we have\nspacecraft ephemeris information, we have phase connected the data and\nmeasured both a period and period derivative.  We chose our epoch (MJD\n52021.3 TDB) to coincide with the first Chandra observation.  We\nmeasure a barycentric period of 5.1728219(14) s where the number given\nin the parentheses marks the 1 sigma error in the least significant\ndigits. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB and HETE teams; T. Cline, on\nbehalf of the Ulysses, Konus-Wind, and HETE GRB teams; E. Mazets and\nS.  Golenetskii, on behalf of the Konus-Wind and Konus-A GRB teams; and\nG. Ricker, D. Lamb, C.  Graziani, E. Fenimore, N. Kawai, and J.-L.\nAtteia, on behalf of the HETE team report:\n\nUlysses, Konus-Wind and Konus-A observed GRB010326A. This burst had a\nduration of ~25 s, a 17 keV - 2.5 MeV fluence of ~4x10^-5 erg/cm2, and\na peak flux over 0.25 s of ~8x10^-6 erg/cm2 s. From a cross-correlation\nof the Ulysses and Konus-Wind time histories, we have triangulated the\nlocation of the burst to an annulus centered at RA(2000)=178.727 deg.,\nDecl(2000)=30.803 deg., and radius 81.702+/- 0.028 deg. (3 sigma confidence).\nThe triangulation based on the Konus-Wind and the Konus-A data resulted\nin an annulus centered at RA(2000)=94.662 deg., Decl(2000)=21.978 deg., and\nradius 69.7+/- 0.4 deg. (1 sigma confidence).  Combining these data, we\nare able to restrict the location of the burst to the following ~180\nsquare arcmin. error box.\n\n  RA(2000)       DEC(2000)\n132.9630 o     -38.3005 o (CENTER)\n132.3408 o     -38.5784 o (CORNER)\n132.3988 o     -38.5441 o (CORNER)\n131.5271 o     -38.0568 o (CORNER)\n131.5851 o     -38.0230 o (CORNER)\n\nThis location is consistent with the spectra and time history seen in \nthe four HETE FREGATE detectors. The above error box can be refined \nby further processing.\n\nOn this basis, we have concluded that the WXM location reported in GCN\n1014 for this burst is spurious.  This burst is distinct from the other \nGRBs (GRB010326B, GCN 1018; GRB010213, GCN 934) for which HETE WXM \nlocations have been reported, in that it has a very low \nsignal-to-noise excess count rate in the WXM, and our further \nanalysis suggests that it is this fact that accounts\nfor the spurious location. The HETE team apologizes for any \ninconvenience arising from the spurious location.","createdOn":985901254000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1055,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10055....1S","body":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14\n\nM. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Roma) and S. Mereghetti (IFC/CNR, Milano),\non behalf of a larger SGR collaboration, and G. Gandolfi, L. Piro\nand E. Costa (IAS/CNR, Roma), on behalf of the BeppoSAX Team,\nreport:\n\n\"A ToO observation of SGR1900+14 was carried out with the\nBeppoSAX Narrow Field Instruments starting on April 18, 15:10 UT,\nless than 8 hours after the large flare reported in GCN #1041.\nIntense bursting activity is present during the 28 hr long\nobservation.  After removing the numerous short bursts, a significant\nflux decay is visible in the MECS and LECS light curves.\nBy using our data and the Chandra 2-10 keV flux (GCN #1046)\nwe find that the decay can be reasonably well described by a power\nlaw with index ~-0.6.  There is also evidence for a spectral softening\ncorrelated with the intensity decrease.\n\nThe average spectrum (after removal of the bursts) can be fit by a\npower law with photon index 2.6+/-0.1 and NH=(4.3 +/-0.3)x10^22 cm^-2.\nThe average 2-10 keV flux during the whole BeppoSAX observation is\n2.9x10^-11 erg/cm^2/s (unabsorbed). The bursts have a significantly\nharder spectrum (power law photon index ~0 in the 2-10 keV range).\n\nPulsations,  with a nearly sinusoidal light curve and a modulation of\nabout 21%, are clearly detected at the barycentered period  P=5.17277(1) s.\nWhen compared with the value measured with Chandra about 3 days later\n(GCN #1049), this yields a dP/dt ~ (4.1 +/- 1.9)x10^-10 s/s.\n\nAn additional BeppoSAX/NFI observation will start on April 29, 20:30 UT.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988388763000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paul Price at RSAA, ANU at CIT  <pap@srl.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB 010326B: Optical observations","circularId":1020,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10020....1M","body":"P.A. Oregon) report on behalf of the larger\nCaltech-NRAO-CARA GRB Collaboration:\n\n\"On 26.27 March 2001, we obtained a second night of exposures of the\nfield of GRB 010324 (GCN/RXTE ASM; Hurley et al., GCN #1011) using\nCOSMIC on the Palomar 200-inch atop Mt. Palomar.  Using the same\npattern as in the first epoch of imaging (GCN #1012), the entire XTE\nerror box was observed in V-band in two pointings with a total of 1800\nsec per pointing.\n\nBoth image differencing and differential aperture photometry between\nthe two epochs revealed no obviously varying source.  No absolute\nphotometry for the field is available at this time.  However, adopting\nV = 19.1 mag for a USNO A2.0 star at RA: 07:11:26.301, DEC:\n+19:58:30.32 (J2000) we estimate the absence of variation by more than\n0.3 mag down to V = 22.3 mag.\n\nSources brighter than V~18.5 mag were saturated however all such sources\nwere previously observed in DPOSS (see GCN #1012); therefore any GRB\nafterglow is now likely to be faint (V > 22.3 mag). One caveat to this\nconclusion is that the GRB field has a high stellar density and so it is\npossible to have missed a varying source near a bright star.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985713383000,"email":"jsb@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Evert Rol at U.Amsterdam  <evert@astro.uva.nl>","subject":"GRB010214, optical observations","circularId":1059,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10059....1F","body":"E. Tanvir (University of Hertfordshire), report on behalf\nof a larger collaboration:\n\n\nIn order to verify the possible counterpart to GRB010214 (Rol et al.,\nGCN 955), we obtained another set of images with the Isaac Newton\nTelescope on February 21, 2001. Examination and comparison of these\nimages with those obtained at the INT on February 17 shows no evidence\nfor a further fading of the possible counterpart, as already suggested\nin other reports (Gorosabel et al., GCN 972; Klose et al., GCN 997;\nFynbo, private comm.). Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, G. The coordinates \n(J2000) of the burst source were:\n\nR.A. = 272.0265 deg.\n\nDec. = -20.2743 deg\n\nThe error circle for the localization is 36 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1806-20 lies 11.8 arcmin from the HETE position. [Another galactic \nX-ray source, GX9+1, lies 100 arcmin from the HETE position.]\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <300 ms. A total of 864 \ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a flux \nof >10 times Crab.\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":992900745000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX/GRBM detection of GRB 010801","circularId":1086,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10086....1S","body":"M. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome) and C. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, G. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 08:33:12 UTC (=30792s UT), a soft spectrum, high \nenergy transient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized \nby HETE.\n(NB: This is the second GRB detected by HETE on 26 March 2001.)\n\nBoth the WXM and the FREGATE instruments detected the event. The \nburst triggered FREGATE in the 6-120 keV band, at the 160ms timescale.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h24m23.36s, \nDec. = -11o09'57\", derived from combining data from the WXM and \nBoresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the WXM \nlocalization is 18 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we estimate \na systematic error radius at present of 10 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 30 \narcsec (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~4 Crab; with WXM \n(2-25 keV), ~2 Crab. The burst duration was about 4 seconds.\n\nThe high galactic latitude of the source, well away from the Galactic \nBulge, and the shape of its spectrum suggest that it is a gamma-ray \nburst similar to those reported for \"X-ray rich\" GRBs by Heise et al \n(2001) from BeppoSAX observations.\n\nFollow-up observations of this unusual transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on the GRB010326B (including light curves), as \nwell as for the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985612698000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. Stars\nbrighter than V=14 are saturated and should be used with care.\nWe have placed the photometric data on our anonymous ftp site:\nftp://ftp.nofs.navy.mil/pub/outgoing/aah/grb/grb010326b.dat\nThe current photometry has a potential external zero-point\nerror of about three percent. Both the FREGATE and the WXM instruments detected the event. \nThe burst triggered FREGATE in the 30-400 keV band.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h50m59.11s, \nDec. = -23�32'44\" (J2000), derived from combining data from the WXM \nand Boresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the \nWXM localization is 10 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we \nestimate a systematic error radius at present of 20 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 2 \narcmin (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe burst exhibited a multiple-peaked structure and lasted about 25 \nseconds. The peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~1 Crab. The \npeak flux was significantly less in the WXM.\n\nFollow-up observations of this GRB event are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on GRB010326 (including light curves and the \nWXM error box), as well as the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985591482000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. Hurley on behalf of the Ulysses GRB Team, report:\n\nGRB010324 (GCN/RXTE ASM Burst Position Notice of Sat. 24 Mar 01 and GCN\n1011) triggered the BeppoSAX/GRBM at 11h32m46s UT, 285.4 s before the ASM\ntrigger. From the GRBM 40-700 keV light curve, the actual onset time is\nabout 80 s before the GRBM trigger time. The event shows a multi-peak\nbehavior with an outstanding peak occurring 10 s after the GRBM trigger\ntime and a peak flux of 1100 cts/s, corresponding to ~1x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s. \nThe trigger time of ASM occurs in correspondence of the tail of the last\npeak of the burst, whose centroid is ~360 s after the onset time and\nits peak flux is a factor 8 lower than that of the main peak. \n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":985627961000,"email":"filippo@tesre.bo.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Giangiacomo Gandolfi at IAS/CNR Frascati  <gandolfi@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"GRB010518: a faint BeppoSAX detection","circularId":1062,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1062....1G","body":"C. Feroci, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM team, report:\n\nWe have completed a search through the data of the Ulysses GRB\nexperiment for possible bursts from SGR1900+14 on 2000 April 17 and\n18. Henden (USRA/USNO) reports on behalf of the USNO GRB team:\n\nWe have acquired single I-band images forming a mosaic\nthat covers about 90 percent of the intersection between the\nHETE error circle (Ricker et al., GCN 1075)\nand the IPN annulus (Hurley et al., GCN 1076) for GRB010629.  The\nimages were taken around 010630.32 UT (19hrs after the burst)\nwith the NOFS 1.0m telescope under poor conditions.\nComparing with the DPOSS-II red plate for\nthis region, we estimate a limiting magnitude of about I=19.\nNo new objects are seen. Price, T.S. Axelrod, B.P. Schmidt (RSAA, ANU), D.E. Reichart, J.S.\nBloom and D. Fox (Caltech) report on behalf of a larger international GRB\ncollaboration:\n\n\"We have observed the error-circle of the HETE-2 GRB 010324 with the\nrobotic 50-inch telescope at Mount Stromlo Observatory starting at 2001\nMar 26.45 UT (7.5 hours after the GRB). This event \nwas promptly distributed as a GCN Notice (HETE BID_1715). No signal \nwas detected in the WXM, indicating that the event was likely to \nbe >40 degrees from the anti-sun direction. For the current HETE \npointing direction, SGR1900+14 is about 48 degrees off the boresight, \nwhile SGR1806-20 is about 56 degrees off the boresight, so that \neither could be a candidate.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~200 ms. A total of 500\ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence\nof ~9 x 10-8 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux was >2 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >50 x Crab flux) over a duration of 30 ms.\n\nA search for this event in the archives of other GRB instruments is \nencouraged. Bremer, IRAM (Grenoble) and A.J. Castro-Tirado, IAA-CSIC (Granada) \nand LAEFF-INTA (Madrid) report:\n\nWe have observed the position of the proposed SGR 1900+14 radio \ncounterpart reported by Frail et al. 1999 (Nature 398, 127) with \nthe IRAM Plateau de Bure Interferometer on April 24, 2001 between \nUT 1:13 - 3:04 (i.e. approximately six days after the giant flare \nreported by Guidorzi et al. in GCN 1041). \n\nThe source was not detected. The following fluxes and 1-sigma errors \n(corrected for atmospheric decorrelation) were measured on the \nphase center:\n\n 92.772 GHz: -0.64 +- 0.60 mJy/beam  (beam: 10.4\" x 5.2\" by PA=-55 deg.)\n217.829 GHz: -2.7  +- 2.8  mJy/beam  (beam: 4.5\"  x 2.3\" by PA=-47 deg.)\n\nNo bright sources were detected within the field of view of the \nprimary beams (53\" and 23\", respectively).","createdOn":988275311000,"email":"bremer@iram.fr"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Scott Barthelmy at NASA/GSFC  <scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"GCN and HETE status","circularId":1085,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1085....1B","body":"INTRO:\nThere have been a lot of HETE triggers in the last week.  Many people\nare wondering what is going on.  This announcement attempts to explain\nthe recent developments.\n\nTRIGGERS:\nStarting about a week ago, the HETE Operations team resumed sending\nthe HETE messages from the s/c to GCN -- there were gaps due to HETE and due\nto GCN (the network problems).  And since the Galactic Center\nis still in the HETE FOV, this has caused a marked step increase\nin the amount of HETE Notices (from zero to several per day).\nThis increase has been further enhanced by the fact that Sco X-1 has left\nthe FOV of the HETE instruments two weeks ago.  The decrease in the background\ndue to the loss of Sco X-1 has increased the sensitivity to the the XRB\nsources in the Galactic Center.\n\nPOSITIONS:\nSince a larger fraction of these triggers is caused by X-ray Burst sources\nwhich are very weak, they produce poor image detections and therefore\nlocations with large uncertainites.  The HETE Operations team\nhas commanded the s/c to suppress the positions if the \"source\"\nin the image is not significant enough.  This results in the large\nnumber of Notices with no positions.\n\nFILTERING:\nI have changed the GCN filtering system to compensate for this change\nin the Notice content.  If there is no position in the S/C_Update,\nS/C_Last, or even the Gnd_Analysis messages, then they are NOT distributed\nthe sites requesting HETE Notices.  The reasoning is that with no position\ninformation in the Notice, what possible use could a follow-up observer\nmake of the notification.  This change was made Saturday, 28 Jul 01.\n\nTOO MANY ALERTS?\nHowever, the S/C_Alerts never were intended to have position information\n(except for rare instances (~10%)), so they are still being distributed\nto those sites that have requested the HETE S/C_Alert subtype.\nEven with the filtering of the U/L/GA's that have no positions, there are\nstill a large number of Alert Notices being distributed to sites.  If you feel\nthat you are receiving too many Alerts (that subsequently have no U/L/GA\nfollow-ups), then you might consider requesting that the Alert subtype\nbe disabled for your site.  (Or you might consider \"toughing it out\"\nfor another 4-6 weeks until the Galactic Center is no longer in the HETE FOV \nin which case the trigger rate should drop dramatically.)\n\nACTION ITEM:\nSites can:\n1) keep their current configurations,   or\n2) request that S/C_Alerts be disabled,   or\n3) request that S/C_Alerts/Updates/Lasts be disabled (say for the next month\nor so, and then request they be turned back on),   or\n4) request that all HETE subtypes (A/U/L/GA) be disabled (again for the next\nmonth or so).\nGiven the no-positions-filtering incorporated last Saturday, choice \"2\"\nseems like a reasonable approach if a site has any concern about \"too many\nNotices\".\n\nSincerely,\n\nScott Barthelmy\nNASA-GSFC\n301-286-3106\nscott@lheamail.gsfs.nasa.gov","createdOn":996530269000,"email":"scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 980326: Late-time HST/STIS observations","circularId":1029,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10029....1G","body":"Andrew Fruchter (STScI), Paul Vreeswijk (University of Amsterdam) and\nPeter Nugent (LBNL) report on behalf of a larger HST GRB collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 980326 with HST/STIS on 31 December 2000,\njust over 1000 days after the burst. The total exposure time was 7080\nseconds in the 50CCD aperture. The images were reduced by the standard\nHST pipeline, and drizzled to a combined image with a pixelscale of\n0.\"0254.\n\nWe projected the location of the early afterglow from a KeckII/LRIS R\nband image, taken by Filippenko, Leonard and Riess on March 27, 1998\n(see GCN 33).  We estimate the 1-sigma error radius to be less than 1.5\ndrizzled HST pixels, which includes both the scatter in the\ntransformation (0.9 pixels, using 6 reference stars) and the\nmeasurement error of the transient in the Keck image (0.8 pixels).\n\nWithin one pixel of the estimated position, there was evidence of a\nsmall source.  We therefore convolved the image with a gaussian with a\nFWHM equal to that of the PSF (3.5 drizzled pixels).  This procedure\nuses the PSF as a matched filter to enhance the the signal-to-noise\nratio of unresolved sources.  In the convolved image an object is\nfound, again offset by one pixel from the expected position with a\nsignificance of ~4.5 sigma.  We estimate a magnitude (in the broad STIS\n50ccd filter) of V = 29.25 +/- 0.25.\n\nBloom et al., (1999, Nature, 401, 453) have suggested that the unusual\nlight curve of this GRB might be explained by an underlying supernova,\nand on the basis of this estimated a redshift of about z~1.   A\nsupernova at this redshift (which in this model peaks around a\nmagnitude of 25) would be expected to be significantly fainter than\nV=29 by now (as would the rapidly decaying GRB afterglow).  Therefore,\nwe may be detecting a faint host galaxy.  Deep HST images have in all\nother cases detected a host underlying the GRB, when good astrometry\nwas available for the GRB.  If we are observing a host galaxy, then the\nabove magnitude could underestimate its brightness by as much as a few\ntenths of a magnitude, due to extended emission missed in this\nmeasurement.  A galaxy at a z~1 with this observed magnitude would lie\na rather remarkable 7 magnitudes below L*, the knee of the of the\ngalaxy luminosity function at that redshift.\n\nGiven the apparent point-source nature of the detected object, and the\nlack of color information, we cannot exclude the possibility (which we\nconsider remote) that we are observing a light echo, from either the\nGRB or the supernova.\n\nImages of the field can be found at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/980326","createdOn":985809183000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"SGR1900+14 - correction","circularId":1054,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1054....1H","body":"In GCN 1053, the date should read 2001 April 17 and 18, not 2000 April 17 and 18.","createdOn":988386763000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Valerie Connaughton at NASA/MSFC/USRA  <valerie@nasa.gov>","subject":"LIGO/Virgo G194575:  Fermi GBM Observations","circularId":18448,"bibcode":"2015GCN.18448....1B","body":"LIGO/Virgo G194575:  Fermi GBM Observations\n\nLindy Blackburn (CfA), Michael S. Dainotti (National Astronomical Observatory of Japan), \nY. Niino (Tokyo University, Institute of Astronomy), \nK. Kalinowski (Aarhus University, Department of Physics and Astronomy),\nB. De Simone (Universita' degli Studi Di Salerno)\nreport: \n\nWe image the field of GRB 231216A detected by Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT)(trigger 1202749)\nwith telescope of Nastro Verde Observatory - Sorrento (Naples), Italy. Member of: \nAAVSO - American Association of Variable Star Observers.\nUAI/SSV - Unione Astrofili Italiani/sezione stelle variabili.\nAstroCampania Associazione\n\nThe observations started at 20:15 UT of  2023/12/16, after 1,40 hours after the GRB trigger, with principal telescope  SC 0.35 f/10 with focal reduced + CCD Sbig ST10 XME\nI took 20 image of 60 sec each. All images are unfiltered, calibrated with masterdark and masterflat,stacked with Tycho Tracker software\nWe have not detected any clearly visible sources, up to 19.5th magnitude  in a sky with light clouds and gusts of wind.\nStart T0+                End T0+        Rlim\n20:15:25 UT            20:36:38 UT      19.5\n\nWe did not found any optical counterpart in the error box of the XRTcandidate.\nT.
