Kennea (PSU), James DeLaunay (PSU), Gayathri Raman (PSU), Tyler Parsotan (NASA GSFC), Aaron Tohuvavohu (Caltech) report:\n\nSwift/BAT was observing >99% of the GW localization probability ([Bilby.multiorder.fits](https://gracedb.ligo.org/api/superevents/S241009l/files/Bilby.multiorder.fits)) at merger time. A fraction 90% of the GW localization posterior is contained inside the BAT coded FoV.\n\nThe LVK notice, distributed in near real-time, triggered the Swift Mission Operations Center operated Gamma-ray Urgent Archiver for Novel Opportunities (GUANO; [Tohuvavohu et al. 2020, ApJ, 900, 1](https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/1538-4357/aba94f)).\n\nUpon trigger by this notice, GUANO sent a command to the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) to save 200 seconds of BAT event-mode data from [-50,+150] seconds around the time of the burst. All the requested event mode data was delivered to the ground.\n\nUsing the NITRATES analysis ([DeLaunay + Tohuvavohu 2022, ApJ, 941, 169](https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/1538-4357/ac9d38)), we searched for emission on 8 timescales from 0.128s to 16.384s in the interval [-20,+20] seconds around the merger time. We find no evidence for a signal, and derive the following upper limits.\n\nWe quote the 5-sigma flux upper limits in the 15-350 keV band, weighted over the GW localization, for four spectral templates (soft, normal, and hard GRB-like templates described in [arXiv:1612.02395], and spectral shape from GRB170817A [arXiv:1710.05446]) and for four time bins. \nIn units of 10^-7 erg/s/cm^2:\n\n|time_bin (s) |soft |normal|  hard | GRB170817\n|-|-|-|-|-|\n|0.256        |2.50| 2.14  |  1.92 |2.34\n|1.024        |1.28| 1.09  |  0.98 |1.19\n|4.096        |0.69| 0.59  |  0.53 |0.64\n|16.384       |0.43| 0.37  |  0.33 |0.40\n\nThe upper limits as function of sky position are plotted here, alongside the GW localization:\n[https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.13992839]()\n\nThe solid and dashed lines indicate the 90% and 50% GW contour levels, respectively. The corresponding fits file is also included.\n\nGUANO is a fully autonomous, extremely low latency, spacecraft\ncommanding pipeline designed for targeted recovery of BAT event mode\ndata around the times of compelling astrophysical events to enable\nmore sensitive GRB searches.\n\nA live reporting of Swift/BAT event data recovered by GUANO can be\nfound at: [https://www.swift.psu.edu/guano/]()","createdOn":1729884936008}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241022A","submitter":"Dmitry Svinkin at Ioffe Institute <svinkin@mail.ioffe.ru>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB 241022A (short/hard) ","circularId":37885,"format":"text/plain","body":"A.S. D'Elia et al. 2024, GCN 37859) and Einstein Probe (D.Y. Li et al. 2024, GCN 37864)\nThe Fermi GBM on-ground location is consistent with the Swift BAT position.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 47 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of multiple close peaks with a duration (T90)\nof about 124 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0+2.3 to T0+125.2 s is best fit by a Band function.\nThe power law index is -0.93 +/- 0.06 and the cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 235 +/- 22 keV.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(1.46 +/- 0.06)E-05 erg/cm^2. The 1-sec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0+46 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 3 +/- 0.2 ph/s/cm^2.\n\nA power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff fits the spectrum equally well.\nThe power law index is -0.92 +/- 0.05 and the cutoff energy, parameterized as\nEpeak, is 232 +/- 18 keV.\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1729890623197}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241025C","submitter":"Lorenzo Scotton at UAH <lscottongcn@outlook.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241025C: Fermi GBM Detection","circularId":37887,"format":"text/plain","body":"L. Scotton (UAH) and C. Meegan (UAH) report on behalf of\nthe Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\"At 15:36:10.66 UT on 25 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB 241025C (trigger 751563375/241025650).\n\nThe GBM on-ground calculated location was reported in GCN Circular 37883.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 75 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of a single emission episode with a duration (T90)\nof about 5 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0-3.0 to T0+3.2 s is best fit by\na power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff.\nThe power law index is -0.68 +/- 0.13 and the cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 103 +/- 7 keV.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(1.71 +/- 0.08)E-06 erg/cm^2. The 1-sec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0+0.26 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 9.7 +/- 0.3 ph/s/cm^2.\n\nA Band function fits the spectrum equally well with\nEpeak = 102 +/- 10 keV, alpha = -0.68 +/- 0.15 and beta = -3.68 +/- 2.34.\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1729896082358}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241025A","submitter":"Phil Evans at U of Leicester <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241025A: Swift-XRT refined Analysis","circularId":37888,"body":"K.L. Page (U. Leicester), T. Sbarrato (INAF-OAB), P. D'Avanzo\n(INAF-OAB), M.G. Bernardini (INAF-OAB), S. Dichiara (PSU), J.A. Kennea\n(PSU), D.N. Burrows (PSU), A.P. Beardmore (U. Leicester) and P.A. Evans\nreport on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nWe have analysed 6.8 ks of XRT data for GRB 241025A, from 109 s to 80.1\nks after the  BAT trigger. The data comprise 321 s in Windowed Timing\n(WT) mode (the first 4 s were taken while Swift was slewing) with the\nremainder in Photon Counting (PC) mode. \n\nThe light curve can be modelled with a series of power-law decays. The\ninitial decay index is alpha=8.0 (+0.0, -0.5). At T+126 s  the decay\nflattens to an alpha of 3.15 (+0.20, -0.21) before breaking again at\nT+221 s to a final decay with index alpha=1.071 (+0.026, -0.025).\n\nA spectrum formed from the WT mode data can be fitted with an absorbed\npower-law with a photon spectral index\tof 1.77 (+/-0.05). The\nbest-fitting absorption column is  3.6 (+/-1.1) x 10^22 cm^-2, at a\nredshift of 4.2, in addition to the Galactic value of 1.2 x 10^21 cm^-2\n(Willingale et al. 2013). The PC mode spectrum has a photon index of\n1.68 (+/-0.12) and a best-fitting absorption column of 2.4 (+2.4, -2.1)\nx 10^22 cm^-2. The counts to observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux\nconversion factor deduced from this spectrum  is 4.3 x 10^-11 (5.1 x\n10^-11) erg cm^-2 count^-1. \n\nA summary of the PC-mode spectrum is thus:\nGalactic foreground: 1.2 x 10^21 cm^-2\nIntrinsic column:    2.4 (+2.4, -2.1) x 10^22 cm^-2 at z=4.2\nPhoton index:\t     1.68 (+/-0.12)\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/01262165.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n","createdOn":1729905845143}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241025A","submitter":"Alan Watson at UNAM <alan@astro.unam.mx>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"GRB 241025A: COLIBRÍ Detection of the Afterglow","circularId":37889,"body":"Alan M. Melandri (INAF-OAR), V. D'Elia (SSDC & INAF-OAR),\nD. M. Palmer (LANL), T. Sakamoto (AGU) and B. Sbarufatti (INAF-OAB)\nreport on behalf of the Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory Team:\n\nAt 22:42:32 UT, the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) triggered and\nlocated GRB 241026A (trigger=1262764).  Swift slewed immediately to the burst.\nThe BAT on-board calculated location is \nRA, Dec 293.423, +57.980 which is \n   RA(J2000) = 19h 33m 42s\n   Dec(J2000) = +57d 58' 49\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3 arcmin (radius, 90% containment, including \nsystematic uncertainty).  The BAT light curve showed a single-peak\nstructure with a duration of about 30 sec.  The peak count rate\nwas ~3600 counts/sec (15-350 keV), at ~0 sec after the trigger.\n\nThe XRT began observing the field at 22:44:26.4 UT, 114.5 seconds after\nthe BAT trigger. Using promptly downlinked data we find an uncatalogued\nX-ray source located at RA, Dec 293.39935, 57.98544 which is equivalent\nto:\n   RA(J2000)  = 19h 33m 35.84s\n   Dec(J2000) = +57d 59' 07.6\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3.7 arcseconds (radius, 90% containment). This\nlocation is 49 arcseconds from the BAT onboard position, within the BAT\nerror circle. This position may be improved as more data are received;\nthe latest position is available at https://www.swift.ac.uk/sper.  We\ncannot determine whether the source is fading at the present time. \n\nA power-law fit to a spectrum formed from promptly downlinked event\ndata gives a column density in excess of the Galactic value (8.92 x\n10^20 cm^-2, Willingale et al. 2013), with an excess column of 4.4\n(+3.14/-2.68) x 10^21 cm^-2 (90% confidence).\n\nUVOT took a finding chart exposure of 150 seconds with the White filter\nstarting 117 seconds after the BAT trigger. No credible afterglow candidate has\nbeen found in the initial data products. Data from the 2.7'x2.7' sub-image are\nnot available at this time. The 8'x8' region for the list of sources generated\non-board covers 100% of the XRT error circle. The list of sources is typically\ncomplete to about 18 mag. No correction has been made for the expected\nextinction corresponding to E(B-V) of 0.073.\n\nBurst Advocate for this burst is A. Melandri (andrea.melandri AT inaf.it).\nPlease contact the BA by email if you require additional information\nregarding Swift followup of this burst. Lian, D. Y. Li, Y. L. Wang, S. X. Wen. W. Yuan (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nWe report on the detection of a fast X-ray transient, designated EP241026b, by the Wide-field X-ray Telescope (WXT) on board the Einstein Probe (EP) mission. The transient started at 2024-10-26T18:14:30(UTC) and lasted for around 100 seconds. The WXT position of EP241026b is R.A.= 56.403 deg, DEC = 41.031 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of 2.9 arcmin (radius, 90% C.L. statistical and systematic).  It has a peak flux of ~1.7 x 10^-9 erg/s/cm^2 in the 0.5-4 keV band. The average 0.5-4 keV spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed power law with a photon index of 2.5(+/-0.8) (with a column density fixed at the Galactic value of 3.38 x 10^21 cm^-2). The derived average unabsorbed 0.5-4 keV flux is 1.2(-0.3, +0.4) x 10^(-10) erg/s/cm^2. The uncertainties are at the 90% confidence level for the above parameters. \n\nNo previously known bright X-ray sources are found within the error circle around the source position. EP-FXT follow-up observation has been arranged. Further follow-up observations are encouraged to identify the nature of this X-ray transient. \n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics). {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Aishwarya L Thakur at INAF-IAPS, Rome <aishth@outlook.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241021a: e-MERLIN radio observation","circularId":37906,"format":"text/plain","body":"G. Gianfagna, G. Bruni, L. Piro, A.L. Thakur (INAF-IAPS) report:\n\nWe observed the new Fast X-ray Transient EP241021a (Hu et al., GCN 37834) with the e-MERLIN radio telescope under the project CY18212 (PI: Gianfagna) at 5 GHz starting on Oct. 24, 16:44 UT (~3 days after the EP trigger, GCN 37834) for a total of ~11 hours. \n\n1331+3030 was used for flux scale calibration, and 0154+0823 for complex gain. The beam size was 104x36 milli-arcsec. Data were reduced with the e-MERLIN pipeline and imaged with CASA. The image RMS was 45 uJy/beam.\n\nWe did not find statistically significant emission at a level above 5-sigma at the position of the optical counterpart reported by Fu et al. (GCN 37840, 37842), Li et al. (GCN 37844, 37846), Ror et al. (GCN 37845), Zheng et al. (GCN 37849), Moskvitin & Spiridonova (GCN 37850), Bochenek et al. (GCN 37869), Kumar (GCN 37875), Busmann (GCN 37877), Jin et al. (GCN 37892). Thus, we estimate a 5-sigma upper limit of ~ 0.2 mJy at 5 GHz. Further e-MERLIN observations are planned. \n\nWe thank the e-MERLIN staff, particularly David Williams, for the prompt scheduling and excellent support with these observations. e-MERLIN is a National Facility operated by the University of Manchester at Jodrell Bank Observatory on behalf of STFC, part of UK Research and Innovation.\n","createdOn":1730025845931}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Daniele B. Malesani at IMAPP / Radboud University <d.malesani@astro.ru.nl>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP 241026b: LBT optical observations","circularId":37907,"format":"text/plain","body":"Daniele B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.), Andrea Rossi (INAF/OAS), Olga Kuhn (LBTO) and Felice Cusano (INAF/OAS) report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of the X-ray transient EP 241026b (Lian et al., GCN 37902) using the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) located on Mount Graham (AZ, USA), equipped with the MODS instrument. Two images (120 s exposure each) were secured in the r and g bands, beginning at 09:50 UT on October 27, that is 15.6 hr after the EP/WXT trigger.\n\nVisual comparison with archival images from Pan-STARRS reveals no new source within the 2.9'-radius error circle provided by EP/WXT, down to the Pan-STARRS depth of r ~ 23 (AB). We note that our image reaches deeper than that, and fainter counterparts may be retrieved once a better reference image is available.","createdOn":1730033796660}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"Phil Evans at U of Leicester <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241026A: Swift-XRT refined Analysis","circularId":37908,"body":"P. D'Avanzo (INAF-OAB), M.G. Bernardini (INAF-OAB), E. Ambrosi \n(INAF-IASFPA) , J.A. Kennea (PSU), D.N. Burrows (PSU), M. A. Williams\n(PSU), A.P. Beardmore (U. Leicester), J.P. Osborne (U. Leicester) and\nP.A. Evans report on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nWe have analysed 7.6 ks of XRT data for GRB 241026A, from 98 s to 45.9\nks after the  BAT trigger. The data comprise 54 s in Windowed Timing\n(WT) mode (the first 9 s were taken while Swift was slewing) with the\nremainder in Photon Counting (PC) mode. \n\nThe light curve can be modelled with a series of power-law decays. The\ninitial decay index is alpha=2.5 (+0.5, -0.4). At T+226 s  the decay\nflattens to an alpha of 0.21 (+0.11, -0.12) before breaking again at\nT+7943 s to a final decay with index alpha=0.90 (+/-0.11).\n\nA spectrum formed from the PC mode data can be fitted with an absorbed\npower-law with a photon spectral index of 1.88 (+/-0.10). The\nbest-fitting absorption column is  1.43 (+0.32, -0.30) x 10^21 cm^-2,\nin excess of the Galactic value of 8.9 x 10^20 cm^-2 (Willingale et al.\n2013). The counts to observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux conversion\nfactor deduced from this spectrum  is 3.7 x 10^-11 (4.6 x 10^-11) erg\ncm^-2 count^-1. \n\nA summary of the PC-mode spectrum is thus:\nTotal column:\t     1.43 (+0.32, -0.30) x 10^21 cm^-2\nGalactic foreground: 8.9 x 10^20 cm^-2\nExcess significance: 3.0 sigma\nPhoton index:\t     1.88 (+/-0.10)\n\nIf the light curve continues to decay with a power-law decay index of\n0.90, the count rate at T+24 hours will be 0.10 count s^-1,\ncorresponding to an observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux of 3.8 x\n10^-12 (4.7 x 10^-12) erg cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/01262764.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n","createdOn":1730037010026}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"EP Team at NAOC/CAS <ep_ta@bao.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241026a (GRB 241026A): EP on-board trigger and follow-up observation","circularId":37909,"format":"text/plain","body":"D. Y. Li, T. Y. Lian, Y. L. Wang, S. X. Wen, W. Yuan (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nWe report on the detection of an X-ray transient detected by EP-WXT, EP241026a, which triggered the on-board processing unit (trigger ID: 01709112485). A preliminary analysis of the EP-WXT data shows that the transient began at 2024-10-26T22:41:28 (UTC), and lasted for around 150 seconds, with the peak flux of around 8 x 10^-9 erg/s/cm^2 in 0.5-4 keV. The averaged spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed powerlaw（NH fixed at the Galactic value 9.2 x 10^20 cm^-2）with a photon index of 0.8 +/- 0.3. The average unabsorbed flux is (1.6 +/- 0.3) x 10^-9 erg/s/cm2 in 0.5-4 keV. An EP-FXT follow-up observation was triggered about 8 hours later, which detected an uncatalogued X-ray source at R.A. = 293.4008 deg, DEC = 57.9857 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of about 10 arcsecs (radius, 90% C.L. statistical and systematic), consistent with the position of the WXT transient within the uncertainties. We note that the trigger time and position of this X-ray transient are consistent with those of GRB 241026A (Fermi GBM team, GCN #37894, Melandri et al. GCN #37896). The averaged EP-FXT spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed powerlaw (NH fixed at the Galactic value), with a photon index of 1.81 +/- 0.08. The derived average unabsorbed flux is (6.4 +/- 0.3) x 10^-12 and (1.06 +/- 0.07) x 10^-11 erg/s/cm2 in 0.5-4 keV and 0.5-10 keV, respectively. All the errors of the parameters quoted are at the 90% C.L.\n\nPlease note that the temporal and spectral analyses presented above are preliminary. Final results will be presented in future publications. EP-FXT will also keep monitoring this transient in the following days.\n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics).","createdOn":1730039655620}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Moskvitin Alexander at SAO RAS <mosk@sao.ru>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"EP241021a: further SAO RAS optical observations","circularId":37910,"body":"A. The images were processed using the WINTER data reduction pipeline (https://github.com/winter-telescope/mirar, https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.13352565). \n\nWe do not detect a source at the optical and enhanced Swift/XRT counterpart location (Evans et al., GCN 37897; Lipunov et al., GCN 37898; Moskvitin et al., GCN 37899; Watson et al., GCN 37900; Zheng et al., GCN 37903; Osborne et al., GCN 37904; Shrestha et al., GCN 37913). We obtain the following 5-sigma upper limit: J ~ 18.2 mag (AB).\n\nWINTER (Wide-field INfrared Transient ExploreR) is a partnership between MIT and Caltech, housed at Palomar Observatory, and funded by NSF MRI, NSF AAG, the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, and the MIT Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research.","createdOn":1730064269772}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"Moskvitin Alexander at SAO RAS <mosk@sao.ru>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"GRB 241026A: BTA redshift identification of z = 2.79","circularId":37916,"body":"A. Trigg (LSU) report on behalf of\nthe Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\"At 22:42:31.28 UT on 26 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB 241026A (trigger 751675356/241026946).\nwhich was also detected by Swift BAT (D. M. Palmer et al. 2024, GCN 37896)\nand Einstein Probe  (D.Y. Li et al. 2024, GCN 37909).\nThe Fermi GBM on-ground location is consistent with the Swift BAT position.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 43 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of a single emission episode with a duration (T90)\nof about 16 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0+0.003 to T0+16.768 s is best fit by\na Comptonized function with a power law index -0.96 +/- 0.05 and a cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 229 +/- 20.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(6.6 +/- 0.3)E-06 erg/cm^2. The 1-sec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0+0.70 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 7.1 +/- 0.3 ph/s/cm^2.\n\nA Band function fits the spectrum equally well with\nEpeak = 183 +/- 22 keV, alpha = -0.87 +/- 0.07 and beta = -2.17 +/- 0.2.\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1730076161197}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"Varun Bhalerao at IIT Bombay <varunb@iitb.ac.in>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241026A: GROWTH-India Telescope optical observations","circularId":37918,"format":"text/markdown","body":"T. Mohan, V. Swain, R. Kumar, V. Bhalerao (IITB), G.C. Anupama, S. Barway (IIA) and K. Angail (IAO) report on behalf of the GIT team:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 241026A (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37894; Melandri et al., GCN 37896, Evans et al., GCN 37897) with 0.7m GROWTH-India Telescope (GIT). We started the observation at 2024-10-27 15:02:21 UT, i.e., 16.3 hours after the Fermi GBM trigger. We obtained multiple exposures of 360 seconds in the r' and i' filters. We detected the afterglow in our images at the positions given by Swift XRT (GCN 37904) and COLIBRI (GCN 37900)\nIn our stacked images, we detected the optical afterglow in the r' filter at the enhanced Swift-XRT position (GCN 37904). Ambrosi (INAF-IASFPA)\nreport on behalf of the Swift/UVOT team:\n\nThe Swift/UVOT began settled observations of the field of GRB 241025A\n126 s after the BAT trigger (Ambrosi et al., GCN Circ. 37859).\nA source consistent with the XRT position (Evans et al.; GCN Circ. 37868) \nis detected in the initial UVOT exposures.\n\nThe preliminary UVOT position is:\n    RA  (J2000) =  22:14:36.83 = 333.65346 (deg.)\n    Dec (J2000) = +83:34:32.2  =  83.57562 (deg.)\nwith an estimated uncertainty of 0.43 arc sec. GCNC 32686), considering the rate of such extremely energetic GRBs observed at higher redshifts.\n\nConsidering a flat cosmology with H0 = 67.4 km/s/Mpc and Omegam = 0.315 (Planck Collaboration et al. 2020), we extrapolate the rate of ���4 extremely energetic GRBs per year derived by Atteia et al. (2017) in the redshift range [1,5], to the volume of the nearby universe enclosed within z = 0.151.\n\n- Assuming a constant GRB formation rate, we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~130 yr.\n- Assuming the GRB formation rate of Palmerio & Daigne (2021), we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~520 yr.\n\nWe conclude that there is a ~10% probability to observe an event like GRB 221009A about 50 years after the discovery of the first GRB.\n\nBibliography :\n- Cenko, S. Kouveliotou, Universities Space Research Association, M. Kippen, P.\nWoods, G. Richardson, University of Alabama in Huntsville, V.\nConnaughton, National Research Council, report on behalf of the BATSE\nteam at NASA/Marshall Space Flight Center:\n\nBATSE has detected repeated soft gamma-ray bursts consistent with the\nsame (previously unknown) location. We recorded three bursts on June\n15.109, 15.296, 15.411 UT (BATSE triggers 6825, 6826, 6827,\nrespectively) with an average duration of ~ 200 milliseconds.\nPreliminary spectral analysis of the data indicates that the events\nare very soft, with power law spectral indices varying between -3.0\nand -7.0. BATSE triggered 5 more times, on June 17.873, 17.901,\n18.004, 18.035, and 18.071 UT (BATSE trigger numbers 6833, 6834, 6835,\n6836 and 6837, respectively). The last trigger had a peak count rate\nof over 300000 counts/sec above background (integrated over 4\ndetectors between 20-1000 keV, in 1 second interval) and a duration of\n~ 3 seconds. Due to its very high peak intensity, deadtime effects\nprevent us from using it for localization, until we receive more data\ntypes. The weighted location of the 7 remaining triggers is centered\non R.A. = 16h27m12.0s and dec = -41d06.0' with an error radius of\nabout 2 degrees.  This location does not correspond to any previously\nknown SGR source; we conclude that we have discovered a new source,\nSGR1627-41. The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], and PyCBC Live [4] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231226av is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.1e-50 Hz, or about one in 1e42 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231226av\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), BNS (<1%), or Terrestrial (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [5] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [5] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 30 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [6], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. Hjorth, M. I. Andersen, H. Pedersen, A. O. Jaunsen on behalf of the NOT \nGRB team and E. Costa & E. Palazzi on behalf of the SAX GRB team report:\n\nOn June 13.9 UT and June 17.9 UT we obtained R band images (600 sec each, \nseeing FWHM=0.7\") of the BeppoSAX error circle of GRB 980613 (Piro & Costa, \nGCN #99) with the 2.5-m Nordic Optical Telescope. We have discovered a faint \npoint source in our June 13.9 image which is not detected in our June 17.9 \nimage (which reaches a similar limiting magnitude). The source is located at \n(+- 0.5\"):\n\nRA(J2000)  =  10 17 57.64\nDec(J2000) = +71 27 26.4\n\nPreliminary photometry (Cousins R) of the source yields:\n\nJune 13.8897 UT: R = 22.9+-0.2\nJune 17.9088 UT: R > 24.0 (formal 10-sigma limit)\n\nThese numbers assume R=19.11 for USNO catalogue entry U1575-03105992 located at \nRA(J2000)=10 17 54.83, Dec(2000)=+71 27 39.8, consistent with the photometry \nof the isolated star 4_r of Odewahn et al. (GCN #105) (assuming r-R=0.35).\n\nThe location of the source is consistent with the BeppoSAX WFC error circle\nof GRB 980613 (GCN #99) and the BeppoSAX MECS error circle for source A\n(Piro, GCN #104; Costa et al., IAUC 6939). \n\nThe photometry is consistent with previously reported upper limits for\noptically variable objects in the field (R > 20.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado \net al., GCN #102; I>21.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado et al., GCN #103; \nr>21.0 on June 16.0, Odewahn et al., GCN #105; I>22.3 on June 14.2, Halpern\net al., GCN #106, I>20.6 on June 14.0 and I>21.5 on June 14.4, Diercks et \nal., GCN #108).\n\nGiven the consistency with the BeppoSAX error circles of GRB 980613 and\nthe rapidly fading nature of the source we suggest that the detected object\nis the optical afterglow of GRB 980613.\n\nFinding charts and updates of these preliminary results will be posted at \nhttp://www.nordita.dk/~jens/grb980613/\n\nThis report may be cited.","createdOn":898186684000,"email":"jens@nordita.dk"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. Henden (USRA/USNO) reports on behalf of the USNO GRB team:\n\nWe have obtained a second night of photometry with the\nNOFS 1.0m telescope for the field of GRB010324. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 010222: HST observations -- host galaxy and late-time decay","circularId":1087,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1087....1F","body":"A. Fruchter, I. Burud, J. Rhoads and A. Levan (STScI) report:\n\nWe have reduced the now public archival HST images of GRB 010222, taken\non 28 February, 17 and 18 March, 5 and 6 April, and 4 and 5 May of \nthis year using the F606W (V/R) and F814W (I) filters on WFPC2.   Using\nthe most recent data, we find that OT of GRB 010222 is clearly superposed\non a host galaxy.  \n\nIn order to accurately determine the decay of the OT and the magnitude\nof the host, we have drizzled the images onto an output grid that\nallows interlacing of these 2-point dithered images.  We have then fit\nfor the decay of the OT and the host galaxy flux using a small (~0.\"2)\naperture, which provides the best estimate of the OT as a function of\ntime, as well as using a larger aperture (~0.\"5), which is more\nappropriate for determining the host galaxy magnitude.\n\nWe find that the late-time decay of the OT is significantly steeper\nthan previously reported.  We find a power-law decay between 28 February\n(day 6) and 5 May (day 71) of -1.7 +/- 0.05.  Formally, we find\na slightly steeper decay (-1.73 +/- 0.02) in F606W than in F814W \n(-1.64 +/- 0.04), but this discrepancy may indicate the level of\nsystematic error in the slope measurement rather than true color\nevolution of the OT.\n\nWe find that the host galaxy is dominated by a compact core (FWHM ~ 0.\"15)\nlocated directly under the OT.  The magnitude of the host is \nF606W(AB) = 26.0 +/- 0.1, F814W(AB) = 25.8 +/- 0.15.  \n\nImages of the host, as well as a plot of the coninuing decline of the OT,\nare available at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/010222","createdOn":997814700000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Doug Welch at McMaster University  <welch@physics.mcmaster.ca>","subject":"GRB221009A: Ionospheric disturbance observed in India","circularId":32745,"bibcode":"2022GCN.32745....1W","body":"Authors: A. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 980326: Late-time HST/STIS observations","circularId":1029,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1029....1F","body":"Andrew Fruchter (STScI), Paul Vreeswijk (University of Amsterdam) and\nPeter Nugent (LBNL) report on behalf of a larger HST GRB collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 980326 with HST/STIS on 31 December 2000,\njust over 1000 days after the burst. The total exposure time was 7080\nseconds in the 50CCD aperture. The images were reduced by the standard\nHST pipeline, and drizzled to a combined image with a pixelscale of\n0.\"0254.\n\nWe projected the location of the early afterglow from a KeckII/LRIS R\nband image, taken by Filippenko, Leonard and Riess on March 27, 1998\n(see GCN 33).  We estimate the 1-sigma error radius to be less than 1.5\ndrizzled HST pixels, which includes both the scatter in the\ntransformation (0.9 pixels, using 6 reference stars) and the\nmeasurement error of the transient in the Keck image (0.8 pixels).\n\nWithin one pixel of the estimated position, there was evidence of a\nsmall source.  We therefore convolved the image with a gaussian with a\nFWHM equal to that of the PSF (3.5 drizzled pixels).  This procedure\nuses the PSF as a matched filter to enhance the the signal-to-noise\nratio of unresolved sources.  In the convolved image an object is\nfound, again offset by one pixel from the expected position with a\nsignificance of ~4.5 sigma.  We estimate a magnitude (in the broad STIS\n50ccd filter) of V = 29.25 +/- 0.25.\n\nBloom et al., (1999, Nature, 401, 453) have suggested that the unusual\nlight curve of this GRB might be explained by an underlying supernova,\nand on the basis of this estimated a redshift of about z~1.   A\nsupernova at this redshift (which in this model peaks around a\nmagnitude of 25) would be expected to be significantly fainter than\nV=29 by now (as would the rapidly decaying GRB afterglow).  Therefore,\nwe may be detecting a faint host galaxy.  Deep HST images have in all\nother cases detected a host underlying the GRB, when good astrometry\nwas available for the GRB.  If we are observing a host galaxy, then the\nabove magnitude could underestimate its brightness by as much as a few\ntenths of a magnitude, due to extended emission missed in this\nmeasurement.  A galaxy at a z~1 with this observed magnitude would lie\na rather remarkable 7 magnitudes below L*, the knee of the of the\ngalaxy luminosity function at that redshift.\n\nGiven the apparent point-source nature of the detected object, and the\nlack of color information, we cannot exclude the possibility (which we\nconsider remote) that we are observing a light echo, from either the\nGRB or the supernova.\n\nImages of the field can be found at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/980326","createdOn":985809183000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"SGR1900+14","circularId":1053,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10053....1X","body":"K. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB000301C: Late-time HST/STIS observation","circularId":1063,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1063....1F","body":"A. Fruchter and P. Vreeswijk report for a larger collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000301c was reobserved by the Hubble Space Telescope\nusing the STIS camera in open (50CCD) mode on the 25 Feb 2001, or\nnearly one year after outburst.   Twelve dithered exposures were\ncombined to produce a final image with an exposure time of 7031s.\n\nNo source is immediately visible at the position of the GRB.  However,\nwhen the image is convolved with gaussians or boxcars with\ncharacteristic sizes from that of the PSF, 0.\"08, to 0.\"2, an extended\nobject appears to be visible under the position of the GRB and to its\nNE.  Although extended light from both a nearby bright star, and the\nlarger galaxy to the NW of the GRB make an exact determination of the\nsignificance of this object difficult, we believe this is approximately\na 3-4 sigma detection.  The probable host has an estimated magnitude of\nR = 28.0 +/- 0.3.  This magnitude is just consistent with the estimates\nof an underlying host from our earlier imaging, GCN 627 and 701.  It\nis, furthermore, about two magnitudes brighter than we would expect the\nOT to have been at this time, had it continued to decline with a\ntemporal power-law steeper than -2 (c.f. GCN 701 and  Rhoads and\nFruchter, ApJ 2001, 546, 177).\n\nIf this is indeed a detection of a host, then in all cases where we\nhave obtained a deep HST image and an OT is well localized (to ~0.\"1),\na host has been found under the GRB. GCN 9868) reveals it is detected in the Fermi\nLarge Area Telescope (LAT) at least until 300 s after the Fermi\nGamma-Ray Burst Monitor (GBM) trigger time, T0=11:05:08.31 UT.\n\nSpectral analysis of the main emission episode, from T0 to T0+25 s, shows a\ndeviation from the Band function obtained from fitting GBM data between\n50 keV and 40 MeV (GCN 9866). This deviation is apparent both below 50\nkeV in the GBM and above 100 MeV in the LAT. It is well-fit by a single\npower-law, with a well-constrained index that is retrieved from a fit of \nthe\nGBM data alone, the LAT data alone, and when jointly fitting the entire\ndata set.\n\nThe parameters for this multi-component fit are Band_alpha =\n0.61 � 0.01, Band_beta = 3.87 � 0.16, Band_EPeak = 798 � 7 keV,\nand a power-law index of 1.94 � 0.01 that shows no evidence for a\nspectral cut-off below 100 GeV. The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], PyCBC Live [4], and SPIIR [5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231206ca is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 3.2e-10 Hz, or about one in 1e2 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231206ca\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), or NSBH (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [6] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [6] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 25 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,1 sky map, the 90% credible region is 1986 deg2. Marginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 3223 +/- 983 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/userguide/.\n\n [1] Klimenko et al. The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], PyCBC Live [4], and SPIIR [5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231206cc is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.9e-35 Hz, or about one in 1e27 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231206cc\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), BNS (<1%), or Terrestrial (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [6] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [6] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 30 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,2, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,2. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome), J.J.M. in 't Zand (Astronomical Institute,\nUtrecht University and SRON), P. Soffitta (IAS/CNR, Rome), K. Hurley\n(UCB, California), F. Frontera (Univ. Ferrara and TESRE/CNR, Bologna)\nand E. Mazets (IOFFE, S. Petersburg), report:\n\n\"A high-time resolution analysis has been performed of the BeppoSAX\nWide Field Camera data of SGR 1900+14 taken on April 18, 2001, when\nthe most recent giant flare was detected (Guidorzi et al., GCN 1041\nand IAUC 7611). The data cover a short intermediate pointing of Wide\nField Camera unit 1 between two scheduled targets. The observation\nstarted 2780 s before the giant flare and ended with the automatic\nswitch off due to that flare. The observation was interrupted when\nBeppoSAX traversed the SAA, from 2282 till 1052 s before the\ngiant flare. The analysis revealed the presence of 3 short X-ray\nprecursors, occurring 2537, 755, and 444 s before the giant flare\n(respectively, 25975, 27757 and 28068 s UT), with durations of 100,\n125 and 55 ms, peak fluxes in excess of 20 Crab units (2-28 keV),\nand 9-28/2-9 keV spectral hardness ratios that are consistent with\npower laws with photon indices between roughly 0.5 and 1.2. None of the\nprecursors was detected in the gamma-ray data from the BeppoSAX/GRBM,\nthe gamma-ray burst detector on Ulysses, and from Konus on Wind.\"","createdOn":988997172000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010612","circularId":1065,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10065....1C","body":"K. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor, N.\nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. Hurley on behalf\nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nThe HETE Fregate instrument has detected a bright (>40 sigma) GRB \nthat has been reported in a GCN Notice as H1761. The burst occurred \nat 18950.56 SOD {05:15:50.56} UT on 21 September.  The burst is seen \nin the WXM X detector and is therefore well-localized in the X \ndirection; the burst was apparently outside the coded FOV of the WXM \nY detector, which therefore gives limited information about the Y \ndirection of the burst.\n\nThe X-detector data gives a good (+/-10 arcmin) localization in the X\ndirection and crude limits on Y, resulting in a localization that is a\nthin, long strip.\n\nTwo points along one side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h52m36s.7, Dec. =  39o35'13\"\nR.A. = 23h10m22s.8, Dec. =  48o57'43\"\n\nTwo points along the other side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h54m04s.0, Dec. =  39o34'23\"\nR.A. = 23h11m52s.5, Dec. =  48o57'00\"\n\nOur estimate is that the strip is  ~10  degrees in the long direction.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~12 s. A total of 5310 \ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence \nof ~1 x 10-6 ergs cm-2. The peak flux was >3 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >8 x Crab flux).\n\nFurther refinement of the X localization is in progress; a further\nattempt is also being made to improve the coarse Y localization.","createdOn":1001067928000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Aaron Zimmerman at U. of Texas at Austin <aaron.zimmerman@utexas.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231226av: Updated Sky localization","circularId":35429,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35429....1L","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) and LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S231226av (GCN Circular 35428). GCN 35379),\nthe BOOTES-2/TELMA (Hu et al. GCN 35381), NOT (Daniele B. Malesani et al., GCN 35382) and the T120 at Observatoire de Haute-Provence (Basa et al., GCN 35384)limits.\n\nWe thank the staff at YaoAn Astronomy Observation Station for their excellent support.\n\n\n\n","createdOn":1702825533823}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1055,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1055....1F","body":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14\n\nM. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Roma) and S. Mereghetti (IFC/CNR, Milano),\non behalf of a larger SGR collaboration, and G. Gandolfi, L. Piro\nand E. Costa (IAS/CNR, Roma), on behalf of the BeppoSAX Team,\nreport:\n\n\"A ToO observation of SGR1900+14 was carried out with the\nBeppoSAX Narrow Field Instruments starting on April 18, 15:10 UT,\nless than 8 hours after the large flare reported in GCN #1041.\nIntense bursting activity is present during the 28 hr long\nobservation.  After removing the numerous short bursts, a significant\nflux decay is visible in the MECS and LECS light curves.\nBy using our data and the Chandra 2-10 keV flux (GCN #1046)\nwe find that the decay can be reasonably well described by a power\nlaw with index ~-0.6.  There is also evidence for a spectral softening\ncorrelated with the intensity decrease.\n\nThe average spectrum (after removal of the bursts) can be fit by a\npower law with photon index 2.6+/-0.1 and NH=(4.3 +/-0.3)x10^22 cm^-2.\nThe average 2-10 keV flux during the whole BeppoSAX observation is\n2.9x10^-11 erg/cm^2/s (unabsorbed). The bursts have a significantly\nharder spectrum (power law photon index ~0 in the 2-10 keV range).\n\nPulsations,  with a nearly sinusoidal light curve and a modulation of\nabout 21%, are clearly detected at the barycentered period  P=5.17277(1) s.\nWhen compared with the value measured with Chandra about 3 days later\n(GCN #1049), this yields a dP/dt ~ (4.1 +/- 1.9)x10^-10 s/s.\n\nAn additional BeppoSAX/NFI observation will start on April 29, 20:30 UT.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988388763000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Dale A. Frail at NRAO  <dfrail@nrao.edu>","subject":"SGR 1900+14, Chandra observations","circularId":1047,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10047....1M","body":"D. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report on behalf of a larger\ncollaboration\"\n\n\"In response to the 18 April 2001 flare of SGR 1900+14 (GCN 1041) the\nChandra X-ray Observatory has undertaken a sequence of two public\n20-ksec observations of this source, on 22 and 30 April 2001.\n\nThe first observation began at 04:58 UT on 22 April and was taken in\ncontinuous-clocking mode (see also GCN 1046).  Examination of the\nlight curve reveals that at least one burst was observed, 9081 s after\nthe start of the observation.  Assuming the best-fit spectral\nparameters for the observation (see below), the peak 1-s flux of this\nburst was of order 5e-10 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (0.5-10 keV).\n\nSpectral fits to the full background-subtracted data set allow for at\nleast two emission models.  A power-law plus absorption model has\nbest-fit parameters of N_H = 3.18(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha =\n2.70(1), and unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of 4.20(4)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1.\nA power-law plus blackbody and absorption model has best-fit\nparameters of N_H = 2.56(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha = 1.88(1),\nblackbody temperature kT = 0.532(3) keV, unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of\n2.17(3)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1, and flux fraction for the blackbody\ncomponent of 29% (0.5-10 keV).  The addition of the blackbody\ncomponent is not supported by an F-test (65% confidence level) but is\nconsistent with models in the literature (Perna et al. 2001,\nastro-ph/0103273).  Analysis of the RXTE PCA data may help to clarify\nthe presence or absence of the blackbody component, as the PCA count\nrates inferred from the two models given above differ by 50%.\n\nNo narrow spectral features are apparent.  The two-sigma upper limit\nto the flux of a persistent 0.2-keV FWHM emission line in the 5-7 keV\nrange is 1e-5 photons cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThis message may be cited.\"","createdOn":988083484000,"email":"dfrail@nrao.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"D. Metzger report for a larger HST GRB Collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000418 was re-observed by the Hubble Space Telescope\nstarting on UT 2001 Feb 11.64 using the STIS camera in open (50CCD)\nmode.  The individual exposures were combined using Drizzle for a total\nexposure time of 5120 s.\n\nWhen this image is subtracted from that obtained by HST on 2000 June\n4.17 a small residual of magnitude R~28 is found at the position of the\ncompact galaxy believed to be the host galaxy (GCN 669); however, the\nresidual is sufficiently faint to be consistent with no detection at\nabout the 2 sigma level. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi,\nF. Frontera, and M. Feroci, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM team, report:\n\nWe have identified a likely precursor to the giant flare from\nSGR1900+14 (GCN 1041, 1043) in the Ulysses data.  This event\noccurred on April 17, 2001, ~42184 s at Ulysses, and if it was\nindeed from SGR1900+14, its Earth-crossing time would have\nbeen ~42332 s.  This burst was ~50 s long, and its time history\nresembles that of the April 18 event, although it is considerably\nless intense.  Its 25-100 keV fluence was ~2.3x10^-5 erg/cm^2,\nand its peak flux over 0.5 s was ~1.5x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s.  Due to\na high solar proton background, these numbers are subject to more\nthan the usual uncertainties.  As SGR1900+14 was Earth-blocked\nat BeppoSAX, it did not observe this event, and there is no\nlocalization data available.\n\nThe time history has been posted at ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010417.\nAlso, we note that the time history of the April 18 event, posted\nat ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010418, was incorrectly labelled \"Counts/\n0.5 s\".  The label should have read \"Counts/Second\".  A corrected\nplot has been posted.\n\nSearches are underway through the Ulysses data for more possible\nevents from this source.","createdOn":987796101000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"GRB980611","circularId":100,"bibcode":"1998GCN...100....1H","body":"K. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 23:24:18.3 UT (84253.3s UT) on 27 June, the HETE FREGATE and WXM \ninstruments detected and localized an intense burst from SGR1900+14, \na soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the second burst localized \nfrom this source in the past week, indicating that it may have \nresumed an active state. (The first burst was reported in GCN \nCircular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 27 June burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.947 (19h07m47s.2)\n\nDec. = +9.362 (+9:21:41)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.6 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <200 ms. A total of 1084 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~2 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >3 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >100 x Crab flux).\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993698624000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Derek Fox at CIT  <derekfox@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB010921 Optical Observations","circularId":1099,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1099....1F","body":"D. Frail at NRAO  <dfrail@nrao.edu>","subject":"SGR 1900+14, Chandra observations","circularId":1047,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1047....1F","body":"D. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report on behalf of a larger\ncollaboration\"\n\n\"In response to the 18 April 2001 flare of SGR 1900+14 (GCN 1041) the\nChandra X-ray Observatory has undertaken a sequence of two public\n20-ksec observations of this source, on 22 and 30 April 2001.\n\nThe first observation began at 04:58 UT on 22 April and was taken in\ncontinuous-clocking mode (see also GCN 1046).  Examination of the\nlight curve reveals that at least one burst was observed, 9081 s after\nthe start of the observation.  Assuming the best-fit spectral\nparameters for the observation (see below), the peak 1-s flux of this\nburst was of order 5e-10 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (0.5-10 keV).\n\nSpectral fits to the full background-subtracted data set allow for at\nleast two emission models.  A power-law plus absorption model has\nbest-fit parameters of N_H = 3.18(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha =\n2.70(1), and unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of 4.20(4)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1.\nA power-law plus blackbody and absorption model has best-fit\nparameters of N_H = 2.56(2)e22 cm^-2, photon index alpha = 1.88(1),\nblackbody temperature kT = 0.532(3) keV, unabsorbed 0.5-10 keV flux of\n2.17(3)e-11 erg cm^-2 s^-1, and flux fraction for the blackbody\ncomponent of 29% (0.5-10 keV).  The addition of the blackbody\ncomponent is not supported by an F-test (65% confidence level) but is\nconsistent with models in the literature (Perna et al. 2001,\nastro-ph/0103273).  Analysis of the RXTE PCA data may help to clarify\nthe presence or absence of the blackbody component, as the PCA count\nrates inferred from the two models given above differ by 50%.\n\nNo narrow spectral features are apparent.  The two-sigma upper limit\nto the flux of a persistent 0.2-keV FWHM emission line in the 5-7 keV\nrange is 1e-5 photons cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThis message may be cited.\"","createdOn":988083484000,"email":"dfrail@nrao.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paul Price at RSAA, ANU at CIT  <pap@srl.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB 010326B: Optical observations","circularId":1020,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1020....1P","body":"P.A. Hjorth, M. I. Andersen, H. Pedersen, A. O. Jaunsen on behalf of the NOT \nGRB team and E. Costa & E. Palazzi on behalf of the SAX GRB team report:\n\nOn June 13.9 UT and June 17.9 UT we obtained R band images (600 sec each, \nseeing FWHM=0.7\") of the BeppoSAX error circle of GRB 980613 (Piro & Costa, \nGCN #99) with the 2.5-m Nordic Optical Telescope. The source is located at \n(+- 0.5\"):\n\nRA(J2000)  =  10 17 57.64\nDec(J2000) = +71 27 26.4\n\nPreliminary photometry (Cousins R) of the source yields:\n\nJune 13.8897 UT: R = 22.9+-0.2\nJune 17.9088 UT: R > 24.0 (formal 10-sigma limit)\n\nThese numbers assume R=19.11 for USNO catalogue entry U1575-03105992 located at \nRA(J2000)=10 17 54.83, Dec(2000)=+71 27 39.8, consistent with the photometry \nof the isolated star 4_r of Odewahn et al. Woods (USRA/NSSTC), C. Kouveliotou (NASA/MSFC), and E. Gogus\n(UAH/NSSTC) report on behalf of a larger collaboration.\n\nToO observations of SGR 1900+14 with the Rossi XTE were initiated on\nApril 19, 2001 and have continued through April 28.  Thus far, more\nthan 60 bursts have been detected in ~110 ks of exposure time. \nCoincidentally, a short (~10 ks) observation of SGR 1900+14 was\nperformed on April 14 (4 days prior to the flare) as part of our\nongoing monitoring campaign.  We find no burst activity within this\nobservation.  For the latest observation on April 28, 4 bursts were\nrecorded in one RXTE orbit, thus the source remains burst active.\n\nSelecting a 6 day subset of these observations for which we have\nspacecraft ephemeris information, we have phase connected the data and\nmeasured both a period and period derivative.  We chose our epoch (MJD\n52021.3 TDB) to coincide with the first Chandra observation.  We\nmeasure a barycentric period of 5.1728219(14) s where the number given\nin the parentheses marks the 1 sigma error in the least significant\ndigits.  The period derivative is found to be +1.58(22) X 10E-10 s/s. \nThe ephemeris we find agrees well with the measured periods reported\nfor both the Chandra (GCN #1049) and BeppoSAX (GCN #1055)\nobservations.  Furthermore, the magnitude of the spindown found here\nis well within the range of historical spindown rates measured for\nthis SGR.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988650865000,"email":"peter.woods@msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Chryssa Kouveliotou at MSFC  <kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"Chandra Observations of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1048,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10048....1R","body":"C. Kouveliotou, A. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on behalf\nof a larger SGR collaboration:\n\nWe have examined our overlapping Chandra/RXTE observations of SGR 1900+14\n(RXTE TOO, P. Woods, PI). We cannot verify the burst reported in GCN #1047. \nThe source was occulted by the earth at the time in question.\n\nWe confirm the burst in the Chandra data at approximately 7:15:25 UT. The burst \nduration appeared to be 0.35 seconds during which 14 counts were recorded \n(ignoring pile-up). Thus the peak count rate was 65 times the quiescent rate.\nAdopting the quiescent source spectrum (GCN # 1046), we estimate the peak flux \nin the 2-10 keV band to be 7.2 x 10^-10 ergs/cm^2 s (2.9 x 10^-9 ergs/cm^2 s in \n0.5-10.0 keV).\n\nWe would like to add a clarification regarding the persistent source flux  \nvalues in the two GCNs (1046, 1047). Our flux estimates are for the 2-10  \nkeV band to facilitate comparison with data from other satellites; when we  \nexpand the energy range to 0.5-10 keV (as in GCN 1047) we find similar  \nvalues for the quiescent flux.\n\nThis message can be cited.\n\n_____________________________________________\nChryssa Kouveliotou\nNSSTC, SD-50, Rm 2057\n320 Sparkman Drive,\nHuntsville, AL 35805\ntel: 256 961 7604 fax: 256 961 7215","createdOn":988150068000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Dimple Panchal at ARIES, India  <dimplepanchal96@gmail.com>","subject":"GRB 220101A: 1.3m DFOT observations","circularId":31384,"bibcode":"2022GCN.31384....1G","body":"Dimple, Ankur Ghosh, Rahul Gupta, Amit Kumar, Amit Ror,  Alaxender Panchal,\nKuntal Misra and S. Rol, I. Salamanca, L. Kaper, P. Vreeswijk (University of\nAmsterdam), N. Tanvir (University of Hertfordshire), report on behalf\nof a larger collaboration:\n\n\nIn order to verify the possible counterpart to GRB010214 (Rol et al.,\nGCN 955), we obtained another set of images with the Isaac Newton\nTelescope on February 21, 2001. Examination and comparison of these\nimages with those obtained at the INT on February 17 shows no evidence\nfor a further fading of the possible counterpart, as already suggested\nin other reports (Gorosabel et al., GCN 972; Klose et al., GCN 997;\nFynbo, private comm.). Ferrara and TESRE/CNR, Bologna)\nand E. Mazets (IOFFE, S. Petersburg), report:\n\n\"A high-time resolution analysis has been performed of the BeppoSAX\nWide Field Camera data of SGR 1900+14 taken on April 18, 2001, when\nthe most recent giant flare was detected (Guidorzi et al., GCN 1041\nand IAUC 7611). The data cover a short intermediate pointing of Wide\nField Camera unit 1 between two scheduled targets. The observation\nstarted 2780 s before the giant flare and ended with the automatic\nswitch off due to that flare. The observation was interrupted when\nBeppoSAX traversed the SAA, from 2282 till 1052 s before the\ngiant flare. The analysis revealed the presence of 3 short X-ray\nprecursors, occurring 2537, 755, and 444 s before the giant flare\n(respectively, 25975, 27757 and 28068 s UT), with durations of 100,\n125 and 55 ms, peak fluxes in excess of 20 Crab units (2-28 keV),\nand 9-28/2-9 keV spectral hardness ratios that are consistent with\npower laws with photon indices between roughly 0.5 and 1.2. None of the\nprecursors was detected in the gamma-ray data from the BeppoSAX/GRBM,\nthe gamma-ray burst detector on Ulysses, and from Konus on Wind.\"","createdOn":988997172000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Srikanta Sinha at ISRO/ISAC  <sinha@isac.ernet.in>","subject":"GRB010427, Gamma Ray Observations","circularId":1058,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10058....1P","body":"S.Sinha,P.Sreekumar,K.Kasturirangan, on behalf of SROSS C-2 (INDIAN GRB \nEXPERIMENT) team report:\n         \n      SROSS C-2 observed this burst at 67456.453 secs U.T (this time is \nnot corrected for some systematic errors). Ricker (MIT), on behalf of the HETE Team, reports:\n\nOver the past few weeks, the number of X-ray bursts (XRBs) reported \nby HETE has been gradually increasing, reaching ~10 per day during \nthe past 2-3 days. This seeming storm of XRBs is being produced by an \nensemble of ~10 distinct XRB sources, which are optimally placed in \nthe HETE field-of-view (FOV) for detectability.\n\nThis dramatic overall increase is due to two factors: 1) Improvements \nin the on-board detection algorithm, resulting from lowered trigger \nthresholds and increased numbers of trigger time scales being \nactivated; 2) Sco X-1 has moved out of the HETE instruments' FOV, \ngreatly reducing the overall background, thus improving the \ninstruments' burst detection efficiency.\n\n(NB: Despite the flurry of XRBs, soft gamma repeaters [SGR] and \ngamma-ray bursts [GRB] positions are now being, and will continue to \nbe, reported for events which trigger the high energy bands of the \nFREGATE instrument directly.)\n\nMany of the faint XRB detections are near threshold, and thus their \nonboard localization is unreliable. In order not to saturate rapid \nresponse telescopes and observing programs which primarily target \nSGRs and GRBs, these XRB events are being reported to the GCN with no \npositions. (In fact, reliable positions are subsequently established \nby the WXM ground software for a large fraction of these XRB events.) \nA  refined reporting algorithm, which will more clearly distinguish \nfainter, poorly-localized XRBs from brighter, well-localized XRBs \nwill be implemented in the near future. In the meantime, the XRB \n\"alert only\" reports will continue.  Beginning in late August, when \nthe Galactic Bulge Region moves out of HETE's FOV, we anticipate a \nprecipitous drop in the reported XRB rate.","createdOn":996527165000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"SGR1806-20: Localization by HETE","circularId":1068,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1068....1R","body":"SGR1806-20: Localization by HETE\n\nG. Connaughton (UAH) report for the Fermi LAT and GBM teams:\n\nFurther analysis of GRB 090902B (Bissaldi et al. GCN 9866, de Palma et al.\n GCN 9867, Kennea et al. GCN 9868) reveals it is detected in the Fermi\nLarge Area Telescope (LAT) at least until 300 s after the Fermi\nGamma-Ray Burst Monitor (GBM) trigger time, T0=11:05:08.31 UT.\n\nSpectral analysis of the main emission episode, from T0 to T0+25 s, shows a\ndeviation from the Band function obtained from fitting GBM data between\n50 keV and 40 MeV (GCN 9866). This deviation is apparent both below 50\nkeV in the GBM and above 100 MeV in the LAT. It is well-fit by a single\npower-law, with a well-constrained index that is retrieved from a fit of \nthe\nGBM data alone, the LAT data alone, and when jointly fitting the entire\ndata set.\n\nThe parameters for this multi-component fit are Band_alpha =\n0.61 � 0.01, Band_beta = 3.87 � 0.16, Band_EPeak = 798 � 7 keV,\nand a power-law index of 1.94 � 0.01 that shows no evidence for a\nspectral cut-off below 100 GeV. The fluence between 8 keV and 30\nGeV is 4.86 � 0.06 x 10-4 ergs/cm2.\n\nThe points of contact for this burst are:\n\nFrancesco de Palma (francesco.depalma@ba.infn.it) and\nElisabetta Bissaldi (ebs@mpe.mpg.de).\n\nThe Fermi LAT is a pair conversion telescope designed to cover the\nenergy band from 20 MeV to greater than 300 GeV.\nIt is the product of an international collaboration between NASA and DOE\nin the U.S. and many scientific institutions across France, Italy, Japan\nand Sweden.\n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":1251963402000,"email":"valerie@nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Vladimir Lipunov at Moscow State U/Krylov Obs  <lipunov@xray.sai.msu.ru>","subject":"IceCube Alert 220220.60:NuEm-220220A: MASTER optical possible counterpart","circularId":31620,"bibcode":"2022GCN.31620....1B","body":"O.Gress & N.M. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 23:24:18.3 UT (84253.3s UT) on 27 June, the HETE FREGATE and WXM \ninstruments detected and localized an intense burst from SGR1900+14, \na soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the second burst localized \nfrom this source in the past week, indicating that it may have \nresumed an active state. (The first burst was reported in GCN \nCircular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 27 June burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.947 (19h07m47s.2)\n\nDec. = +9.362 (+9:21:41)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.6 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <200 ms. A total of 1084 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~2 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >3 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >100 x Crab flux).\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993698624000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Paul Price at RSAA, ANU at CIT  <pap@srl.caltech.edu>","subject":"GRB 010326A: Further optical observations","circularId":1022,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1022....1P","body":"P.A. Saracco, G. Chincarini, S. Covino, G. Ghisellini, M. Longhetti, F.\nZerbi\n(Osservatorio Astronomico di Brera, Merate, Italy)\nD. Lazzati (Institute of Astronomy,Cambridge, UK)\nP. Severgnini (Osservatorio Astronomico di Arcetri, Firenze, Italy)\n\nWe have obtained twelve 540-second dithered images in the Rc (Bessell)\nband centered on the position of  GRB 990705. These images have been\nobtained  from  20th to 28th December 2000 at the ESO-VLT UT1 telescope\nwith FORS1 as a part of a survey of host galaxies (Saracco et al. 2000;\nProg. ID: 66.B-0539(A)).\n\nObservations have been carried out under seeing conditions of 0.6-0.7\narcsec.\nThe limiting magnitude reached on the final coadded image is Rc=26.6\n(3 sigmas within the seeing disk).\nWe confirm the presence of a late-type (Sc) galaxy located at the\nposition of\nGRB 990705 as previously found by Holland et al. (2000; GCN #753).\n\nWe measure a magnitude Rc=22.2(+-0.1) (galactic extinction A(R)=0.2)\nwithin an aperture radius of 2 arcsec.\nConsidering the V-band aperture magnitude obtained by Holland et al.\n(GCN #753) we estimate for the host galaxy a color V-Rc=0.6(+-0.2).\nGiven the large uncertainty in this estimate, such a color is\nconsistent with that of an Sc galaxy  at redshift z<1.3.\n\nThis message can be cited.\n\n\n--\nPaolo Saracco\nOsservatorio Astronomico di Brera\nVia E. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 03:34:06.53 UTC (12846.53 s UT) on 2 July, the HETE FREGATE and \nWXM instruments detected and localized an intense burst from \nSGR1900+14, a soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the highest \nfluence burst yet detected by HETE from SGR1900+14 during its current \nepisode of activity. (The first burst in the current series was \nreported in GCN Circular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 2 \nJuly burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.846 (19h07m23s.1)\n\nDec. =  +9.344 (+9o20'40\")\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~4 s. A total of 44000 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >7 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >200 x Crab flux) over a duration of \n10 ms.\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":994051790000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Aaron Zimmerman at U. of Texas at Austin <aaron.zimmerman@utexas.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S231224e: Updated Sky localization and Source Classification","circularId":35424,"bibcode":"2023GCN.35424....1Z","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) and LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S231224e (GCN Circular 35423). The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], PyCBC Live [4], and SPIIR [5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231206cc is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.9e-35 Hz, or about one in 1e27 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231206cc\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), BNS (<1%), or Terrestrial (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [6] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [6] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 30 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,2, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,2. H. Ishwara Chandra (NCRA, Pune),\nD. Bhattacharya (RRI, Bangalore) and A.J. Castro-Tirado (IAA, Granada)\nreport on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nThe afterglow of GRB030329 (Peterson & Price, GCN 1985) was observed\nwith the GMRT for about 5 hours on May 31, 2003. The observations were at\n1288  MHz with a bandwidth of 12MHz and effective angular resolution of\n~3.5\". The flux density of the source seen at the position of the GRB on\n31 March and 01 April 2003 (Rao et al, GCN 2073) has increased to 1.1 mJy\nconfirming that the radio source is related to the GRB.\n\nThe details of the GMRT measurements of GRB030329 at 1288 MHz:\n\nDate                        Time               Flux Density\n\n31 May 2003                14-18 UT         1100+/-150 microJy\n31 March/01 April 2003     14-22 UT          330+/-100 microJy\n\nThe quoted error bars are 2-sigma, and include systematic errors of\ncalibration.\n\nNote that the flux density at 31 March/01 April epoch has been\nrevised upwards in comparison to that reported in GCN 2073,\nfollowing a better absolute flux density calibration.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":1054720826000,"email":"dipankar@rri.res.in"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Chryssa Kouveliotou at MSFC  <kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"Chandra Observations of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1046,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1046....1K","body":"C.Kouveliotou, A. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on\nbehalf of a large SGR collaboration:\n\nChandra observed the newly active (GCN #1041) Soft Gamma Repeater,\nSGR 1900+14, on April 22, 2001 starting at 4:45 UT, for 20,000 seconds.\nThe ACIS S3 observation mode was Continuous Clocking (CC). We have fitted a\nspectrum to the whole data set; we find the best fit to be a single power law\nwith spectral (photon) index of 2.9 +/- 0.1 and a hydrogen column density (NH)\nof (3.4 +/- 0.1)x10^22 cm^-2. We detect no black body contribution in \nthe spectrum.  The source (unabsorbed) flux is 1.1x10^-11 ergs/cm^2 s\n(2-10 keV), nearly identical to the quiescent source flux level.\nThe pulse period is 5.1725 s (barycenter corrected); the pulse profile\nappears sinusoidal.\n\nMore detailed analysis and comparison with RXTE simultaneous \nobservations is underway.","createdOn":988070436000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Alain Klotz at IRAP-CNRS-OMP  <Alain.Klotz@free.fr>","subject":"GRB 160821A: Maisoncelles observatory optical observations","circularId":20007,"bibcode":"2016GCN.20007....1S","body":"Soulier J.-F. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 15:06:36.51 (54396.51s) UTC on 28 June, the HETE FREGATE and WXM \ninstruments detected and localized an intense burst from SGR1900+14, \na soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the third burst reported \nfrom this source in the past week, and the second one reported by \nHETE on 28 June. (The previous HETE burst was reported in GCN \nCircular #1073.) The coordinates (J2000) of the burst localized by \nHETE are:\n\nR.A. = 286.803 deg. (19h07m12s.62)\n\nDec. =  +9.340 deg. (+9:20:22)\n\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 24 arcmin in radius.\nSGR1900+14 lies 6.2 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~400 ms. A total of 4700\ncounts above background were detected during that interval,\ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux\nwas ~4 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >150 x Crab flux) during a 5 ms interval.\n\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993745828000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010921 (=H1761)","circularId":1097,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10097....1G","body":"K. The candidate was found by the GstLAL [1] analysis pipeline.\n\nS231231ag is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 8.4e-15 Hz, or about one in 1e7 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231231ag\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), NSBH (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [2] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [2] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 27 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. The photometric conditions were good with a seeing of about 1.3 arcsec. \nWe have obtained three 180-s R-band images with the SCORPIO instrument\n(http://www.sao.ru/~moisav/scorpio/scorpio.html) at the 6-m telescope of SAO\nRAS.
