Spectroscopic observations (12 x 600-s \nexposures) were obtained with the 300 lines/mm grating giving a spectral \nresolution (FWHM) of about 20 A and an effective wavelength coverage of \n3500 - 9500 A. The slit was placed along the extended object. The analysis \nrevealed that the object is double with a spectra showing the continua\nwith clearly detected Balmer break. The redshift for each component is:\n\nObject A:  z = 0.398 +/- 0.002, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           O[III] 4959,5007AA emission lines (brighter component)\n\n\nObject B:  z = 0.3399 +/- 0.0005, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           Hbeta 4861AA, emission lines (fainter component)\n\nIf the radio transient is related to GRB 001109 indeed, then this is the\nnearest host galaxy detected so far.\n\nThe R-band image can be seen at:\nhttp://www.sao.ru/~sokolov/GRB/HOSTS/GRB001109/GRB001109.html\n\nThis message may be cited\".\n\n-Vladimir Sokolov, on behalf of the RAS Special Astrophysical Observatory\nGRB followup team.","createdOn":999934127000,"email":"sokolov@sao.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Giangiacomo Gandolfi at IAS/CNR Frascati  <gandolfi@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"GRB010518: a faint BeppoSAX detection","circularId":1062,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10062....1M","body":"C. On \ncomparing these frames we don't find any new fading object down to a limiting \nmagnitude of R ~ 21.0.\n\nThis message may be cited.\"","createdOn":987501235000,"email":"vijay@upso.ernet.in"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"Dramatic Increase in the Rate of X-ray Bursts Reported by HETE","circularId":1084,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1084....1R","body":"Dramatic Increase in the Rate of X-ray Bursts Reported by HETE\n\nG. Ricker (MIT), on behalf of the HETE Team, reports:\n\nOver the past few weeks, the number of X-ray bursts (XRBs) reported \nby HETE has been gradually increasing, reaching ~10 per day during \nthe past 2-3 days. This seeming storm of XRBs is being produced by an \nensemble of ~10 distinct XRB sources, which are optimally placed in \nthe HETE field-of-view (FOV) for detectability.\n\nThis dramatic overall increase is due to two factors: 1) Improvements \nin the on-board detection algorithm, resulting from lowered trigger \nthresholds and increased numbers of trigger time scales being \nactivated; 2) Sco X-1 has moved out of the HETE instruments' FOV, \ngreatly reducing the overall background, thus improving the \ninstruments' burst detection efficiency.\n\n(NB: Despite the flurry of XRBs, soft gamma repeaters [SGR] and \ngamma-ray bursts [GRB] positions are now being, and will continue to \nbe, reported for events which trigger the high energy bands of the \nFREGATE instrument directly.)\n\nMany of the faint XRB detections are near threshold, and thus their \nonboard localization is unreliable. In order not to saturate rapid \nresponse telescopes and observing programs which primarily target \nSGRs and GRBs, these XRB events are being reported to the GCN with no \npositions. (In fact, reliable positions are subsequently established \nby the WXM ground software for a large fraction of these XRB events.) \nA  refined reporting algorithm, which will more clearly distinguish \nfainter, poorly-localized XRBs from brighter, well-localized XRBs \nwill be implemented in the near future. In the meantime, the XRB \n\"alert only\" reports will continue.  Beginning in late August, when \nthe Galactic Bulge Region moves out of HETE's FOV, we anticipate a \nprecipitous drop in the reported XRB rate.","createdOn":996527165000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Josh Bloom at CIT  <jsb@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"HETE Trigger #1760 (GRB 010920B?): a new optical source","circularId":1094,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1094....1B","body":"J. extended X-ray emission","circularId":1049,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1049....1F","body":"D. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Analysis of data from the 22 April 2001 Chandra observation (GCN\n1046, 1047), barycenter-corrected with the preliminary CXC ephemeris,\nreveals that the source emission is pulsed at a period of P =\n5.17288(5) s with a pulse strength of 14.3(2)% RMS that remains\nconstant (within errors) throughout the observation.  Separation of\nthe source photons into \"on-pulse\" and \"off-pulse\" components of 1/3\ncycle each reveals that the off-pulse spatial distribution is\nsignificantly broader than the on-pulse distribution.  Since the\nobservation is taken in continuous-clocking mode, we can only make\nthis determination in one dimension.  Nonetheless, the sigma-widths of\nthe one-dimensional Gaussian PSFs are 0.98(1) arcsec for on-pulse\nphotons and 1.08(2) arcsec for off-pulse photons, different at\n>5-sigma level.  We attribute this difference in widths to the\npresence of an underlying X-ray nebula.\"","createdOn":988243520000,"email":"derekfox@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 03:34:06.53 UTC (12846.53 s UT) on 2 July, the HETE FREGATE and \nWXM instruments detected and localized an intense burst from \nSGR1900+14, a soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the highest \nfluence burst yet detected by HETE from SGR1900+14 during its current \nepisode of activity. (The first burst in the current series was \nreported in GCN Circular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 2 \nJuly burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.846 (19h07m23s.1)\n\nDec. =  +9.344 (+9o20'40\")\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~4 s. A total of 44000 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >7 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >200 x Crab flux) over a duration of \n10 ms.\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":994051790000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Filippo Frontera at U. of Ferrara, Physics Dept  <frontera@fe.infn.it>","subject":"SGR1900+14 burst seen by HETE: BeppoSAX data","circularId":1081,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1081....1M","body":"E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi and F. Frontera, Physics Dept., University of\nFerrara, Italy; F. Calura, Astronomy Dept., University of Trieste; M.\nFeroci, IAS, CNR, Rome, Italy, report:\n\nThe short burst from SGR1900+14 detected by HETE (GCN # 1078) was also\ndetected by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor aboard BeppoSAX. The burst\ntriggered the GRBM on board logic at 03:34:07.15 UT of July 2, 2001. The\nevent duration was about 2 s.\n\nThe event showed significant flux only in the 40-100 keV energy band. The\ntotal counts above the background level in this range were 400 +/- 50. \nAssuming a power law spectral shape, from our data we can set a lower\nlimit to the photon index of 3.5. With a photon index of 4.0, the derived\nfluence is (1.2+/- 0.2) x 10-6 erg cm-2 in the band from 40 to 100 keV. \nUsing the high time resolution data only available in the 40-700 keV band,\nthe peak flux obtained from 125 ms bins corresponds to (1.4 +/- 0.4)x10-6\nerg cm-2 s-1. \n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":994267010000,"email":"frontera@fe.infn.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Peter Shawhan at U of Maryland/LSC  <pshawhan@umd.edu>","subject":"LIGO/Virgo S190602aq: Identification of a GW compact binary merger candidate","circularId":24717,"bibcode":"2019GCN.24717....1T","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration and the Virgo Collaboration report:\n\nWe identified the compact binary merger candidate S190602aq during\nreal-time processing of data from LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1), LIGO\nLivingston Observatory (L1), and Virgo Observatory (V1) at 2019-06-02\n17:59:27.089 UTC (GPS time: 1243533585.089). The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S190602aq\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending\nprobability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), NSBH (<1%),\nor MassGap (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, there is strong\nevidence against the lighter compact object having a mass < 3 solar\nmasses (HasNS: <1%). Using the masses and spins inferred from the\nsignal, there is strong evidence against matter outside the final\ncompact object (HasRemnant: <1%).\n\nOne skymap is available at this time and can be retrieved from the\nGraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.fits.gz, an updated localization generated by BAYESTAR\n[6], distributed via GCN notice about 6 minutes after the candidate\n\nFor the bayestar.fits.gz skymap, the 90% credible region is 1172 deg2.\nMarginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance\nestimate is 797 +/- 238 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard\ndeviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of\nthis alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo Public Alerts User Guide\n<https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/userguide/>.\n\n [1] Nitz et al. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB000418:  HST/STIS Second-epoch Observations","circularId":1061,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10061....1L","body":"A. Fruchter and M. Metzger report for a larger HST GRB Collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000418 was re-observed by the Hubble Space Telescope\nstarting on UT 2001 Feb 11.64 using the STIS camera in open (50CCD)\nmode.  The individual exposures were combined using Drizzle for a total\nexposure time of 5120 s.\n\nWhen this image is subtracted from that obtained by HST on 2000 June\n4.17 a small residual of magnitude R~28 is found at the position of the\ncompact galaxy believed to be the host galaxy (GCN 669); however, the\nresidual is sufficiently faint to be consistent with no detection at\nabout the 2 sigma level.  Taking into account the varying brightness of\nthe host galaxy we find an upper limit to the brightness of the OT on\n2000 June 4.2 of R > 27.5.\n\nThis upper limit on the R-band flux implies that the decay of the\noptical transient steepened to at least t ^ -1.75 to -2 at late times,\nin agreement with the result obtainted primarily from radio data by\nBerger et al (20001, astro-ph/0102278).\n\nThe images of the STIS field, with transient location indicated, can be\nseen at http://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/000418.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":989703442000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"SGR1806-20: A Second, Intense Burst Localized by HETE","circularId":1070,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1070....1R","body":"SGR1806-20: A Second, Intense Burst Localized by HETE\n\nG. This event, disseminated in near real time as a \nGCN Alert (HETE BID_1566; see \nhttp://gcn.gsfc.nasa.gov/gcn/hete_grbs.html), is the second burst \nlocalized from this source in the past week. (The first burst was \nreported in GCN Circular #1068). The coordinates (J2000) of the 23 \nJune burst are:\n\nR.A. = 272.1460 deg. (18h08m35s.02)\n\nDec. = -20.3658 deg. (-20:21:56)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 6 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1806-20 lies 3.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~200 ms, comprised of two \npeaks each <100ms in duration. A total of 2250 counts were detected \nduring that interval, corresponding to a fluence of ~4 x 10-7 ergs \ncm-2 . The peak flux was >6 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s (ie >200 x Crab flux).\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993320504000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Sylvio Klose at TLS Tautenburg  <klose@tls-tautenburg.de>","subject":"SGR1900+14, I-band observations","circularId":1044,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10044....1C","body":"S. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, G. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 08:33:12 UTC (=30792s UT), a soft spectrum, high \nenergy transient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized \nby HETE.\n(NB: This is the second GRB detected by HETE on 26 March 2001.)\n\nBoth the WXM and the FREGATE instruments detected the event. The \nburst triggered FREGATE in the 6-120 keV band, at the 160ms timescale.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h24m23.36s, \nDec. = -11o09'57\", derived from combining data from the WXM and \nBoresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the WXM \nlocalization is 18 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we estimate \na systematic error radius at present of 10 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 30 \narcsec (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~4 Crab; with WXM \n(2-25 keV), ~2 Crab. The burst duration was about 4 seconds.\n\nThe high galactic latitude of the source, well away from the Galactic \nBulge, and the shape of its spectrum suggest that it is a gamma-ray \nburst similar to those reported for \"X-ray rich\" GRBs by Heise et al \n(2001) from BeppoSAX observations.\n\nFollow-up observations of this unusual transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on the GRB010326B (including light curves), as \nwell as for the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985612698000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"Probable SGR or Short Duration GRB Detected by HETE","circularId":1089,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1089....1R","body":"Probable SGR or Short Duration GRB Detected by HETE\n\nG. This event \nwas promptly distributed as a GCN Notice (HETE BID_1715). No signal \nwas detected in the WXM, indicating that the event was likely to \nbe >40 degrees from the anti-sun direction. For the current HETE \npointing direction, SGR1900+14 is about 48 degrees off the boresight, \nwhile SGR1806-20 is about 56 degrees off the boresight, so that \neither could be a candidate.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~200 ms. A total of 500\ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence\nof ~9 x 10-8 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux was >2 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >50 x Crab flux) over a duration of 30 ms.\n\nA search for this event in the archives of other GRB instruments is \nencouraged. It had a duration\nof ~2 s, a 25-100 keV fluence of 2.8 x 10^-6 erg/cm^2, and a peak flux\nover 0.25 s of 3.9x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s.  Triangulation gives an annulus\ncentered at RA(2000), Decl(2000) = 17.530 deg, +33.050 deg, with radius\n85.548 +/- 0.027 deg.  The center line of this annulus passes ~0.018\ndeg from SGR1900+14. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi,\nF. Frontera, and M. Feroci, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM team, report:\n\nWe have identified a likely precursor to the giant flare from\nSGR1900+14 (GCN 1041, 1043) in the Ulysses data.  This event\noccurred on April 17, 2001, ~42184 s at Ulysses, and if it was\nindeed from SGR1900+14, its Earth-crossing time would have\nbeen ~42332 s.  This burst was ~50 s long, and its time history\nresembles that of the April 18 event, although it is considerably\nless intense.  Its 25-100 keV fluence was ~2.3x10^-5 erg/cm^2,\nand its peak flux over 0.5 s was ~1.5x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s.  Due to\na high solar proton background, these numbers are subject to more\nthan the usual uncertainties.  As SGR1900+14 was Earth-blocked\nat BeppoSAX, it did not observe this event, and there is no\nlocalization data available.\n\nThe time history has been posted at ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010417.\nAlso, we note that the time history of the April 18 event, posted\nat ssl.berkeley.edu/ipn3/010418, was incorrectly labelled \"Counts/\n0.5 s\".  The label should have read \"Counts/Second\". Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 15:54:53.123 UT on 23 June, the HETE FREGATE and WXM instruments \ndetected and localized an intense burst from SGR1806-20, a soft \ngamma-ray repeater. This event, disseminated in near real time as a \nGCN Alert (HETE BID_1566; see \nhttp://gcn.gsfc.nasa.gov/gcn/hete_grbs.html), is the second burst \nlocalized from this source in the past week. (The first burst was \nreported in GCN Circular #1068). The coordinates (J2000) of the 23 \nJune burst are:\n\nR.A. = 272.1460 deg. (18h08m35s.02)\n\nDec. = -20.3658 deg. (-20:21:56)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 6 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1806-20 lies 3.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~200 ms, comprised of two \npeaks each <100ms in duration. A total of 2250 counts were detected \nduring that interval, corresponding to a fluence of ~4 x 10-7 ergs \ncm-2 . The peak flux was >6 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s (ie >200 x Crab flux).\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), A. Smith (Rice University) and R. P. J. Tilanus (Joint Astronomy Centre) \nreport on behalf of the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope (JCMT) GRB collaboration:\n \nWe used the SCUBA sub-millimeter continuum bolometer array on the JCMT to \nobserve the variable radio source VLA J0702+3850 proposed by Taylor et al. \n(GCN #40) as the radio afterglow to GRB 980329.\n \nOn UT 1998 April 5.2 we detected a source at 850 microns with a preliminary \nflux density of 5 +/- 1.5 mJy.  This source was confirmed on April 6.2 with \na flux density of 4 +/- 1.2 mJy, resulting in an average of 4.5 +/- 1 mJy \nover the two days.  The 850 micron source is present in all our separate \nintegrations making us confident it is real.  A hint of a fading trend \nappears to be confirmed by observations on April 7.2 when the (preliminary)\n850 micron flux density was 2 +/- 0.8 mJy. \n\nThe source was not detected at 450 microns with a preliminary rms of 10.0 \nmJy averaged over the first two days.\n\nAssuming these fluxes are due to the burst counterpart, they should represent\n\"clean\" measures of its intensity, unaffected by scintillation and extinction.  \nMonitoring with SCUBA is continuing.\n\nWe wish to thank Dr. L. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on\nbehalf of a large SGR collaboration:\n\nChandra observed the newly active (GCN #1041) Soft Gamma Repeater,\nSGR 1900+14, on April 22, 2001 starting at 4:45 UT, for 20,000 seconds.\nThe ACIS S3 observation mode was Continuous Clocking (CC). We have fitted a\nspectrum to the whole data set; we find the best fit to be a single power law\nwith spectral (photon) index of 2.9 +/- 0.1 and a hydrogen column density (NH)\nof (3.4 +/- 0.1)x10^22 cm^-2. We detect no black body contribution in \nthe spectrum. The peak flux measured by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor, \nafter background subtraction and no dead time correction, is around 15400\nc/s. The flare has an approximate duration of 40 s. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB000301C: Late-time HST/STIS observation","circularId":1063,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10063....1M","body":"A. Fruchter and P. Vreeswijk report for a larger collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000301c was reobserved by the Hubble Space Telescope\nusing the STIS camera in open (50CCD) mode on the 25 Feb 2001, or\nnearly one year after outburst.   Twelve dithered exposures were\ncombined to produce a final image with an exposure time of 7031s.\n\nNo source is immediately visible at the position of the GRB.  However,\nwhen the image is convolved with gaussians or boxcars with\ncharacteristic sizes from that of the PSF, 0.\"08, to 0.\"2, an extended\nobject appears to be visible under the position of the GRB and to its\nNE.  Although extended light from both a nearby bright star, and the\nlarger galaxy to the NW of the GRB make an exact determination of the\nsignificance of this object difficult, we believe this is approximately\na 3-4 sigma detection.  The probable host has an estimated magnitude of\nR = 28.0 +/- 0.3.  This magnitude is just consistent with the estimates\nof an underlying host from our earlier imaging, GCN 627 and 701.  It\nis, furthermore, about two magnitudes brighter than we would expect the\nOT to have been at this time, had it continued to decline with a\ntemporal power-law steeper than -2 (c.f. GCN 701 and  Rhoads and\nFruchter, ApJ 2001, 546, 177).\n\nIf this is indeed a detection of a host, then in all cases where we\nhave obtained a deep HST image and an OT is well localized (to ~0.\"1),\na host has been found under the GRB. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, reports:\n\nIn addition to observing the burst from SGR1806-20 on 2001 June 23\nat 57293 s UT (GCN 1070), Ulysses observed a later event whose\norigin is likely to be this same SGR.  This burst would have had\nan Earth-crossing time of 61056.8 s.  Its duration was ~0.032\ns, and its 25-100 keV fluence was ~2x10^-7 erg/cm^2.  It had\na peak flux over 0.032 s of ~6x10^-6 erg/cm^2 s. Frontera (on behalf of the BeppoSAX team)\n \nReport:\n \nWe have obtained K'-band images of a 10' x 10' region centred at the\nBSAX/WFC error box for GRB 980613, with the 3.5-m telescope (+ OMEGA) at the\nGerman-Spanish Calar Alto Observatory, on June 13.87-13.92 . R-band\nand I-band images were also obtained at the 1.23-m telescope on June \n13.88-14.00. No variable object, by more than 0.5 mag, is seen when \ncomparing the co-added R-band image with the POSS chart, down to R = 20.5.\n \n We notice however, the presence of a point-like object on several IR images, \nwith K' = 17.5 +/- 0.5 (very preliminary). The object is not seen on the\nR-band image (limiting magnitude R = 22), implying R-K' > 4. Its  position \nis AR(2000) = 10 18 23.15, Dec(2000) = +71 32 18.5 (+/- 1\"). Further IR\nand radio observations are encouraged in order to discern whether this is \nthe true IR counterpart to GRB 980613, resembling that of GRB 980329.","createdOn":897825389000,"email":"ajct@laeff.esa.es"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Scott Barthelmy at NASA/GSFC  <scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"GCN and HETE status","circularId":1085,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10085....1E","body":"INTRO:\nThere have been a lot of HETE triggers in the last week.  Many people\nare wondering what is going on.  This announcement attempts to explain\nthe recent developments.\n\nTRIGGERS:\nStarting about a week ago, the HETE Operations team resumed sending\nthe HETE messages from the s/c to GCN -- there were gaps due to HETE and due\nto GCN (the network problems).  And since the Galactic Center\nis still in the HETE FOV, this has caused a marked step increase\nin the amount of HETE Notices (from zero to several per day).\nThis increase has been further enhanced by the fact that Sco X-1 has left\nthe FOV of the HETE instruments two weeks ago.  The decrease in the background\ndue to the loss of Sco X-1 has increased the sensitivity to the the XRB\nsources in the Galactic Center.\n\nPOSITIONS:\nSince a larger fraction of these triggers is caused by X-ray Burst sources\nwhich are very weak, they produce poor image detections and therefore\nlocations with large uncertainites.  The HETE Operations team\nhas commanded the s/c to suppress the positions if the \"source\"\nin the image is not significant enough.  This results in the large\nnumber of Notices with no positions.\n\nFILTERING:\nI have changed the GCN filtering system to compensate for this change\nin the Notice content.  If there is no position in the S/C_Update,\nS/C_Last, or even the Gnd_Analysis messages, then they are NOT distributed\nthe sites requesting HETE Notices.  The reasoning is that with no position\ninformation in the Notice, what possible use could a follow-up observer\nmake of the notification.  This change was made Saturday, 28 Jul 01.\n\nTOO MANY ALERTS?\nHowever, the S/C_Alerts never were intended to have position information\n(except for rare instances (~10%)), so they are still being distributed\nto those sites that have requested the HETE S/C_Alert subtype.\nEven with the filtering of the U/L/GA's that have no positions, there are\nstill a large number of Alert Notices being distributed to sites.  If you feel\nthat you are receiving too many Alerts (that subsequently have no U/L/GA\nfollow-ups), then you might consider requesting that the Alert subtype\nbe disabled for your site.  (Or you might consider \"toughing it out\"\nfor another 4-6 weeks until the Galactic Center is no longer in the HETE FOV \nin which case the trigger rate should drop dramatically.)\n\nACTION ITEM:\nSites can:\n1) keep their current configurations,   or\n2) request that S/C_Alerts be disabled,   or\n3) request that S/C_Alerts/Updates/Lasts be disabled (say for the next month\nor so, and then request they be turned back on),   or\n4) request that all HETE subtypes (A/U/L/GA) be disabled (again for the next\nmonth or so).\nGiven the no-positions-filtering incorporated last Saturday, choice \"2\"\nseems like a reasonable approach if a site has any concern about \"too many\nNotices\".\n\nSincerely,\n\nScott Barthelmy\nNASA-GSFC\n301-286-3106\nscott@lheamail.gsfs.nasa.gov","createdOn":996530269000,"email":"scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Michael Bremer at IRAM Grenoble  <bremer@iram.fr>","subject":"Millimeter observation of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1050,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10050....1B","body":"Millimeter observations of SGR 1900+14\n----------------------------------------\nM. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Our earlier report of a pulse phase-variable PSF width in Chandra\nobservations of SGR 1900+14 (GCN 1049) was in error.  Appropriate\ntreatment of the background counts relative to source counts reveals\nthat the one-dimensional PSF is consistent with a Gaussian of fixed\nstandard deviation equal to 0.41(1) arcseconds throughout the pulse\nphase. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. The coordinates \n(J2000) of the 29 June burst are:\n\nR.A. = 248.158 deg. (16h32m38s.3)\n\nDec. =  -18.723 deg. (-18o43'24\")\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 15 arcmin in radius.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~20 s, with two peaks \nseparated by ~12 s. A total of ~11600 counts above background were \ndetected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence of ~2 x \n10-6 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux was >3 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >10 x \nCrab flux).\n\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993849476000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010613","circularId":1067,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10067....1L","body":"K. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 980326: Late-time HST/STIS observations","circularId":1029,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10029....1G","body":"Andrew Fruchter (STScI), Paul Vreeswijk (University of Amsterdam) and\nPeter Nugent (LBNL) report on behalf of a larger HST GRB collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 980326 with HST/STIS on 31 December 2000,\njust over 1000 days after the burst. The total exposure time was 7080\nseconds in the 50CCD aperture. The images were reduced by the standard\nHST pipeline, and drizzled to a combined image with a pixelscale of\n0.\"0254.\n\nWe projected the location of the early afterglow from a KeckII/LRIS R\nband image, taken by Filippenko, Leonard and Riess on March 27, 1998\n(see GCN 33).  We estimate the 1-sigma error radius to be less than 1.5\ndrizzled HST pixels, which includes both the scatter in the\ntransformation (0.9 pixels, using 6 reference stars) and the\nmeasurement error of the transient in the Keck image (0.8 pixels).\n\nWithin one pixel of the estimated position, there was evidence of a\nsmall source.  We therefore convolved the image with a gaussian with a\nFWHM equal to that of the PSF (3.5 drizzled pixels).  This procedure\nuses the PSF as a matched filter to enhance the the signal-to-noise\nratio of unresolved sources.  In the convolved image an object is\nfound, again offset by one pixel from the expected position with a\nsignificance of ~4.5 sigma.  We estimate a magnitude (in the broad STIS\n50ccd filter) of V = 29.25 +/- 0.25.\n\nBloom et al., (1999, Nature, 401, 453) have suggested that the unusual\nlight curve of this GRB might be explained by an underlying supernova,\nand on the basis of this estimated a redshift of about z~1.   A\nsupernova at this redshift (which in this model peaks around a\nmagnitude of 25) would be expected to be significantly fainter than\nV=29 by now (as would the rapidly decaying GRB afterglow).  Therefore,\nwe may be detecting a faint host galaxy.  Deep HST images have in all\nother cases detected a host underlying the GRB, when good astrometry\nwas available for the GRB.  If we are observing a host galaxy, then the\nabove magnitude could underestimate its brightness by as much as a few\ntenths of a magnitude, due to extended emission missed in this\nmeasurement.  A galaxy at a z~1 with this observed magnitude would lie\na rather remarkable 7 magnitudes below L*, the knee of the of the\ngalaxy luminosity function at that redshift.\n\nGiven the apparent point-source nature of the detected object, and the\nlack of color information, we cannot exclude the possibility (which we\nconsider remote) that we are observing a light echo, from either the\nGRB or the supernova.\n\nImages of the field can be found at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/980326","createdOn":985809183000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"SGR1900+14","circularId":1053,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1053....1H","body":"K. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and C. Guidorzi,\nE. Montanari, and F. Frontera, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM\nteam, report:\n\nThis burst (RXTE/ASM and GCN 1011) had a duration of\napproximately 15 seconds in 25-150 keV gamma-rays.  Its\nEarth-crossing time was ~41558 s, and its 25-100 keV\nfluence was ~1.8x10^-6 erg/cm^2; over 0.25 s, its peak\nflux was ~4.3x10^-7 erg/cm^2 s.  The latter numbers are\nuncertain by about a factor of 2 at present, but can\nprobably be refined with further processing.","createdOn":985540932000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Filippo Frontera at U. of Ferrara, Physics Dept  <frontera@fe.infn.it>","subject":"SGR1900+14 burst seen by HETE: BeppoSAX data","circularId":1081,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10081....1M","body":"E. Montanari, C. Guidorzi and F. Frontera, Physics Dept., University of\nFerrara, Italy; F. Calura, Astronomy Dept., University of Trieste; M.\nFeroci, IAS, CNR, Rome, Italy, report:\n\nThe short burst from SGR1900+14 detected by HETE (GCN # 1078) was also\ndetected by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor aboard BeppoSAX. The burst\ntriggered the GRBM on board logic at 03:34:07.15 UT of July 2, 2001. The\nevent duration was about 2 s.\n\nThe event showed significant flux only in the 40-100 keV energy band. The\ntotal counts above the background level in this range were 400 +/- 50. \nAssuming a power law spectral shape, from our data we can set a lower\nlimit to the photon index of 3.5. With a photon index of 4.0, the derived\nfluence is (1.2+/- 0.2) x 10-6 erg cm-2 in the band from 40 to 100 keV. \nUsing the high time resolution data only available in the 40-700 keV band,\nthe peak flux obtained from 125 ms bins corresponds to (1.4 +/- 0.4)x10-6\nerg cm-2 s-1. \n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":994267010000,"email":"frontera@fe.infn.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Scott Barthelmy at NASA/GSFC  <scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"GCN and HETE status","circularId":1085,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1085....1B","body":"INTRO:\nThere have been a lot of HETE triggers in the last week.  Many people\nare wondering what is going on.  This announcement attempts to explain\nthe recent developments.\n\nTRIGGERS:\nStarting about a week ago, the HETE Operations team resumed sending\nthe HETE messages from the s/c to GCN -- there were gaps due to HETE and due\nto GCN (the network problems).  And since the Galactic Center\nis still in the HETE FOV, this has caused a marked step increase\nin the amount of HETE Notices (from zero to several per day).\nThis increase has been further enhanced by the fact that Sco X-1 has left\nthe FOV of the HETE instruments two weeks ago.  The decrease in the background\ndue to the loss of Sco X-1 has increased the sensitivity to the the XRB\nsources in the Galactic Center.\n\nPOSITIONS:\nSince a larger fraction of these triggers is caused by X-ray Burst sources\nwhich are very weak, they produce poor image detections and therefore\nlocations with large uncertainites.  The HETE Operations team\nhas commanded the s/c to suppress the positions if the \"source\"\nin the image is not significant enough.  This results in the large\nnumber of Notices with no positions.\n\nFILTERING:\nI have changed the GCN filtering system to compensate for this change\nin the Notice content.  If there is no position in the S/C_Update,\nS/C_Last, or even the Gnd_Analysis messages, then they are NOT distributed\nthe sites requesting HETE Notices.  The reasoning is that with no position\ninformation in the Notice, what possible use could a follow-up observer\nmake of the notification.  This change was made Saturday, 28 Jul 01.\n\nTOO MANY ALERTS?\nHowever, the S/C_Alerts never were intended to have position information\n(except for rare instances (~10%)), so they are still being distributed\nto those sites that have requested the HETE S/C_Alert subtype.\nEven with the filtering of the U/L/GA's that have no positions, there are\nstill a large number of Alert Notices being distributed to sites.  If you feel\nthat you are receiving too many Alerts (that subsequently have no U/L/GA\nfollow-ups), then you might consider requesting that the Alert subtype\nbe disabled for your site.  (Or you might consider \"toughing it out\"\nfor another 4-6 weeks until the Galactic Center is no longer in the HETE FOV \nin which case the trigger rate should drop dramatically.)\n\nACTION ITEM:\nSites can:\n1) keep their current configurations,   or\n2) request that S/C_Alerts be disabled,   or\n3) request that S/C_Alerts/Updates/Lasts be disabled (say for the next month\nor so, and then request they be turned back on),   or\n4) request that all HETE subtypes (A/U/L/GA) be disabled (again for the next\nmonth or so).\nGiven the no-positions-filtering incorporated last Saturday, choice \"2\"\nseems like a reasonable approach if a site has any concern about \"too many\nNotices\".\n\nSincerely,\n\nScott Barthelmy\nNASA-GSFC\n301-286-3106\nscott@lheamail.gsfs.nasa.gov","createdOn":996530269000,"email":"scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, G. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 03:15:00 UTC, a hard spectrum, high energy \ntransient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized by \nHETE. Both the FREGATE and the WXM instruments detected the event. \nThe burst triggered FREGATE in the 30-400 keV band.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h50m59.11s, \nDec. = -23�32'44\" (J2000), derived from combining data from the WXM \nand Boresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the \nWXM localization is 10 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we \nestimate a systematic error radius at present of 20 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 2 \narcmin (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe burst exhibited a multiple-peaked structure and lasted about 25 \nseconds. The peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~1 Crab. The \npeak flux was significantly less in the WXM.\n\nFollow-up observations of this GRB event are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on GRB010326 (including light curves and the \nWXM error box), as well as the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985591482000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Derek Fox at CIT  <derekfox@astro.caltech.edu>","subject":"SGR 1900+14: Correction to GCN 1049","circularId":1052,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1052....1F","body":"D. Kouveliotou, A. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on behalf\nof a larger SGR collaboration:\n\nWe have examined our overlapping Chandra/RXTE observations of SGR 1900+14\n(RXTE TOO, P. Woods, PI). We cannot verify the burst reported in GCN #1047. \nThe source was occulted by the earth at the time in question.\n\nWe confirm the burst in the Chandra data at approximately 7:15:25 UT. The burst \nduration appeared to be 0.35 seconds during which 14 counts were recorded \n(ignoring pile-up). Thus the peak count rate was 65 times the quiescent rate.\nAdopting the quiescent source spectrum (GCN # 1046), we estimate the peak flux \nin the 2-10 keV band to be 7.2 x 10^-10 ergs/cm^2 s (2.9 x 10^-9 ergs/cm^2 s in \n0.5-10.0 keV).\n\nWe would like to add a clarification regarding the persistent source flux  \nvalues in the two GCNs (1046, 1047). Kawai, and J.-L.\nAtteia, on behalf of the HETE team report:\n\nUlysses, Konus-Wind and Konus-A observed GRB010326A. This burst had a\nduration of ~25 s, a 17 keV - 2.5 MeV fluence of ~4x10^-5 erg/cm2, and\na peak flux over 0.25 s of ~8x10^-6 erg/cm2 s. From a cross-correlation\nof the Ulysses and Konus-Wind time histories, we have triangulated the\nlocation of the burst to an annulus centered at RA(2000)=178.727 deg.,\nDecl(2000)=30.803 deg., and radius 81.702+/- 0.028 deg. (1 sigma confidence).  Combining these data, we\nare able to restrict the location of the burst to the following ~180\nsquare arcmin. error box.\n\n  RA(2000)       DEC(2000)\n132.9630 o     -38.3005 o (CENTER)\n132.3408 o     -38.5784 o (CORNER)\n132.3988 o     -38.5441 o (CORNER)\n131.5271 o     -38.0568 o (CORNER)\n131.5851 o     -38.0230 o (CORNER)\n\nThis location is consistent with the spectra and time history seen in \nthe four HETE FREGATE detectors. The above error box can be refined \nby further processing.\n\nOn this basis, we have concluded that the WXM location reported in GCN\n1014 for this burst is spurious.  This burst is distinct from the other \nGRBs (GRB010326B, GCN 1018; GRB010213, GCN 934) for which HETE WXM \nlocations have been reported, in that it has a very low \nsignal-to-noise excess count rate in the WXM, and our further \nanalysis suggests that it is this fact that accounts\nfor the spurious location. The candidate was found by the GstLAL [1] analysis pipeline.\n\nS231231ag is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 8.4e-15 Hz, or about one in 1e7 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231231ag\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), NSBH (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [2] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [2] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 27 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,1 sky map, the 90% credible region is 24218 deg2. Marginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 1114 +/- 357 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/userguide/.\n\n [1] Tsukada et al. PRD 92, 023002 (2015)\n","createdOn":1703392495539}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Varun Bhalerao at Indian Inst of Tech  <varunb@iitb.ac.in>","subject":"LIGO/Virgo S190602aq: AstroSat CZTI upper limits","circularId":24736,"bibcode":"2019GCN.24736....1B","body":"We have carried a search for X-ray candidates in Astrosat CZTI data in a 100 sec window around the trigger time of the BBH merger event S190602aq (UTC 2019-06-02 17:59:27.00, GraceDB event). CZTI is a coded aperture mask instrument that has considerable effective area for about 29% of the entire sky, but is also sensitive to brighter transients from the entire sky. At the time of merger, Astrosat's nominal pointing is (RA=295.71, DEC=-10.36), which is 134.4 deg away from the maximum probability location. In a time interval of 100 sec around the event, 51% of sky locations are visible in the satellite's frame and the rest of 49% with the inclusion of maximum probability location for the event are occulted by earth. \n\nCZTI data were de-trended to remove orbit-wise background variation. We then searched data from three of the four independent, identical quadrants to look for coincident spikes in the count rates. Searches were undertaken by binning the data in 0.1s, 1s, and 10s respectively. Statistical fluctuations in count rates were estimated by using data from 10 (+-5) neighbouring orbits. We selected confidence levels such that the probability of a false trigger in a 1000 sec window is 10^-4.We do not find any evidence for any hard X-ray transient in this window, in the CZTI energy range of 20-200 keV.\n\nWe convert our count rates into flux by assuming that the source spectrum is a power law with alpha = -1.0. We use a detailed mass model of the satellite to calculate the instrument response for every htm grid point that fall in 90% LIGO localization region and calculate flux limit in that direction. We get the following upper limits for source flux in the 20-200 keV band by taking a probability weighted mean of flux limit and are reported here :  \n\n0.1 s: flux limit= 8.7 e-7 ergs/cm^2/s \n1.0 s: flux limit= 3.0 e-6 ergs/cm^2/s \n10.0 s: flux limit= 3.6 e-6 ergs/cm^2/s\n\nCZTI is built by a TIFR-led consortium of institutes across India, including VSSC, ISAC, IUCAA, SAC and PRL. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Analysis of data from the 22 April 2001 Chandra observation (GCN\n1046, 1047), barycenter-corrected with the preliminary CXC ephemeris,\nreveals that the source emission is pulsed at a period of P =\n5.17288(5) s with a pulse strength of 14.3(2)% RMS that remains\nconstant (within errors) throughout the observation.  Separation of\nthe source photons into \"on-pulse\" and \"off-pulse\" components of 1/3\ncycle each reveals that the off-pulse spatial distribution is\nsignificantly broader than the on-pulse distribution.  Since the\nobservation is taken in continuous-clocking mode, we can only make\nthis determination in one dimension.  Nonetheless, the sigma-widths of\nthe one-dimensional Gaussian PSFs are 0.98(1) arcsec for on-pulse\nphotons and 1.08(2) arcsec for off-pulse photons, different at\n>5-sigma level.  We attribute this difference in widths to the\npresence of an underlying X-ray nebula.\"","createdOn":988243520000,"email":"derekfox@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kira Simpson at PSU  <kira.simpson1984@gmail.com>","subject":"GRB 190531B: Swift/UVOT Upper Limits","circularId":24731,"bibcode":"2019GCN.24731....1U","body":"GRB 190531B: Swift/UVOT Upper Limits\n\nK. Hurley on behalf\nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nThe HETE Fregate instrument has detected a bright (>40 sigma) GRB \nthat has been reported in a GCN Notice as H1761. The burst occurred \nat 18950.56 SOD {05:15:50.56} UT on 21 September.  The burst is seen \nin the WXM X detector and is therefore well-localized in the X \ndirection; the burst was apparently outside the coded FOV of the WXM \nY detector, which therefore gives limited information about the Y \ndirection of the burst.\n\nThe X-detector data gives a good (+/-10 arcmin) localization in the X\ndirection and crude limits on Y, resulting in a localization that is a\nthin, long strip.\n\nTwo points along one side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h52m36s.7, Dec. =  39o35'13\"\nR.A. = 23h10m22s.8, Dec. =  48o57'43\"\n\nTwo points along the other side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h54m04s.0, Dec. =  39o34'23\"\nR.A. = 23h11m52s.5, Dec. =  48o57'00\"\n\nOur estimate is that the strip is  ~10  degrees in the long direction.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~12 s. A total of 5310 \ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence \nof ~1 x 10-6 ergs cm-2. The peak flux was >3 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >8 x Crab flux).\n\nFurther refinement of the X localization is in progress; a further\nattempt is also being made to improve the coarse Y localization.","createdOn":1001067928000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Richard McMahon at Inst.Astonomy, U Cambridge  <rgm@ast.cam.ac.uk>","subject":"GRB980613 Near Infra-Red Observations","circularId":101,"bibcode":"1998GCN...101....1M","body":"R. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB and HETE teams; T. Cline, on\nbehalf of the Ulysses, Konus-Wind, and HETE GRB teams; E. Mazets and\nS.  Golenetskii, on behalf of the Konus-Wind and Konus-A GRB teams; and\nG. Ricker, D. Lamb, C.  Graziani, E. Fenimore, N. Kawai, and J.-L.\nAtteia, on behalf of the HETE team report:\n\nUlysses, Konus-Wind and Konus-A observed GRB010326A. This burst had a\nduration of ~25 s, a 17 keV - 2.5 MeV fluence of ~4x10^-5 erg/cm2, and\na peak flux over 0.25 s of ~8x10^-6 erg/cm2 s. From a cross-correlation\nof the Ulysses and Konus-Wind time histories, we have triangulated the\nlocation of the burst to an annulus centered at RA(2000)=178.727 deg.,\nDecl(2000)=30.803 deg., and radius 81.702+/- 0.028 deg. (3 sigma confidence).\nThe triangulation based on the Konus-Wind and the Konus-A data resulted\nin an annulus centered at RA(2000)=94.662 deg., Decl(2000)=21.978 deg., and\nradius 69.7+/- 0.4 deg. (1 sigma confidence).  Combining these data, we\nare able to restrict the location of the burst to the following ~180\nsquare arcmin. error box.\n\n  RA(2000)       DEC(2000)\n132.9630 o     -38.3005 o (CENTER)\n132.3408 o     -38.5784 o (CORNER)\n132.3988 o     -38.5441 o (CORNER)\n131.5271 o     -38.0568 o (CORNER)\n131.5851 o     -38.0230 o (CORNER)\n\nThis location is consistent with the spectra and time history seen in \nthe four HETE FREGATE detectors. The above error box can be refined \nby further processing.\n\nOn this basis, we have concluded that the WXM location reported in GCN\n1014 for this burst is spurious.  This burst is distinct from the other \nGRBs (GRB010326B, GCN 1018; GRB010213, GCN 934) for which HETE WXM \nlocations have been reported, in that it has a very low \nsignal-to-noise excess count rate in the WXM, and our further \nanalysis suggests that it is this fact that accounts\nfor the spurious location. Kouveliotou, Universities Space Research Association, M. Kippen, P.\nWoods, G. Richardson, University of Alabama in Huntsville, V.\nConnaughton, National Research Council, report on behalf of the BATSE\nteam at NASA/Marshall Space Flight Center:\n\nBATSE has detected repeated soft gamma-ray bursts consistent with the\nsame (previously unknown) location. We recorded three bursts on June\n15.109, 15.296, 15.411 UT (BATSE triggers 6825, 6826, 6827,\nrespectively) with an average duration of ~ 200 milliseconds.\nPreliminary spectral analysis of the data indicates that the events\nare very soft, with power law spectral indices varying between -3.0\nand -7.0. BATSE triggered 5 more times, on June 17.873, 17.901,\n18.004, 18.035, and 18.071 UT (BATSE trigger numbers 6833, 6834, 6835,\n6836 and 6837, respectively). The last trigger had a peak count rate\nof over 300000 counts/sec above background (integrated over 4\ndetectors between 20-1000 keV, in 1 second interval) and a duration of\n~ 3 seconds. Due to its very high peak intensity, deadtime effects\nprevent us from using it for localization, until we receive more data\ntypes. The weighted location of the 7 remaining triggers is centered\non R.A. = 16h27m12.0s and dec = -41d06.0' with an error radius of\nabout 2 degrees.  This location does not correspond to any previously\nknown SGR source; we conclude that we have discovered a new source,\nSGR1627-41. We have initiated an RXTE ToO and we strongly encourage\nwide field observations at other wavelengths.","createdOn":898140980000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Peter Woods at UAH/MSFC  <peter.woods@msfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"SGR 1900+14 : RXTE observations","circularId":1056,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10056....1B","body":"P. Woods (USRA/NSSTC), C. Kouveliotou (NASA/MSFC), and E. Gogus\n(UAH/NSSTC) report on behalf of a larger collaboration.\n\nToO observations of SGR 1900+14 with the Rossi XTE were initiated on\nApril 19, 2001 and have continued through April 28.  Thus far, more\nthan 60 bursts have been detected in ~110 ks of exposure time. \nCoincidentally, a short (~10 ks) observation of SGR 1900+14 was\nperformed on April 14 (4 days prior to the flare) as part of our\nongoing monitoring campaign.  We find no burst activity within this\nobservation.  For the latest observation on April 28, 4 bursts were\nrecorded in one RXTE orbit, thus the source remains burst active.\n\nSelecting a 6 day subset of these observations for which we have\nspacecraft ephemeris information, we have phase connected the data and\nmeasured both a period and period derivative.  We chose our epoch (MJD\n52021.3 TDB) to coincide with the first Chandra observation.  We\nmeasure a barycentric period of 5.1728219(14) s where the number given\nin the parentheses marks the 1 sigma error in the least significant\ndigits.  The period derivative is found to be +1.58(22) X 10E-10 s/s. \nThe ephemeris we find agrees well with the measured periods reported\nfor both the Chandra (GCN #1049) and BeppoSAX (GCN #1055)\nobservations.  Furthermore, the magnitude of the spindown found here\nis well within the range of historical spindown rates measured for\nthis SGR.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988650865000,"email":"peter.woods@msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. S. Bloom, P. A. Price, D. W. Fox, S. G. Djorgovski (CIT), and\nJ. M. Schombert (U. Oregon) report on behalf of the larger\nCaltech-NRAO-CARA GRB Collaboration:\n\n\"On 26.27 March 2001, we obtained a second night of exposures of the\nfield of GRB 010324 (GCN/RXTE ASM; Hurley et al., GCN #1011) using\nCOSMIC on the Palomar 200-inch atop Mt. Palomar.  Using the same\npattern as in the first epoch of imaging (GCN #1012), the entire XTE\nerror box was observed in V-band in two pointings with a total of 1800\nsec per pointing.\n\nBoth image differencing and differential aperture photometry between\nthe two epochs revealed no obviously varying source.  No absolute\nphotometry for the field is available at this time.  However, adopting\nV = 19.1 mag for a USNO A2.0 star at RA: 07:11:26.301, DEC:\n+19:58:30.32 (J2000) we estimate the absence of variation by more than\n0.3 mag down to V = 22.3 mag.\n\nSources brighter than V~18.5 mag were saturated however all such sources\nwere previously observed in DPOSS (see GCN #1012); therefore any GRB\nafterglow is now likely to be faint (V > 22.3 mag). One caveat to this\nconclusion is that the GRB field has a high stellar density and so it is\npossible to have missed a varying source near a bright star.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985713383000,"email":"jsb@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Evert Rol at U.Amsterdam  <evert@astro.uva.nl>","subject":"GRB010214, optical observations","circularId":1059,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10059....1F","body":"E. Rol, I. Salamanca, L. Kaper, P. Vreeswijk (University of\nAmsterdam), N. Tanvir (University of Hertfordshire), report on behalf\nof a larger collaboration:\n\n\nIn order to verify the possible counterpart to GRB010214 (Rol et al.,\nGCN 955), we obtained another set of images with the Isaac Newton\nTelescope on February 21, 2001. Examination and comparison of these\nimages with those obtained at the INT on February 17 shows no evidence\nfor a further fading of the possible counterpart, as already suggested\nin other reports (Gorosabel et al., GCN 972; Klose et al., GCN 997;\nFynbo, private comm.). Instead, the source has the same magnitude as\nmeasured in the images obtained at the William Herschel Telescope on\nFebruary 16, R = 22.9 (Rol et al, GCN 955). We therefore conclude that\nthe optical counterpart of GRB010214 has not been detected, with upper\nlimits R ~ 23.5, R ~ 24.2 and R ~ 23.8 on Feb. 15.26, Feb. 17.25 and\nFeb. 22.22 respectively (using the calibration of Henden, GCN\n988). Since the decrease in intensity on Feb. 17 does not appear to be\nan artifact in the images, the detected source likely is a variable\nstar.\n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":988972984000,"email":"evert@astro.uva.nl"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN TRIANGULATION OF GRB010324","circularId":1011,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10011....1O","body":"K. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 010222: HST observations -- host galaxy and late-time decay","circularId":1087,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10087....1C","body":"A. Fruchter, I. Burud, J. Rhoads and A. Levan (STScI) report:\n\nWe have reduced the now public archival HST images of GRB 010222, taken\non 28 February, 17 and 18 March, 5 and 6 April, and 4 and 5 May of \nthis year using the F606W (V/R) and F814W (I) filters on WFPC2.   Using\nthe most recent data, we find that OT of GRB 010222 is clearly superposed\non a host galaxy.  \n\nIn order to accurately determine the decay of the OT and the magnitude\nof the host, we have drizzled the images onto an output grid that\nallows interlacing of these 2-point dithered images.  We have then fit\nfor the decay of the OT and the host galaxy flux using a small (~0.\"2)\naperture, which provides the best estimate of the OT as a function of\ntime, as well as using a larger aperture (~0.\"5), which is more\nappropriate for determining the host galaxy magnitude.\n\nWe find that the late-time decay of the OT is significantly steeper\nthan previously reported.  We find a power-law decay between 28 February\n(day 6) and 5 May (day 71) of -1.7 +/- 0.05.  Formally, we find\na slightly steeper decay (-1.73 +/- 0.02) in F606W than in F814W \n(-1.64 +/- 0.04), but this discrepancy may indicate the level of\nsystematic error in the slope measurement rather than true color\nevolution of the OT.\n\nWe find that the host galaxy is dominated by a compact core (FWHM ~ 0.\"15)\nlocated directly under the OT.  The magnitude of the host is \nF606W(AB) = 26.0 +/- 0.1, F814W(AB) = 25.8 +/- 0.15.  \n\nImages of the host, as well as a plot of the coninuing decline of the OT,\nare available at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/010222","createdOn":997814700000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Roma) and S. Mereghetti (IFC/CNR, Milano),\non behalf of a larger SGR collaboration, and G. Gandolfi, L. Piro\nand E. Costa (IAS/CNR, Roma), on behalf of the BeppoSAX Team,\nreport:\n\n\"A ToO observation of SGR1900+14 was carried out with the\nBeppoSAX Narrow Field Instruments starting on April 18, 15:10 UT,\nless than 8 hours after the large flare reported in GCN #1041.\nIntense bursting activity is present during the 28 hr long\nobservation.  After removing the numerous short bursts, a significant\nflux decay is visible in the MECS and LECS light curves.\nBy using our data and the Chandra 2-10 keV flux (GCN #1046)\nwe find that the decay can be reasonably well described by a power\nlaw with index ~-0.6.  There is also evidence for a spectral softening\ncorrelated with the intensity decrease.\n\nThe average spectrum (after removal of the bursts) can be fit by a\npower law with photon index 2.6+/-0.1 and NH=(4.3 +/-0.3)x10^22 cm^-2.\nThe average 2-10 keV flux during the whole BeppoSAX observation is\n2.9x10^-11 erg/cm^2/s (unabsorbed). The bursts have a significantly\nharder spectrum (power law photon index ~0 in the 2-10 keV range).\n\nPulsations,  with a nearly sinusoidal light curve and a modulation of\nabout 21%, are clearly detected at the barycentered period  P=5.17277(1) s.\nWhen compared with the value measured with Chandra about 3 days later\n(GCN #1049), this yields a dP/dt ~ (4.1 +/- 1.9)x10^-10 s/s.\n\nAn additional BeppoSAX/NFI observation will start on April 29, 20:30 UT.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988388763000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. binary merger candidate S231206ca during real-time processing of data from LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1) and LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1) at 2023-12-06 23:31:34.528 UTC (GPS time: 1385940712.528). The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], PyCBC Live [4], and SPIIR [5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231206ca is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 3.2e-10 Hz, or about one in 1e2 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231206ca\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), or NSBH (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [6] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [6] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 25 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. Magnitude         Aperture\n---------------------------------------------------------\n  B        2500             26.13 +/- 0.17   2.0 arcsec\n  V        1500             25.85 +/- 0.22   2.0 arcsec\n  Rc       1260             26.31+/-  0.25   2.0 arcsec\n  Ic       1800             24.7 +/-  0.4    2.0 arcsec\n---------------------------------------------------------\n\nThe faint R-band  magnitude can be explained by a graphite band\nas on the Galactic extinction curves. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome) and C. Guidorzi (University of Ferrara)\nreport on behalf of the BeppoSAX/GRBM team:\n\n\"The BeppoSAX Gamma Ray Burst Monitor (GRBM) was triggered by a gamma-ray\nburst on August 1st, 2001, 18:30:34.39 UT. This event is most likely the\nsame event detected by HETE-2 on the same day at 18:30:37.42 UT (HETE\nTrigger Number 1669). As seen in unit #2 of the GRBM, in the 40-700 keV\nenergy range, the event was bright (about 4,300 counts/s at peak)\nand long (approx. 33 s). It showed a main, structured pulse 10 s long,\nfollowed by a bunch of much shorter and weaker pulses starting about 4 s\nafter the end of the main pulse.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":996701872000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"Duration, ECT, peak flux and fluence of GRB010324","circularId":1013,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10013....1G","body":"K. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB team, and C. Guidorzi,\nE. Montanari, and F. Frontera, on behalf of the BeppoSAX GRBM\nteam, report:\n\nThis burst (RXTE/ASM and GCN 1011) had a duration of\napproximately 15 seconds in 25-150 keV gamma-rays.  Its\nEarth-crossing time was ~41558 s, and its 25-100 keV\nfluence was ~1.8x10^-6 erg/cm^2; over 0.25 s, its peak\nflux was ~4.3x10^-7 erg/cm^2 s. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, G. Pizzichini, \nand G. Prigozhin, on behalf of the HETE Operations and HETE \nOptical-SXC Teams;\n\nN. Kawai, M. Matsuoka, Y. Shirasaki, T. Tamagawa, A. Yoshida, E. \nFenimore, M. Galassi, and  C. Graziani, on behalf of the HETE WXM \nTeam;\n\nJ-L Atteia, M. Boer, J-F Olive, J-P Dezalay, and K. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 08:33:12 UTC (=30792s UT), a soft spectrum, high \nenergy transient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized \nby HETE.\n(NB: This is the second GRB detected by HETE on 26 March 2001.)\n\nBoth the WXM and the FREGATE instruments detected the event. The \nburst triggered FREGATE in the 6-120 keV band, at the 160ms timescale.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h24m23.36s, \nDec. = -11o09'57\", derived from combining data from the WXM and \nBoresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the WXM \nlocalization is 18 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we estimate \na systematic error radius at present of 10 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 30 \narcsec (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~4 Crab; with WXM \n(2-25 keV), ~2 Crab. The burst duration was about 4 seconds.\n\nThe high galactic latitude of the source, well away from the Galactic \nBulge, and the shape of its spectrum suggest that it is a gamma-ray \nburst similar to those reported for \"X-ray rich\" GRBs by Heise et al \n(2001) from BeppoSAX observations.\n\nFollow-up observations of this unusual transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on the GRB010326B (including light curves), as \nwell as for the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985612698000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"SGR1806-20: Localization by HETE","circularId":1068,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10068....1H","body":"SGR1806-20: Localization by HETE\n\nG. This event may indicate the \nonset of a new period of activity by this source. The coordinates \n(J2000) of the burst source were:\n\nR.A. = 272.0265 deg.\n\nDec. = -20.2743 deg\n\nThe error circle for the localization is 36 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1806-20 lies 11.8 arcmin from the HETE position. [Another galactic \nX-ray source, GX9+1, lies 100 arcmin from the HETE position.]\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <300 ms. A preliminary analysis of\nthe GRBM data shows a very complex, multi-pulse time profile. Hurley on behalf\nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 05:06:30.61 UTC (18390.61 s UT) on 22 August, the HETE FREGATE \ninstrument detected a short, intense burst from a probable soft \ngamma-ray repeater or (less likely) a short duration GRB. This event \nwas promptly distributed as a GCN Notice (HETE BID_1715). No signal \nwas detected in the WXM, indicating that the event was likely to \nbe >40 degrees from the anti-sun direction. For the current HETE \npointing direction, SGR1900+14 is about 48 degrees off the boresight, \nwhile SGR1806-20 is about 56 degrees off the boresight, so that \neither could be a candidate.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~200 ms. A total of 500\ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence\nof ~9 x 10-8 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux was >2 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >50 x Crab flux) over a duration of 30 ms.\n\nA search for this event in the archives of other GRB instruments is \nencouraged. Melandri et al., GCN #37896), SVOM/GRM (Yan-Qiu Zhang et al., GCN #37921) and EP/WXT (D. Y. Li et al., GCN #37909).\n\nAccording to the GECAM-B light curves in about 6-6000 keV, this burst mainly consists of multiple pulses with a duration (T90) of about 14.9（+4.8,-3.6）s.\nThe time-averaged spectrum from T0-0.32 to T0+14.61 s could be fit by a power law with a fluence of about 6.67 (+0.36,-0.35) E-06 erg/cm^2 in 10-1000 keV.\n\nThe GECAM light curve could be found here:\nhttps://twikinew.ihep.ac.cn/pubgecam/Sandbox/GRB/GECAMB_GRB241026A.png\n\nWe note that these results are very preliminary. Refined analysis will be reported later.\n\nGravitational wave high-energy Electromagnetic Counterpart All-sky Monitor (GECAM) mission originally consists of two microsatellites (GECAM-A and GECAM-B) launched in Dec. 2020. As the third member of GECAM constellation, GECAM-C was launched onboard SATech-01 experimental satellite in July 2022. Izzo (INAF/OAC), O. Kuhn (LBTO), A. Rossi (INAF/OAS), D. B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.), V. D'Elia (ASI/SSDC & INAF-OAR) and F. Cusano (INAF/OAS), report on behalf of a larger collaboration: \n\nWe observed the optical counterpart (Moskvitin et al.,, GCN 37899) of GRB 241026A (Melandri et al., GCN 37896; Trigg, GCN 37917; Zhang et al., GCN 37921) using the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) located on Mount Graham (AZ, USA). Observations were carried out with the MODS instrument, and consisted of two 600-s spectra taken in each of the red and blue channels, starting on 2024 October 27.204 UT (6.18 hr after the trigger).\n\nStrong continuum is detected, showing a multitude of absorption lines, which we interpret as due to, among others, Si II 1526, Si II* 1533, C IV 1458,1550, Fe II 1600, Al II 1670, Si II 1808, Al III 1854, 1862, all at a common redshift of z = 2.791.\n\nWe thus confirm the redshift value measured by Moskvitin et al. Svinkin, D. Frederiks, A. Lysenko, A. Ridnaia,\nA. Tsvetkova,  M. Ulanov, and T. Cline,\non behalf of the Konus-Wind team, report:\n\nThe long-duration GRB 241025A\n(Swift-BAT detection: Ambrosi et al., GCN 37859;\nFermi-GBM detection: Fermi GBM team, GCN 37860;\nGodwin, GCN 37886;\nSVOM-GRM detection: Wang et al., GCN 37863;\nEP-WXT detection: Li et al., GCN 37864)\nwas detected by Konus-Wind (KW) in the waiting mode\nat T0~5786 s UT (01:36:26).\n\nA Bayesian block analysis of the KW  waiting mode data\nin the 20-300 keV band reveals a >20 sigma count rate\nincrease in the interval from T0-13 s to ~T0+128 s.\n\nThe Konus-Wind light curve of this GRB is available at\nhttp://www.ioffe.ru/LEA/GRBs/GRB241025A/\n\nThe total burst fluence is 1.58(-0.14,+0.14)x10^-5 erg/cm^2,\nand the 2.944 s peak energy flux, measured from T0+0.143 s,\nis 4.5(-0.5,+0.5)x10^-7 erg/cm^2.\n(both in the 20 keV - 10 MeV energy range).\n\nThe time-integrated spectrum of the burst,\nmeasured from T0-13 s to T0+128 s,\ncan be described by a power law with exponential cutoff (CPL) model\ndN/dE ~ (E^alpha)*exp(-E*(2+alpha)/Ep)\nwith alpha = -0.85(-0.13,+0.15) and Ep = 238(-33,+38) keV.\n\nThe spectrum near the peak count rate, measured from T0+12 s to T0+30 s,\ncan be described by a CPL model with\nalpha = -0.04(-0.17,+0.20) and Ep = 261(-23,+24) keV.\n\nAssuming the redshift z=4.20 (Xu et al., GCN 37866)\nand a standard cosmology with H_0 = 67.3 km/s/Mpc, Omega_M = 0.315,\nand Omega_Lambda = 0.685 (Planck Collaboration, 2014),\nwe estimate the following rest-frame parameters:\nthe isotropic energy release E_iso is (5.5+/-0.5)x10^53 erg,\nthe peak luminosity L_iso is (8.2+/-0.9)x10^52 erg/s,\nthe rest-frame peak energy of the time-averaged spectrum\nEp,i,z is (1238+/-182) keV, and the spectrum near the maximum count rate \nEp,p,z is (1357+/-120) keV.\n\nWith the obtained estimates, GRB 241025A is inside 68% prediction bands for \n'Amati' and 'Yonetoku' relations for the sample of >300 long KW GRBs with \nknown redshifts (Tsvetkova et al., 2017; Tsvetkova et al., 2021), \nsee http://www.ioffe.ru/LEA/GRBs/GRB241025A/GRB241025A_rest_frame.pdf\n\nAll the quoted errors are estimated at the 68% confidence level.\nAll the presented results are preliminary.","createdOn":1730126038758}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"Xiaofeng Wang at Tsinghua University <wang_xf@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241026A: TNOT optical counterpart detection","circularId":37928,"format":"text/plain","body":"X. F. Wang (THU), A. Iskandar（XAO), J. L. Liu (THU)，L. T. Wang (XAO), J. Mo (THU), Y.S. Yan (THU), A. Esamdin (XAO), S. Antier (OCA)，and W. X. Li (NAOC) report the optical detections of the afterglow of GRB 241026A/EP241026a with a redshift of 2.79 (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37894; A. Melandri et al., GCN 37896; Yan-Qiu Zhang et al., GCN 37921; D. Y. Li et al., GCN 37909; Shrestha et al.,GCN 37913; Moskvitin et al.,GCN 37916; Mohan et al., GCN 37918; Moskvitin et al., GCN 37922; Izzo et al., GCN 37925).\n\nWe obtained 120sx16 (~16.7 hrs after the GRB detection) r-band and 120sx20 (~17.9 hrs after the GRB detection) i-band images with the 0.8~m Tsinghua-Nanshan Optical Telescope (TNOT) located at Nanshan Station of Xinjiang Astronomy Observatory. The afterglow is clearly detected on the stacked images, with the following magnitudes:\n \nr = 21.01 +- 0.07 mag (MJD = 60611.14)\nr = 20.85 +- 0.08 mag (MJD = 60611.19)\n\nThe above photometric results are calibrated using the field stars from the Pan-STARRS1 catalog and are not corrected for the Galactic extinction. Pal (Konkoly Observatory), M. Dafcikova, J. Ripa, M. Kolar, N. Werner (Masaryk U.), M. Ohno, H. Takahashi (Hiroshima U.), L. Meszaros, B. Csak (Konkoly Observatory), N. Husarikova, F. Munz , M. Topinka, M. Duriskova, L. Szakszonova, J.-P. Breuer, F. Hroch (Masaryk U.), T. Urbanec, M. Kasal,  A. Povalac (Brno U. of Technology), J. Hudec, J. Kapus, M. Frajt (Spacemanic s.r.o), R. Laszlo, M. Koleda (Needronix s.r.o), M. Smelko, P. Hanak, P. Lipovsky (Technical U. of Kosice), G. Galgoczi (Wigner Research Center/Eotvos U.), Y. Uchida, H. Poon, H. Matake (Hiroshima U.), N. Uchida (ISAS/JAXA), T. Bozoki (Eotvos U.), G. Dalya (Eotvos U.), T. Enoto (Kyoto U.), Zs. Frei (Eotvos U.), G. Friss (Eotvos U.), Y. Fukazawa, K. Hirose (Hiroshima U.), S. Hisadomi (Nagoya U.), Y. Ichinohe (Rikkyo U.), K. Kapas (Eotvos U.), L. L. Kiss (Konkoly Observatory),  T. Mizuno (Hiroshima U.), K. Nakazawa (Nagoya U.), H. Odaka (Univ of Tokyo), J. Takatsy (Eotvos U.), K. Torigoe (Hiroshima U.), N. Kogiso, M. Yoneyama (Osaka Metropolitan U.), M. Moritaki (U. Tokyo), T. Kano (U. Michigan) -- the GRBAlpha collaboration.\n\nWe report a detection of GRB 241026A, the 100th GRB detected by GRBAlpha 1U CubeSat (Pal et al. 2023, A&A, 677, 40; https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2023A%26A...677A..40P/abstract). The event was also observed by Fermi/GBM (GCN 37894), Swift/BAT (GCN 37896), EP/WXT (GCN 37909), SVOM/GRM (GCN 379210), GECAM-B (GCN 37924), and INTEGRAL/SPI-ACS (peak detection at 2024-10-26 ~22:42:31 UTC).\n\nThe detection was confirmed at the peak time 2024-10-26 22:42:32.3 UTC. The T90 duration measured by GRBAlpha is 10.0 s and the overall significance during T90 reaches 6.9 sigma.\n\nThe light curve obtained by GRBAlpha is available here: https://grbalpha.konkoly.hu/static/share/GRB241026A_GCN.pdf\n\nAll GRBAlpha detections are listed at: https://monoceros.physics.muni.cz/hea/GRBAlpha/\nGRBAlpha, launched on 2021 March 22, is a demonstration mission for a future CubeSat constellation (Werner et al. Proc. SPIE 2018). The detector of GRBAlpha consists of a 75 x 75 x 5 mm3 CsI scintillator read out by a SiPM array, covering the energy range from ~50 keV to ~1000 keV. To increase the duty cycle and the downlink rate, the upgrade of the on-board data acquisition software stack is in progress. The ground segment is also supported by the radio amateur community and it takes advantage of the SatNOGS network for increased data downlink volume.\n","createdOn":1730127942377}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Daniele B. Malesani at IMAPP / Radboud University <d.malesani@astro.ru.nl>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241021a: Gemini-South detection of optical rebrightening","circularId":37930,"format":"text/plain","body":"J. A. Quirola-Vasquez (Radboud Univ.), D. B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI & Radboud Univ.), A. J. Levan (Radboud), F. E. Bauer (PUC), P. G. Jonker (Radboud Univ.), report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe observed the optical counterpart of EP241021a (Fu et al., GCN 37840; Gompertz et al., GCN 37835; Lipunov et al., GCN 37839; Fu et al., GCN 37842; Yang et al., GCN 37843; Li et al., GCN 37844; Li et al., GCN 37846; Zheng et al., GCN 37849; Moskvitin et al., GCN 37850; Pugliese et al., GCN 37852; Pérez-Fournon et al., GCN 37858; Bochenek et al., GCN 37869; Kumar et al., GCN 37875; Jin et al., GCN 37892), using the Gemini-South (GS) telescope equipped with the GMOS instrument.\n\nWe obtained 4x180 s exposures in the r-band, starting on 2024-10-28 at 00:21:06 UT, i.e., approximately ~6.8 days after the X-ray trigger. We detect the source at an r-band magnitude of ~21.90 AB mag, calibrated against nearby Pan-STARRS objects. Compared to both reports from the literature (e.g., Bochenek & Perley, GCN 37869; Busmann et al., GCN 37878) and our own data, this shows that the source has brightened. Such a brightening is reminiscent of that shown by EP240414a (Shubham et al. 2024, arXiv:2409.19070; van Dalen et al. 2024, arXiv:2409.19056), though occurring at a slightly later epoch.\n\nWe thank the staff of the Gemini-South for excellent support.","createdOn":1730129747222}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"Xiaofeng Wang at Tsinghua University <wang_xf@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn>","editedBy":"Judith Racusin at NASA/GSFC <judith.racusin@nasa.gov> on behalf of Xiaofeng Wang at Tsinghua University <wang_xf@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241026A: TNOT optical counterpart detection","circularId":37928,"format":"text/plain","body":"X.
