Brink, Alexei V. Filippenko (UC Berkeley), and Yi\nYang (Tsinghua Univ., Beijing), report on behalf of the KAIT GRB team:\n\n\nWe observed the location of the GRB 240821A optical afterglow\n(Quirola-Vasquez et al., GCN 37319) with the Low Resolution Imaging\nSpectrometer (LRIS; Oke et al. 1995) with the Keck I 10 m telescope by\ncentering on the slit the host-galaxy counterpart from the Legacy Survey as\nnoticed by Quirola-Vasquez et al. (GCN 37319). Observations were performed\non Sep. 2, 2024, and consisted of 4 x 1200 s exposures with the 600/4000\ngrism and 400/8500 grating. The spectrum has low signal-to-noise ratio\nowing to the faintness of the host galaxy. We detect and confirm the\nemission line at 8123 Ang reported by Saccardi et al. (GCN 37369) and\nSchneider et al. (GCN 37731) from VLT/X-shooter data. The [N II] 6584 and\npossibly [O II] 3727 emission lines reported by Schneider et al. (GCN 37731)\n are marginally detected. SVOM/ECLAIRs","circularId":37934,"format":"text/plain","body":"SVOM/ECLAIRs Commissioning Team: Stéphane Schanne, Nicolas Dagoneau, Hervé Le Provost, Frédéric Chateau (CEA), Wenjin Xie, Donghua Zhao (NAOC), Jean-Luc Atteia, Laurent Bouchet, Sebastien Guillot, Juliette Alaux, Hui Yang (IRAP), Tais Maiolino (LUPM), Floriane Cangemi (APC), Karine Mercier, Marie-Claire Charmeau, Stefano Crepaldi (CNES)\n\nSVOM JSWG: Jian-Yan Wei (NAOC), Bertrand Cordier (CEA), Shuang-Nan Zhang (IHEP), Stéphane Basa (LAM), Olivier Godet (IRAP), Arnaud Claret (CEA), Zi-Gao Dai (USTC), Frédéric Daigne (IAP), Jin-Song Deng (NAOC), Andrea Goldwurm (APC), Diego Götz (CEA), Xu-Hui Han (NAOC), Cyril Lachaud (APC), En-Wei Liang (GXU), Yu-Lei Qiu (NAOC), Susanna Vergani (Obs.Paris), Jing Wang (NAOC), Chao Wu (NAOC), Li-Ping Xin (NAOC), Bing Zhang (UNLV)\n\nReport on behalf of the SVOM team:\n\nDuring the commissioning phase, the SVOM/ECLAIRs telescope detected and localized a bright long duration GRB 241029A at 2024-10-29T02:19:53 UTC (Tb), previously detected by Fermi (Fermi GBM team, GCN circular 37932), and by SVOM/GRM (SVOM reference: sb241002901).\n\nThe onboard trigger was not in operations, the following information was obtained by reprocessing on ground the data in the flight trigger algorithms. The burst was detected by the Count-Rate Trigger (CRT) and Image Trigger (IMT) which produced 22 Alert messages. The best Alert was obtained by CRT in the 8-120 keV energy band with a signal-to-noise ratio of 67.1 in a time window of 20.48 s starting at Tb.\n\nThe event location is RA, Dec = 325.327, Dec: 5.086 (J2000).\n\nThe statistical uncertainty on this position is 1.5 arcminutes to which we recommend adding 2 arcminutes of systematic uncertainty in quadrature.\n\nSVOM did not slew to the burst since automated slewing was not enabled.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA), French Space Agency (CNES), and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. ECLAIRs was developed jointly by APC, CEA, CNES, and IRAP.\n\nThe SVOM point of contact for this burst is: b.cordier AT cea.fr.","createdOn":1730188055012}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241029A","submitter":"Chenwei Wang at IHEP <cwwang@ihep.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241029A: SVOM/GRM observation","circularId":37935,"format":"text/plain","body":"SVOM/GRM team: Chen-Wei Wang, Shi-Jie Zheng, Yong-Wei Dong, Jiang-Tao Liu, Jian-Chao Sun, Yue Huang, Jiang He, Min Gao, Hao-Xuan Guo, Lu Li, Yong-Ye Li, Hong-Wei Liu, Xin Liu, Hao-Li Shi, Li-Ming Song, You-Li Tuo, Wen-Long Zhang, Wen-Jun Tan, Hao-Xi Wang, Jin Wang, Jin-Zhou Wang, Ping Wang, Rui-Jie Wang, Yu-Xi Wang, Bo-Bing Wu, Shao-Lin Xiong, Jian-Ying Ye, Yi-Tao Yin, Wen-Hui Yu, Fan Zhang, Li Zhang, Peng Zhang, Shuang-Nan Zhang, Yan-Qiu Zhang, Yan-Ting Zhang, Shu-Min Zhao, Xiao-Yun Zhao, Chao Zheng (IHEP), Maria-Grazia Bernardini (LUPM/INAF-OAB), Laurent Bouchet (IRAP), David Corre (CEA), Tais Maiolino (LUPM), Frédéric Piron (LUPM), Stéphane Schanne (CEA), Jingwei Wang (IAP), JeanLuc Attéia (IRAP)\n\nSVOM JSWG: Jian-Yan Wei (NAOC), Bertrand Cordier (CEA), Shuang-Nan Zhang (IHEP), Stéphane Basa (LAM), Arnaud Claret (CEA), Zi-Gao Dai (USTC), Frédéric Daigne (IAP), Jin-Song Deng (NAOC), Olivier Godet (IRAP),  Andrea Goldwurm (APC), Diego Götz (CEA), Xu-Hui Han (NAOC), Cyril Lachaud (APC), En-Wei Liang (GXU), Yu-Lei Qiu (NAOC), Susanna Vergani (Obs.Paris), Jing Wang (NAOC), Chao Wu (NAOC), Li-Ping Xin (NAOC),  Shao-Lin Xiong (IHEP), Bing Zhang  (UNLV)\n\nreport on behalf of the SVOM team:\n\nDuring the commissioning phase, the SVOM/GRM was triggered in-flight by GRB 241029A at 2024-10-29T02:19:58 UT (T0), which was also observed by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37932) and SVOM/ECLAIRs (Schanne et al. GCN 37934).\n\nThe real-time alert data and light curves of SVOM/GRM were downlinked to the ground through the VHF system with low latency. With the event-by-event data downloaded through the X-band ground station, the GRM light curve shows that this burst consists of multiple pulses with a T90 of 14.6 +0.6/-0.3 s.\n\nThe GRM light curve can be found here:\nhttps://www.bursthub.cn//admin/static/svgrb241029A.png\n\nThis burst is located at about 29 degrees from the SVOM optical axis.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA, China), National Center for Space Studies (CNES, France) and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS, China), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. GRM is developed by the Institute of High Energy Physics (IHEP) of CAS.\n\nThe SVOM point of contact for this burst is: Chen-Wei Wang (IHEP)(cwwang@ihep.ac.cn)","createdOn":1730196871702}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241029A","submitter":"Phil Evans at U of Leicester <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241029A: Swift ToO observations","circularId":37936,"body":"P. Malesani at IMAPP / Radboud University <d.malesani@astro.ru.nl>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP 241026b: LBT possible optical counterpart (brightening source)","circularId":37938,"format":"text/plain","body":"Andrea Rossi (INAF/OAS), Daniele B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.), E. Maiorano (INAF/OAS), report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe performed a second observation of the field of the fast X-ray transient EP241026b (Lian et al., GCN 37902), using the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT), equipped with the LBC instrument. Observations were carried out again in the SDSS r filter, and consisted of 6 exposures by 120 s each. The observation mid time was October 28.244 UT (1.48 days after the EP trigger).\n\nDigital image subtraction was carried out with HOTPANTS (Becker, 2015) between this data set and our earlier observation (Malesani et al., GCN 37907). In the difference image, a very obvious transient is detected within the EP/WXT error circle, and is located at coordinates (J2000):\n\nRA = 03:45:37.55\nDec = +41:01:51.9\n\nThis transient is observed to brighten by about 1.9 mag among the two observations, and has a magnitude r = 21.6 (AB) in our second (brighter) epoch. No source is visible at this position in the Pan-STARRS images of this field. While this behavior is unusual for GRB afterglows, brightening episodes have been noticed recently in a number of EP-detected transients (e.g., EP240414a: Srivastav et al., arXiv:2409.19070, van Dalen et al., arXiv:2409.19056; EP 241021a: Quirola-Vasquez et al., GCN 37930). We also note that this position is only 10 deg off the Galactic plane, so a Galactic origin cannot be excluded.\n\nNo other transient source is detected in the difference image, down to a limiting magnitude r = 25.1 (AB).\n\nWe acknowledge excellent support from the LBTO and LBT-INAF staff, particularly O. Kuhn, R. Ansaldi, E. Marini and F. (GCN 37937) in 300s of r band images and the preliminary estimated magnitude is 20.47+- 0.11 (r-band, 12:19:27 2024-10-29 UT). Further analysis is in progress.\n\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nMephisto (Multi-channel Photometric Survey Telescope) is a 1.6m wide-field multi-channel telescope, the first of its type in the world, capable of imaging the same field of view in three optical bands simultaneously. It provides real-time, high-quality colors of stellar objects. The on-site telescope assemblage and commissioning were carried out in September 2022. Pollacco report on behalf of the GOTO collaboration:\n\nWe report on observations with the Gravitational-wave Optical Transient Observer (GOTO; Steeghs et al. 2022, Dyer et al. 2024) in response to GRB 241029A, detected by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37932), SVOM/ECLAIRs (Schanne et al., GCN 37934) and SVOM/GRM (Wang et al., GCN 37935). Observations were performed by GOTO-S between 09:46:21 and 12:06:59 UT on 2024-10-29 (starting 7.34 hours after trigger). Myers (NPP/GSFC), M. Godwin (UAH) report on behalf of the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\nAt 02:19:59.87 UT on 29 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB 241029A (trigger 751861204/241029097).\nwhich was also detected by SVOM/ECLAIRs (S. Schanne et al., GCN [37934](https://gcn.nasa.gov/circulars/37934)).\nThe Fermi GBM on-ground location is consistent with the SVOM position.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 76 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of multiple peaks with a duration (T90)\nof about 13.3 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0 to T0+13.152 s is best fit by\na power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff.\nThe power law index is -1.01 +/- 0.04 and the cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 220 +/- 10 keV.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(9.2 +/- 0.3)E-06 erg/cm^2. The 1-sec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0-0.064 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 9.6 +/- 0.4 ph/s/cm^2.\n\nA Band function fits the spectrum equally well\nwith Epeak= 190 +/- 20 keV, alpha = -0.96 +/- 0.05 and beta = -2.5 +/- 0.3.\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/","createdOn":1730226011586}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241029A","submitter":"Phil Evans at U of Leicester <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241029A: Swift-XRT observations","circularId":37946,"body":"M.G. Capalbi (INAF-IASFPA) and P.A.\nEvans (U. Leicester) reports on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nSwift-XRT has performed follow-up observations of the\nSVOM/ECLAIRs-detected burst GRB 241029A, collecting 747 s of Photon\nCounting (PC) mode data between T0+29.1 ks and T0+30.0 ks. \n\nOne uncatalogued X-ray source has been detected consistent with being\nwithin 434 arcsec of the SVOM/ECLAIRs position, it is below the RASS\nlimit and shows no definitive signs of fading. [Enhanced position])\n  Count-rate: 0.080 +/- 0.012 ct s^-1\t\n  Distance: 87 arcsec from SVOM/ECLAIRs position.\n  Flux: (2.60 +/- 0.39)e-12 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (observed, 0.3-10 keV)\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis of the XRT observations,\nincluding a position-specific upper limit calculator, are available at\nhttps://www.swift.ac.uk/ToO_GRBs/00021726.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n\n","createdOn":1730227158365}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"Mike Siegel at PSU/Swift MOC <mhs18@psu.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241026A: Swift/UVOT Upper Limits","circularId":37947,"format":"text/plain","body":"M. Saccardi (GEPI/Obs. de Paris & CEA \nParis-Saclay), report on behalf of the MISTRAL GRB collaboration:\n\nWe first performed imaging of the field of GRB 241029A (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37932; Schanne et al., \nGCN 37934; Chenwei Wang et al., GCN 37935; Evans et al., GCN 37936; Jiang et al., GCN 37937; \nWeikang Lin et al., GCN 37939; Jiang et al., GCN 37940; Francile et al., GCN 37941; Ackley et al., \nGCN 37943; Odeh et al., GCN 37944; Myers et al., GCN 37945; Bernardini et al., GCN 37946) with \nMISTRAL mounted on the 1.93 m telescope at Observatoire du Haut Provence (OHP, France). \n\nThe observations consisted of 300s + 600s exposures in r-band plus 2x600s in g-band. We have \nvery clear detections of the transient object both in g and r-band images: using as reference \nfield stars from the Pan-STARRS catalogue, we determine preliminar magnitudes of r(AB) = \n21.6 +/- 0.1 mag and g(AB) = 21.4 +/- 0.1 mag at a mean date of 2024-10-29T18:12:00 UT, ~16 \nhours after the burst.\n\nWe immediately after took a spectrum of the object using the MISTRAL blue grism (end of data \ncollection at 2024-10-29T19:45:21UT, ~17h30 after ther burst). Our spectrum cover the wavelength \nrange 4200-8000 AA and consist of one exposure of 1500 seconds. We detect a weak but significant \ncontinuum between ~5700/5900 and ~6500AA and this suggests an upper limit of 3.7/3.9 for the \nredshift.\n\nWe acknowledge the excellent support from Observatoire de Haute-Provence and in particular \nYoann Degot-Longhi for the MISTRAL observations and Thomas Baycroft.","createdOn":1730240007205}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Roberto Ricci at INAF-IRA <ricci@ira.inaf.it>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241021a: ATCA radio observations","circularId":37949,"format":"text/plain","body":"R. Siegel (PSU)\nreport on behalf of the Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory Team:\n\nAt 05:48:03 UT, the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) triggered and\nlocated GRB 241030A (trigger=1263718).  Swift slewed immediately to the burst.\nThe BAT on-board calculated location is \nRA, Dec 343.033, +80.439 which is \n   RA(J2000) = 22h 52m 08s\n   Dec(J2000) = +80d 26' 20\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3 arcmin (radius, 90% containment, including \nsystematic uncertainty). Berlanas (IAC and ULL), and I. Pérez-Fournon (IAC and ULL)\n\nWe report on optical follow-up observations of the likely long GRB 241030A detected by the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM) at 05:48:03 UT on 30 Oct 2024 (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37955) and by Swift BAT, XRT, and UVOT (Klinger et al., GCN 37956).\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 241030A with the Las Cumbres Observatory Global telescope network (LCOGT) Planewave Delta Rho 350 telescope and QHY600 CMOS camera located at the LCOGT node at McDonald Observatory (Texas, USA) in the SDSS g' and r' filters (600 sec exposures in both filters).\nWe detect a bright optical counterpart at a position consistent with the Swift UVOT coordinates (Klinger et al., GCN 37956) with magnitudes g' = 15.92 +/- 0.02 (starting at 06:25:11 UT  \non 30 Oct 2024, about 37 minutes after the Fermi trigger) and r'= 15.87 +/- 0.02 (starting at 06:35:19 UT on 30 Oct 2024, about 47 minutes after the Fermi trigger), calibrated against the PanSTARRS DR2 catalog and without corrections for Galactic extinction.\n\n\nThe bright optical counterpart has also been detected by COLIBRÍ (Watson et al., GCN 37957).\n\nWe encourage multiwavelength follow up.\n\n\nThese results are based on observations made with the Las Cumbres Observatory’s education network telescopes that were upgraded through generous support from the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, as part of a course on Astrophysical Techniques of the Master in Astrophysics of the Universidad de La Laguna, Tenerife, Spain (LCOGT observing programme IAC2024B-010, ULL-ASTRO-MASTER).\n\n","createdOn":1730278937956}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030A","submitter":"Weikang Zheng at UC Berkeley <weikang@berkeley.edu>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"GRB 241030A: Keck/LRIS spectroscopic redshift z = 1.411","circularId":37959,"body":"WeiKang Zheng, Thomas G. Brink, Alexei V. Filippenko (UC Berkeley), and Yi\nYang (Tsinghua Univ., Beijing), report on behalf of the KAIT GRB team:\n\n\nFollowing the detection of GRB 241030A (Klingler et al., GCN 37956), we\nobserved its optical counterpart (Klingler et al., GCN 37956; Watson et\nal., GCN 37957; Fernández-Rodríguez et al., GCN 37958) with the Low\nResolution Imaging Spectrometer (LRIS; Oke et al. 1995) on the Keck I 10 m\ntelescope. Observations started at 2024-10-30 06:47 UTC (about 1.0 hr after\nthe burst), and consisted of 3 x 200 s exposures with the 600/4000 grism\nand 400/8500 grating. The spectrum shows a well-detected continuum\nthroughout the complete range (3400-10,200 Ang). Numerous narrow absorption\nlines are present, including Mg II 2796, 2803 Ang doublets at redshifts of\n0.456, 0.862, 1.302, and 1.411. We conclude that the redshift of the GRB is\nlikely to be 1.411, but perhaps larger if the highest-redshift doublet is\nnot associated with the interstellar medium in the host galaxy.\n\nThe data presented herein were obtained at the W. M. Keck Observatory,\nwhich is operated as a scientific partnership among the California\nInstitute of Technology, the University of California, and the National\nAeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by\nthe generous financial support of the W. M. Keck Foundation. The authors\nwish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and\nreverence that the summit of Maunakea has always had within the indigenous\nHawaiian community. Xu (NAOC) report on behalf of a large collaboration:\n\nWe observed the optical afterglow of GRB 241030A detected by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37955) and Swift/BAT (Klingler et al., GCN 37956), using the 0.7-m telescope of the Thai Robotic Telescope network (TRT), located at Fresno, California, U.S.A.\n\nObservations started at 06:14:49.0 UTC on 2024-10-30, i.e., 27 mins after the Swift/BAT trigger, and we obtained a series of 60 s, 90 s, and 180 s frames in the R-filter.\n\nThe optical afterglow was decaying during our observations, and had R = 14.77 +/- 0.01 mag at 0.45 hr post-trigger, calibrated with nearby Pan-STARRS stars and not corrected for Galactic extinction.","createdOn":1730282090595}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241029A","submitter":"vishwajeet.s@iitb.ac.in","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241029A: GROWTH-India Telescope optical follow up","circularId":37961,"format":"text/plain","body":"A.P. Saikia, T. Mohan, V. Swain, R. Kumar, V. Bhalerao (IITB), G.C. Anupama, S. Barway (IIA) and K. Angail (IAO) report on behalf of the GIT team:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 241029A by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37932), SVOM/ECLAIRs & SVOM/GRM  (Schanne et al., GCN 37934; Wang et al., GCN 37935) with 0.7m GROWTH-India Telescope (GIT). We started the observation at 2024-10-29 14:08:55 UT, i.e., 11.8 hours after the Fermi GBM trigger. We obtained multiple exposures of 360 seconds in r' filter. We clearly detected the afterglow in our stacked image at the positions given by TRT (Jiang et. al., GCN 37937). The photometry result follows as:\n\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n| JD (mid)          | t-t0 (days) | Filter | Total Exposure (s) | Magnitude (AB) | \n| ----------------- | ----------- |------- | ------------------ | -------------- |\n| 2460613.16666     |    13.6     |   r'   |      6x360         | 20.97 +/- 0.10 |\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nOur result is consistent with Jiang et al., (GCN 37937), Lin et al., (GCN 37939), Jiang et al., (GCN 37940), Francile et al., (GCN 37941), Ackley et al., (GCN 37943), Odeh et al., (GCN 37944), Moskvitin et al., (GCN 37954).\n\nThe measurement is calibrated against PanSTARRS DR1 (Chambers et al., 2016) and not corrected for Galactic extinction.\n\nThe GROWTH India Telescope (GIT; Kumar et al. 2022) is a 70-cm telescope with a 0.7-degree field of view, set up by the Indian Institute of Astrophysics (IIA) and the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay (IITB) with funding from DST-SERB and IUSSTF. It is located at the Indian Astronomical Observatory (Hanle), operated by IIA. We acknowledge funding by the IITB alumni batch of 1994, which partially supports the operations of the telescope. Ruffini, L. Becerra, C.L. Bianco, M. Della Valle, Liang Li, G.J. Mathews, M.T. Mirtorabi, R. Moradi, F. Rastegar Nia, J.A. Rueda and Y. Wang\n\t\nWe are comparing and contrasting the seven episodes of BdHN I observed in GRB 241025A with Eiso = 5.5 x 10^53 erg (GCN 37927) and GRB 220101A with Eiso = 3.7 x 10^54 erg (GCN 31365). Both are highly energetic and located at a redshift greater than 4 (GCN 37866, GCN 31353), which allows a zoom-in investigation due to cosmological expansion. By examining the onset of black hole formation and the ultra-relativistic prompt emission (UPE), we gain insight into the rotational dynamics within these systems. This investigation requires additional observational data, particularly optical emission measurements from the newly born pulsar and extended X-ray afterglow data up to more than 10^6 seconds. Concurrent monitoring by Fermi-LAT will be crucial for capturing high-energy emissions, while the already performed Fermi-GBM observations enable the identification of the jetted emission. On this basis, the energy extraction process from a newly formed black hole will be determine.\n","createdOn":1730290260079}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030A","submitter":"Liping Xin at NAOC, SVOM <xlp@nao.cas.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241030A:  SVOM/VT optical afterglow observations","circularId":37965,"format":"text/plain","body":"SVOM/VT commissioning team: Y. Lian, Y. L. Wang, D. Y. Li, S. X. Wen, W. Yuan (NAO, CAS) on behalf of the Einstein Probe team \n\nFollowing the detection of the fast X-ray transient EP241026b (Lian et al., GCN 37902), we performed an observation of EP241026b with the Follow-up X-ray Telescope (FXT) on board the Einstein Probe. The observation started at 2024-10-27T03:36:23 (UTC), about 9 hours after the EP-WXT detection, with an exposure time of 4037 seconds. An uncatalogued X-ray source is detected at R.A. = 56.4058 deg, DEC = 41.0312 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of 10 arcsec in radius (90% C.L. statistical and systematic). The average FXT spectrum in 0.5-10 keV band can be fitted by an absorbed power law with a photon index of 2.3(+1.5/-1.4) (with a column density fixed at the Galactic one of 3.38 x 10^21 cm^-2), giving an average unabsorbed flux of 1.5(+2.8/-0.5) x 10^-13 erg/s/cm^2 in the 0.5-10 keV band. The FXT position is 2 arcsec away from the likely optical counterpart detected by LBT (Rossi et al., GCN 37938). We thus consider that the FXT detection is the X-ray counterpart of EP241026b. \n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics).","createdOn":1730294066216}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Brajesh Kumar at SWIFAR, YNU <brajesh@ynu.edu.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241021a: Optical rebrightening observations with Mephisto","circularId":37968,"format":"text/plain","body":"Yu Pan, Brajesh Kumar, Weikang Lin, Guowang Du, Yangwei Zhang, Tao Wang, Runnan Jiang, Yaosong Yu, Xingzhu Zou, Xinlei Chen, Jinghua Zhang, Yuanpei Yang, Yuan Fang, Yehao Cheng, Chenxu Liu, Xiangkun Liu, Xiaowei Liu (SWIFAR, YNU) report on behalf of the Mephisto Team:\n\nWe observed the field of EP241021a (Hu et al., GCN 37834) on 2024-10-29 with the 1.6m Multi-channel Photometric Survey Telescope (Mephisto) of Yunnan University located at Lijiang Observatory. (NAOC),  Shao-Lin Xiong (IHEP), Bing Zhang  (UNLV)\n\nreport on behalf of the SVOM team:\n\nDuring the commissioning phase, the SVOM/GRM was triggered in-flight by GRB 241030A at 2024-10-30T05:48:14 UT (T0), which was also observed by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37955) and Swift/BAT (Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory Team, GCN 37956).\n\nThe real-time alert data and light curves of SVOM/GRM were downlinked to the ground through the VHF system with low latency. With the event-by-event data downloaded through the X-band ground station, the GRM light curve shows that this burst consists of multiple pulses.\n\nThe GRM light curve can be found here:\nhttps://www.bursthub.cn//admin/static/svgrb241030A.png\n\nThis burst is located at about 41.56 degrees from the SVOM optical axis. However, at the time of the burst ECLAIRs was not collecting data.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA, China), National Center for Space Studies (CNES, France) and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS, China), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. D’Elia (ASI-SSDC & INAF-OAR) reports on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nAfter the rebrightening reported by Quirola-Vasquez et al. (GCN 37930) 6.7 day post trigger, a further Swift follow-up observation was performed. \n\nThe observation was secured between 8.1 and 8.5 days after the EP detection (Hu et al., GCN 37834). The new dataset has an exposure of 4.4 ks. An X-ray source is now detected at the position of the optical transient (see, e.g., Fu et al., GCN 37840) with a S/N of about 3. The count rate of the X-ray counterpart is (3+/-1)E-3 cts s^-1, corresponding to a 0.3-10 keV\nobserved flux of (1.3+/-0.4)E-13 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (assuming a typical GRB spectrum).\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.","createdOn":1730299663058}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241029A","submitter":"vishwajeet.s@iitb.ac.in","editedBy":"Judith Racusin at NASA/GSFC <judith.racusin@nasa.gov> on behalf of V. Salafia (INAF-OAB)\n\nAt 16:50:36 UT on 2024 Oct 8 (T_mid = 26.7 days post-burst)\nthe Karl G. NRAO joint program agreement.\n","createdOn":1730307906495}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030A","submitter":"Roberta Pillera at Politecnico and INFN Bari <roberta.pillera@ba.infn.it>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241030A: Fermi-LAT detection","circularId":37979,"format":"text/plain","body":"GRB 241030A: Fermi-LAT detection\n\nR. Pillera (INFN Bari), R. Gupta (NASA GSFC), D. Kocevski (NASA/MSFC), and P. Loizzo (UniTrento and INFN Bari) report on behalf of the Fermi-LAT Collaboration:\n\nOn Oct 30, 2024, Fermi-LAT detected high-energy emission from GRB 241030A, which was also detected by Fermi-GBM (trigger 751960088 / 241030242, GCN 37955), Swift-BAT (Klingler et al., GCN 37956), and SVOM-GRM (Wang et al., GCN 37972).\n\nThe best LAT on-ground location is found to be:\n\nRA, Dec = 343.0, 80.4 (J2000)\n\nwith an error radius of 0.2 deg (90 % containment, statistical error only).\n\nThis was 16 deg from the LAT boresight at the time of the GBM trigger: T0 = 05:48:03 UT.\n\nThe data from the Fermi-LAT show a significant increase in the event rate that is spatially and temporally correlated with the GBM emission with high significance. The photon flux above 100 MeV in the time interval 0-800 s after the GBM trigger is (4.0 +/- 1.0) E-6 ph/cm2/s. The estimated photon index above 100 MeV is -2.13 +/- 0.27.\n\nThe highest-energy photon is a 2 GeV event which is observed ~ 470 seconds after the GBM trigger.\n\nThe Fermi-LAT point of contact for this burst is Roberta Pillera (roberta.pillera@ba.infn.it).\n\nThe Fermi-LAT is a pair conversion telescope designed to cover the energy band from 20 MeV to greater than 300 GeV. It is the product of an international collaboration between NASA and DOE in the U.S. and many scientific institutions across France, Italy, Japan and Sweden.","createdOn":1730313291097}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030B","submitter":"Fermi GBM Team at MSFC/Fermi-GBM <do_not_reply@GIOC.nsstc.nasa.gov>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241030B: Fermi GBM Final Real-time Localization","circularId":37980,"body":"The Fermi GBM team reports the detection of a likely LONG GRB\n\nAt 18:34:20 UT on 30 Oct 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM) triggered and located GRB 241030B (trigger 752006065.391554 / 241030774).\n\nThe on-ground calculated location, using the Fermi GBM trigger data, is RA = 52.7, Dec = 36.0 (J2000 degrees, equivalent to J2000 03h 30m, 36d 00'), with a statistical uncertainty of 3.0 degrees.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 52.0 degrees.\n\nThe skymap can be found here:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/FTP/fermi/data/gbm/triggers/2024/bn241030774/quicklook/glg_skymap_all_bn241030774.png\n\nThe HEALPix FITS file, including the estimated localization systematic, can be found here:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/FTP/fermi/data/gbm/triggers/2024/bn241030774/quicklook/glg_healpix_all_bn241030774.fit\n\nThe GBM light curve can be found here:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/FTP/fermi/data/gbm/triggers/2024/bn241030774/quicklook/glg_lc_medres34_bn241030774.gif\n\n","createdOn":1730313928886}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030B","submitter":"David Palmer at LANL <palmer@lanl.gov>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241030B: Swift detection of a burst","circularId":37981,"body":"N. J. Klingler (GSFC/UMBC/CRESSTII), M. Ferro (INAF-OAB),\nJ. A. Kennea (PSU), F. E. Marshall (NASA/GSFC),\nK. L. Page (U Leicester), D. M. Palmer (LANL), T. M. Parsotan (GSFC),\nC. Salvaggio (INAF-OAB), T. Sbarrato (INAF-OAB) and\nM. A. Williams (PSU) report on behalf of the Neil Gehrels Swift\nObservatory Team:\n\nAt 18:34:20 UT, the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) triggered and\nlocated GRB 241030B (trigger=1263840).  Swift slewed immediately to the burst.\nThe BAT on-board calculated location is \nRA, Dec 50.788, +34.432 which is \n   RA(J2000) = 03h 23m 09s\n   Dec(J2000) = +34d 25' 57\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3 arcmin (radius, 90% containment, including \nsystematic uncertainty).  The BAT light curve showed a single peak\nstructure with a duration of about 8 sec.  The peak count rate\nwas ~2500 counts/sec (15-350 keV), at ~0 sec after the trigger.\n\nThe XRT began observing the field at 18:36:58.0 UT, 157.2 seconds after\nthe BAT trigger. Using promptly downlinked data we find an uncatalogued\nX-ray source located at RA, Dec 50.79212, 34.44596 which is equivalent\nto:\n   RA(J2000)  = 03h 23m 10.11s\n   Dec(J2000) = +34d 26' 45.5\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3.7 arcseconds (radius, 90% containment). This\nlocation is 51 arcseconds from the BAT onboard position, within the BAT\nerror circle. This position may be improved as more data are received;\nthe latest position is available at https://www.swift.ac.uk/sper.  We\ncannot determine whether the source is fading at the present time. \n\nA power-law fit to a spectrum formed from promptly downlinked event\ndata gives a column density consistent with the Galactic value of 2.01\nx 10^21 cm^-2 (Willingale et al. 2013).\n\nUVOT took a finding chart exposure of 150 seconds with the White filter\nstarting 160 seconds after the BAT trigger. No credible afterglow candidate has\nbeen found in the initial data products. The 2.7'x2.7' sub-image covers 100% of\nthe XRT error circle. The typical 3-sigma upper limit has been about 19.6 mag.\nThe 8'x8' region for the list of sources generated on-board covers 100% of the\nXRT error circle. The list of sources is typically complete to about 18 mag. No\ncorrection has been made for the expected extinction corresponding to E(B-V) of\n0.203.\n\nBurst Advocate for this burst is N. J. Ridnaia, D. Frederiks, A. Lysenko, D. Svinkin,\nA. Tsvetkova,  M. Ulanov, and T. Cline,\non behalf of the Konus-Wind team, report:\n\nThe long-duration GRB 241030A\n(Fermi-GBM detection: Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37955;\nSwift-BAT detection: Klingler et al., GCN 37956;\nSVOM/GRM observation: Wang et al., GCN 37972;\nFermi-LAT detection: Pillera et al., GCN 37979)\ntriggered Konus-Wind at T0=20996.591 s UT (05:49:56.591).\n\nThe burst light curve shows a multipeaked structure\nwhich starts at ~T0-112.7 s and has a total duration of ~210.4 s.\nThe emission is seen up to ~10 MeV.\n\nThe Konus-Wind light curve of this GRB is available at\nhttp://www.ioffe.ru/LEA/GRBs/GRB241030_T20996/\n\nAs observed by Konus-Wind, the burst\nhad a fluence of 5.48(-1.28,+1.95)x10^-5 erg/cm2,\nand a 64-ms peak flux, measured from T0+26.448 s,\nof 3.45(-0.82,+0.89)x10^-6 erg/cm2/s\n(both in the 20 keV - 10 MeV energy range).\n\nThe time-averaged spectrum of the burst\n(measured from T0 to T0+103.168 s)\nis best fit in the 20 keV - 10 MeV range\nby the GRB (Band) model with the following parameters:\nthe low-energy photon index alpha = -0.99(-0.19,+0.40),\nthe high energy photon index beta = -2.26(-0.61,+0.30),\nthe peak energy Ep = 140(-43,+35) keV\n(chi2 = 123/87 dof).\n\nThe spectrum near the maximum count rate\n(measured from T0+22.016 to T0+28.160 s)\nis best fit in the 20 keV - 10 MeV range\nby a power law with exponential cutoff model:\ndN/dE ~ (E^alpha)*exp(-E*(2+alpha)/Ep)\nwith  alpha = -0.91(-0.21,+0.23)\nand Ep = 196(-35,+55) keV (chi2 = 91/88 dof).\nFitting by a GRB (Band) model yields the same alpha and Ep,\nand an upper limit on the high energy photon index: beta < -2.2\n(chi2 = 91/87 dof).\n\nAssuming the redshift z=1.411 (Zheng et al., (GCN 37959))\nand a standard cosmology with H_0 = 67.3 km/s/Mpc, Omega_M = 0.315,\nand Omega_Lambda = 0.685 (Planck Collaboration, 2014),\nwe estimate the following rest-frame parameters:\nthe isotropic energy release E_iso is 2.84(-0.68,+1.04)x10^53 erg,\nthe peak luminosity L_iso is 4.47(-1.07,+1.15)x10^52 erg/s,\nthe rest-frame peak energy of the time-averaged spectrum\nEp,i,z is 339(-103,+84) keV and the spectrum near the maximum count rate\nEp,p,z is 473(-84,+133) keV.\n\nWith the obtained estimates, GRB 241030A is inside 68% prediction bands for\nboth 'Amati' and 'Yonetoku' relations derived for the sample of >300 long\nKW GRBs with known redshifts (Tsvetkova et al., 2017; Tsvetkova et al., 2021),\nsee http://www.ioffe.ru/LEA/GRBs/GRB241030_T20996/GRB241030A_rest_frame.pdf\n\nAll the quoted errors are at the 90% confidence level.\nAll the quoted values are preliminary.\n","createdOn":1730314859935}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030B","submitter":"Phil Evans at U of Leicester <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241030B: Prompt enhanced Swift-XRT position","circularId":37983,"body":"P.A. The burst was detected by both the on-board Count-Rate Trigger (CRT) and Image Trigger (IMT) and 15 alerts were received. The light-curve shows a single peak of about 8 s duration. The CRT detected the bust on time-windows from 2.56 to 20.48 s duration. The best detection is obtained by CRT with a signal-to-noise ratio of 37.6 in the 8-120 keV energy band over a time window of 5.12 s starting at Tb. \n\nThe GRB localization is RA, Dec = 50.794, 34.439 (J2000).\n\nThe statistical uncertainty on this position is 2.3 arcminutes, to which we recommend adding 2 arcminutes of systematic uncertainty in quadrature.\n\nAn automatic slew on this position was performed by SVOM upon request by the onboard trigger.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA), French Space Agency (CNES), and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. Liu (XAO) report on behalf of a large collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 241030B detected by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37980), Swift/BAT (Klingler et al., GCN 37981), and SVOM/ECLAIRs (Zhao et al., GCN 37984), using the HMT-0.5m telescope located at Nanshan, Xinjiang, China. Ambrosi  (INAF-IASFPA) , M. A. Williams (PSU), S. Dichiara (PSU),\nJ.A. Kennea (PSU), J.P. Osborne (U. Leicester), K.L. Page (U.\nLeicester), A.P. Beardmore (U. Leicester), M. Capalbi (INAF-IASFPA), M.\nPerri (SSDC & INAF-OAR) and P.A. Evans report on behalf of the\nSwift-XRT team:\n\nWe have analysed 11 ks of XRT data for GRB 241030A, from 63 s to 45.7\nks after the  BAT trigger. The data comprise 859 s in Windowed Timing\n(WT) mode (the first 9 s were taken while Swift was slewing) with the\nremainder in Photon Counting (PC) mode. \n\nThe late-time light curve (from T0+4.5 ks) can be modelled with an\ninitial power-law decay with an index of alpha=0.87 (+0.17, -0.57),\nfollowed by a break at T+10.4 ks to an alpha of 1.58 (+/-0.10).\n\nA spectrum formed from the WT mode data can be fitted with an absorbed\npower-law with a photon spectral index\tof 1.720 (+0.016, -0.011). The\nbest-fitting absorption column is  consistent with the Galactic value\nof 1.8 x 10^21 cm^-2 (Willingale et al. 2013). The PC mode spectrum has\na photon index of 1.95 (+0.08, -0.06) and a best-fitting absorption\ncolumn consistent with the Galactic value. The counts to observed\n(unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux conversion factor deduced from this\nspectrum  is 3.6 x 10^-11 (4.8 x 10^-11) erg cm^-2 count^-1. \n\nA summary of the PC-mode spectrum is thus:\nGalactic foreground: 1.8 x 10^21 cm^-2\nIntrinsic column:    1.8 (+1.8, -0.0) x 10^21 cm^-2 at z=1.411\nPhoton index:\t     1.95 (+0.08, -0.06)\n\nIf the light curve continues to decay with a power-law decay index of\n1.58, the count rate at T+24 hours will be 0.034 count s^-1,\ncorresponding to an observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux of 1.2 x\n10^-12 (1.6 x 10^-12) erg cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/01263718.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n","createdOn":1730325504501}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030B","submitter":"Cristina Andrade at UMN <andra104@umn.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB241030B: GRANDMA/TAROT Upper Limit","circularId":37989,"format":"text/plain","body":"A. Mukherjee (USRA), S. Dalessi (UAH), S. Bala (USRA) and C. Meegan (UAH) report on behalf of\nthe Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\"At 18:34:20.39 UT on 30 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB241030B (trigger 752006065/241030774).\nwhich was also detected by Swift/BAT (N. Klingler et al. 2024, GCN 37981), \nand SVOM/ECLAIRs (D. Zhao et al. 2024, GCN 37984).\nThe Fermi GBM on-ground location is consistent with the Swift/BAT position.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 54 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of a single bright peak with a duration (T90)\nof about 6.8 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0-1.0 to T0+9.2 s is best fit by\na power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff.\nThe power law index is -1.04 +/- 0.07 and the cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 200 +/- 20 keV.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(3.2 +/- 0.2)E-06 erg/cm^2. The 1-sec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0+0.83 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 6.7 +/- 0.2 ph/s/cm^2.\n\nA Band function fits the spectrum equally well with\nEpeak = 190 +/- 26 keV, alpha = -1.03 +/- 0.08 and beta = -2.81 +/- 1.\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1730339061076}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030A","submitter":"EP Team at NAOC/CAS <ep_ta@bao.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241030a: EP detection of GRB 241030A X-ray Afterglow","circularId":37997,"format":"text/plain","body":"H. Z. Wu (HUST), B. T. Wang (YNAO, CAS), D. F. Hu, Y. F. Liang (PMO,CAS), Q. Y. Wu, S. Q. Jiang, H. N. Yang, C. C. Jin, Z. X. Ling (NAO,CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nWe report on the detection of an X-ray transient, designated EP241030a, by the Wide-field X-ray Telescope (WXT) on board the Einstein Probe (EP) mission. The observation started at 2024-10-30T06:33:18(UTC) with an exposure of about 1.2 ks. The WXT position of EP241030a is R.A.= 343.013 deg, DEC = 80.449 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of 2.4 arcmin (radius, 90% C.L. statistical and systematic).\n\nThe average 0.5-4 keV spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed power-law with a photon index of 2.5(+0.8/-0.7) (with a column density fixed at the Galactic value of 1.8 x 10^21 cm^-2). The derived average unabsorbed 0.5-4 keV flux is 7.5(+3.0/-2.4) x 10^-11 erg/s/cm^2. The uncertainties are at the 90% confidence level for the above parameters. \n\nEP241030a is spatially and temporally consistent with GRB 241030A (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37955; Klingler et al., GCN 37956; Wang et al., GCN 37972; Ridnaia et al., GCN 37982). We thus consider the EP-WXT detection the X-ray afterglow of GRB 241030A. EP-FXT follow-up observation has been arranged. \n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics). Antier (OCA), Alan M. Watson (UNAM), Stéphane Basa (UAR Pytheas),\nWilliam H. Lee (UNAM), D. Akl (AUS), Jean-Luc Atteia (IRAP), Nathaniel R.\nButler (ASU), Damien Dornic (CPPM), J.-G. Ducoin (CPPM), Francis Fortin\n(IRAP), Simona Lombardo (LAM), Francesco Magnani (CPPM), and Margarita\nPereyra (UNAM) report:\n\nWe imaged again the field of GRB 241030A detected by Fermi/GBM, Swift/BAT,\nand Swift/XRT (Fermi GBM Team, GCN Circ. 37955; Klingler et al., GCN Circ.\n37956) during the commissioning of the COLIBRÍ (SVOM/F-GFT) telescope at\nthe Observatorio Astronómico Nacional on the Sierra de San Pedro Mártir in\nMexico.\n\nWe observed with the engineering test camera in a red filter that\napproximates SDSS r. The data were reduced using custom software and then\nanalysed and calibrated against the PS1 catalog using the STDWeb service\n(Karpov et al. 2022).\n\nIn 1200 seconds of exposure from 2024-10-31 01:46:50 to 02:10:56 UTC (0.83\nto 0.85 days after the trigger), we detect the optical counterpart with an\nAB magnitude of:\n\nr = 19.95 +/- 0.06\n\nThis magnitude is consistent with the last optical observations reported\n(GCN Circ. 37993, 37976, 37966 ).\n\nFurther observations are planned.\n\nWe warmly thank the COLIBRI engineering team and the staff of the\nObservatorio Astronómico Nacional on the Sierra de San Pedro Mártir\n","createdOn":1730363774719}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030B","submitter":"hagio.h.ffca@m.isct.ac.jp","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241030B : MITSuME Akeno optical upper limits","circularId":38001,"format":"text/plain","body":"H. Hagio, Y. Kubo, N. Higuchi, I. Takahashi, M. Niwano, M. Sasada, S. Hayatsu, H. Seki, S. Joshima, Y. Yatsu and N. Kawai (Science Tokyo) report on behalf of the MITSuME collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 241030B (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37980, Klingler et al. GCN 37981) with the optical three-color (g', Rc, and Ic) CCD cameras attached to the MITSuME 50-cm telescope Akeno. \n\nThe observation started at 2024-10-30 18:44:33.72 UT (10.2 minutes after the Swift/BAT trigger). We stacked the images with good conditions. We did not detect any uncatalogued sources within the enhanced Swift/XRT error region(Evans et al. GCN 37992). We obtained the 5-sigma limits of the stacked images as follows.\n\nT0+[min] | MID-UT | T-EXP[sec] | 5-sigma limits\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n15.9 | 2024-10-30 18:50:13.75 | 480 | g'>18.7, Rc>18.6, Ic>18.1\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nT0+ : Elapsed time after the trigger\nT-EXP: Total Exposure time\n\nWe used the PS1 catalog for flux calibration. The catalog magnitudes in PS1 g, r and i bands were converted to our g', Rc and Ic band magnitudes following Tonry et al. (2012), Table 6. The magnitudes are expressed in the AB system. (NAOC), Li-Ping Xin (NAOC),  Shao-Lin Xiong (IHEP), Bing Zhang  (UNLV)\n\nreport on behalf of the SVOM team:\n\nDuring the commissioning phase, the SVOM/GRM was triggered in-flight by GRB 241030B at 2024-10-30T18:34:22.000 UT (T0), which was also observed by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37980), Swift/BAT (Klingler et al, GCN 37981), Swift/XRT (Evans et al, GCN 37983) and SVOM/ECLAIRs (Zhao et al, GCN 37984).\n\nThe real-time alert data and light curves of SVOM/GRM were downlinked to the ground through the VHF system with low latency. With the event-by-event data downloaded through the X-band ground station, the GRM light curve shows that this burst consists of a single pulse with a T90 of 6.8 +1.5/-0.5 s. The SVOM/GRM on-ground position is consistent with the SVOM/ECLAIRs on-board localization.\n\nThe GRM light curve can be found here:\nhttps://www.bursthub.cn//admin/static/svgrb241030B.png\n\nThis burst is located at about 29.4 degrees from the SVOM optical axis.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA, China), National Center for Space Studies (CNES, France) and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS, China), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030B","submitter":"Antonio Martin-Carrillo at UCD,Space Science Group <antonio.martin-carrillo@ucd.ie>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241030B: GTC/OSIRIS+ tentative spectroscopic redshift z = 2.82","circularId":38004,"format":"text/plain","body":"N. R. Tanvir (U. Leicester), C. C. Thoene (ASU-CAS, AbAO), J. P. U. Fynbo (DAWN/NBI), A. de Ugarte Postigo (LAM/OCA, CNRS), L. Izzo (INAF-OACn & DARK/NBI), D. B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.), A. Martin-Carrillo (UCD), J. F. Agui Fernandez (CAHA), G. Lombardi (GTC), S. Geier (GTC) and G. Gómez Velarde (GTC) report:\n\nWe observed the optical counterpart (Fu et al., GCN 37985) of GRB 241030B (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37980; Klingler et al., GCN 37981; Zhao et al., GCN 37984) using OSIRIS+ on the 10.4 m GTC telescope, at the Roque de los Muchachos Observatory (La Palma, Spain). The observation consisted of 4 spectra of 1200 s each, obtained with grism R1000B, covering the spectral range between 3650 and 7800 AA, at a resolving power of 600.\n\nThe acquisition image, obtained on 2024-10-31 at 02:42:33 UT, 8.14 hr since the trigger, shows the afterglow at r(AB) = 23.53 +/- 0.12 mag, as compared to Pan-STARRS field stars.\n\nThe spectrum shows a faint continuum over the complete spectral range, though a drop in flux is observed blueward of ~4700 AA, suggesting the onset of the Lyman-alpha forest. No clear DLA trough is visible, but several, low S/N absorption features are present to the red of the drop, which we tentatively interpret as Si II 1526, Si IV 1393, C IV 1548,1550 (blended), Al II 1670, Al III 1854,1862 at z = 2.82, which we propose as the redshift of GRB 241030B.","createdOn":1730375640174}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Vladimir Lipunov at Moscow State U/Krylov Obs <lipunov@xray.sai.msu.ru>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"Fermi  trigger No 752006065: Global MASTER-Net observations report","circularId":38005,"body":"V. Lipunov, V.Kornilov, E. Gorbovskoy, K. Zhirkov, N.Tyurina, P.Balanutsa, A.Kuznetsov, V.Senik,  D. Vlasenko,\nG.Antipov, D.Zimnukhov, E.Minkina, A.Chasovnikov, V.Topolev, D.Kuvshinov, D. Cheryasov, Ya.Kechin, Yu.Tselik, A. Sosnovskij\n(Lomonosov Moscow State University, SAI, Physics Department),\n\nR. Podesta, C.Lopez, F. Izzo (INAF-OACn and DARK/NBI) and D. B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.) report:\n\nWe observed the field of the GRB 241029A (Schanne et al., GCN #37934; Wang et al., GCN #37935; Myers & Godwin, GCN 37945) with the Sinistro instrument mounted on the 1-m telescope of the LCO network, located at the Siding Spring Observatory, Australia. Observations started on 2024 October 29 at 09:21:56 UT (7.03 hr after the GRB trigger). We obtained a sequence of 3x180 s images in the SDSS-r filter.\n\nIn the stacked r-band image, we clearly detect the optical afterglow previously reported by other facilities (Jiang et al., GCN #37937; Lin et al., GCN #37939; Jiang et al., GCN #37940; Francile et al., GCN #37941; Ackley et al., GCN #37943; Odeh et al., GCN #37944; Adami et al., GCN #37948; Agui Fernandez et al., GCN #37950; Moskvitin & Spiridonova, GCN #37954; Saikia et al., GCN #37961; Qiu et al., GCN #37994) and by Swift-XRT (Bernardini et al., GCN #37946). We measure a preliminary magnitude of r = 20.32 +/- 0.07 mag (AB), calibrated against nearby stars from the Pan-STARRS catalog.\n  \nThis project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation program under grant agreement No 101004719.\n","createdOn":1730376845062}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Vladimir Lipunov at Moscow State U/Krylov Obs <lipunov@xray.sai.msu.ru>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"EP EP241030a: Global MASTER-Net observations report","circularId":38007,"body":"V. Sakamoto (AGU)\n(i.e. the Swift-BAT team):\n Using the data set from T-240 to T+963 sec from the recent telemetry downlink,\nwe report further analysis of BAT GRB 241030A (trigger #1263718)\n(Klingler, et al., GCN Circ. 37956). The initial episode\nstarts from T0 following four overlapping pulses, and ends around T+45 sec. Then,\nthe bright episode starts at T+105 sec, peaks at T+148 sec, and ends at T+230 sec.\nT90 (15-350 keV) is 173.3 +- 5.0 sec (estimated error including systematics).\n The time-averaged spectrum from T-0.86 to T+276.48 sec is best fit by a simple\npower-law model. Cucchiara (NASA) report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe observed the Fermi/Swift GRB 241030B field (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37980; Klingler et al., GCN 37981)  with the LCOGT 1-meter Sinistro instrument at the Teide Observatory, Tenerife site, on October 30, from 21:50 to 22:22 UT (corresponding to 3.27 to 3.8 hours after the GRB trigger time) with the sdss r and i filters.\n\nWe performed a series of 3x300s exposures in i- and r-bands. Meegan (UAH) report on behalf of the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\"At 05:48:03.33 UT on 30 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB241030A (trigger 751960088/241030242).\nwhich was also detected by Swift-BAT (Klingler et al. 2024, GCN 37956), SVOM-GRM (Wang et al. 2024, GCN 37972), and Konus-Wind (Ridnaia et al. 2024, GCN 37982)\nThe Fermi GBM on-ground location is consistent with the Swift position.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 17 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of multiple emission episodes with a duration (T90)\nof about 166 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0-21 to T0+217 s is best fit by\na Band function with Epeak = 129 +/- 7 keV,\nalpha = -1.35 +/- 0.02, and beta = -2.31 +/- 0.08.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(6.235 +/- 0.095)E-05 erg/cm^2. Bochenek at Liverpool John Moores University <a.m.bochenek@2023.ljmu.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241026b: Liverpool Telescope optical follow-up","circularId":38018,"format":"text/plain","body":"A. Bochenek and D. A. Perley (LJMU) report:\n\nWe observed the field of the fast X-ray transient EP241026b (Lian et al., GCN 37902) using the IO:O optical camera on the 2m robotic Liverpool Telescope. We obtained 6x200s exposures the SDSS r filter starting at 2024-10-31 01:41:20 UT, approximately 4.31 days after the trigger.\n \nThe potential optical counterpart reported by Rossi et al. (GCN 37938) is marginally detected:  forced photometry at the source location gives a 1.7-sigma detection, at a magnitude of r = 23.0 (-0.5, +0.9).   More conservatively, a 2-sigma upper limit on the source magnitude is r > 22.1. Photometry was obtained using nearby PanSTARRS secondary standards and was not corrected for extinction.\n \nThe transient has therefore faded since the observation by Rossi et al. (GCN 37938) - comparing their detection to our upper limit, it has faded by at least 0.6 mag between 1.48 and 4.31 days post-trigger.","createdOn":1730407112156}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030A","submitter":"Malte Busmann at Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München <m.busmann@physik.lmu.de>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241030A / EP241030a: FTW Optical and NIR observations of the optical counterpart","circularId":38019,"format":"text/plain","body":"Malte Busmann (LMU), Daniel Gruen (LMU), Brendan O’Connor (Carnegie Mellon U.) and Antonella Palmese (Carnegie Mellon U.) report:\n\nWe observed the optical counterpart of GRB 241030A (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37955; Klingler et al., GCN 37956; Watson et al., GCN 37957; Fernández-Rodríguez et al., GCN 37958; Zheng et al., GCN 37959, An et al., GCN 37960, Higuchi at al., GCN 3763; Qui et al., GCN 37965; Lin et al., GCN 37966 and similar) which was also detected as an X-ray transient by Swift (Klingler et al., GCN 37956) and Einstein Probe (Wu et al., GCN 37997) as EP241030a with the Three Channel Imager (3KK) at the Fraunhofer\nTelescope Wendelstein (FTW) in the r, i and J band simultaneously for 20 x 180 s starting at 2024-10-31T17:18:20 UT (1.48 days after the trigger). Abdikamalov (NU) report on behalf of the Energetic Cosmos Laboratory:\n\nThe Nazarbayev University Transient Telescope at Assy-Turgen Astrophysical Observatory (NUTTelA-TAO) observed the field of GRB 241030B observing in Sloan g' and r' bands, with the Burst Simultaneous Three-Channel Imager (BSTI; Grossan, Kumar & Smoot 2019, JHEA, 32, 14).\n\nWe started observations at 20:15:59 UT on 2024-10-30, 1.7 h after the BAT trigger. We report the following results:\n\nstart time  t-t0(s)  end time    UL g'   UL r'  exposure_time (s)\n-----------------------------------------------------------------\n20:15:59     6100    20:16:59    19.2    19.0     60\n\nstart time is in UT. t-t0(s) gives the time since trigger, in seconds. UL g' and UL r' give the 5 sigma upper limit sensitivity in magnitudes, for images co-added to the given exposure time. The results in in the table corresponds to co-adds of an initial short exposure image sequence of 0.5 s (these sub-second exposures are read-noise suppressed by our EMCCD cameras, with high gain electron multiplication active). M. Parsotan (GSFC), S. Dichiara (PSU), R. Gupta (NASA GSFC),\nT. Sakamoto (AGU) and T. Sbarrato (INAF-OAB) report on behalf of the\nNeil Gehrels Swift Observatory Team:\n\nAt 05:41:45 UT, the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) triggered and\nlocated GRB 241101A (trigger=1264304).  The BAT on-board calculated location is \nRA, Dec 204.333, +28.264 which is \n\n  RA(J2000)  = 13h 37m 20s\n  Dec(J2000) = +28d 15' 49\"\n\nwith an uncertainty of 3 arcmin (radius, 90% containment, including \nsystematic uncertainty).  The BAT light curve showed a double-peaked \nstructure with a duration of about 15 sec.  The peak count rate\nwas ~2300 counts/sec (15-350 keV), at ~1 sec after the trigger.\n\nDue to a Sun observing constraint, Swift cannot slew to the BAT\nposition until 17:57 UT on 2024 November 05. There will thus be no XRT\nor UVOT data for this trigger before this time.\n\nBurst Advocate for this burst is T. M. Parsotan (tyler.parsotan AT nasa.gov).\nPlease contact the BA by email if you require additional information\nregarding Swift followup of this burst. In extremely urgent cases, after\ntrying the Burst Advocate, you can contact the Swift PI by phone (see\nSwift TOO web site for information: http://www.swift.psu.edu/)\n\n","createdOn":1730440629971}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030A","submitter":"EP Team at NAOC/CAS <ep_ta@bao.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241030a: EP/FXT observation of GRB 241030A X-ray Afterglow","circularId":38026,"format":"text/plain","body":"Y. F. Liang (PMO, CAS), S. Q. Jiang (NAO, CAS), D. F. Hu (PMO, CAS), H. Z. Wu (HUST), B. T. Wang (YNAO, CAS), C. C. Jin, Q. Y. Wu, H. N. Yang, Z. X. Ling (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nWe performed a follow-up observation of the X-ray transient detected by EP-WXT, EP241030a (Wu et al., GCN 37997), which was associated with the GRB 241030A (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37955; Klingler et al., GCN 37956; Wang et al., GCN 37972; Ridnaia et al., GCN 37982) about 21 hours later. An uncatalogued X-ray source was detected at R.A. = 343.1426 deg, DEC = 80.4498 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of about 10 arcsecs (radius, 90% C.L. statistical and systematic), consistent with the position of the WXT transient within the uncertainties. The averaged EP-FXT spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed power-law (NH fixed at the Galactic value 1.8 x 10^21 cm^-2), with a photon index of 2.2 (+/- 0.2). The derived average unabsorbed flux is 1.5 (+0.2/-0.1) x 10^-12 erg/s/cm^2 in 0.5-10 keV. All the errors of the parameters quoted are at the 90% C.L.\n\nEP-FXT will keep monitoring this transient in the following days.\n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics).\n","createdOn":1730448727828}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030A","submitter":"Rui-Zhi Li at Yunnan Observatories, CAS <liruizhi@ynao.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241030A / EP241030a: GMG spectroscopic redshift possible at  z ~ 1.4","circularId":38027,"body":"R.-Z. Li, H. Lin, S.-S. Li, H.-C. Feng, B.-T. Wang, F.-F. Song, J. Mao and J.-M. Bai (YNAO, CAS) report:\n\nWe observed the optical counterpart of GRB 241030A (Klingler et al., GCN 37956; Watson et al., GCN 37957; Fernández-Rodríguez et al., GCN 37958; Zheng et al., GCN 37959; An et al., GCN 37960; Higuchi et al., GCN 37963; Qiu et al., GCN 37965; Lin et al., GCN 37966; Wu et al., GCN 37970; Breeveld &amp; Klingler, GCN 37974; Méndez-Lapido et al., GCN 37993; Moskvitin et al., GCN 38016; Busmann et al., GCN 38019; Schneider et al., GCN 38021), which was independently detected by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37955), Swift (Klingler et al., GCN 37956), SVOM/GRM (SVOM/GRM Team, GCN 37972), and Einstein Probe (Wu et al., GCN 37997; Liang et al., GCN 38026) as EP241030a.\n\nThe observation was conducted with the Gao-Mei-Gu (GMG) 2.4m telescope. Grism #3 was used, providing a wavelength coverage of 3400–9100 AA. A single 1-hour spectrum was obtained, with exposure beginning at 13:15:33 UT on 2024-10-30, about 7.46 hours after the Swift trigger.\n\nDespite the low signal-to-noise ratio of the spectrum, we identified a strong absorption line of Al II at 1671 AA, along with weaker absorption lines of Fe II at 2374 AA, 2383 AA, 2587 AA, and 2600 AA, Mg II at 2800 AA, and Mg I at 2852 AA. These metal absorption features consistently indicate a redshift of z ~ 1.4, consistent with the Keck/LRIS result (Zheng et al., GCN 37959).\n\nWe acknowledge the staff at the Lijiang Observatory for conducting the observation.\n","createdOn":1730452237838}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"Moskvitin Alexander at SAO RAS <mosk@sao.ru>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"GRB 241026A: SAO RAS optical observations","circularId":38028,"body":"A. Evans (U. Leicester) reports on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nWe have analysed 5.6 ks of XRT data for GRB 241030B, from 168 s to 51.2\nks after the  BAT trigger. The data are entirely in Photon Counting\n(PC) mode. \n\nThe light curve can be modelled with a power-law decay with a decay\nindex of alpha=1.17 (+/-0.07).\n\nA spectrum formed from the PC mode data can be fitted with an absorbed\npower-law with a photon spectral index of 2.00 (+0.31, -0.28). The\nbest-fitting absorption column is  2.9 (+1.3, -0.9) x 10^21 cm^-2,\nconsistent with the Galactic value of 2.0 x 10^21 cm^-2 (Willingale et\nal. 2013). The counts to observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux\nconversion factor deduced from this spectrum  is 3.8 x 10^-11 (5.5 x\n10^-11) erg cm^-2 count^-1. \n\nA summary of the PC-mode spectrum is thus:\nTotal column:\t     2.9 (+1.3, -0.9) x 10^21 cm^-2\nGalactic foreground: 2.0 x 10^21 cm^-2\nExcess significance: <1.6 sigma\nPhoton index:\t     2.00 (+0.31, -0.28)\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/01263840.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n\n","createdOn":1730457001633}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"A. Sakamoto (AGU)\n(i.e. the Swift-BAT team):\n \nUsing the data set from T-60 to T+243 sec from the recent telemetry downlink,\nwe report further analysis of BAT GRB 241101A (trigger #1264304)\n(Parsotan, et al., GCN Circ. 38025). T90 (15-350 keV) is\n10.3 +- 4.5 sec (estimated error including systematics).\n \nThe time-averaged spectrum from T-2.76 to T+12.86 sec is best fit by a simple\npower-law model. Abdikamalov (NU) report on behalf of the Energetic Cosmos Laboratory:\n\nThe Nazarbayev University Transient Telescope at Assy-Turgen Astrophysical Observatory (NUTTelA-TAO) observed the field of GRB 241030B observing in Sloan g' and r' bands, with the Burst Simultaneous Three-Channel Imager (BSTI; Grossan, Kumar & Smoot 2019, JHEA, 32, 14).\n\nWe started observations at 20:15:59 UT on 2024-10-30, 1.7 h after the BAT trigger. Observations were made in partly cloudy conditions. No source consistent with the XRT (P.A. Evans 2024, GCN 37983) was detected. We report the following results:\n\nstart time  t-t0(s)  end time    UL g'   UL r'  exposure_time (s)\n-----------------------------------------------------------------\n20:15:59     6100    20:16:59    19.2    19.0     60\n\nstart time is in UT. t-t0(s) gives the time since trigger, in seconds. UL g' and UL r' give the 5 sigma upper limit sensitivity in magnitudes, for images co-added to the given exposure time. The results in in the table corresponds to co-adds of an initial short exposure image sequence of 0.5 s (these sub-second exposures are read-noise suppressed by our EMCCD cameras, with high gain electron multiplication active). Li, H. Lin, S.-S. Li, H.-C. Feng, B.-T. Wang, F.-F. Song, J. Mao and J.-M. Bai (YNAO, CAS) report:\n\nWe observed the optical counterpart of GRB 241030A (Klingler et al., GCN 37956; Watson et al., GCN 37957; Fernández-Rodríguez et al., GCN 37958; Zheng et al., GCN 37959; An et al., GCN 37960; Higuchi et al., GCN 37963; Qiu et al., GCN 37965; Lin et al., GCN 37966; Wu et al., GCN 37970; Breeveld &amp; Klingler, GCN 37974; Méndez-Lapido et al., GCN 37993; Moskvitin et al., GCN 38016; Busmann et al., GCN 38019; Schneider et al., GCN 38021), which was independently detected by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37955), Swift (Klingler et al., GCN 37956), SVOM/GRM (SVOM/GRM Team, GCN 37972), and Einstein Probe (Wu et al., GCN 37997; Liang et al., GCN 38026) as EP241030a.\n\nThe observation was conducted with the Gao-Mei-Gu (GMG) 2.4m telescope. Grism #3 was used, providing a wavelength coverage of 3400–9100 AA. A single 1-hour spectrum was obtained, with exposure beginning at 13:15:33 UT on 2024-10-30, about 7.46 hours after the Swift trigger.\n\nDespite the low signal-to-noise ratio of the spectrum, we identified a strong absorption line of Al II at 1671 AA, along with weaker absorption lines of Fe II at 2374 AA, 2383 AA, 2587 AA, and 2600 AA, Mg II at 2800 AA, and Mg I at 2852 AA. These metal absorption features consistently indicate a redshift of z ~ 1.4, consistent with the Keck/LRIS result (Zheng et al., GCN 37959).\n\nWe acknowledge the staff at the Lijiang Observatory for conducting the observation.\n","editedOn":1730468099786,"createdOn":1730452237838,"version":2}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Dmitry Svinkin at Ioffe Institute <svinkin@mail.ioffe.ru>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241021a: Upper limit from Konus-Wind observations","circularId":38034,"format":"text/plain","body":"D. The candidate was found by the GstLAL [1] analysis pipeline.\n\nS241101ee is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.4e-11 Hz, or about one in 1e3 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S241101ee\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), NSBH (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [2] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [2] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state for maximum neutron star mass. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 32 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,1 sky map, the 90% credible region is 9938 deg2. Marginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 2003 +/- 601 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/.\n\n [1] Tsukada et al. F. Liang (PMO, CAS), Q. C. Liu (THU), Q. Y. Wu, D. H. Zhao, H. N. Yang, W. M. Yuan (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nWe report on the detection of a fast X-ray transient designated EP241101a, which was detected by EP-WXT at 2024-11-01T23:52:49 (UTC) and triggered the on-board processing unit at 2024-11-01T23:54:17 (trigger ID: 01709114858). The WXT position of EP241101a is R.A.= 37.763 deg, DEC = 22.731 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of 2.8 arcmin (radius, 90% C.L. statistical and systematic). The light curve of the transient observed by the WXT lasts more than 100 seconds. The average 0.5-4 keV spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed power-law with a photon index of 0.9 (+0.6/-0.6) (with the column density fixed at the Galactic value of 1.5x10^21 cm^-2). The unabsorbed average flux in 0.5-4 keV is 1.2 (+0.5/-0.4) x 10^(-9) erg/s/cm^2. \n\nAn autonomous observation was performed by the Follow-up X-ray Telescope (FXT) about 45 minutes later, the exposure time is about 1.6 ks. The delay of the FXT observation was due to the Earth obscuration. No significant source was detected by the FXT during its autonomous observation within the WXT error circle, thus we obtained a flux upper limit of 7.1 x 10^(-14) erg/s/cm^2 in the 0.5-10 keV. The quoted uncertainties are at the 90% confidence level for the above parameters. \n \nNo previously known bright X-ray sources are found within the error circle around the source position. Further follow-up observations are encouraged to identify the nature of this X-ray transient.  \n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with onboard X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics). \n","createdOn":1730535100642}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030A","submitter":"EP Team at NAOC/CAS <ep_ta@bao.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241030a: Futher EP-FXT observation of the X-ray Afterglow of GRB 241030A","circularId":38040,"format":"text/plain","body":"Y. F. Liang (PMO, CAS), S. Q. Jiang (NAO, CAS), H. Z. Wu (HUST), B. T. Wang (YNAO, CAS), D. F. Hu (PMO, CAS), H. N. Yang, C. C. Jin, H. Sun, Q. Y. Wu, Z. X. Ling (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nWe conducted a second follow-up observation of the X-ray transient detected by EP-WXT, EP241030a (Wu et al., GCN 37997 , Liang et al., GCN 38026), which was associated with the GRB 241030A (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37955; Klingler et al., GCN 37956; Wang et al., GCN 37972; Ridnaia et al., GCN 37982) about 2.8 days later. The observation began at 2024-11-02T01:58:27(UTC), with an exposure time about 3.2 ks, during which the afterglow was clearly detected. The averaged EP-FXT spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed power-law (NH fixed at the Galactic value of 1.8 x 10^21 cm^-2), with a photon index of 2.3 (+/- 0.6). The derived average unabsorbed flux is 2.4 (+1.0/-0.6) x 10^(-13) erg/s/cm^2 in 0.5-10 keV. All the errors of the parameters quoted are at the 90% C.L.\n\nEP-FXT will keep monitoring this transient in the following days.\n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics).\n","createdOn":1730537548376}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030A","submitter":"Christophe Adami at LAM <christophe.adami@lam.fr>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB241030A: OHP/T193 optical observations","circularId":38041,"format":"text/plain","body":"C. The candidate was found by the cWB [1], cWB BBH [2], GstLAL [3], MBTA [4], PyCBC Live [5], and SPIIR [6] analysis pipelines.\n\nS241102br is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.1e-41 Hz, or about one in 1e33 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S241102br\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), Terrestrial (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [7] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [7] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state for maximum neutron star mass. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is 14%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [8], distributed via GCN notice about 28 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [8], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,1 sky map, the 90% credible region is well fit by an ellipse with an area of 47 deg2 described by the following DS9 region (right ascension, declination, semi-major axis, semi-minor axis, position angle of the semi-minor axis):\n   icrs; ellipse(23h00m, +40d28m, 7.08d, 2.10d, 96.84d)\nMarginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 354 +/- 63 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/.\n\n [1] Klimenko et al. For each GW alert, these products are automatically generated and made available within minutes to expedite efficient electromagnetic follow-up observations. galaxies in NED-LVS that fall in the 90% probability volume for S241102br sorted by the joint probability of 3D position and WISE W1 luminosity (P_3D * P_LumW1). Galaxy is the NED preferred name. RA and Dec are the Equatorial coordinates in degrees (J2000). Objtype is the object type of the galaxy candidate. Distance is the distance to the galaxy in Mpc. m_NUV and mErr_NUV are the apparent magnitude and error from GALEX. m_Ks and mErr_Ks are the apparent magnitude and error from 2MASS. m_W1 and mErr_W1 are the apparent magnitude and error from AllWISE. P_3D is the probability that the galaxy is in the volume given the distance of GW event. The candidate was found by the cWB [1], cWB BBH [2], GstLAL [3], MBTA [4], PyCBC Live [5], and SPIIR [6] analysis pipelines.\n\nS241102cy is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 1.5e-08 Hz, or about one in 2 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S241102cy\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), or NSBH (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [7] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [7] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state for maximum neutron star mass. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [8], distributed via GCN notice about 28 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [8], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. For the bayestar.multiorder.fits,1 sky map, the 90% credible region is 1069 deg2. Marginalized over the whole sky, the a posteriori luminosity distance estimate is 2815 +/- 704 Mpc (a posteriori mean +/- standard deviation).\n\nFor further information about analysis methodology and the contents of this alert, refer to the LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA Public Alerts User Guide https://emfollow.docs.ligo.org/.\n\n [1] Klimenko et al. Proc. SPIE 2018). The detector of GRBAlpha consists of a 75 x 75 x 5 mm3 CsI scintillator read out by a SiPM array, covering the energy range from ~50 keV to ~1000 keV. To increase the duty cycle and the downlink rate, the upgrade of the on-board data acquisition software stack is in progress. Zhang (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nWe report on the detection of an X-ray transient designated EP241103a by the Einstein Probe (EP) mission. The transient event triggered the Wide-field X-ray Telescope (WXT) on-board processing unit at 2024-11-03T01:24:37 (UTC). The autonomous follow-up observation performed by the Follow-up X-ray Telescope (FXT) started about 55 minutes later (the delay of the FXT observation was due to the Earth obscuration). Afterwards, the FXT on-board processing unit was also triggered, showing that an uncatalogued source was detected at R.A. = 27.7572, DEC = 18.9587 (J2000) with an uncertainty of about 20 arcsec (radius, 90% C.L. statistical and systematic).  \n\nMore information on this source will be updated when the full telemetry data are received. Izzo (INAF-OACn and DARK/NBI) and D. B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.) report:\n\nWe observed the field of the EP burst 241103A (Zhao et al., GCN #38051) with the Sinistro instrument mounted on the 1-m telescope of the LCO network, located at the MacDonald Observatory, TX, United States. Observations started on 2024 November 3rd at 03:18:17 UT (1.89 hr after EP trigger). We obtained a sequence of 3x180 s images in the SDSS-r filter.\n\nIn the stacked r-band image, we did not detect any new source consistent with the position of the X-ray source reported by EP-FXT (Zhao et al., GCN #38051) up to a limit of r = 20.9 mag. \n\nThis project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation program under grant agreement No 101004719.\n\n","createdOn":1730610187291}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Wenxiong Li <liwenxiong1992@gmail.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241103a: GSP optical upper limit","circularId":38054,"format":"text/plain","body":"W. X. Li, S. J. Xue (NAOC), M. Andrews, J. Farah, D. A. Howell, M. Newsome, E. Padilla Gonzalez, C. McCully, and G. Terreran (Las Cumbres Observatory), on behalf of a larger collaboration, report:\nFollowing the detection of the fast X-ray transient EP241103a by the Einstein Probe (Zhao et al., GCN 38051) with the Sinistro instrument mounted on the 1-m telescope of the LCO, we initiated observations of the fast X-ray transient location starting on 2024 November 3rd at 03:45:21 UT (~2.3 hours after the EP/WXT trigger) in the i band.
