L. Wang, Y. Wang, H. Wang, H. Zhou, Z. P. Jin, Y. Z. Fan (PMO) reports:\n\nSwift-UVOT began to observe the field of GRB 241030A about 83 seconds after the trigger in the event mode (Klingler et al. GCN [37956](https://gcn.nasa.gov/circulars/37956), Breeveld et al. GCN [37974](https://gcn.nasa.gov/circulars/37974)).\n\nSimilar to [Jin+2023](https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2023NatAs...7.1108J/abstract) and [Zhou+2023](https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2023ApJS..268...65Z/abstract), we construct white-band and U-band light curves with the time bin of 20 seconds, and the light curves clearly show two bumps peak around 135s and 405s.\n\nThe behavior of the first bump is similar to that of X-ray and Gamma-ray light curves, which implies the first bump seems to orginate from the prompt flare, and the second one could be the onset of the afterglow.\n\nThe multi-band light curve is avaliable at [https://postimg.cc/BX25wrFn](https://postimg.cc/BX25wrFn).\n","createdOn":1730627856305}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S241102br","submitter":"EP Team at NAOC/CAS <ep_ta@bao.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S241102br: EP-WXT X-ray follow-up and flux limits","circularId":38056,"format":"text/plain","body":"Q. Y. Wu (NAO, CAS), J. Mao(YNAO, CAS), Y. F. Liang (PMO, CAS), Q. C. Liu (THU), R. D. Liang, D. H. Zhao, H. N. Yang, W. Yuan (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nFollowing on the trigger of the detection of the gravitational-wave (GW) event S241102br (LVK Collaboration, GCN 38043), we carried out a target-of-opportunity observation of the GW sky region with the Wide-field X-ray telescope(WXT) on board the Einstein Probe (EP). The observation started at 2024-11-02 15:44:04 (UTC), about 3 hours after the trigger of the GW event, lasting for around 5 hours. The 90% credible region of the event was fully covered by the large field-of-view of WXT, centering at the nominal GW source position at (RA=23h00m, Dec=+40d28m). The total effective exposure time is about 8 ks within the source credible region. No new X-ray source is found in this observation. This observation sets upper limits on the 0.5-4 keV flux in the source credible region to be approximately 2.42 x 10^(-12) erg/cm^2/s (90%. C.L.). Furthermore, we derived upper limits (see the Table below) for the top 20 galaxies from the galaxy list within the 90% volume reported by Cook et al. (GCN 38044). For queries on more information about this observation and the upper limits, please contact Qinyu Wu at the EP science center (ep_ta@nao.cas.cn).\n\n       galaxy name       |    ra     |    dec   |  flux upper limit (0.5-4 keV)\n                         |    deg    |    deg   |  ergs/cm^2/s\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nWISEAJ225919.78+394535.0 | 344.83242 | 39.75972 | 1.42E-12\nWISEAJ225952.51+442917.7 | 344.96871 | 44.48825 | 1.51E-12\nWISEAJ230520.33+400018.8 | 346.33458 | 40.00514 | 1.88E-12\nWISEAJ230012.95+415343.7 | 345.05417 | 41.89553 | 1.86E-12\nWISEAJ225938.70+415648.8 | 344.91125 | 41.94689 | 1.51E-12\nWISEAJ230201.05+423126.9 | 345.50446 | 42.52411 | 1.09E-12\nWISEAJ225743.15+404134.4 | 344.42971 | 40.69286 | 1.19E-12\nWISEAJ225708.96+394204.3 | 344.28733 | 39.70117 | 2.25E-12\nWISEAJ225745.81+373140.1 | 344.44088 | 37.52783 | 1.63E-12\nWISEAJ230533.61+424929.5 | 346.39000 | 42.82489 | 1.91E-12\nWISEAJ230113.12+354411.0 | 345.30462 | 35.73639 | 1.65E-12\nWISEAJ230419.52+423037.8 | 346.08129 | 42.51047 | 1.07E-12\nWISEAJ230200.39+415916.5 | 345.50162 | 41.98792 | 1.35E-12\nWISEAJ225832.97+415012.0 | 344.63725 | 41.83658 | 1.95E-12\nWISEAJ230133.36+394404.8 | 345.38892 | 39.73472 | 1.13E-12\nWISEAJ230257.02+393909.0 | 345.73754 | 39.65240 | 1.99E-12\nWISEAJ225902.80+411053.6 | 344.76171 | 41.18158 | 1.49E-12\nWISEAJ225942.19+421403.0 | 344.92588 | 42.23417 | 1.17E-12\nWISEAJ230431.87+440856.3 | 346.13275 | 44.14900 | 1.77E-12\nWISEAJ230530.98+394323.1 | 346.37912 | 39.72308 | 1.73E-12\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with onboard X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics). Zhao (NAO, CAS), Y. F. Liang (PMO, CAS), H. Y. Liu, W. D. Zhang (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nBased on the newly received telemetry data, we update the information of the fast X-ray transient EP241103a, initially detected by EP (Zhao et al., GCN 38051). The transient flare started at 2024-11-03T01:23:37 (UTC) and lasted for around 60 seconds. The average 0.5-4 keV spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed power law with a photon index of 0.8+/-0.4 (with N_H, the neutral hydrogen column density, fixed at the Galactic value of 6.3×10^20 cm^-2). The derived average unabsorbed 0.5-4 keV flux is 3.8 (+1.1/-0.9)×10^(-9) erg/s/cm^2, while the peak flux of the flare is found to be around 1.1×10^(-8) erg/s/cm^2. The uncertainties are at the 90% confidence level for the above parameters.\n\nThe EP-FXT autonomous follow-up observation started at 2024-11-03T01:28:50 (UTC). The observation clearly unveiled an uncatalogued X-ray source located at R.A. = 27.7578 deg, DEC = 18.9566 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of 10 arcsec in radius (90% C.L. statistical and systematic). During the 2,300-second exposure, no significant variation is observed in the light curve. We fit an absorbed power law model to the 0.5-10 keV energy spectrum with N_H fixed at the Galactic value. The average flux is 6.0 (+2.3/-1.4)×10^(-13) erg/s/cm^2, and the photon index is 2.0+/-0.4. Further follow-up observations are encouraged to identify the nature of this X-ray transient. \n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics).\n\n","createdOn":1730634414241}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Daniele B. Martin-Carrillo (UCD), report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe observed the location of the fast X-ray transient EP241103a (Zhao et al., GCNs 38051, 38058) using the Gemini South telescope equipped with the GMOS instrument. A total of 4x120 s images were secured in the r filter, carried out at a mean epoch 2024 Nov 3.267 UT, 5.0 hr after the EP/WXT trigger.\n\nA number of faint sources, none of which obviously point-like, are visible inside the refined EP/WXT error circle (Zhao et al., GCN 38058). Huber (both IfA, Hawaii) report: \n\nWe observed the field of the fast X-ray transient EP241101a (Liang et al., GCN 38039; Perez-Garcia et al., GCN 38047; Lipunov et al., GCN 38049; Adami et al., GCN 38060) using the 1m LOT at Lulin Observatory in Taiwan as part of the Kinder collaboration (Chen & Yang et al., 2024arXiv240609270C). The first LOT epoch of observations started at 16:59 UTC on the 2nd of November 2024 (MJD = 60616.707), 0.71d after the EP WXT trigger. \n\nWe utilized the astroalign (Beroiz et al. 2020, A&C, 32, 100384) and astropy (Astropy Collaboration et al. 2022, ApJ, 935, 167) packages to align and stack the individual frames. We do not find any evidence of a new and uncataloged source in the stacked images within the 2.8 arcminute error circle of EP-WXT localization. \n\nMoreover, we utilized the Python-based package AutoPhOT (Brennan & Fraser, 2022, A&A, 667, A62) to perform the PSF photometry on our stacked frames. Jonker (Radboud Univ.), A. Martin-Carrillo (UCD), D.B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI & Radboud Univ.), J.A. Quirola-Vasquez (Radboud Univ.), A.J. Levan (Radboud Univ and Warwick Univ), F.E. Bauer (PUC), report for a larger collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of EP241103a (Zhao et al., GCN 38051) with Swift/XRT starting on 2024-11-03 at 10:04:02 (UTC) for 984 seconds. We detect a faint X-ray source consistent with the improved Einstein Probe Follow-up X-ray Telescope position (Zhao et al., GCN 38058) at an enhanced position RA, Dec = 27.75834, 18.95698 (=01:51:02, +18:57:25.1) with an error radius of 4.6′′ (90% confidence) using the XRT UK build products website (Goad et al. 2007, A&A, 476, 1401; Evans et al. 2009, MNRAS, 397, 1177). An approximate X-ray flux of 4x10^-13 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (0.3-10 keV) was derived, implying a modest drop in source flux in the ~8.5 hours between the start times of the EP-FXT and the Swift/XRT observation (although still consistent at 1-sigma due to large uncertainty on both flux measurements). \n","createdOn":1730650421436}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Malte Busmann at Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München <m.busmann@physik.lmu.de>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241101a: Possible detection of an optical counterpart with FTW","circularId":38064,"format":"text/plain","body":"Malte Busmann (LMU), Daniel Gruen (LMU), Brendan O’Connor (Carnegie Mellon U.) and Antonella Palmese (Carnegie Mellon U.) report:\n\nWe observed the 90% localization area of EP241101a (Liang et al., GCN 38039) with the Three Channel Imager (3KK) at the Fraunhofer Telescope Wendelstein (FTW) for 40 x 180 s in the r, i and J band simultaneously. Observations started at 2024-11-03T01:36:19 UT (1.07 days after the EP-WXT trigger). Our observations are calibrated against the PS1 catalog and reach 24.5 AB mag in the r band and 24.0 AB mag in the i band at the 3σ limit.\n\nWe performed difference imaging in the r band with images from the DESI Legacy Survey DR10. In the difference image, we detect a source at \n\nRA, DEC (J2000) = 02:31:10.85, +22:44:54.75\n\ncorresponding to PSO J037.7952+22.7485 in the PS1 catalog, which is labeled as a variable source and a possible AGN/QSO. Compared to the mean magnitude in PS1 the source is brighter by ~0.5 mag in r-band and ~0.4 mag in i-band. This detection is consistent with the upper limits from Perez-Garcia et al., GCN 38047; Lipunov et al., GCN 38049 and Aryan et al., GCN 38061.\n\nWhile it is difficult to explain the short duration flare of EP241101a in the context of an AGN/QSO, we do not uncover any other variable sources to depth r>24.5 AB mag and i>24.0 AB mag over the entire 90% WXT localization.\n\nFurther observations are encouraged to determine the nature of the source.\n\nWe thank the staff of the Wendelstein Observatory for obtaining these observations.\n","createdOn":1730656573474}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S241102br","submitter":"carl.haster@unlv.edu","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S241102br: Updated Sky localization","circularId":38065,"format":"text/plain","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1), LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1), and Virgo Observatory (V1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S241102br (GCN Circular 38043). Pollacco report on behalf of the GOTO collaboration:\n\nWe report on observations of EP241103a (Zhao et al., GCN 38051) with the Gravitational-wave Optical Transient Observer (GOTO; Steeghs et al. 2022, Dyer et al. 2024). The position of the X-ray counterpart detected by EP/FXT (Zhao et al., GCN 38058) and Swift/XRT (Jonker et al., GCN 38063) was serendipitously covered by GOTO-N in survey mode at 02:03:32 UT on 2024-11-03, 39 minutes after trigger. The observation consisted of 4x45s exposures in the GOTO L-band (400-700 nm).\n\nNo new optical source is detected to a 3-sigma limit of L > 20.2 mags (AB).\n\nMagnitudes were calibrated using ATLAS-REFCAT2 (Tonry et al. 2018) and are not corrected for Galactic extinction.\n\nGOTO (https://goto-observatory.org) is a network of telescopes that is principally funded by the STFC and operated at the Roque de los Muchachos Observatory on La Palma, Spain, and Siding Spring Observatory in NSW, Australia, on behalf of a consortium including the University of Warwick, Monash University, Armagh Observatory & Planetarium, the University of Leicester, the University of Sheffield, the National Astronomical Research Institute of Thailand (NARIT), the University of Turku, the University of Portsmouth, the University of Manchester and the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias (IAC).\n\n","createdOn":1730664590398}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S241102cy","submitter":"carl.haster@unlv.edu","submittedHow":"web","subject":"LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA S241102cy: Updated Sky localization","circularId":38067,"format":"text/plain","body":"The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration report:\n\nWe have conducted further analysis of the LIGO Hanford Observatory (H1), LIGO Livingston Observatory (L1), and Virgo Observatory (V1) data around the time of the compact binary merger (CBC) candidate S241102cy (GCN Circular 38045). A. Smith (Rice University) and R. P. J. Tilanus (Joint Astronomy Centre) \nreport on behalf of the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope (JCMT) GRB collaboration:\n \nWe used the SCUBA sub-millimeter continuum bolometer array on the JCMT to \nobserve the variable radio source VLA J0702+3850 proposed by Taylor et al. \n(GCN #40) as the radio afterglow to GRB 980329.\n \nOn UT 1998 April 5.2 we detected a source at 850 microns with a preliminary \nflux density of 5 +/- 1.5 mJy.  This source was confirmed on April 6.2 with \na flux density of 4 +/- 1.2 mJy, resulting in an average of 4.5 +/- 1 mJy \nover the two days.  The 850 micron source is present in all our separate \nintegrations making us confident it is real.  A hint of a fading trend \nappears to be confirmed by observations on April 7.2 when the (preliminary)\n850 micron flux density was 2 +/- 0.8 mJy. \n\nThe source was not detected at 450 microns with a preliminary rms of 10.0 \nmJy averaged over the first two days.\n\nAssuming these fluxes are due to the burst counterpart, they should represent\n\"clean\" measures of its intensity, unaffected by scintillation and extinction.  \nMonitoring with SCUBA is continuing.\n\nWe wish to thank Dr. L. Kouveliotou, Universities Space Research Association, M. Kippen, P.\nWoods, G. Richardson, University of Alabama in Huntsville, V.\nConnaughton, National Research Council, report on behalf of the BATSE\nteam at NASA/Marshall Space Flight Center:\n\nBATSE has detected repeated soft gamma-ray bursts consistent with the\nsame (previously unknown) location. We recorded three bursts on June\n15.109, 15.296, 15.411 UT (BATSE triggers 6825, 6826, 6827,\nrespectively) with an average duration of ~ 200 milliseconds.\nPreliminary spectral analysis of the data indicates that the events\nare very soft, with power law spectral indices varying between -3.0\nand -7.0. BATSE triggered 5 more times, on June 17.873, 17.901,\n18.004, 18.035, and 18.071 UT (BATSE trigger numbers 6833, 6834, 6835,\n6836 and 6837, respectively). The last trigger had a peak count rate\nof over 300000 counts/sec above background (integrated over 4\ndetectors between 20-1000 keV, in 1 second interval) and a duration of\n~ 3 seconds. Due to its very high peak intensity, deadtime effects\nprevent us from using it for localization, until we receive more data\ntypes. The weighted location of the 7 remaining triggers is centered\non R.A. = 16h27m12.0s and dec = -41d06.0' with an error radius of\nabout 2 degrees.  This location does not correspond to any previously\nknown SGR source; we conclude that we have discovered a new source,\nSGR1627-41. We have initiated an RXTE ToO and we strongly encourage\nwide field observations at other wavelengths.","createdOn":898140980000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Jens Hjorth at NORDITA  <jens@nordita.dk>","subject":"GRB 980613 Optical Observations","circularId":109,"bibcode":"1998GCN...109....1H","body":"GRB 980613 Optical Observations\n\nJ. Hjorth, M. I. Andersen, H. Pedersen, A. O. Jaunsen on behalf of the NOT \nGRB team and E. Costa & E. Palazzi on behalf of the SAX GRB team report:\n\nOn June 13.9 UT and June 17.9 UT we obtained R band images (600 sec each, \nseeing FWHM=0.7\") of the BeppoSAX error circle of GRB 980613 (Piro & Costa, \nGCN #99) with the 2.5-m Nordic Optical Telescope. We have discovered a faint \npoint source in our June 13.9 image which is not detected in our June 17.9 \nimage (which reaches a similar limiting magnitude). The source is located at \n(+- 0.5\"):\n\nRA(J2000)  =  10 17 57.64\nDec(J2000) = +71 27 26.4\n\nPreliminary photometry (Cousins R) of the source yields:\n\nJune 13.8897 UT: R = 22.9+-0.2\nJune 17.9088 UT: R > 24.0 (formal 10-sigma limit)\n\nThese numbers assume R=19.11 for USNO catalogue entry U1575-03105992 located at \nRA(J2000)=10 17 54.83, Dec(2000)=+71 27 39.8, consistent with the photometry \nof the isolated star 4_r of Odewahn et al. (GCN #105) (assuming r-R=0.35).\n\nThe location of the source is consistent with the BeppoSAX WFC error circle\nof GRB 980613 (GCN #99) and the BeppoSAX MECS error circle for source A\n(Piro, GCN #104; Costa et al., IAUC 6939). \n\nThe photometry is consistent with previously reported upper limits for\noptically variable objects in the field (R > 20.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado \net al., GCN #102; I>21.5 on June 13.9, Castro-Tirado et al., GCN #103; \nr>21.0 on June 16.0, Odewahn et al., GCN #105; I>22.3 on June 14.2, Halpern\net al., GCN #106, I>20.6 on June 14.0 and I>21.5 on June 14.4, Diercks et \nal., GCN #108).\n\nGiven the consistency with the BeppoSAX error circles of GRB 980613 and\nthe rapidly fading nature of the source we suggest that the detected object\nis the optical afterglow of GRB 980613.\n\nFinding charts and updates of these preliminary results will be posted at \nhttp://www.nordita.dk/~jens/grb980613/\n\nThis report may be cited.","createdOn":898186684000,"email":"jens@nordita.dk"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"SAX Science Operations at IAS/CNR Frascati  <saxsci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"GRB980613 BeppoSAX-NFI follow up","circularId":104,"bibcode":"1998GCN...104....1P","body":"GRB980613: follow-up with NFI:\n\nLuigi Piro on behalf of the BeppoSAX team report:\n\n\nTwo previously unknown X-ray sources have been found in the WFC error\ncircle by the MECS during the follow up observation started 9 hrs after\nthe GRB.\n\nSource A is at\nR.A.(2000)= 10h17m53s\nDec.(2000)= +71d27'24\"\n\nSource B is at\nR.A.(2000)= 10h18m04s\nDec.(2000)= +71d33'30\"\n\nThe error radius is 50\".\n\nSource B does not show substantial variability.\nSource A shows a rather strong decay during the observation, and is very\nlikely the X-ray afterglow of GB980613.","createdOn":897952217000,"email":"saxsci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Jules Halpern at Columbia U.  <jules@astro.columbia.edu>","subject":"GRB980613 Optical Observations","circularId":106,"bibcode":"1998GCN...106....1H","body":"J. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 08:33:12 UTC (=30792s UT), a soft spectrum, high \nenergy transient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized \nby HETE.\n(NB: This is the second GRB detected by HETE on 26 March 2001.)\n\nBoth the WXM and the FREGATE instruments detected the event. The \nburst triggered FREGATE in the 6-120 keV band, at the 160ms timescale.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h24m23.36s, \nDec. = -11o09'57\", derived from combining data from the WXM and \nBoresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the WXM \nlocalization is 18 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we estimate \na systematic error radius at present of 10 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 30 \narcsec (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~4 Crab; with WXM \n(2-25 keV), ~2 Crab. The burst duration was about 4 seconds.\n\nThe high galactic latitude of the source, well away from the Galactic \nBulge, and the shape of its spectrum suggest that it is a gamma-ray \nburst similar to those reported for \"X-ray rich\" GRBs by Heise et al \n(2001) from BeppoSAX observations.\n\nFollow-up observations of this unusual transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on the GRB010326B (including light curves), as \nwell as for the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985612698000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Luigi Piro at IAS/CNR Frascati  <piro@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX GRB ALERT: GRB010412","circularId":1033,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1033....1P","body":"BeppoSAX GRB ALERT: GRB010412\n\n\nOn Apr. 12, 21:46 U.T. a  GRB has been detected simultaneously by the GRBM and WFC1\naboard BeppoSAX.\n\nPreliminary  coordinates from WFC are:\n\nR.A.(2000)= 294.89\nDEC.(2000)= 13.62\n\nThe error radius at this stage of analysis is 10'.\n\nWe are not planning a follow-up observation of this burst, due to the\non-going pointing of another TOO\n\nLuigi Piro\nBeppoSAX Mission Scientist","createdOn":987129797000,"email":"piro@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Howard E Bond at STScI  <bond@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 010326 optical observations","circularId":1016,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1016....1B","body":"I have obtained CCD images centered on the position of GRB 010326,\n11:50:59.1 -23:32:44 (J2000), with the Cerro Tololo Interamerican\nObservatory 0.9-m reflector, on 2001 March 26 from 08:18 to 08:50 UT. Hurley, on behalf of the Ulysses GRB and HETE teams; T. Cline, on\nbehalf of the Ulysses, Konus-Wind, and HETE GRB teams; E. Mazets and\nS. Kawai, and J.-L.\nAtteia, on behalf of the HETE team report:\n\nUlysses, Konus-Wind and Konus-A observed GRB010326A. This burst had a\nduration of ~25 s, a 17 keV - 2.5 MeV fluence of ~4x10^-5 erg/cm2, and\na peak flux over 0.25 s of ~8x10^-6 erg/cm2 s. From a cross-correlation\nof the Ulysses and Konus-Wind time histories, we have triangulated the\nlocation of the burst to an annulus centered at RA(2000)=178.727 deg.,\nDecl(2000)=30.803 deg., and radius 81.702+/- 0.028 deg. (3 sigma confidence).\nThe triangulation based on the Konus-Wind and the Konus-A data resulted\nin an annulus centered at RA(2000)=94.662 deg., Decl(2000)=21.978 deg., and\nradius 69.7+/- 0.4 deg. (1 sigma confidence).  Combining these data, we\nare able to restrict the location of the burst to the following ~180\nsquare arcmin. error box.\n\n  RA(2000)       DEC(2000)\n132.9630 o     -38.3005 o (CENTER)\n132.3408 o     -38.5784 o (CORNER)\n132.3988 o     -38.5441 o (CORNER)\n131.5271 o     -38.0568 o (CORNER)\n131.5851 o     -38.0230 o (CORNER)\n\nThis location is consistent with the spectra and time history seen in \nthe four HETE FREGATE detectors. The above error box can be refined \nby further processing.\n\nOn this basis, we have concluded that the WXM location reported in GCN\n1014 for this burst is spurious.  This burst is distinct from the other \nGRBs (GRB010326B, GCN 1018; GRB010213, GCN 934) for which HETE WXM \nlocations have been reported, in that it has a very low \nsignal-to-noise excess count rate in the WXM, and our further \nanalysis suggests that it is this fact that accounts\nfor the spurious location. Montanari, C. Guidorzi and F. Frontera, Physics Dept., University of\nFerrara, Italy; F. Calura, Astronomy Dept., University of Trieste; M.\nFeroci, IAS, CNR, Rome, Italy, report:\n\nThe short burst from SGR1900+14 detected by HETE (GCN # 1078) was also\ndetected by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor aboard BeppoSAX. The burst\ntriggered the GRBM on board logic at 03:34:07.15 UT of July 2, 2001. The\nevent duration was about 2 s.\n\nThe event showed significant flux only in the 40-100 keV energy band. The\ntotal counts above the background level in this range were 400 +/- 50. \nAssuming a power law spectral shape, from our data we can set a lower\nlimit to the photon index of 3.5. With a photon index of 4.0, the derived\nfluence is (1.2+/- 0.2) x 10-6 erg cm-2 in the band from 40 to 100 keV. \nUsing the high time resolution data only available in the 40-700 keV band,\nthe peak flux obtained from 125 ms bins corresponds to (1.4 +/- 0.4)x10-6\nerg cm-2 s-1. \n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":994267010000,"email":"frontera@fe.infn.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"SGR1900+14 - correction","circularId":1054,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1054....1H","body":"In GCN 1053, the date should read 2001 April 17 and 18, not 2000 April 17 and 18.","createdOn":988386763000,"email":"khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andrew S. Metzger report for a larger HST GRB Collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000418 was re-observed by the Hubble Space Telescope\nstarting on UT 2001 Feb 11.64 using the STIS camera in open (50CCD)\nmode.  The individual exposures were combined using Drizzle for a total\nexposure time of 5120 s.\n\nWhen this image is subtracted from that obtained by HST on 2000 June\n4.17 a small residual of magnitude R~28 is found at the position of the\ncompact galaxy believed to be the host galaxy (GCN 669); however, the\nresidual is sufficiently faint to be consistent with no detection at\nabout the 2 sigma level. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. Morgan, G. \nPizzichini, and G. Prigozhin, on behalf of the HETE Operations and \nHETE Optical-SXC Teams;\n\nN. Kawai, M. Matsuoka, Y. Shirasaki, T. Tamagawa, K.Torii, T. \nSakamoto, A. Yoshida, E. Fenimore, M. Galassi, and  C. Graziani, on \nbehalf of the HETE WXM Team;\n\nJ-L Atteia, M. Boer, J-F Olive, J-P Dezalay, and K. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 15:54:53.123 UT on 23 June, the HETE FREGATE and WXM instruments \ndetected and localized an intense burst from SGR1806-20, a soft \ngamma-ray repeater. This event, disseminated in near real time as a \nGCN Alert (HETE BID_1566; see \nhttp://gcn.gsfc.nasa.gov/gcn/hete_grbs.html), is the second burst \nlocalized from this source in the past week. (The first burst was \nreported in GCN Circular #1068). The coordinates (J2000) of the 23 \nJune burst are:\n\nR.A. = 272.1460 deg. (18h08m35s.02)\n\nDec. = -20.3658 deg. (-20:21:56)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 6 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1806-20 lies 3.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~200 ms, comprised of two \npeaks each <100ms in duration. A total of 2250 counts were detected \nduring that interval, corresponding to a fluence of ~4 x 10-7 ergs \ncm-2 . Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 15:06:36.51 (54396.51s) UTC on 28 June, the HETE FREGATE and WXM \ninstruments detected and localized an intense burst from SGR1900+14, \na soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the third burst reported \nfrom this source in the past week, and the second one reported by \nHETE on 28 June. (The previous HETE burst was reported in GCN \nCircular #1073.) The coordinates (J2000) of the burst localized by \nHETE are:\n\nR.A. = 286.803 deg. (19h07m12s.62)\n\nDec. =  +9.340 deg. (+9:20:22)\n\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 24 arcmin in radius.\nSGR1900+14 lies 6.2 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~400 ms. A total of 4700\ncounts above background were detected during that interval,\ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux\nwas ~4 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >150 x Crab flux) during a 5 ms interval.\n\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993745828000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andrew S. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 980326: Late-time HST/STIS observations","circularId":1029,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1029....1F","body":"Andrew Fruchter (STScI), Paul Vreeswijk (University of Amsterdam) and\nPeter Nugent (LBNL) report on behalf of a larger HST GRB collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of GRB 980326 with HST/STIS on 31 December 2000,\njust over 1000 days after the burst. The total exposure time was 7080\nseconds in the 50CCD aperture. The images were reduced by the standard\nHST pipeline, and drizzled to a combined image with a pixelscale of\n0.\"0254.\n\nWe projected the location of the early afterglow from a KeckII/LRIS R\nband image, taken by Filippenko, Leonard and Riess on March 27, 1998\n(see GCN 33).  We estimate the 1-sigma error radius to be less than 1.5\ndrizzled HST pixels, which includes both the scatter in the\ntransformation (0.9 pixels, using 6 reference stars) and the\nmeasurement error of the transient in the Keck image (0.8 pixels).\n\nWithin one pixel of the estimated position, there was evidence of a\nsmall source.  We therefore convolved the image with a gaussian with a\nFWHM equal to that of the PSF (3.5 drizzled pixels).  This procedure\nuses the PSF as a matched filter to enhance the the signal-to-noise\nratio of unresolved sources.  In the convolved image an object is\nfound, again offset by one pixel from the expected position with a\nsignificance of ~4.5 sigma.  We estimate a magnitude (in the broad STIS\n50ccd filter) of V = 29.25 +/- 0.25.\n\nBloom et al., (1999, Nature, 401, 453) have suggested that the unusual\nlight curve of this GRB might be explained by an underlying supernova,\nand on the basis of this estimated a redshift of about z~1.   A\nsupernova at this redshift (which in this model peaks around a\nmagnitude of 25) would be expected to be significantly fainter than\nV=29 by now (as would the rapidly decaying GRB afterglow).  Therefore,\nwe may be detecting a faint host galaxy.  Deep HST images have in all\nother cases detected a host underlying the GRB, when good astrometry\nwas available for the GRB.  If we are observing a host galaxy, then the\nabove magnitude could underestimate its brightness by as much as a few\ntenths of a magnitude, due to extended emission missed in this\nmeasurement.  A galaxy at a z~1 with this observed magnitude would lie\na rather remarkable 7 magnitudes below L*, the knee of the of the\ngalaxy luminosity function at that redshift.\n\nGiven the apparent point-source nature of the detected object, and the\nlack of color information, we cannot exclude the possibility (which we\nconsider remote) that we are observing a light echo, from either the\nGRB or the supernova.\n\nImages of the field can be found at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/980326","createdOn":985809183000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Filippo Frontera at ITESRE CNR  <filippo@tesre.bo.cnr.it>","subject":"Giant flare from SGR1900+14","circularId":1041,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1041....1G","body":"C.Guidorzi, E.Montanari and F.Frontera, University of Ferrara, Italy;  E.\nCosta, G.Gandolfi, M.Feroci and L.Piro, IAS-CNR, Roma;  L.Amati, TESRE,\nCNR, Bologna; J.J.M. in 't Zand, SRON and Astronomical Institute, Utrecht,\nNL; G. D'Andreta, R. Kaptein, L. Reboa, BeppoSAX Science Operation Center,\nreport:  \nA giant flare of SGR1900+14 was detected by BeppoSAX at 7:55:12 UT of\nApril 18, 2001. The peak flux measured by the Gamma Ray Burst Monitor, \nafter background subtraction and no dead time correction, is around 15400\nc/s. The flare has an approximate duration of 40 s. The 5s pulsation is\napparent.  The Wide Field Camera #1 was switched off by rate protection at\na level of 1300 c/s before the flare peak.  A BeppoSAX TOO is in\nprogress. \n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":987599842000,"email":"filippo@tesre.bo.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andrew S. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB000301C: Late-time HST/STIS observation","circularId":1063,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1063....1F","body":"A. Fruchter and P. Vreeswijk report for a larger collaboration:\n\nThe field of GRB 000301c was reobserved by the Hubble Space Telescope\nusing the STIS camera in open (50CCD) mode on the 25 Feb 2001, or\nnearly one year after outburst.   Twelve dithered exposures were\ncombined to produce a final image with an exposure time of 7031s.\n\nNo source is immediately visible at the position of the GRB.  However,\nwhen the image is convolved with gaussians or boxcars with\ncharacteristic sizes from that of the PSF, 0.\"08, to 0.\"2, an extended\nobject appears to be visible under the position of the GRB and to its\nNE.  Although extended light from both a nearby bright star, and the\nlarger galaxy to the NW of the GRB make an exact determination of the\nsignificance of this object difficult, we believe this is approximately\na 3-4 sigma detection.  The probable host has an estimated magnitude of\nR = 28.0 +/- 0.3.  This magnitude is just consistent with the estimates\nof an underlying host from our earlier imaging, GCN 627 and 701.  It\nis, furthermore, about two magnitudes brighter than we would expect the\nOT to have been at this time, had it continued to decline with a\ntemporal power-law steeper than -2 (c.f. GCN 701 and  Rhoads and\nFruchter, ApJ 2001, 546, 177).\n\nIf this is indeed a detection of a host, then in all cases where we\nhave obtained a deep HST image and an OT is well localized (to ~0.\"1),\na host has been found under the GRB.   However, again, due to the\nscattered and extended light in this region of the image, the detection\nmust be considered tentative.\n\nThe image can be seen at http://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/000301C","createdOn":991165718000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"SGR1806-20: Localization by HETE","circularId":1068,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1068....1R","body":"SGR1806-20: Localization by HETE\n\nG. L. Kaplan, J. A. Eisner, S. R. Kulkarni and J. S. Bloom,\nCalifornia Institute of Technology, Pasadena, report\n\n\"On June 19, 2001 UT, we observed the position of the optical transient\nof GRB 000630 (Fynbo et al. astro-ph/0101425) with the Echelle\nSpectrograph & Imager (ESI) on Keck II.  Images were obtained in R and\nI bands. The seeing was 0.75 arcsec but the observations suffered from\nvariable extinction due to clouds. In our preliminary analysis of the\nR-band data we detect a faint source at the position of the OT.  This\nsource is about 2 magnitudes fainter than the galaxy two arcseconds to\nthe North of the OT (see Fynbo et al. for discussion of this galaxy).\nWe identify this faint object as the host galaxy of GRB 000630.\"","createdOn":992967555000,"email":"srk@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Vladimir Sokolov at SAO RAS  <sokolov@sao.ru>","subject":"GRB000926, Host Galaxy Observations","circularId":1091,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1091....1D","body":"S. Dodonov, T. Fatkhullin, V. Sokolov (SAO RAS), Andrew Fruchter (STScI),\nV. Komarova, A. Moiseev (SAO RAS), A. Cherepashchuk, K. Postnov (SAI-MSU Moscow)\nreport:\n\n\"On July 24 and 25, 2001 UT, we have observed the field of the optical\ntransient of GRB 000926 (Fynbo et al., 2001, A&A, 373, 796).\nWe have obtained B, V, Rc, Ic images with the SCORPIO\n(http://www.sao.ru/~moisav/scorpio/scorpio.html) at the\n6-m telescope of SAO RAS. Photometric conditions were good and\nthe seeing was about 1.3 arcsec. Photometric calibration was\nperformed using Stetson standards in Landolt standard field PG1633.\n\nAt the position of the optical transient we have detected an object -\na host galaxy. At about 3\" to the East from the OT position an extended\nemission is clearly seen. This extended emission is most likely the galaxy\nseen in early HST image (see Price et al., 2001, ApJ, 549, L7) and its\nassociation with the host is unclear.\n\nThe exposure times and magnitudes of the object are:\n\n Filter  Exposure (sec.)  Magnitude         Aperture\n---------------------------------------------------------\n  B        2500             26.13 +/- 0.17   2.0 arcsec\n  V        1500             25.85 +/- 0.22   2.0 arcsec\n  Rc       1260             26.31+/-  0.25   2.0 arcsec\n  Ic       1800             24.7 +/-  0.4    2.0 arcsec\n---------------------------------------------------------\n\nThe faint R-band  magnitude can be explained by a graphite band\nas on the Galactic extinction curves. Indeed, for the redshift z=2.0369\n(Castro et al., GCN #851) this band (2200A) goes to the observed R-band.\nIf so, then this is the second case of direct observations of this\nfeature (see Sokolov et al., 2001, A&A, 372, 438, the case of the HG\nGRB 980703).\n\nWe also performed the photometry of entire system of the objects using\nan aperture of 4.5 arcsec. Below we present the obtained magnitudes:\n\n Filter  Exposure (sec.)     Magnitude        Aperture\n---------------------------------------------------------\n  B        2500             24.73 +/- 0.11   4.5 arcsec\n  V        1500             24.81 +/- 0.19   4.5 arcsec\n  Rc       1800*            24.38+/-  0.10   4.5 arcsec\n  Ic       1800             23.68 +/- 0.30   4.5 arcsec\n---------------------------------------------------------\n* The R-band data obtained on 25 Aug. are coadded.\n\nImages can be seen at\nhttp://www.sao.ru/~sokolov/GRB/HOSTS/GRB000926/GRB000926.html\n\nThis message may be cited\".\n\n-Vladimir Sokolov, on behalf of the RAS Special Astrophysical Observatory\nGRB followup team.","createdOn":999935125000,"email":"sokolov@sao.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"SGR1900+14: A Burst Localized by HETE","circularId":1073,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1073....1R","body":"SGR1900+14: A Burst Localized by HETE\n\nG. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 23:24:18.3 UT (84253.3s UT) on 27 June, the HETE FREGATE and WXM \ninstruments detected and localized an intense burst from SGR1900+14, \na soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the second burst localized \nfrom this source in the past week, indicating that it may have \nresumed an active state. (The first burst was reported in GCN \nCircular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 27 June burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.947 (19h07m47s.2)\n\nDec. = +9.362 (+9:21:41)\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.6 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was <200 ms. A total of 1084 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~2 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >3 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >100 x Crab flux).\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":993698624000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"GRB010326: Localization by HETE","circularId":1014,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1014....1R","body":"G. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nOn 26 March 2001 at 03:15:00 UTC, a hard spectrum, high energy \ntransient at high galactic latitude was detected and localized by \nHETE. Both the FREGATE and the WXM instruments detected the event. \nThe burst triggered FREGATE in the 30-400 keV band.\n\nThe preliminary coordinates of the burst are R.A. = 11h50m59.11s, \nDec. = -23�32'44\" (J2000), derived from combining data from the WXM \nand Boresighted Optical Cameras. The statistical error radius in the \nWXM localization is 10 arcmin (90% confidence). In addition, we \nestimate a systematic error radius at present of 20 arcmin about this \nlocation. The spacecraft aspect was known to an accuracy of +/- 2 \narcmin (95% confidence) from the optical cameras, and will be \nimproved.\n\nThe burst exhibited a multiple-peaked structure and lasted about 25 \nseconds. The peak flux seen with FREGATE (6-30 keV) was ~1 Crab. The \npeak flux was significantly less in the WXM.\n\nFollow-up observations of this GRB event are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on GRB010326 (including light curves and the \nWXM error box), as well as the HETE mission, is available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms:\nHETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985591482000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"Duration, ECT, peak flux and fluence of GRB010324","circularId":1013,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1013....1H","body":"K. W. Fox and D. L. Kaplan (Caltech) report:  \n\n\"Analysis of data from the 22 April 2001 Chandra observation (GCN\n1046, 1047), barycenter-corrected with the preliminary CXC ephemeris,\nreveals that the source emission is pulsed at a period of P =\n5.17288(5) s with a pulse strength of 14.3(2)% RMS that remains\nconstant (within errors) throughout the observation.  Separation of\nthe source photons into \"on-pulse\" and \"off-pulse\" components of 1/3\ncycle each reveals that the off-pulse spatial distribution is\nsignificantly broader than the on-pulse distribution.  Since the\nobservation is taken in continuous-clocking mode, we can only make\nthis determination in one dimension.  Nonetheless, the sigma-widths of\nthe one-dimensional Gaussian PSFs are 0.98(1) arcsec for on-pulse\nphotons and 1.08(2) arcsec for off-pulse photons, different at\n>5-sigma level.  We attribute this difference in widths to the\npresence of an underlying X-ray nebula.\"","createdOn":988243520000,"email":"derekfox@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Peter Woods at UAH/MSFC  <peter.woods@msfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"SGR 1900+14 : RXTE observations","circularId":1056,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1056....1W","body":"P. Woods (USRA/NSSTC), C. Kouveliotou (NASA/MSFC), and E. Gogus\n(UAH/NSSTC) report on behalf of a larger collaboration.\n\nToO observations of SGR 1900+14 with the Rossi XTE were initiated on\nApril 19, 2001 and have continued through April 28.  Thus far, more\nthan 60 bursts have been detected in ~110 ks of exposure time. \nCoincidentally, a short (~10 ks) observation of SGR 1900+14 was\nperformed on April 14 (4 days prior to the flare) as part of our\nongoing monitoring campaign.  We find no burst activity within this\nobservation.  For the latest observation on April 28, 4 bursts were\nrecorded in one RXTE orbit, thus the source remains burst active.\n\nSelecting a 6 day subset of these observations for which we have\nspacecraft ephemeris information, we have phase connected the data and\nmeasured both a period and period derivative.  We chose our epoch (MJD\n52021.3 TDB) to coincide with the first Chandra observation.  We\nmeasure a barycentric period of 5.1728219(14) s where the number given\nin the parentheses marks the 1 sigma error in the least significant\ndigits.  The period derivative is found to be +1.58(22) X 10E-10 s/s. \nThe ephemeris we find agrees well with the measured periods reported\nfor both the Chandra (GCN #1049) and BeppoSAX (GCN #1055)\nobservations.  Furthermore, the magnitude of the spindown found here\nis well within the range of historical spindown rates measured for\nthis SGR.\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988650865000,"email":"peter.woods@msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. This event \nwas promptly distributed as a GCN Notice (HETE BID_1715). No signal \nwas detected in the WXM, indicating that the event was likely to \nbe >40 degrees from the anti-sun direction. For the current HETE \npointing direction, SGR1900+14 is about 48 degrees off the boresight, \nwhile SGR1806-20 is about 56 degrees off the boresight, so that \neither could be a candidate.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~200 ms. S. Bloom, P. A. Price, D. W. Fox, S. G. Djorgovski (CIT), and\nJ. M. Schombert (U. Oregon) report on behalf of the larger\nCaltech-NRAO-CARA GRB Collaboration:\n\n\"On 26.27 March 2001, we obtained a second night of exposures of the\nfield of GRB 010324 (GCN/RXTE ASM; Hurley et al., GCN #1011) using\nCOSMIC on the Palomar 200-inch atop Mt. Palomar.  Using the same\npattern as in the first epoch of imaging (GCN #1012), the entire XTE\nerror box was observed in V-band in two pointings with a total of 1800\nsec per pointing.\n\nBoth image differencing and differential aperture photometry between\nthe two epochs revealed no obviously varying source.  No absolute\nphotometry for the field is available at this time.  However, adopting\nV = 19.1 mag for a USNO A2.0 star at RA: 07:11:26.301, DEC:\n+19:58:30.32 (J2000) we estimate the absence of variation by more than\n0.3 mag down to V = 22.3 mag.\n\nSources brighter than V~18.5 mag were saturated however all such sources\nwere previously observed in DPOSS (see GCN #1012); therefore any GRB\nafterglow is now likely to be faint (V > 22.3 mag). One caveat to this\nconclusion is that the GRB field has a high stellar density and so it is\npossible to have missed a varying source near a bright star.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":985713383000,"email":"jsb@astro.caltech.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. Henden at USNO/USRA  <aah@nofs.navy.mil>","subject":"GRB010324, field photometry","circularId":1028,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1028....1H","body":"A. Henden (USRA/USNO) reports on behalf of the USNO GRB team:\n\nWe have acquired preliminary BVRcIc all-sky photometry for\nan 11x11 arcmin field centered at the RXTE ASM localization\n(GCN/RXTE ASM; Hurley et al., GCN #1011) for GRB010324\nwith the USNOFS 1.0-m telescope on one marginally photometric\nnight.  Stars brighter than V=15 are saturated and should be used\nwith care.\n  We have placed the photometric data on our anonymous ftp site:\nftp://ftp.nofs.navy.mil/pub/outgoing/aah/grb/grb010324.dat\nThe astrometry in this file is based on linear plate solutions\nwith respect to USNO-A2.0.  The internal errors are less than 100mas.\n  We have less confidence than usual in the quality of this\nphotometry.  The all-sky reduction of standards had an RMS\nerror of 1.4 percent, but a high-airmass standard observation\nthat immediately followed the GRB field observation deviated\nfrom the mean by 4 percent.  We will attempt to reobserve\nthis field on the next photometric night.","createdOn":985808988000,"email":"aah@nofs.navy.mil"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Chryssa Kouveliotou at MSFC  <kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"Chandra Observations of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1046,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1046....1K","body":"C.Kouveliotou, A. F. Tennant, M. C. Weisskopf, NASA/MSFC, report on\nbehalf of a large SGR collaboration:\n\nChandra observed the newly active (GCN #1041) Soft Gamma Repeater,\nSGR 1900+14, on April 22, 2001 starting at 4:45 UT, for 20,000 seconds.\nThe ACIS S3 observation mode was Continuous Clocking (CC). We have fitted a\nspectrum to the whole data set; we find the best fit to be a single power law\nwith spectral (photon) index of 2.9 +/- 0.1 and a hydrogen column density (NH)\nof (3.4 +/- 0.1)x10^22 cm^-2. We detect no black body contribution in \nthe spectrum.  The source (unabsorbed) flux is 1.1x10^-11 ergs/cm^2 s\n(2-10 keV), nearly identical to the quiescent source flux level.\nThe pulse period is 5.1725 s (barycenter corrected); the pulse profile\nappears sinusoidal.\n\nMore detailed analysis and comparison with RXTE simultaneous \nobservations is underway.","createdOn":988070436000,"email":"kouveliotou@eagles.msfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14","circularId":1055,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1055....1F","body":"BeppoSAX/NFI Follow-up Observation of SGR 1900+14\n\nM. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Roma) and S. Mereghetti (IFC/CNR, Milano),\non behalf of a larger SGR collaboration, and G. Gandolfi, L. Piro\nand E. Costa (IAS/CNR, Roma), on behalf of the BeppoSAX Team,\nreport:\n\n\"A ToO observation of SGR1900+14 was carried out with the\nBeppoSAX Narrow Field Instruments starting on April 18, 15:10 UT,\nless than 8 hours after the large flare reported in GCN #1041.\nIntense bursting activity is present during the 28 hr long\nobservation.  After removing the numerous short bursts, a significant\nflux decay is visible in the MECS and LECS light curves.\nBy using our data and the Chandra 2-10 keV flux (GCN #1046)\nwe find that the decay can be reasonably well described by a power\nlaw with index ~-0.6.  There is also evidence for a spectral softening\ncorrelated with the intensity decrease.\n\nThe average spectrum (after removal of the bursts) can be fit by a\npower law with photon index 2.6+/-0.1 and NH=(4.3 +/-0.3)x10^22 cm^-2.\nThe average 2-10 keV flux during the whole BeppoSAX observation is\n2.9x10^-11 erg/cm^2/s (unabsorbed). The bursts have a significantly\nharder spectrum (power law photon index ~0 in the 2-10 keV range).\n\nPulsations,  with a nearly sinusoidal light curve and a modulation of\nabout 21%, are clearly detected at the barycentered period  P=5.17277(1) s.\nWhen compared with the value measured with Chandra about 3 days later\n(GCN #1049), this yields a dP/dt ~ (4.1 +/- 1.9)x10^-10 s/s.\n\nAn additional BeppoSAX/NFI observation will start on April 29, 20:30 UT.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":988388763000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Evert Rol at U.Amsterdam  <evert@astro.uva.nl>","subject":"GRB010214, optical observations","circularId":1059,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1059....1R","body":"E. Rol, I. Salamanca, L. Kaper, P. Vreeswijk (University of\nAmsterdam), N. Tanvir (University of Hertfordshire), report on behalf\nof a larger collaboration:\n\n\nIn order to verify the possible counterpart to GRB010214 (Rol et al.,\nGCN 955), we obtained another set of images with the Isaac Newton\nTelescope on February 21, 2001. Examination and comparison of these\nimages with those obtained at the INT on February 17 shows no evidence\nfor a further fading of the possible counterpart, as already suggested\nin other reports (Gorosabel et al., GCN 972; Klose et al., GCN 997;\nFynbo, private comm.). Instead, the source has the same magnitude as\nmeasured in the images obtained at the William Herschel Telescope on\nFebruary 16, R = 22.9 (Rol et al, GCN 955). We therefore conclude that\nthe optical counterpart of GRB010214 has not been detected, with upper\nlimits R ~ 23.5, R ~ 24.2 and R ~ 23.8 on Feb. 15.26, Feb. 17.25 and\nFeb. 22.22 respectively (using the calibration of Henden, GCN\n988). Since the decrease in intensity on Feb. 17 does not appear to be\nan artifact in the images, the detected source likely is a variable\nstar.\n\nThis message can be cited.","createdOn":988972984000,"email":"evert@astro.uva.nl"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"X-ray precursors to the large flare from SGR 1900+14","circularId":1060,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1060....1F","body":"X-ray precursors to the large flare from SGR 1900+14\n\nM. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome), J.J.M. in 't Zand (Astronomical Institute,\nUtrecht University and SRON), P. Soffitta (IAS/CNR, Rome), K. Hurley\n(UCB, California), F. Frontera (Univ. Ferrara and TESRE/CNR, Bologna)\nand E. Mazets (IOFFE, S. Petersburg), report:\n\n\"A high-time resolution analysis has been performed of the BeppoSAX\nWide Field Camera data of SGR 1900+14 taken on April 18, 2001, when\nthe most recent giant flare was detected (Guidorzi et al., GCN 1041\nand IAUC 7611). The data cover a short intermediate pointing of Wide\nField Camera unit 1 between two scheduled targets. The observation\nstarted 2780 s before the giant flare and ended with the automatic\nswitch off due to that flare. The observation was interrupted when\nBeppoSAX traversed the SAA, from 2282 till 1052 s before the\ngiant flare. The analysis revealed the presence of 3 short X-ray\nprecursors, occurring 2537, 755, and 444 s before the giant flare\n(respectively, 25975, 27757 and 28068 s UT), with durations of 100,\n125 and 55 ms, peak fluxes in excess of 20 Crab units (2-28 keV),\nand 9-28/2-9 keV spectral hardness ratios that are consistent with\npower laws with photon indices between roughly 0.5 and 1.2. None of the\nprecursors was detected in the gamma-ray data from the BeppoSAX/GRBM,\nthe gamma-ray burst detector on Ulysses, and from Konus on Wind.\"","createdOn":988997172000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"George Ricker at MIT  <grr@space.mit.edu>","subject":"GRB010629: A Burst Localized by HETE","circularId":1075,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1075....1R","body":"GRB010629: A Gamma-ray Burst Localized by HETE\n\nG. Ricker, D. Lamb, and S. Woosley on behalf of the HETE Science Team;\n\nR. Vanderspek, G. Crew, J. Doty, G. Monnelly, J. Villasenor; N. \nButler, T. Cline, J.G. Jernigan, A. Levine, F. Martel, E. Hurley on behalf \nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nAt 03:34:06.53 UTC (12846.53 s UT) on 2 July, the HETE FREGATE and \nWXM instruments detected and localized an intense burst from \nSGR1900+14, a soft gamma-ray repeater. This event is the highest \nfluence burst yet detected by HETE from SGR1900+14 during its current \nepisode of activity. (The first burst in the current series was \nreported in GCN Circular #1071.) The coordinates (J2000) of the 2 \nJuly burst are:\n\nR.A. = 286.846 (19h07m23s.1)\n\nDec. =  +9.344 (+9o20'40\")\n\nThe error circle for this localization is 12 arcmin in radius. \nSGR1900+14 lies 4.1 arcmin from the HETE position.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-40 keV band was ~4 s. A total of 44000 \ncounts above background were detected during that interval, \ncorresponding to a fluence of ~8 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 . The peak flux \nwas >7 x 10-6 ergs cm-2 s-1 (ie >200 x Crab flux) over a duration of \n10 ms.\n\nFollow-up observations of this transient are encouraged.\n\nAdditional information on this burst detection (including light \ncurves), as well as for the HETE mission, will be available at:\n\nhttp://space.mit.edu/HETE/\n\nAcronyms: HETE=High Energy Transient Explorer\nFREGATE=French Gamma Ray Telescope\nWXM=Wide Field X-ray Monitor\nSXC=Soft X-ray Camera\n\nThis message is citeable.","createdOn":994051790000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Marco Feroci at IAS/CNR Frascati  <feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it>","subject":"BeppoSAX/GRBM detection of GRB 010801","circularId":1086,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1086....1F","body":"M. Feroci (IAS/CNR, Rome) and C. Guidorzi (University of Ferrara)\nreport on behalf of the BeppoSAX/GRBM team:\n\n\"The BeppoSAX Gamma Ray Burst Monitor (GRBM) was triggered by a gamma-ray\nburst on August 1st, 2001, 18:30:34.39 UT. This event is most likely the\nsame event detected by HETE-2 on the same day at 18:30:37.42 UT (HETE\nTrigger Number 1669). As seen in unit #2 of the GRBM, in the 40-700 keV\nenergy range, the event was bright (about 4,300 counts/s at peak)\nand long (approx. 33 s). It showed a main, structured pulse 10 s long,\nfollowed by a bunch of much shorter and weaker pulses starting about 4 s\nafter the end of the main pulse.\"\n\nThis message may be cited.","createdOn":996701872000,"email":"feroci@ias.rm.cnr.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andrew S. Fruchter at STScI  <fruchter@stsci.edu>","subject":"GRB 010222: HST observations -- host galaxy and late-time decay","circularId":1087,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1087....1F","body":"A. Fruchter, I. Burud, J. Rhoads and A. Levan (STScI) report:\n\nWe have reduced the now public archival HST images of GRB 010222, taken\non 28 February, 17 and 18 March, 5 and 6 April, and 4 and 5 May of \nthis year using the F606W (V/R) and F814W (I) filters on WFPC2.   Using\nthe most recent data, we find that OT of GRB 010222 is clearly superposed\non a host galaxy.  \n\nIn order to accurately determine the decay of the OT and the magnitude\nof the host, we have drizzled the images onto an output grid that\nallows interlacing of these 2-point dithered images.  We have then fit\nfor the decay of the OT and the host galaxy flux using a small (~0.\"2)\naperture, which provides the best estimate of the OT as a function of\ntime, as well as using a larger aperture (~0.\"5), which is more\nappropriate for determining the host galaxy magnitude.\n\nWe find that the late-time decay of the OT is significantly steeper\nthan previously reported.  We find a power-law decay between 28 February\n(day 6) and 5 May (day 71) of -1.7 +/- 0.05.  Formally, we find\na slightly steeper decay (-1.73 +/- 0.02) in F606W than in F814W \n(-1.64 +/- 0.04), but this discrepancy may indicate the level of\nsystematic error in the slope measurement rather than true color\nevolution of the OT.\n\nWe find that the host galaxy is dominated by a compact core (FWHM ~ 0.\"15)\nlocated directly under the OT.  The magnitude of the host is \nF606W(AB) = 26.0 +/- 0.1, F814W(AB) = 25.8 +/- 0.15.  \n\nImages of the host, as well as a plot of the coninuing decline of the OT,\nare available at\n\nhttp://www.stsci.edu/~fruchter/GRB/010222","createdOn":997814700000,"email":"fruchter@stsci.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Vladimir Sokolov at SAO RAS  <sokolov@sao.ru>","subject":"GRB001109, Host Galaxy Spectroscopic Observations","circularId":1090,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1090....1A","body":"V. Afanasiev, T. Fatkhullin, S. Dodonov, V. Sokolov, (SAO RAS),\nA. Castro-Tirado (IAA-CSIC Granada; LAEFF-INTA, Madrid), V. Komarova,\nA. Moiseev (SAO RAS), A. Cherepashchuk, K. Postnov (SAI-MSU Moscow)\nreport:\n\n\"On July 24, 2001 UT, we observed the field of GRB 001109 (Gandolfi, GCNs #878,\n#879). The photometric conditions were good with a seeing of about 1.3 arcsec. \nWe have obtained three 180-s R-band images with the SCORPIO instrument\n(http://www.sao.ru/~moisav/scorpio/scorpio.html) at the 6-m telescope of SAO\nRAS. At the position of the VLA radiosource (Taylor et al. GCN #880) which\nis presumably a radio afteglow (Rol et al. GCN #889) we detected an extended\nobject as already reported by Vreeswijk et al. (GCN #886) and Greiner et al. \n(GCN#887), most likely double. Spectroscopic observations (12 x 600-s \nexposures) were obtained with the 300 lines/mm grating giving a spectral \nresolution (FWHM) of about 20 A and an effective wavelength coverage of \n3500 - 9500 A. The slit was placed along the extended object. The analysis \nrevealed that the object is double with a spectra showing the continua\nwith clearly detected Balmer break. The redshift for each component is:\n\nObject A:  z = 0.398 +/- 0.002, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           O[III] 4959,5007AA emission lines (brighter component)\n\n\nObject B:  z = 0.3399 +/- 0.0005, based on identification of the Halfa 6563A,\n           Hbeta 4861AA, emission lines (fainter component)\n\nIf the radio transient is related to GRB 001109 indeed, then this is the\nnearest host galaxy detected so far.\n\nThe R-band image can be seen at:\nhttp://www.sao.ru/~sokolov/GRB/HOSTS/GRB001109/GRB001109.html\n\nThis message may be cited\".\n\n-Vladimir Sokolov, on behalf of the RAS Special Astrophysical Observatory\nGRB followup team.","createdOn":999934127000,"email":"sokolov@sao.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Kevin Hurley at UCBerkeley/SSL  <khurley@sunspot.ssl.berkeley.edu>","subject":"IPN triangulation of GRB010921 (=H1761)","circularId":1097,"bibcode":"2001GCN..1097....1H","body":"K. Hurley on behalf\nof the HETE FREGATE Team;\n\nwrite:\n\nThe HETE Fregate instrument has detected a bright (>40 sigma) GRB \nthat has been reported in a GCN Notice as H1761. The burst occurred \nat 18950.56 SOD {05:15:50.56} UT on 21 September.  The burst is seen \nin the WXM X detector and is therefore well-localized in the X \ndirection; the burst was apparently outside the coded FOV of the WXM \nY detector, which therefore gives limited information about the Y \ndirection of the burst.\n\nThe X-detector data gives a good (+/-10 arcmin) localization in the X\ndirection and crude limits on Y, resulting in a localization that is a\nthin, long strip.\n\nTwo points along one side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h52m36s.7, Dec. =  39o35'13\"\nR.A. = 23h10m22s.8, Dec. =  48o57'43\"\n\nTwo points along the other side of the strip are:\n\nR.A. = 22h54m04s.0, Dec. =  39o34'23\"\nR.A. = 23h11m52s.5, Dec. =  48o57'00\"\n\nOur estimate is that the strip is  ~10  degrees in the long direction.\n\nThe burst duration in the 8-85 keV band was ~12 s. A total of 5310 \ncounts were detected during that interval, corresponding to a fluence \nof ~1 x 10-6 ergs cm-2. The peak flux was >3 x 10-7 ergs cm-2 s-1 \n(ie >8 x Crab flux).\n\nFurther refinement of the X localization is in progress; a further\nattempt is also being made to improve the coarse Y localization.","createdOn":1001067928000,"email":"grr@space.mit.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"INTEGRAL Shift Ops at INTEGRAL  <shift@isdcmail.unige.ch>","subject":"GRB021219: Correction to GCN 1766","circularId":1769,"bibcode":"2002GCN..1769....1I","body":"Due to a typing mistake the GRB declination in GCN 1766\nwas reported as  +31deg 52s.\nThe correct value is  +31deg 52min\nThere was also a spelling error in the name of J.Borkowski","createdOn":1040322241000,"email":"shift@isdcmail.unige.ch"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arto Oksanen at Nyrola Obs., Finland  <oksanen@nyrola.jklsirius.fi>","subject":"GRB 030329: visual observations","circularId":2010,"bibcode":"2003GCN..2010....1O","body":"A. Nysewander \nreport:\n\nSkynet has continued to observe the afterglow (Haislip et al., GCN 9937) of \nGRB 090926A (Bissaldi, GCN 9933) with two of the 16\" PROMPT telescopes at \nCTIO in RI.\n\nAfter peaking in brightness approximately 1 day after the trigger (Haislip \net al., GCN 9953) and fading with a power-law index of around -1.4 until \napproximately 4 days after the trigger (Haislip, et al., GCN 9982), the \nafterglow faded with a shallower power-law index of around -0.8 until \napproximately 6 days after the trigger (Haislip et al., GCN 9984).\n\nBetween 6 and 11 days after the trigger, the afterglow has been fading with \na steeper power-law index of around -1.7.\n\nAt 11.1 days after the trigger, its magnitude is R = 21.45 +0.22 -0.18 \n(statistical) +/- 0.57 (systematic; calibrated to 172 USNO B1 stars).\n\nSkynet's most recent BVRI light curve, calibrated to USNO B1 and NOMAD \nstars, can be found here:\n\nhttp://skynet.unc.edu/grb/grb090926a.jpg\n\nContinued observations with larger telescopes are encouraged.","createdOn":1255109080000,"email":"haislip@physics.unc.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Aaron LaCluyze at U.North Carolina  <lacluyze@physics.unc.edu>","subject":"GRB 090530A: Skynet/DSO Detections","circularId":10015,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10015....1S","body":"A. Iceland), and Ilya \nIlyin (AIP), report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe observed again the field of GRB 090904A (Perri et al., GCN 9879) with \nthe NOT equipped with StanCam. Observations were carried out in the R \nband, for a total exposure time of 30 min, with a mean time September \n6.218 UT (2.176 days after the GRB trigger).\n\nThe object identified in our previous epoch of imaging (Malesani et al., \nGCN 9884) has clearly faded and is hardly detectable, if at all. A faint \nsource is visible at its position, with magnitude R = 24.0 +- 0.3. If \nreal, the inferred decay slope is alpha = 0.55 +- 0.12, assuming F(t) \npropto t^-alpha. The value of alpha is shallower than usually found at \nlate times, and may indicate some host contribution or an unusual light \ncurve.\n\nThe position of the transient is consistent with the latest available \nUVOT-enhanced XRT position (Goad et al., GCN 9885; see also \nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_positions/index.php). Bissaldi and D. Gruber (all MPE)\nreport on behalf of the Fermi GBM Team:\n\n\n\"At 02:43:09.32 UT on 10 October 2009, the Fermi Gamma-Ray Burst Monitor\ntriggered and located GRB 091010 (trigger 276835391 / 091010113),\nwhich was also detected by SuperAGILE (Donnarumma et al., GCN 10004).\nThe GBM on-ground location is consistent with the Swift-XRT position\n(Margutti et al. 2009, GCN 10006 and Evans et al. 2009, GCN 10012).\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 55.7 degrees.\nMoreover, this burst was bright enough to result in\na Fermi spacecraft repointing maneuver.\n\nThis burst was also independently detected by INTEGRAL SPI-ACS.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of multiple peaks\nwith a duration (T90) of about 8.1 +/- 0.5 s (8-1000 keV).\nThe time-averaged spectrum from T0-0.128 s to T0+8.064 s is\nbest fit by a power law function with an exponential\nhigh energy cutoff. The power law index is -1.11 +/- 0.03 and\nthe cutoff energy, parameterized as Epeak, is 150 (+6/-5) keV\n(C-stat 446 for 359 d.o.f.).\n\nThe event fluence (8-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(1.09 +/- 0.02)E-05 erg/cm^2. Salotti (ASI)\n\n\n\"The long GRB 091010 localized by SuperAGILE (Donnarumma et al., GCN \n10004) triggered also the MCAL instrument onboard AGILE, sensitive in\nthe energy range 330 keV - 100 MeV, at 02:43:10 UT (T0).\nAs seen by MCAL the burst has a double-peaked light curve, with a\nduration of 3.5 s.\nThe time integrated spectrum in the time interval [T0-1.5 s, T0+2.0 s]\ncan be fit in the energy range 400 keV - 2 MeV with a single powerlaw\nwith photon index -3.0 (-0.6, +0.8) (reduced chi2 = 1.09 with 9 d.o.f.).\nThe estimated fluence is (1.40 +/- 0.3)x10-6 erg/cm2 in the same energy\nrange.\nAll reported errors are at the 90% confidence level.\nNo significant emission is detected above 2 MeV.\n\nThe photon index and fluence are consistent with those reported by\nKonus-Wind (Golenetskii et al., GCN 10013), when the different energy\nrange is accounted for.\n\nNo significant emission is detected by AGILE GRID.\nA 3-sigma Upper Limit for emission in the GRID energy range (E>30 MeV)\nin the same 3.5 seconds time interval used for MCAL analysis can be\nplaced at 0.043 ph/cm2.\nUsing a 60-seconds time interval starting from T0 the 3-sigma Upper\nLimit is 0.1 ph/cm2.\"","createdOn":1255448680000,"email":"marisaldi@iasfbo.inaf.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Masanori Ohno at ISAS/JAXA  <ohno@astro.isas.jaxa.jp>","subject":"GRB 091010: Suzaku WAM observation of the prompt emission","circularId":10023,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10023....1V","body":"N. Sugita (Nagoya U.)on behalf of the Suzaku WAM team, report:\n\n\nThe long GRB 091010 (Fermi trigger #276835391/091010113,\nvon Kienlin et al., GCN10018, SuperAGILE Donnarumma et al., GCN 10004)\ntriggered the Suzaku Wide-band  All-sky Monitor (WAM) in a energy  \nrange from\n  50 keV to 5 MeV at 02:43:09.50 UT (=T0).\n\nThe observed light curve shows a multi-peaked structure, starting at\nT0 s and ending at T0+7s, with a total duration (T90) of 6.5 s.\nThe fluence in 100 - 1000 keV was 6.22(+0.48,-0.42) x 10-6 erg/cm^2.\nThe 1-s peak flux measured from T0+1 s was 9.91(+0.89,-1.03) photons/s/ \ncm^2\nin the same energy range.\n\nPreliminary result shows that the time-averaged spectrum from\nT0-1s  to T0+7s is well fitted by a single power-law with\na photon index of 2.50 (+0.24,-0.22) (chi^2/d.o.f = 11.7/8).\nAll the quoted errors are at statistical 90% confidence level,\nin which the systematic uncertainties are not included.\n\nThe light curves for this burst are available at:\n\nhttp://www.astro.isas.jaxa.jp/suzaku/HXD-WAM/WAM-GRB/grb/trig/grb_table.html","createdOn":1255600582000,"email":"ohno@astro.isas.jaxa.jp"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Raffaella Margutti at U. di Milano Bicocca  <raffaella.margutti@brera.inaf.it>","subject":"GRB 091010: Swift-XRT refined analysis","circularId":10024,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10024....1M","body":"R. Margutti (INAF-OAB) reports on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nThe Swift ToO observations of the SuperAGILE GRB 091010\n(Donnarumma et al., GCN Circ. 10004; Feroci, GCN Circ. 10005) started\non 2009 Oct 10th at 14:48:26 UT. The XRT data set consists of 9 ks\nexposure in PC mode. The UVOT-enhanced XRT position was given by\nEvans et al. in GCN Circ. 10012.\n\nThe X-ray source reported by Margutti & Guidorzi, GCN Circ. 10006\nhas faded to a level of (2.4 +/- 1.0)e-3 count/sec, with a best fit\npower-law decay index of alpha=-1.4 +/- 0.6 .\nThis source is thus confirmed as the afterglow of GRB 091010.\n\nThe spectrum extracted in the time interval 43-50 ks contains about\n170 photons and can be fitted using an absorbed power law model.\nSpectral channels have been grouped so as to have 5 counts per bin\nand then weighted using the Churazov method (Churazov et al. 1996).\nThe best fit photon index is found to be 2.3 +/- 0.4. The spectrum\nshows evidence of absorption at the level of (1.9 +/- 0.1)e21 cm-2,\nin excess of the Galactic value in the direction of the burst which\nis 8.1e20 cm-2, Kalberla et al. 2005.\nThe observed (unabsorbed) flux over this time interval is 1.5e-12\n(2.8e-12) erg cm^-2 s^-1. The counts to observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV\nflux conversion factor deduced from this spectrum is 3.6 x 10^-11\n(6.6 x 10^-11) erg cm^-2 count^-1.\n\nAll quoted errors are at 90% confidence level.\n\nThe results of the xrt automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/00020116.\n\nThis is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.","createdOn":1255616386000,"email":"raffaella.margutti@brera.inaf.it"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Valentin Pal'shin at Ioffe Inst  <lanzelot@mail.ru>","subject":"Konus-RF observation of GRB 091018","circularId":10045,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10045....1G","body":"S. Svinkin on behalf of\nthe Konus-RF team, report:\n\nThe soft GRB 091018 (Swift-BAT trigger #373172: Stamatikos et al.,\nGCN 10034, Markwardt et al., GCN 10040) triggered Konus-RF\nat T0=74900.651 s UT (20:48:20.651).\n\nThe burst light curve shows a single pulse with a duration of ~5 s.\n\nAs observed by Konus-RF the burst\nhad a fluence of 1.44(-0.16, +0.19)x10^-6 erg/cm2,\nand a 256-ms peak flux measured from T0-0.280 s\nof 4.32(-0.94, +0.97)x10^-7 erg/cm2/s\n(both in the 20 keV - 1 MeV energy range).\n\nThe time-integrated spectrum of the burst (from T0-2s to T0+3s)\nis well fitted (in the 10 keV - 1 MeV range)\nby a power law with exponential cutoff model:\ndN/dE ~ (E^alpha)*exp(-E*(2+alpha)/Ep), with\nalpha = -1.53(-0.39, +0.59),  and\nEp = 28(-16, +10) keV (chi2 = 83.4/94 dof).\nFitting by GRB (Band) model yields the same alpha and Ep,\nand only an upper limit on the high energy\nphoton index: beta < -2.44 (chi2 = 81.7/93 dof).\n\nAll the quoted values are preliminary.\nAll the quoted errors are at the 90% confidence level.\n\nAssuming z = 0.971 (Chen et al., GCN 10038) and\na standard cosmology model with H_0 = 70 km/s/Mpc, Omega_M = 0.27,\nOmega_Lambda = 0.73, the isotropic energy release E_iso ~3.7x10^51 erg,\nthe peak luminosity (L_iso)_max ~2.2x10^51 erg/s,\nand Ep_rest ~55 keV.\n\nThe Konus-RF light curve of this GRB is available\nat http://www.ioffe.ru/LEA/GRBs/GRB091018_T74900/KRF/","createdOn":1255988113000,"email":"lanzelot@mail.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Takeo Minezaki at U.of Tokyo/Astro  <minezaki@mtk.ioa.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp>","subject":"GRB 091018: miniTAO/ANIR Observations","circularId":10047,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10047....1M","body":"K. Ukwatta (GWU)\n(i.e. the Swift-BAT team):\n\nUsing the data set from T-61 to T+242 sec from the recent telemetry downlink,\nwe report further analysis of BAT GRB 091020 (trigger #373458)\n(Racusin, et al., GCN Circ. 10048). T90 (15-350 keV) is\n34.6 +- 2.7 sec (estimated error including systematics).\n\nThe time-averaged spectrum from T-8.7 to T+38.3 sec is best fit by a simple\npower-law model. B. Markwardt (CRESST/GSFC/UMD), S. D. Barthelmy (GSFC),\nA. P. Beardmore (U Leicester), D. N. Burrows (PSU),\nP. A. Evans (U Leicester), N. Gehrels (NASA/GSFC), D. Grupe (PSU),\nC. Stamatikos (OSU/NASA/GSFC) report on behalf\nof the Swift Team:\n\nAt 13:11:30 UT, the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) triggered and\nlocated GRB 091026 (trigger=373871).  Swift slewed immediately to the burst. \nThe BAT on-board calculated location is \nRA, Dec 276.583, -86.121 which is \n   RA(J2000)  =  18h 26m 20s\n   Dec(J2000) = -86d 07' 16\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3 arcmin (radius, 90% containment, including \nsystematic uncertainty).  The BAT light curve shows a FRED pulse\nwith a duration of about 20 sec.  The peak count rate\nwas ~2500 counts/sec (15-350 keV), at ~0 sec after the trigger. \n\nThe XRT began observing the field at 13:12:48.9 UT, 78.7 seconds after\nthe BAT trigger. Using promptly downlinked data we find a bright,\nuncatalogued X-ray source located at RA, Dec 276.59337, -86.11056 which\nis equivalent to:\n   RA(J2000)  = 18h 26m 22.41s\n   Dec(J2000) = -86d 06' 38.0\"\nwith an uncertainty of 4.0 arcseconds (radius, 90% containment). This\nlocation is 37 arcseconds from the BAT onboard position, within the BAT\nerror circle. This position may be improved as more data are received;\nthe latest position is available at http://www.swift.ac.uk/sper. \n\nA power-law fit to a spectrum formed from promptly downlinked event\ndata gives a column density in excess of the Galactic value (8.36e+20\ncm^-2, Kalberla et al. 2005), with an excess column of 3.6\n(+2.72/-2.29) x 10^21 cm^-2 (90% confidence). \n\nThe initial flux in the 2.5 s image was 3.42e-09 erg cm^-2 s^-1 (0.2-10\nkeV). \n\nUVOT took a finding chart exposure of 150 seconds with the White filter\nstarting 87 seconds after the BAT trigger. No credible afterglow candidate has\nbeen found in the initial data products. The 2.7'x2.7' sub-image covers 100% of\nthe XRT error circle. The typical 3-sigma upper limit has been about 19.6 mag. \nThe 8'x8' region for the list of sources generated on-board covers 100% of the\nXRT error circle. The list of sources is typically complete to about 18 mag. No\ncorrection has been made for the expected extinction corresponding to E(B-V) of\n0.13. \n\nBurst Advocate for this burst is C. B. Markwardt (Craig.Markwardt AT nasa.gov). \nPlease contact the BA by email if you require additional information\nregarding Swift followup of this burst. A.Zyatkov (MephI, Moscow, Russia) report:\n\n\nThe very bright GRB 090926A (FERMI-GBM trigger 275631628 / 090926181;\nBissaldi, GCN 9933) is detected by RT-2 Experiment onboard CORONAS-PHOTON\nsatellite at T0 = 04h 20m 27s (UT). The satellite was in LIGHT mode (pointing\ntowards the SUN) for a short duration at a high latitude in its orbit. During\nthis time, the GOOD time (away from the polar and SAA regions) observation was\nfor 348 sec starting at 04h 16m 55sec (UT) and ending at 04h 22m 43sec (UT).\n\nThe burst light curve consists of multiple peaks of total duration of ~ 17\nsec, followed by a weak tail ending at ~ T0+30 sec.
