The BAT ground-calculated position is\nRA, Dec = 32.191, -57.546 deg, which is \n   RA(J2000)  =  02h 08m 45.9s \n   Dec(J2000) = -57d 32' 45.0\" \nwith an uncertainty of 1.0 arcmin, (radius, sys+stat, 90% containment).\nThe partial coding was 84%.\n \nThe mask-weighted light curve shows the FRED peak starting at ~T-5 sec,\npeaking at T+1.1 sec, and ending at ~T+20 sec.  T90 (15-350 keV) is\n4.4 +- 0.6 sec (estimated error including systematics).\n \nThe time-averaged spectrum from T-0.3 to T+7.7 sec is best fit by a power law\nwith an exponential cutoff.  This fit gives a photon index 1.77 +- 0.24, \nand Epeak of 19.2 +18,-11 keV (chi squared 40.01 for 56 d.o.f.).  For this\nmodel the total fluence in the 15-150 keV band is 1.4 +- 0.1 x 10^-6 erg/cm2\nand the 1-sec peak flux measured from T+0.80 sec in the 15-150 keV band is\n10.3 +- 0.4 ph/cm2/sec. Cenko, D. A. Perley, B. E. Cobb, J. S. Bloom, and N. R. Butler (UC\nBerkeley) report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe have imaged the field of the Fermi GRB090926A (Bissaldi et al., GCN\n9933; Uehara et al., GCN 9934) with the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph\nmounted on the 8-m Gemini South telescope.  Observations were taken in\nthe Sloan g', r', and i' filters beginning at 2:28 UT on 19 October 2009\n(~ 22.9 d after the GBM trigger).\n\nWe detect a faint source in all filters at the location of the optical\nafterglow (Haislip et al., GCN 9937, Gronwall et al., GCN 9938). Using\nseveral unsaturated USNO-B objects in the field of view, along with the\nfilter transformations of Jordi, Grebel, and Ammon (2006 A&A 460, 339), we\nmeasure a magnitude of r' ~ 23.7 for this source.  Along with its\nrelatively blue color (g' - i' ~ 0), the object appears marginally\nextended, suggesting it is likely dominated by emission from the host\ngalaxy of GRB090926A.  We caution, however, that the host candidate is\npartially blended with a nearby object (~ 1.5\" in the SW direction, just\noutside the optical and X-ray afterglow error circle) of comparable\nmagnitude, which likely affects the photometry.\n\nComparing with the last reported R-band detection (R ~ 21.5 at t ~ 11.1 d;\nHaislip et al., GCN 10003), the optical decay must have significantly\nsteepened from previous measurements (power-law index alpha >~ 2.5).  A\nsimilar steepening is hinted at in the latest XRT observations of this\nsource (see http://astro.berkeley.edu/~nat/swift/00020113/bat_xrt.jpg),\nsuggesting a possible jet break. D. Barthelmy (GSFC) on behalf of the Swift team:\n \nSwift-BAT triggers 373679-373684 are not real.  They are due\nto false positive detections in image-trigger mode while the \nthe spacecraft star tracker was in loss-of-lock.\n\nThere is filtering code within GCN to prevent distribution\nof Swift notices for image triggers that occur during star tracker\nloss-of-lock intervals, but sometimes this filtering gets confused\n(e.g. when the BAT_Position message is not received at GCN, or when\nthe messages carry over into the next orbit).  Receiving these\nnotices can be confusing because many notices of the sequence\nyou normally receive are missing.\n\nOf the 69 messages received, 10 were distributed.  Please disregard\nthese notices.  We apologize for the inconvenience.","createdOn":1256405462000,"email":"scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Alexander Kann at TLS Tautenburg  <kann@tls-tautenburg.de>","subject":"GRB 091024: TLS Upper Limit","circularId":10077,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10077....1K","body":"D. (GCN #10097) at\n\nRA (J2000.0) = 04h 00m 42.7 s\n\nDEC (J2000.0) = -55d 57' 19\n\nwith an uncertainty of 0.5\".\n\nBased on the first 5.3 min of total exposures in g'r'i'z' and 6.7 min in\nJHK, we estimate preliminary magnitudes (all in AB system) of\n\ng' = 17.72 +- 0.1 mag,\n\nr' = 17.45 +- 0.1 mag,\n\nJ = 17.00 +- 0.08 mag.\n\nGiven magnitudes are calibrated against GROND zeropoints as well as 2MASS\nfield stars and are not corrected for the expected Galactic foreground\nextinction corresponding to a reddening of E_(B-V)=0.02 mag in the\ndirection of the burst (Schlegel et al. 1998).","createdOn":1256791355000,"email":"aupdike@clemson.edu"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Dmitry Frederiks at Ioffe Institute  <fred@mail.ioffe.ru>","subject":"Konus-Wind observations of GRB 091020 (correction to GCN 10057)","circularId":10059,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10059....1F","body":"Dmitry Frederiks reports:\n\nI made a mistake in the subject line of GCN 10057:\nit should be \"Konus-Wind observations of GRB 091020\"\ninstead of \"Konus-Wind observations of GRB 091010\".\n\nI apologize for the confusion.","createdOn":1256135080000,"email":"fred@mail.ioffe.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Nial Tanvir at IofA U.Cambridge  <nrt@ast.cam.ac.uk>","subject":"GRB 091024 Gemini-North redshift","circularId":10065,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10065....1C","body":"A. Page (U. Leicester) and F.E. Marshall (NASA/GSFC) report on behalf of \nthe Swift-XRT team:\n\nFollowing an Earth-limb constraint, Swift-XRT began observing the field of \nGRB 091024 at 09:49:13, about 53 minutes after the BAT trigger. We detect \na bright, uncatalogued X-ray source at a position of RA, Dec = 339.25167, \n56.88928, which is equivalent to\n\nRA (J2000):   22 37 00.40\nDec (J2000):  56 53 21.4\n\nwith an uncertainty of 6 arcsec (radius, 90% confidence). This is 6.1 \narcsec from the optical afterglow candidate given by Mundell et al. (GCN \nCirc. 10063) and 6.0 arcsec from the position given by Nissinen & Hentunen \n(GCN Circ. 10064).\n\nOnly one orbit of data has been collected thus far (spanning 3.2-5.4 ks \nafter the burst), but the source does appear to be fading, albeit with a \nrelatively large uncertainty: alpha = 1.2 +/- 0.4.\n\nThe spectrum of the source, extracted from the 2.2 ks of Photon Counting \nmode data, can be fitted by an absorbed power-law with Gamma = 1.70 +/- \n0.17, the Galactic column of NH = 4.86 x 10^21 cm^-2 and an intrinsic \ncolumn of (2.3 +1.0/-0.9) x 10^22 at a redshift of 1.092 (Cucchiara, Fox & \nTanvir, GCN Circ. 10065). The observed (unabsorbed) flux over this time is \n7.23 x 10^-11 (1.15 x 10^-10) erg cm^-2 s^-1, corresponding to a counts to \nobserved (unabsorbed) flux conversion of 7.5 x 10^-11 (1.2 x 10^-10) erg \ncm^-2 count^-1.\n\nIf the source continues to fade with alpha ~ 1.2, the predicted count rate \nat 24 hours will be 0.034 count s^-1, corresponding to an observed \n(unabsorbed) flux of 2.6x10^-12 (4.1x10^-12) erg cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at \nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/00373674.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.","createdOn":1256395879000,"email":"kpa@star.le.ac.uk"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Scott Barthelmy at NASA/GSFC  <scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"Swift-BAT Triggers 373776-373778 are not real","circularId":10079,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10079....1B","body":"S. D. Barthelmy (GSFC)  on behalf of the Swift team:\n \nSwift-BAT triggers 373776, 373777, and 373778 are not real.\nThey are due to false positive detections in image-trigger mode\nwhile the the spacecraft star tracker was in loss-of-lock.\n\nOnly five SIMBAD_NED notices were distributed.  None of the other Swift Notices\nin the usual sequence were distributed -- they were blocked in GCN.\n(I am working on code in GCN to prevent even this limited scenario.)\n\nPlease disregard these notices.  We apologize for the inconvenience.","createdOn":1256485325000,"email":"scott@lheamail.gsfc.nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Phil Evans at U of Leicester  <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","subject":"GRB 091026: Swift-XRT refined analysis","circularId":10085,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10085....1E","body":"P.A. Evans, J.P. Osborne (U. Leicester)  and C. B. Markwardt (CRESST/GSFC/UMD)\nreport on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nWe have analysed 2.2 ks of XRT data for GRB 091026 (Markwardt et al. GCN\nCirc. 10081), from 85 s to 6.8 ks after the BAT trigger. The data\ncomprise 326 s in Windowed Timing (WT) mode with the remainder in Photon\nCounting (PC) mode. The enhanced XRT position for this burst was given\nby Evans et al. (GCN. Circ 10084).\n\nThe light curve shows three flares in the first snapshot, with peaks\nat T0+180 s, T0+340 s and T0+~890 s. The orbital gap interrupts the\nfinal flare, making its peak time somewhat uncertain. If these flares\nare disregarded (i.e. fitting only the data from 85 s to 150 s and 2 ks to\n6.8 ks), the underlying light curve can be modelled with an initial\npower-law decay with an index of alpha=3.40 (+0.31, -0.26), followed by\na break at T+149 s to an alpha of 0.98 (+0.07, -1.7).\n\nA spectrum formed from the WT mode data can be fitted with an absorbed\npower-law with a photon spectral index of 1.97 (+/-0.08). The\nbest-fitting absorption column is 2.93 (+0.28, -0.27) x 10^21 cm^-2, in\nexcess of the Galactic value of 8.4 x 10^20 cm^-2 (Kalberla et al.\n2005). The PC mode spectrum has a photon index of 2.01 (+0.18, -0.17)\nand a best-fitting absorption column of 3.5 (+0.7, -0.6) x 10^21 cm^-2.\nThe counts to observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux conversion factor\ndeduced from this spectrum is 4.6 x 10^-11 (7.6 x 10^-11) erg cm^-2\ncount^-1.\n\nIf the light curve continues to decay with a power-law decay index of\n0.98, the count rate at T+24 hours will be 0.018 count s^-1,\ncorresponding to an observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux of 8.3 x\n10^-13 (1.4 x 10^-12) erg cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/00373871.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.","createdOn":1256587432000,"email":"pae9@star.le.ac.uk"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Takanori Sakamoto at NASA/GSFC  <takanori@milkyway.gsfc.nasa.gov>","subject":"GRB 091024: Burst was outside the Swift-BAT FOV after T0(BAT)+460sec","circularId":10086,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10086....1S","body":"T. Oslo), Johannes \nAndersen (NBI and NOT), report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe observed the optical afterglow of GRB 091020 (Racusin et al., GCN \n10048; Gorbovskoy et al., GCN 10052) with the Nordic Optical Telescope \nequipped with ALFOSC. We detect the afterglow with a magnitude R ~ 20, \nbased on a nearby USNO star, with mean time Oct 21.220 UT (0.315 days \nafter the GRB).\n\nWe secured low-resolution spectroscopy (30 min exposure), covering the \nwavelength range 3500-9100 AA, starting on Oct. 21.231 UT. Wavelength \ncalibration was carried out using archival frames.\n\nIn a preliminary analysis we detect several absorption features, which \nwe interpret as FeII 2344, 2374, 2382, Al III 1854, 1862, Mg II 2798 (Mg \nII 2803 is blended with the telluric A band), all at the common z = \n1.71. Stratta (ASDC) reports on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nThe Swift-XRT began observing GRB 091018 (trigger=373172) on\n2009-10-18 at 20:49:20.5 UT, 60.9 seconds after the BAT trigger\n(Stamatikos et al., GCN Circ. 7226). The data have been\ntaken in Windowed Timing (WT) mode from T + 67 s to T + 144 s\nand in Photon Counting (PC) mode later on.\n\nEnhanced position of the detected, bright X-ray afterglow\nwas given by Osborne et al. (GCN Circ. 10037)\n\nThe X-ray light curve from T + 67 s to T + 53.3 ks is well\nfit by a broken power law model (chi^2 = 115 for 128 degrees\nof freedom) with a temporal break at tb = T + (500 +/- 100) s and\ndecay indices alpha1 = -0.4 +/- 0.1 and alpha2 = -1.17 +/- 0.03\nbefore and after the break, respectively.\n\nThe 0.3-10 keV spectrum from T + 156 s to T + 7.1 ks\nis well fit by an absorbed power law (reduced chi2 of 1.0, with\n50 degrees of freedom). GCN Circ.10038) of\nNHz = (1.4 +/- 0.8)e21 cm^-2 in addition to the Galactic column\nalong the line of sight, that is NH = 2.8e20 cm^-2\n(Kalberla et al. 2005). Errors are given at 90% confidence level.\nThe observed (unabsorbed) flux in the 0.3-10 keV band is\n1.5(1.8)e-10 erg cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.","createdOn":1256126155000,"email":"giulia.stratta@gmail.com"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Samantha Oates at MSSL  <sro@mssl.ucl.ac.uk>","subject":"GRB091020 Swift/UVOT observations","circularId":10054,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10054....1O","body":"S. Golenetskii, R.Aptekar, E. Mazets, V. Pal'shin, D. Frederiks,\nP. Oleynik, M. Ulanov, and D. Svinkin on behalf of\nthe Konus-Wind and Konus-RF teams, and\nT. Cline on behalf of the Konus-Wind team, report:\n\nThe long GRB 091024 (Swift-BAT trigger #373674: Marshall et al. GCN \n10062, Sakamoto et al. GCN 10072) was observed by Konus-Wind in the \nwaiting mode. The emission was detected in all three Konus-Wind energy \nbands: G1 (18-70  keV), G2 (70-360 keV) and G3 (360-1360 keV) with high \nS/N.\n\nThe burst light curve shows three pulses: the first pulse starts at \n~T0-10 s and has a duration of ~90 s, the second starts at ~T0+600 s and \nhas a duration of ~100 s, and the most intense third pulse starts at \nT0+840 s and has a duration of ~400 s; there is a low-level emission \nbetween the first and second pulses.\n\nThe most intense part of the third pulse was also detected by Konus-RF, \nwhile Coronas-F was exiting the SAA.\n\nThe GBM localizations suggest a common origin of these events (Bissaldi \n& Connaughton, GCN 10070). Both the K-W light curve and the K-W ecliptic \nlatitude response confirms this suggestion. So, we believe all these \npulses belong to the extremely long burst, GRB 091024, which has a total \nduration of ~1200 s. Hence, some optical observations of this burst were \nperformed during the most intense part of the prompt emission, but no \nbright optical flares have been reported.\n\nModeling of the K-W 3-channel spectra by\na power law with exponential cutoff model:\ndN/dE ~ E^(-alpha)*exp(-E*(2-alpha)/Ep)\nyields the following parameters:\n--------------------------------------------------\n       Tstart    Tstop       alpha      Ep (keV)\n--------------------------------------------------\nP1     -7          80   -1.1+/-0.2    500+/-160\nP2    606         703   -1.6+/-0.2    200+/-120\nP3    835        1194   -1.4+/-0.2    230+/-50\nTotal  -7        1194   -1.5+/-0.4    280+/-120\n--------------------------------------------------\nTstart, Tstop - seconds since the BAT trigger time\n\n\nAs observed by Konus-Wind, the burst had a fluence of (1.13 +/- \n0.12)x10^-4 erg/cm2 (in the 20 - 1300 keV energy range).\n\nAssuming z = 1.092 (Cucchiara, Fox & Tanvir, GCN 10065) and a standard \ncosmology model with H_0 = 70 km/s/Mpc, Omega_M=0.27, Omega_\\Lambda = \n0.7, the isotropic energy release E_iso ~3.2x10^53 erg.\n\nAll the quoted errors are estimated at the 1 sigma confidence level.\n\nThe K-W light curve of this burst is available at\nhttp://www.ioffe.rssi.ru/LEA/GRBs/GRB091024/","createdOn":1256577528000,"email":"val@mail.ioffe.ru"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Andy Beardmore at U Leicester  <apb@star.le.ac.uk>","subject":"GRB 091020: Swift-XRT refined analysis","circularId":10056,"bibcode":"2009GCN.10056....1B","body":"A. P. Beardmore, P. A. Evans (U. Leicester) and J. L. Racusin\n(NASA/GSFC/ORAU) report on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nWe have analysed 13 ks of Swift-XRT data for GRB 091020 (Racusin et\nal., GCN Circ. 10048), from 87 s to 29.6 ks after the BAT trigger\n(#373458). The data comprise 350 s in Windowed Timing (WT) mode with\nthe remainder in Photon Counting (PC) mode. The enhanced XRT position\nfor this burst was given by Beardmore et al. (GCN. Circ 10050).\n\nThe light curve shows an initial steep decay with an index of 3.7 +/-0.6,\nbreaking at T+130 s to a shallower decay of slope 0.90 +/- 0.03, with a\nsmall flare superimposed at T+190s. A further break to a decay slope of\n1.39 +/- 0.1 is apparent at T+6.6 ks.\n\nThe WT mode spectrum, from 87 s to 434 s after the trigger, can be fit\nby an absorbed power-law with a photon index of 1.99 +/- 0.07. The\nbest-fitting absorption column is (6.08 +1.04 -0.99) x 10^21 cm^-2, at\na redshift of 1.71 (Xu et al., GCN Circ 10053), in addition to the\nGalactic value of 1.4 x 10^20 cm^-2 (Kalberla et al. 2005). The PC\nmode spectrum from 436 s to 7.3 ks (with an exposure time of 3.5 ks)\nhas a photon index of (2.15 +0.12 -0.11) and a best-fitting intrinsic\nabsorption column of (5.1 +1.6 -1.5) x 10^21 cm^-2. The counts to\nobserved (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux conversion factor deduced from\nthis spectrum is 3.4 x 10^-11 (4.4 x 10^-11) erg cm^-2 count^-1.\n\nIf the light curve continues to decay at the same rate, the count rate\nat T+24 hours will be 0.015 count s^-1, which corresponds to an\nobserved (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux of 4.8 x 10^-13 (6.3 x 10^-13)\nerg cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/00373458.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.","createdOn":1256134127000,"email":"apb@star.le.ac.uk"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Daniel Perley at U.C. Chornock, W. Li, and A. V. Filippenko (UC Berkeley) report on behalf of the\nKAIT GRB team:\n\nThe Katzman Automatic Imaging Telescope (KAIT) at Lick Observatory automatically\nresponded to the Swift BAT trigger for GRB 091024 (Marshall et al., GCN 10062)\nwith a sequence of observations starting 82 s after the BAT trigger. At\n09:06:29.36, GBM triggered on what appears to be the continuation of this\nburst (trigger 278067991 / 091024380).   The GBM on-ground location for \nthis\nsecond trigger is also consistent with the Swift position for GRB 091024.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight at the time of the\nfirst trigger is 97 degrees and at the time of the second trigger\nit is 14 degrees.  Furthermore, at 09:12:14.28, the Fermi spacecraft \nexecuted\na maneuver to place the burst near the center of the Large Area Telescope\n(LAT) field-of-view and observe this region for 5 hours subject to\nEarth angle constraints.\n\nThe first emission episode appears to last about 50 s, with 2 peaks \nseparated\nby a few seconds.  A brighter emission periods starts at the time of the \n2nd\ntrigger, 630 s later, and persists for at least 400 s.   This second \nemission period\nshows an initial pulse (at 630 s) lasting about 40 s, followed by a \nmulti-peaked\nepisode starting 210 s later (840 s from the first trigger) and lasting \nover 100 s. \nThere is evidence for lower-level emission beyond this time.  The Fermi\nspacecraft entered the South Atlantic Anomaly 2200 s after trigger \n091024380,\nby which time there was no obvious emission in GBM.\n\nIn a first, preliminary analysis, we have fit time-integrated spectra \nfor each of the\n3 main emission blocks.  The first trigger appears to have an EPeak of \nabout\n400 keV;  the first peak of the second trigger is quite weak and best \nfit using\na power-law of index around -1.5;  the long and brighter emission period of\nthe second trigger has an EPeak of around 300 keV.  Detailed spectral\nanalyses and fluence values will be given in a future circular.\n\nThe POC for this burst is Elisabetta Bissaldi (ebs@mpe.mpg.de).","createdOn":1256404357000,"email":"valerie@nasa.gov"}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Arne A. Tueller (GSFC)\n(i.e. the Swift-BAT team):\n \nUsing the data set from T-60 to T+243 sec from the recent telemetry downlink,\nwe report further analysis of BAT GRB 091026 (trigger #373871)\n(Markwardt, et al., GCN Circ. 10081). T90 (15-350 keV) is 41.6 +- 7.2 sec (estimated error \nincluding systematics).\n \nThe time-averaged spectrum from T-3.7 to T+47.9 sec is best fit by a simple\npower-law model. gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Israel Martinez-Castellanos at UMD/HAWC  <imc@umd.edu>","subject":"LIGO/Virgo S190602aq: No counterpart candidates in HAWC observations","circularId":24718,"bibcode":"2019GCN.24718....1H","body":"The HAWC Collaboration (https://www.hawc-observatory.org) reports:\n\nThe HAWC Collaboration performed a follow-up of the gravitational wave\ntrigger S190602aq. At the time of the trigger the HAWC\nlocal zenith was oriented towards (RA, Dec) = (63.2 deg, 18.9 deg).\n57% of the GW candidate sky location probability fell within our\nobservable field of view (0-45 deg zenith angle).\n\nWe performed a search for a short timescale emission using 6 sliding\ntime windows (dt = 0.3s, 1s, 3s, 10s, 30s and  100s), shifted forward\nin time by 20% of their width. We searched the 95% probability\ncontainment area in a timescale-dependent time period, from t0-5dt to\nt0+10dt, where t0 is the time of the GW trigger.\n\nNo significant gamma-ray detection above the background was observed.\n\nThe sensitivity of this analysis is greatly dependent on zenith angle,\nranging from 14.4 deg to 45 deg for the area searched in this\nanalysis. The 5sigma detection sensitivity to a 1s (100s) burst in the\n80-800GeV energy range goes from 1.6e-6 erg/cm^2 to 1.1e-4 erg/cm^2\n(8.6e-6 erg/cm^2 to 5.0e-4 erg/cm^2), depending on the zenith\nangle.\n\nHAWC is a TeV gamma ray water Cherenkov array located in the state of\nPuebla, Mexico. It is sensitive to the energy range ~0.1-100TeV, and\nmonitors 2/3 of the sky every day with an instantaneous field-of-view\nof ~2 sr.","createdOn":1559500672000,"email":"imc@umd.edu"}Topic: GCNC 32632, Krimm et al. 32688), Fermi (Veres et al. GCNC 32636, Bissaldi et al. GCNC 32637, Lesage et al. GCNC 32642, Pillera et al. GCNC 32658, Omodei et al. GCNC 32760), AGILE (Ursi et al. Various estimates of its prompt isotropic energy ranks it among the most energetic GRBs (Cenko et al. 2011, Atteia et al. 2017):\nGotz et al. GCNC 32660 -���������� Eiso = 8e53 ergs in [75 keV 1 MeV] ;\nFrederiks et al. GCNC 32668 - Eiso = 3e54 ergs in [20 keV - 10 MeV ?] ;\nKann et al. GCNC 32762 -���������� Eiso = 6e54 ergs in [0.1 keV - 100 MeV] ;\n\nWe discuss here the chance to observe such an energetic GRB at redshift z = 0.151 (de Ugarte Postigo GCNC 32648, Castro-Tirado et al. GCNC 32686), considering the rate of such extremely energetic GRBs observed at higher redshifts.\n\nConsidering a flat cosmology with H0 = 67.4 km/s/Mpc and Omegam = 0.315 (Planck Collaboration et al. 2020), we extrapolate the rate of ���4 extremely energetic GRBs per year derived by Atteia et al. (2017) in the redshift range [1,5], to the volume of the nearby universe enclosed within z = 0.151.\n\n- Assuming a constant GRB formation rate, we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~130 yr.\n- Assuming the GRB formation rate of Palmerio & Daigne (2021), we obtain 1 extremely energetic GRB per ~520 yr.\n\nWe conclude that there is a ~10% probability to observe an event like GRB 221009A about 50 years after the discovery of the first GRB.\n\nBibliography :\n- Cenko, S. The candidate was found by the CWB [1], GstLAL [2], MBTA [3], PyCBC Live [4], and SPIIR [5] analysis pipelines.\n\nS231206ca is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 3.2e-10 Hz, or about one in 1e2 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S231206ca\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), Terrestrial (<1%), BNS (<1%), or NSBH (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [6] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [6] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassgap) is <1%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 25 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [7], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. galaxies in NED-LVS that fall in the 90% probability volume for S241011k sorted by the joint probability of 3D position and WISE W1 luminosity (P_3D * P_LumW1). Galaxy is the NED preferred name. RA and Dec are the Equatorial coordinates in degrees (J2000). Objtype is the object type of the galaxy candidate. Distance is the distance to the galaxy in Mpc. m_NUV and mErr_NUV are the apparent magnitude and error from GALEX. m_Ks and mErr_Ks are the apparent magnitude and error from 2MASS. m_W1 and mErr_W1 are the apparent magnitude and error from AllWISE. report:\n\nWe observed the field of the SVOM/ECLAIRs GRB 241017A (Le Provost et al, GCN 37799) in the near-infrared J-band with the Palomar 1-m telescope, equipped with the 1-square degree WINTER camera (Lourie et al. 2020, Frostig et al. 2024).\n\nOur observations began at 2024-10-17T07:40:52 UTC (~3.7 hours after the GRB trigger) and consisted of 30x120s exposures. The images were processed using the WINTER data reduction pipeline (https://github.com/winter-telescope/mirar, https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10888436), with image subtraction performed relative to J-band images from the UKIRT Hemisphere survey (Dye et al., 2017).\n\nOur observations covered 95% of the SVOM/ECLAIRs statistical error circle. In the stacked and subtracted images, we do not detect any new source down to a 5-sigma depth of J ~ 19.3 mag (AB).\n\nWINTER (Wide-field INfrared Transient ExploreR) is a partnership between MIT and Caltech, housed at Palomar Observatory, and funded by NSF MRI, NSF AAG, the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, and the MIT Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research.","createdOn":1729181767329}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Jessie Thwaites at IceCube/U Wisc-Madison <thwaites@wisc.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"IceCube-Cascade 241019A: Upper limits from a search for additional neutrino events in IceCube","circularId":37833,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37833....1I","body":"The IceCube Collaboration (http://icecube.wisc.edu/) reports:\n\nIceCube has performed a search [1] for additional track-like muon neutrino events arriving from the direction of IceCube-Cascade 241019A (https://gcn.gsfc.nasa.gov/notices_amon_icecube_cascade/139992_18206409.amon) in a time range of 1000 seconds centered on the alert event time (2024-10-19 23:20:39.840 UTC to 2024-10-19 23:37:19.840 UTC) during which IceCube was collecting good quality data. Excluding the event that prompted the alert, one track-like event is found within the 90% containment region of IceCube-Cascade 241019A. We find that this additional event is well described by atmospheric background expectations, with a p-value of 0.05 (which doesn’t account for statistical trials). The IceCube sensitivity to neutrino point sources with an E^-2.5 spectrum (E^2 dN/dE at 1 TeV) within the locations spanned by the 90% spatial containment region of IceCube-Cascade 241019A ranges from 1.3e-01 to 7.4e+00 GeV cm^-2 in a 1000 second time window. 90% of events IceCube would detect from a source at this declination with an E^-2.5 spectrum have energies in the approximate energy range between 3e+02 GeV and 3e+06 GeV. \n\nA subsequent search was performed including 2 days of data centered on the alert event time (2024-10-18 23:28:59.840 UTC to 2024-10-20 23:28:59.840 UTC). In this search we report a p-value of 0.04, without accounting for statistical trials. This is consistent with no significant excess of track events. The IceCube sensitivity to neutrino point sources with an E^-2.5 spectrum (E^2 dN/dE at 1 TeV) within the locations spanned by the 90% spatial containment region of IceCube-Cascade 241019A ranges from 1.5e-01 to 7.5e+00 GeV cm^-2 in a 2 day time window. \n\nThe best-fit position for a potential source producing the cascade and the track-like events in the two-day search is RA: 171.4 deg, Dec: -16.6 deg (J2000), with an estimated error radius of 0.5 deg at 90% containment. There are three track-like events which include this best-fit position in their 90% error region, and are also inside of the 90% contour of the cascade event. Properties of these coincident events are shown below.\n\ndt [s]\t\tRA [deg]\tDec [deg]\tAngular uncertainty [deg] \n-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------        \n415\t\t171.65\t\t-16.09\t\t1.18\n21967 \t\t170.90\t\t-16.81\t\t0.71\n62271\t\t171.44\t\t-16.72\t\t0.71\n\nwhere:\ndt = Time difference between the track-like event and the cascade event (i.e. T_track - T_cascade) [sec]\nAngular uncertainty = Angular uncertainty of track event: the radius of a circle representing 90% CL containment by area.\n\nThe IceCube Neutrino Observatory is a cubic-kilometer neutrino detector operating at the geographic South Pole, Antarctica. Abbasi  et al., ApJ 910 4 (2021)\n","createdOn":1729545417661}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"EP Team at NAOC/CAS <ep_ta@bao.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241021a: EP detection of a fast X-ray transient","circularId":37834,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37834....1H","body":"J. W. Hu (NAOC, CAS), Y. Wang (PMO, CAS), H. He, S. K. Yang (WHU), Y. H. Cheng (SWIFAR, YNU), W. M. Yuan (NAOC, CAS) on behalf of the Einstein Probe team \n\nWe report on the detection of a fast X-ray transient, designated EP241021a, by the Wide-field X-ray Telescope (WXT) on board the Einstein Probe (EP) mission. The transient started at 2024-10-21T05:07:56(UTC) and lasted for around 100 seconds. The WXT position of EP241021a is R.A. = 28.852 deg, DEC = 5.957 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of 2.4 arcmin (radius, 90% C.L. statistical and systematic). It has a peak flux of ~1 x 10^-9 erg/s/cm^2 in the 0.5-4 keV band. The average 0.5-4 keV spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed power law with a photon index of 1.48(-1.22, +1.24) (with a column density fixed at the Galactic one of 5 x 10^20 cm^-2). The derived average unabsorbed 0.5-4 keV flux is 3.3(-1.6, +4.8) x 10^(-10) erg/s/cm^2. The uncertainties are at the 90% confidence level for the above parameters. \n\nNo previously known bright X-ray sources are found within the error circle around the source position. Further follow-up observations are encouraged to identify the nature of this X-ray transient. \n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics). ","createdOn":1729581045754}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Dong Xu at NAOC/CAS <dxu@nao.cas.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241021a: NOT likely optical counterpart","circularId":37840,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37840....1F","body":"S.Y. Turkki (NOT) report on behalf of a large collaboration:\n\nWe observed the field of EP241021a detected by Einstein Probe (EP, Hu et al., GCN 37834), using the ALFOSC instrument mounted on the Nordic Optical Telescope (NOT), with 5 x 200 s and 5 x 300 s photometry in the SDSS-z and SDSS-r bands, respectively. Observations started at 23:31:48.4 UT on 2024-10-22, i.e. 1.77 days after the EP trigger.\n\nAn uncatalogued source is detected in the individual as well as the stacked frames within the EP/WXT error circle (Hu et al., GCN 37834) and localized at coordinates\n\nR.A. (J2000) =  01:55:23.41\nDec. (J2000) = +05:56:18.01\n\nwith an uncertainty of ~ 0.5 arcsec. The source is not present in the Legacy Survey, which is well deeper than the r-/z-band detection. The candidate was found by the GstLAL [1] analysis pipeline.\n\nS241011k is an event of interest because its false alarm rate, as estimated by the online analysis, is 2.5e-34 Hz, or about one in 1e26 years. The event's properties can be found at this URL:\n\nhttps://gracedb.ligo.org/superevents/S241011k\n\nThe classification of the GW signal, in order of descending probability, is BBH (>99%), NSBH (<1%), Terrestrial (<1%), or BNS (<1%).\n\nAssuming the candidate is astrophysical in origin, the probability that the lighter compact object is consistent with a neutron star mass (HasNS) is <1%. [2] Using the masses and spins inferred from the signal, the probability of matter outside the final compact object (HasRemnant) is <1%. [2] Both HasNS and HasRemnant consider the support of several neutron star equations of state for maximum neutron star mass. The probability that either of the binary components lies between 3 and 5 solar masses (HasMassGap) is 3%.\n\nTwo sky maps are available at this time and can be retrieved from the GraceDB event page:\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,0, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 28 seconds after the candidate event time.\n * bayestar.multiorder.fits,1, an initial localization generated by BAYESTAR [3], distributed via GCN notice about 5 minutes after the candidate event time.\n\nThe preferred sky map at this time is bayestar.multiorder.fits,1. Bissaldi (Politecnico and INFN Bari) and C. Meegan (UAH) \nreport on behalf of the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\n\"At 11:12:40.13 UT on 16 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB 241016B (trigger 750769965/241016467),\nwhich was also detected by SVOM/GRM (Zhang et al. 2024, GCN 37803)\nand by Swift/BAT-GUANO (DeLaunay et al. 2024, GCN 37806).\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 86 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of two peaks with a duration (T90)\nof about 0.8 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0-0.6s to T0+0.7s is best fit by\na power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff.\nThe power law index is 0.0 +/- 0.5 and the cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 840 +/- 380 keV.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(4.1 +/- 0.5)E-07 erg/cm^2. The 64-msec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0-0.064 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 6.4 +/- 0.7 ph/s/cm^2.\n\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1729258364752}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241013A","submitter":"Matteo Ferro at INAF-OAB <matteo.ferro@inaf.it>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB241013A: REM observations","circularId":37787,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37787....1F","body":"M. Kennea (PSU), Tyler Parsotan (NASA GSFC) report: \n\nSwift/BAT did not localize GRB 241016B onboard (T0: 2024-10-16 11:12:40.13 UTC, Fermi trig 750769965, GCN 37797, SVOM/GRM GCN 37803) \n\nThe Fermi notice, distributed in near real-time, triggered the Swift Mission Operations Center operated Gamma-ray Urgent Archiver for Novel Opportunities (GUANO; Tohuvavohu et al. 2020, ApJ, 900, 1). \n\nUpon trigger by this notice, GUANO sent a command to the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) to save 200 seconds of BAT event-mode data from [-50,+150] seconds around the time of the burst. All the requested event mode data was delivered to the ground. \n\nThe BAT likelihood search, NITRATES (DeLaunay + Tohuvavohu 2022, ApJ, 941, 169), performed on the temporal window [T0-20 s, T0+20 s], detects the burst with a sqrt(TS) of 7.2 in a 0.128 s analysis time bin, starting at T0 - 0.064 s. \n\nUsing the NITRATES analysis, parameter estimation was performed to obtain the localization of this burst in the form of a HEALPIX Multi-Order Coverage (MOC) skymap. This localization accounts for both statistical and systematic errors. More details in the creation and calibration of these maps will soon be published (DeLaunay et al. 2024. in prep)\n\nThe 90% credible area is 16,614 deg2 and the 50% credible area is 7,705 deg2.\nThe integrated probability inside the coded field of view is 2%. \n\nA plot of the probability skymap can be viewed here,\n[https://guano.swift.psu.edu/trigger_report?id=750769994/#:~:text=Probability%20Skymap](https://guano.swift.psu.edu/trigger_report?id=750769994/#:~:text=Probability%20Skymap)\n\nThe probability skymap file can be downloaded from the link here,\nhttps://guano.swift.psu.edu/files/750769994/0_n_PROBMAP\n\nInstructions on how to read and manipulate this map can be found here,\nhttps://guano.swift.psu.edu/documentation\n\nMore details about this burst can be found on the trigger report page here\nhttps://guano.swift.psu.edu/trigger_report?id=750769994\n\nGUANO is a fully autonomous, extremely low latency, spacecraft commanding pipeline designed for targeted recovery of BAT event mode data around the times of compelling astrophysical events to enable more sensitive GRB searches. \n\nA live reporting of Swift/BAT event data recovered by GUANO can be found at: https://www.swift.psu.edu/guano/\n","createdOn":1729193735412}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241001A","submitter":"Damien Turpin at CEA-Saclay <dturpin-astro@hotmail.com>","editedBy":"Judith Racusin at NASA/GSFC <judith.racusin@nasa.gov> on behalf of Damien Turpin at CEA-Saclay <dturpin-astro@hotmail.com>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241001A: EP-FXT afterglow detection","format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37809....1T","body":"D. Compared to the first Swift/XRT epoch (Osborne et al., GCN 37670) the source had faded by about an order of magnitude to F_X =  5.1e-14 +/- 1.2e-14 erg.cm-2.s-1 in the 0.3-10 keV energy band.\n \nWe thus confirm that the Swift/XRT source #2 is the afterglow of GRB 241001A.\n \nThe above observation was made with the EP-FXT instrument. Upon further examination by the IceCube collaboration, the event was found to clearly not be of astrophysical origin.  \n\nAt the time of this alert, the detector was operating with several portions of the detector removed from data taking. Zhou (PMO)\n\nSVOM JSWG: Jian-Yan Wei (NAOC), Bertrand Cordier (CEA), Shuang-Nan Zhang (IHEP), Stéphane Basa (LAM), Olivier Godet (IRAP), Arnaud Claret (CEA), Zi-Gao Dai (USTC), Frédéric Daigne (IAP), Jin-Song Deng (NAOC), Andrea Goldwurm (APC), Diego Götz (CEA), Xu-Hui Han (NAOC), Cyril Lachaud (APC), En-Wei Liang (GXU), Yu-Lei Qiu (NAOC), Susanna Vergani (Obs.Paris), Jing Wang (NAOC), Chao Wu (NAOC), Li-Ping Xin (NAOC), Bing Zhang (UNLV)\n\nreport on behalf of the SVOM team:\n\nVT started to observe the field of GRB 241018A triggered by SVOM/Eclairs(Atteia et al., GCN 37812) in an automatic way after the slew of the satellite. The VT conducted observations simultaneously in two channels: VT_B (400nm-650nm) and VT_R (650nm-1000nm).\n\nWith the VHF data started at 2024-10-18T12:00:28 UT, in which the cataloged source brighter than 21 mag is completed relative to the PS1 catalog. An uncatalogued source was found within the errorbox of Eclairs and has an angular distance of 1.8509 arcmin from the position of MXT (Maggi et al., 37814). \n\nThe position is RA=04:31:59, DEC=+43:01:12, error=1.0 arcsec, J2000.\n\nThe brightness of the source is fading rapidly in 10 min, from 20.9 mag to 22.2 mag for VT_B and from 18.7 mag to 20.5 mag for VT_R.\n\nWe proposed that this source might be the counterpart of the burst. More analysis is continuing with X-band data. \n\nFurther follow-ups are encouraged especially in red wavelength. \n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA, China), National Center for Space Studies (CNES, France) and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS, China), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. VT was jointly developed by Xi'an Institute of Optics and Precision Mechanics (XIOPM), CAS and National astronomical observatories (NAOC),CAS.","createdOn":1729280625256}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241018A","submitter":"Alberto Castro-Tirado at Inst.de Astro. de Andalucia <ajct@iaa.es>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241018A: BOOTES-4/MET optical upper limit","circularId":37828,"bibcode":"2024GCN.37828....1F","body":"E. Zhao (Yunnan Observatories of CAS), on behalf of a larger collaboration, report:\n\nFollowing the detection of GRB 241018A by SVOM (Atteia et al., GCNC 37812; Maggi et al., GCNC 37814;), we triggered the 0.6m BOOTES-4/MET robotic telescope at Lijiang Astronomical Observatory (China) to follow-up this burst starting on Oct. 18 at 13:12:19 UT (~ 78 min after trigger). The fast decaying afterglow (Qiu et al.  GCNC 37819, GCNC 37826) is not detected in the co-added image (15 x 60 s, z filter) down to 19.7 mag, which is consistent with the reports from LCO (Turpin et al. GCNC 37818), NOT (Malesani et al. GCNC 37821), REM (Ferro et al. GCNC 37822), Xinglong (Song et al. GCNC 378), GROWTH (Mohan et al. GCNC 7825) and Mondy (Pankov et al. GCNC 37827).\n\nWe thank the staff at Lijiang observatory for their excellent support.\n\n","createdOn":1729366490494}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Moskvitin Alexander at SAO RAS <mosk@sao.ru>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"EP241021a: SAO RAS optical observations","circularId":37850,"bibcode":"2024GCN.37850....1M","body":"A. Lee (UNAM) and Eleonora Troja (UTOV) report:\n\nWe observed the field of the GRB 241025A detected by Swift (Ambrosi et al., GCN 37859; Fermi GBM team, GCN 37860) with the DDOTI/OAN wide-field imager at the Observatorio Astronómico Nacional on Sierra San Pedro Mártir (http://ddoti.astroscu.unam.mx) on 2024-10-25 from 02:28 to 02:43 UTC, 51min to 1.1hrs after the event, obtaining a total of 11 minutes of exposure in the w filter.\n\nWe detect a source at 22:14:36.94 +83:34:31.9, consistent with the position of the UVOT afterglow (Ambrosi et al., GCN 37859 ; Jiang et al, GCN 37862), with the following magnitude and 10-sigma uncertainty: w = 20.20 +/- 0.19 mag.\n\nOur photometry is calibrated against the APASS catalog, on an approximate AB system, and is not corrected for Galactic extinction in the direction of the GRB.\n\nWe thank the DDOTI technical team and the staff of the Observatorio Astronómico Nacional.\n","createdOn":1729831800294}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241025A","submitter":"David Palmer at LANL <palmer@lanl.gov>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241025A: Swift detection of a burst with an optical counterpart","circularId":37859,"bibcode":"2024GCN.37859....1A","body":"E. Sbarufatti (INAF-OAB) report on behalf of the Neil Gehrels Swift\nObservatory Team:\n\nAt 01:36:50 UT, the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) triggered and\nlocated GRB 241025A (trigger=1262165).  Swift slewed immediately to the burst.\nThe BAT on-board calculated location is \nRA, Dec 333.330, +83.566 which is \n   RA(J2000) = 22h 13m 19s\n   Dec(J2000) = +83d 33' 59\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3 arcmin (radius, 90% containment, including \nsystematic uncertainty).  The BAT light curve showed a complex\nstructure with a duration of about 180 sec.  The peak count rate\nwas ~1800 counts/sec (15-350 keV), at ~2 sec after the trigger.\n\nThe XRT began observing the field at 01:38:46.2 UT, 115.7 seconds after\nthe BAT trigger. XRT found a bright, uncatalogued X-ray source located\nat RA, Dec 333.6488, 83.5739 which is equivalent to:\n   RA(J2000)  = 22h 14m 35.71s\n   Dec(J2000) = +83d 34' 26.0\"\nwith an uncertainty of 4.8 arcseconds (radius, 90% containment). This\nlocation is 131 arcseconds from the BAT onboard position, within the\nBAT error circle. No event data are yet available to determine the\ncolumn density using X-ray spectroscopy.\n\nUVOT took a finding chart exposure of 150 seconds with the White filter\nstarting 125 seconds after the BAT trigger. Cline,\non behalf of the Konus-Wind team, report:\n\nThe long GRB 241018A (SVOM detection: Atteia et al., GCN 37812)\ntriggered Konus-Wind (KW) at T0=42881.464 s UT (11:54:41.464).\n\nThe burst light curve shows a multi-peaked structure,\nwhich starts at ~T0-3 s, peaks at ~T0+4 s,\nand has a total duration of ~12 s.\nThe emission is seen up to ~3 MeV.\n\nThe Konus-Wind light curve of this GRB is available at\nhttp://www.ioffe.ru/LEA/GRBs/GRB241018_T42881/\n\nAs observed by Konus-Wind, the burst had\na fluence of (1.22 ± 0.18)x10^-5 erg/cm^2 and\na 64-ms peak energy flux, measured from T0 + 4.224 s,\nof (5.34 ± 0.64)x10^-6 erg/cm^2/s (both in the 20 keV - 10 MeV energy range).\n\nThe time-integrated spectrum (measured from T0 to T0+8.448 s)\nis best fit in the 20 keV - 15 MeV range\nby a GRB (Band) function with the following model parameters:\nthe low-energy photon index alpha = -1.12 (-0.21,+0.27),\nthe high energy photon index beta = -2.49 (-0.29,+0.18),\nthe peak energy Ep = 110 (-14,+16) keV,\nchi2 = 78/86 dof.\n\nAll the quoted errors are estimated at the 90% confidence level.\nAll the presented results are preliminary\n\n","createdOn":1729523778792}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"Ben Gompertz at U of Birmingham <b.gompertz@bham.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"EP241021a: GOTO optical upper limits","circularId":37835,"bibcode":"2024GCN.37835....1G","body":"B. Pollacco report on behalf of the GOTO collaboration:\n\nThe Gravitational-wave Optical Transient Observer (GOTO; Steeghs et al. 2022, Dyer et al. 2024) serendipitously covered the field of EP241021a (Hu et al., GCN 37834) in survey mode at 23:44:44 UT on 2024-10-21, approximately 18.5 hours after the trigger. The observation was taken by GOTO-N, and consisted of 4x45s exposures in the GOTO L-band (400-700 nm).\n\nImages were processed immediately after acquisition using the GOTO pipeline. Difference imaging was performed using deeper template observations of the same pointings. <ep_ta@bao.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241026b: EP detection of a fast X-ray transient","circularId":37902,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37902....1L","body":"T.Y. Lian, D. Y. Li, Y. L. Wang, S. X. Wen. W. Yuan (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nWe report on the detection of a fast X-ray transient, designated EP241026b, by the Wide-field X-ray Telescope (WXT) on board the Einstein Probe (EP) mission. The transient started at 2024-10-26T18:14:30(UTC) and lasted for around 100 seconds. The WXT position of EP241026b is R.A.= 56.403 deg, DEC = 41.031 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of 2.9 arcmin (radius, 90% C.L. statistical and systematic).  It has a peak flux of ~1.7 x 10^-9 erg/s/cm^2 in the 0.5-4 keV band. The average 0.5-4 keV spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed power law with a photon index of 2.5(+/-0.8) (with a column density fixed at the Galactic value of 3.38 x 10^21 cm^-2). The derived average unabsorbed 0.5-4 keV flux is 1.2(-0.3, +0.4) x 10^(-10) erg/s/cm^2. The uncertainties are at the 90% confidence level for the above parameters. \n\nNo previously known bright X-ray sources are found within the error circle around the source position. EP-FXT follow-up observation has been arranged. Further follow-up observations are encouraged to identify the nature of this X-ray transient. \n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics). ","createdOn":1730003598546}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"EP Team at NAOC/CAS <ep_ta@bao.ac.cn>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP241026a (GRB 241026A): EP on-board trigger and follow-up observation","circularId":37909,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37909....1L","body":"D. Y. Li, T. Y. Lian, Y. L. Wang, S. X. Wen, W. Yuan (NAO, CAS) report on behalf of the Einstein Probe team:\n\nWe report on the detection of an X-ray transient detected by EP-WXT, EP241026a, which triggered the on-board processing unit (trigger ID: 01709112485). A preliminary analysis of the EP-WXT data shows that the transient began at 2024-10-26T22:41:28 (UTC), and lasted for around 150 seconds, with the peak flux of around 8 x 10^-9 erg/s/cm^2 in 0.5-4 keV. The averaged spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed powerlaw（NH fixed at the Galactic value 9.2 x 10^20 cm^-2）with a photon index of 0.8 +/- 0.3. The average unabsorbed flux is (1.6 +/- 0.3) x 10^-9 erg/s/cm2 in 0.5-4 keV. An EP-FXT follow-up observation was triggered about 8 hours later, which detected an uncatalogued X-ray source at R.A. = 293.4008 deg, DEC = 57.9857 deg (J2000) with an uncertainty of about 10 arcsecs (radius, 90% C.L. statistical and systematic), consistent with the position of the WXT transient within the uncertainties. We note that the trigger time and position of this X-ray transient are consistent with those of GRB 241026A (Fermi GBM team, GCN #37894, Melandri et al. GCN #37896). The averaged EP-FXT spectrum can be fitted with an absorbed powerlaw (NH fixed at the Galactic value), with a photon index of 1.81 +/- 0.08. The derived average unabsorbed flux is (6.4 +/- 0.3) x 10^-12 and (1.06 +/- 0.07) x 10^-11 erg/s/cm2 in 0.5-4 keV and 0.5-10 keV, respectively. All the errors of the parameters quoted are at the 90% C.L.\n\nPlease note that the temporal and spectral analyses presented above are preliminary. Final results will be presented in future publications. EP-FXT will also keep monitoring this transient in the following days.\n\nLaunched on January 9, 2024, EP is a space X-ray observatory to monitor the soft X-ray sky with X-ray follow-up capability (Yuan et al. 2022, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-ray Astrophysics).","createdOn":1730039655620}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"atrigg2@lsu.edu","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241026A Fermi GBM Analysis","circularId":37917,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37917....1T","body":"A. Trigg (LSU) report on behalf of\nthe Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Team:\n\n\"At 22:42:31.28 UT on 26 October 2024, the Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM)\ntriggered and located GRB 241026A (trigger 751675356/241026946).\nwhich was also detected by Swift BAT (D. M. Palmer et al. 2024, GCN 37896)\nand Einstein Probe  (D.Y. Li et al. 2024, GCN 37909).\nThe Fermi GBM on-ground location is consistent with the Swift BAT position.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 43 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of a single emission episode with a duration (T90)\nof about 16 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0+0.003 to T0+16.768 s is best fit by\na Comptonized function with a power law index -0.96 +/- 0.05 and a cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 229 +/- 20.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(6.6 +/- 0.3)E-06 erg/cm^2. The 1-sec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0+0.70 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 7.1 +/- 0.3 ph/s/cm^2.\n\nA Band function fits the spectrum equally well with\nEpeak = 183 +/- 22 keV, alpha = -0.87 +/- 0.07 and beta = -2.17 +/- 0.2.\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1730076161197}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"Daniele B. Malesani at IMAPP / Radboud University <d.malesani@astro.ru.nl>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241026A: LBT redshift confirmation","circularId":37925,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37925....1I","body":"L. Izzo (INAF/OAC), O. Kuhn (LBTO), A. Rossi (INAF/OAS), D. B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.), V. D'Elia (ASI/SSDC & INAF-OAR) and F. Cusano (INAF/OAS), report on behalf of a larger collaboration: \n\nWe observed the optical counterpart (Moskvitin et al.,, GCN 37899) of GRB 241026A (Melandri et al., GCN 37896; Trigg, GCN 37917; Zhang et al., GCN 37921) using the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) located on Mount Graham (AZ, USA). Observations were carried out with the MODS instrument, and consisted of two 600-s spectra taken in each of the red and blue channels, starting on 2024 October 27.204 UT (6.18 hr after the trigger).\n\nStrong continuum is detected, showing a multitude of absorption lines, which we interpret as due to, among others, Si II 1526, Si II* 1533, C IV 1458,1550, Fe II 1600, Al II 1670, Si II 1808, Al III 1854, 1862, all at a common redshift of z = 2.791.\n\nWe thus confirm the redshift value measured by Moskvitin et al. (GCN 37916).\n\nWe acknowledge support from R. Leicester <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241030A: Swift-XRT refined Analysis","circularId":37988,"bibcode":"2024GCN.37988....1A","body":"E. Ambrosi  (INAF-IASFPA) , M. A. Williams (PSU), S. Dichiara (PSU),\nJ.A. Kennea (PSU), J.P. Osborne (U. Leicester), K.L. Page (U.\nLeicester), A.P. Beardmore (U. Leicester), M. Capalbi (INAF-IASFPA), M.\nPerri (SSDC & INAF-OAR) and P.A. Evans report on behalf of the\nSwift-XRT team:\n\nWe have analysed 11 ks of XRT data for GRB 241030A, from 63 s to 45.7\nks after the  BAT trigger. The data comprise 859 s in Windowed Timing\n(WT) mode (the first 9 s were taken while Swift was slewing) with the\nremainder in Photon Counting (PC) mode. \n\nThe late-time light curve (from T0+4.5 ks) can be modelled with an\ninitial power-law decay with an index of alpha=0.87 (+0.17, -0.57),\nfollowed by a break at T+10.4 ks to an alpha of 1.58 (+/-0.10).\n\nA spectrum formed from the WT mode data can be fitted with an absorbed\npower-law with a photon spectral index\tof 1.720 (+0.016, -0.011). The\nbest-fitting absorption column is  consistent with the Galactic value\nof 1.8 x 10^21 cm^-2 (Willingale et al. 2013). The PC mode spectrum has\na photon index of 1.95 (+0.08, -0.06) and a best-fitting absorption\ncolumn consistent with the Galactic value. The counts to observed\n(unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux conversion factor deduced from this\nspectrum  is 3.6 x 10^-11 (4.8 x 10^-11) erg cm^-2 count^-1. \n\nA summary of the PC-mode spectrum is thus:\nGalactic foreground: 1.8 x 10^21 cm^-2\nIntrinsic column:    1.8 (+1.8, -0.0) x 10^21 cm^-2 at z=1.411\nPhoton index:\t     1.95 (+0.08, -0.06)\n\nIf the light curve continues to decay with a power-law decay index of\n1.58, the count rate at T+24 hours will be 0.034 count s^-1,\ncorresponding to an observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux of 1.2 x\n10^-12 (1.6 x 10^-12) erg cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/01263718.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n","createdOn":1730325504501}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241029A","submitter":"kendall.ackley@warwick.ac.uk","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241029A: GOTO optical afterglow detection","circularId":37943,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37943....1A","body":"K. Pollacco report on behalf of the GOTO collaboration:\n\nWe report on observations with the Gravitational-wave Optical Transient Observer (GOTO; Steeghs et al. 2022, Dyer et al. 2024) in response to GRB 241029A, detected by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37932), SVOM/ECLAIRs (Schanne et al., GCN 37934) and SVOM/GRM (Wang et al., GCN 37935). Observations were performed by GOTO-S between 09:46:21 and 12:06:59 UT on 2024-10-29 (starting 7.34 hours after trigger). Each observation consisted of 4x90s exposures in the GOTO L-band (400-700 nm).\n\nImages were processed immediately after acquisition using the GOTO pipeline. Xu (NAOC), L. Izzo (INAF/OACn and DARK/NBI), Z.P. Zhu, S.Y. Fu (NAOC), N. Koivisto (NOT), T. Bäcker, M. Varding, R. Tuomainen, A. Willstedt Justel, T. Gobold (UH) report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe have observed the optical counterpart (Ambrosi et al., GCN#37859; Jiang et al., GCN#37862) of GRB 241025A (Ambrosi et al., GCN#37859; Fermi GBM team, GCN#37860; Wang et al., GCN#37863; Li et al., GCN 37864), using the Nordic Optical Telescope (NOT) equipped with the ALFOSC spectrograph. Grism #4 was used, covering the wavelength range 3650-9500 AA. Four spectra of 1200 s exposure time each have been obtained, with the first sequence starting at 02:07:32 UT on 2024-10-25, i.e., 0.51 hr after the Swift trigger.\n\nPreliminary analysis of the data reveals a bright continuum in the red part of the spectrum, with a clear break around 6310 AA, which we interpret as due to Lyman alpha. P. Gompertz (U. Birmingham), A. J. Levan (Radboud Univ. and Warwick Univ.), D. B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.), B. Schneider (MIT), L. Izzo (INAF-OACn & DARK/NBI), T. Laskar (University of Utah) and A. Martin-Carrillo (UCD) report for a larger collaboration:\n\nWe obtained spectroscopic observations of the optical counterpart (Izzo & Malesani., GCNs 37667 and 37673; Breeveld et al., GCN 37678; Turpin et al., GCN 37679; SVOM/VT commissioning team, GCN 37695) to the SVOM/ECLAIRs-detected GRB 241001A (SVOM/ECLAIRs Commissioning Team; GCN 37655) at redshift z = 0.57 (Palmerio et al., GCN 37677) with the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST). Observations were carried out using the NIRSpec instrument on 2024-10-23, 21.5 days after trigger (13.7 days in the GRB rest frame). The total integration time was 1.7 hours with the clear prism in the wavelength range 0.5 - 5.5 µm.\n\nThe trace reveals a blue spectrum showing multiple broad absorption/emission features, similar to those observed in broad-lined type-Ic SNe commonly associated with long-duration GRBs. In particular, the spectrum matches well the one of GRB980425 / SN1998bw at 14 - 21 rest-frame days after collapse (Patat et al. 2001, Apj, 555, 900).\n\nWe acknowledge excellent support from Diane Karakla and Amber Armstrong (both STScI) in preparing these observations.\n\n","createdOn":1729844410437}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241025A","submitter":"Alan Watson at UNAM <alan@astro.unam.mx>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"GRB 241025A: COLIBRÍ Detection of the Afterglow","circularId":37889,"bibcode":"2024GCN.37889....1W","body":"Alan M. Sun, S.L, R.Wang Y.M Mao report on behalf of a large collaboration:\nFollowing the detection of EP241021a by EP-WXT (Hu et al., GCN 37834), we observed the field of EP241021a using the 80-cm telescope at Xinglong Observatory, NAOC. Pugliese (API-UvA), D. Xu (NAOC), L. Izzo (INAF-OACn & DARK/NBI), A. J. Levan (Radboud Univ. and Warwick Univ.), Z.P. Zhu (NAOC), D. B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.), V. D'Elia (ASI/SSDC and INAF/OAR), P. G. Jonker (Radboud Univ.), A. Martin-Carrillo (UCD), B. P. Gompertz (Birmingham), A. Rossi (INAF/OAS), A. Saccardi (GEPI/Obs. de Paris) report on behalf of the Stargate collaboration:\n\nWe observed the optical counterpart of the fast X-ray transient EP 241021a (Hu et al., GCN 37834) reported by Fu et al. (GCN 37840, 37842), Li et al. (GCN 37844, 37846), Ror et al. (GCN 37845), Zheng et al. (GCN 37849), Moskvitin & Spiridonova (GCN 37850). We used the FORS2 spectrograph mounted on the ESO VLT UT1 (Antu), equipped with the 300V grism and no order-sorting filter. Two spectra by 20 min each were secured, with mean epoch 2024 Oct 24.229 UT (about 3.01 days after the trigger). Seeing conditions were excellent at 0.5\", as measured in the acquisition image.\n\nIn the acquisition image (taken 2.998 days after the trigger), we measure a preliminary magnitude r = 22.06 +- 0.05 (AB, calibrated against nearby objects from Pan-STARRS).\n\nContinuum is detected at least across the range 4600-8600 AA. A strong emission line is visible at 6519 AA, which we identify as due to [O II] 3728 AA at z = 0.75. This interpretation is confirmed by the detection of a doublet in absorption at 4897 AA, which matches well Mg II at z = 0.748.\n\nWe note the persistently flat light curve of the optical counterpart (Fu et al., GCN 37840, 37842; Li et al., GCN 37844, 37846; Ror et al., GCN 37845; Moskvitin & Spiridonova, GCN 37850; our own acquisition measurement), which is unusual for a GRB afterglow over such a long time range. We encourage further photometric monitoring at all wavelengths.\n\nWe acknowledge the expert support from the ESO observing staff at Paranal, in particular Martina Baratella.","createdOn":1729765290834}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241010A","submitter":"Priya Gokuldass at ERAU <gokuldap@my.erau.edu>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241010A: VIRT Optical Upper Limit","circularId":37854,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37854....1S","body":"K. D'Elia et al. 2024, GCN 37859) and Einstein Probe (D.Y. Li et al. 2024, GCN 37864)\nThe Fermi GBM on-ground location is consistent with the Swift BAT position.\n\nThe angle from the Fermi LAT boresight is 47 degrees.\n\nThe GBM light curve consists of multiple close peaks with a duration (T90)\nof about 124 s (50-300 keV). The time-averaged spectrum\nfrom T0+2.3 to T0+125.2 s is best fit by a Band function.\nThe power law index is -0.93 +/- 0.06 and the cutoff energy,\nparameterized as Epeak, is 235 +/- 22 keV.\n\nThe event fluence (10-1000 keV) in this time interval is\n(1.46 +/- 0.06)E-05 erg/cm^2. The 1-sec peak photon flux measured\nstarting from T0+46 s in the 10-1000 keV band is 3 +/- 0.2 ph/s/cm^2.\n\nA power law function with an exponential high-energy cutoff fits the spectrum equally well.\nThe power law index is -0.92 +/- 0.05 and the cutoff energy, parameterized as\nEpeak, is 232 +/- 18 keV.\n\nThe spectral analysis results presented above are preliminary;\nfinal results will be published in the GBM GRB Catalog:\nhttps://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/W3Browse/fermi/fermigbrst.html\n\nFor Fermi GBM data and info, please visit the official Fermi GBM Support Page:\nhttps://fermi.gsfc.nasa.gov/ssc/data/access/gbm/\"","createdOn":1729890623197}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241025A","submitter":"Moskvitin Alexander at SAO RAS <mosk@sao.ru>","submittedHow":"email-legacy","subject":"GRB 241025A: SAO RAS optical observations","circularId":37914,"bibcode":"2024GCN.37914....1M","body":"A. D'Avanzo (INAF-OAB), M.G. Bernardini (INAF-OAB), E. Ambrosi \n(INAF-IASFPA) , J.A. Kennea (PSU), D.N. Burrows (PSU), M. A. Williams\n(PSU), A.P. Beardmore (U. Leicester), J.P. Osborne (U. Leicester) and\nP.A. Evans report on behalf of the Swift-XRT team:\n\nWe have analysed 7.6 ks of XRT data for GRB 241026A, from 98 s to 45.9\nks after the  BAT trigger. The data comprise 54 s in Windowed Timing\n(WT) mode (the first 9 s were taken while Swift was slewing) with the\nremainder in Photon Counting (PC) mode. \n\nThe light curve can be modelled with a series of power-law decays. The\ninitial decay index is alpha=2.5 (+0.5, -0.4). At T+226 s  the decay\nflattens to an alpha of 0.21 (+0.11, -0.12) before breaking again at\nT+7943 s to a final decay with index alpha=0.90 (+/-0.11).\n\nA spectrum formed from the PC mode data can be fitted with an absorbed\npower-law with a photon spectral index of 1.88 (+/-0.10). The\nbest-fitting absorption column is  1.43 (+0.32, -0.30) x 10^21 cm^-2,\nin excess of the Galactic value of 8.9 x 10^20 cm^-2 (Willingale et al.\n2013). The counts to observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux conversion\nfactor deduced from this spectrum  is 3.7 x 10^-11 (4.6 x 10^-11) erg\ncm^-2 count^-1. \n\nA summary of the PC-mode spectrum is thus:\nTotal column:\t     1.43 (+0.32, -0.30) x 10^21 cm^-2\nGalactic foreground: 8.9 x 10^20 cm^-2\nExcess significance: 3.0 sigma\nPhoton index:\t     1.88 (+/-0.10)\n\nIf the light curve continues to decay with a power-law decay index of\n0.90, the count rate at T+24 hours will be 0.10 count s^-1,\ncorresponding to an observed (unabsorbed) 0.3-10 keV flux of 3.8 x\n10^-12 (4.7 x 10^-12) erg cm^-2 s^-1.\n\nThe results of the XRT-team automatic analysis are available at\nhttp://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_products/01262764.\n\nThis circular is an official product of the Swift-XRT team.\n","createdOn":1730037010026}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241026A","submitter":"Varun Bhalerao at IIT Bombay <varunb@iitb.ac.in>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"GRB 241026A: GROWTH-India Telescope optical observations","circularId":37918,"format":"text/markdown","bibcode":"2024GCN.37918....1M","body":"T. GCN 37934).\n\nThe real-time alert data and light curves of SVOM/GRM were downlinked to the ground through the VHF system with low latency. With the event-by-event data downloaded through the X-band ground station, the GRM light curve shows that this burst consists of multiple pulses with a T90 of 14.6 +0.6/-0.3 s.\n\nThe GRM light curve can be found here:\nhttps://www.bursthub.cn//admin/static/svgrb241029A.png\n\nThis burst is located at about 29 degrees from the SVOM optical axis.\n\nThe Space Variable Objects Monitor (SVOM) is a China-France joint mission led by the Chinese National Space Administration (CNSA, China), National Center for Space Studies (CNES, France) and the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS, China), which is dedicated to observing gamma-ray bursts and other transient phenomena in the energetic universe. Malesani at IMAPP / Radboud University <d.malesani@astro.ru.nl>","submittedHow":"web","subject":"EP 241026b: LBT possible optical counterpart (brightening source)","circularId":37938,"format":"text/plain","bibcode":"2024GCN.37938....1R","body":"Andrea Rossi (INAF/OAS), Daniele B. Malesani (DAWN/NBI and Radboud Univ.), E. Maiorano (INAF/OAS), report on behalf of a larger collaboration:\n\nWe performed a second observation of the field of the fast X-ray transient EP241026b (Lian et al., GCN 37902), using the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT), equipped with the LBC instrument. Observations were carried out again in the SDSS r filter, and consisted of 6 exposures by 120 s each. The observation mid time was October 28.244 UT (1.48 days after the EP trigger).\n\nDigital image subtraction was carried out with HOTPANTS (Becker, 2015) between this data set and our earlier observation (Malesani et al., GCN 37907). In the difference image, a very obvious transient is detected within the EP/WXT error circle, and is located at coordinates (J2000):\n\nRA = 03:45:37.55\nDec = +41:01:51.9\n\nThis transient is observed to brighten by about 1.9 mag among the two observations, and has a magnitude r = 21.6 (AB) in our second (brighter) epoch. No source is visible at this position in the Pan-STARRS images of this field. While this behavior is unusual for GRB afterglows, brightening episodes have been noticed recently in a number of EP-detected transients (e.g., EP240414a: Srivastav et al., arXiv:2409.19070, van Dalen et al., arXiv:2409.19056; EP 241021a: Quirola-Vasquez et al., GCN 37930). We also note that this position is only 10 deg off the Galactic plane, so a Galactic origin cannot be excluded.\n\nNo other transient source is detected in the difference image, down to a limiting magnitude r = 25.1 (AB).\n\nWe acknowledge excellent support from the LBTO and LBT-INAF staff, particularly O. Kuhn, R. Ansaldi, E. Marini and F. Melandri et al., GCN #37896), SVOM/GRM (Yan-Qiu Zhang et al., GCN #37921) and EP/WXT (D. Y. Li et al., GCN #37909).\n\nAccording to the GECAM-B light curves in about 6-6000 keV, this burst mainly consists of multiple pulses with a duration (T90) of about 14.9（+4.8,-3.6）s.\nThe time-averaged spectrum from T0-0.32 to T0+14.61 s could be fit by a power law with a fluence of about 6.67 (+0.36,-0.35) E-06 erg/cm^2 in 10-1000 keV.\n\nThe GECAM light curve could be found here:\nhttps://twikinew.ihep.ac.cn/pubgecam/Sandbox/GRB/GECAMB_GRB241026A.png\n\nWe note that these results are very preliminary. Pillera (INFN Bari), R. Gupta (NASA GSFC), D. Kocevski (NASA/MSFC), and P. Loizzo (UniTrento and INFN Bari) report on behalf of the Fermi-LAT Collaboration:\n\nOn Oct 30, 2024, Fermi-LAT detected high-energy emission from GRB 241030A, which was also detected by Fermi-GBM (trigger 751960088 / 241030242, GCN 37955), Swift-BAT (Klingler et al., GCN 37956), and SVOM-GRM (Wang et al., GCN 37972).\n\nThe best LAT on-ground location is found to be:\n\nRA, Dec = 343.0, 80.4 (J2000)\n\nwith an error radius of 0.2 deg (90 % containment, statistical error only).\n\nThis was 16 deg from the LAT boresight at the time of the GBM trigger: T0 = 05:48:03 UT.\n\nThe data from the Fermi-LAT show a significant increase in the event rate that is spatially and temporally correlated with the GBM emission with high significance. The photon flux above 100 MeV in the time interval 0-800 s after the GBM trigger is (4.0 +/- 1.0) E-6 ph/cm2/s. The estimated photon index above 100 MeV is -2.13 +/- 0.27.\n\nThe highest-energy photon is a 2 GeV event which is observed ~ 470 seconds after the GBM trigger.\n\nThe Fermi-LAT point of contact for this burst is Roberta Pillera (roberta.pillera@ba.infn.it).\n\nThe Fermi-LAT is a pair conversion telescope designed to cover the energy band from 20 MeV to greater than 300 GeV. J. Klingler (GSFC/UMBC/CRESSTII), M. Ferro (INAF-OAB),\nJ. A. Kennea (PSU), F. E. Marshall (NASA/GSFC),\nK. L. Page (U Leicester), D. M. Palmer (LANL), T. M. Parsotan (GSFC),\nC. Salvaggio (INAF-OAB), T. Sbarrato (INAF-OAB) and\nM. A. Williams (PSU) report on behalf of the Neil Gehrels Swift\nObservatory Team:\n\nAt 18:34:20 UT, the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) triggered and\nlocated GRB 241030B (trigger=1263840).  Swift slewed immediately to the burst.\nThe BAT on-board calculated location is \nRA, Dec 50.788, +34.432 which is \n   RA(J2000) = 03h 23m 09s\n   Dec(J2000) = +34d 25' 57\"\nwith an uncertainty of 3 arcmin (radius, 90% containment, including \nsystematic uncertainty). This position may be improved as more data are received;\nthe latest position is available at https://www.swift.ac.uk/sper.  We\ncannot determine whether the source is fading at the present time. \n\nA power-law fit to a spectrum formed from promptly downlinked event\ndata gives a column density consistent with the Galactic value of 2.01\nx 10^21 cm^-2 (Willingale et al. 2013).\n\nUVOT took a finding chart exposure of 150 seconds with the White filter\nstarting 160 seconds after the BAT trigger. Ridnaia, D. Frederiks, A. Lysenko, D. Svinkin,\nA. Tsvetkova,  M. Ulanov, and T. Cline,\non behalf of the Konus-Wind team, report:\n\nThe long-duration GRB 241030A\n(Fermi-GBM detection: Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37955;\nSwift-BAT detection: Klingler et al., GCN 37956;\nSVOM/GRM observation: Wang et al., GCN 37972;\nFermi-LAT detection: Pillera et al., GCN 37979)\ntriggered Konus-Wind at T0=20996.591 s UT (05:49:56.591).\n\nThe burst light curve shows a multipeaked structure\nwhich starts at ~T0-112.7 s and has a total duration of ~210.4 s.\nThe emission is seen up to ~10 MeV.\n\nThe Konus-Wind light curve of this GRB is available at\nhttp://www.ioffe.ru/LEA/GRBs/GRB241030_T20996/\n\nAs observed by Konus-Wind, the burst\nhad a fluence of 5.48(-1.28,+1.95)x10^-5 erg/cm2,\nand a 64-ms peak flux, measured from T0+26.448 s,\nof 3.45(-0.82,+0.89)x10^-6 erg/cm2/s\n(both in the 20 keV - 10 MeV energy range).\n\nThe time-averaged spectrum of the burst\n(measured from T0 to T0+103.168 s)\nis best fit in the 20 keV - 10 MeV range\nby the GRB (Band) model with the following parameters:\nthe low-energy photon index alpha = -0.99(-0.19,+0.40),\nthe high energy photon index beta = -2.26(-0.61,+0.30),\nthe peak energy Ep = 140(-43,+35) keV\n(chi2 = 123/87 dof).\n\nThe spectrum near the maximum count rate\n(measured from T0+22.016 to T0+28.160 s)\nis best fit in the 20 keV - 10 MeV range\nby a power law with exponential cutoff model:\ndN/dE ~ (E^alpha)*exp(-E*(2+alpha)/Ep)\nwith  alpha = -0.91(-0.21,+0.23)\nand Ep = 196(-35,+55) keV (chi2 = 91/88 dof).\nFitting by a GRB (Band) model yields the same alpha and Ep,\nand an upper limit on the high energy photon index: beta < -2.2\n(chi2 = 91/87 dof).\n\nAssuming the redshift z=1.411 (Zheng et al., (GCN 37959))\nand a standard cosmology with H_0 = 67.3 km/s/Mpc, Omega_M = 0.315,\nand Omega_Lambda = 0.685 (Planck Collaboration, 2014),\nwe estimate the following rest-frame parameters:\nthe isotropic energy release E_iso is 2.84(-0.68,+1.04)x10^53 erg,\nthe peak luminosity L_iso is 4.47(-1.07,+1.15)x10^52 erg/s,\nthe rest-frame peak energy of the time-averaged spectrum\nEp,i,z is 339(-103,+84) keV and the spectrum near the maximum count rate\nEp,p,z is 473(-84,+133) keV.\n\nWith the obtained estimates, GRB 241030A is inside 68% prediction bands for\nboth 'Amati' and 'Yonetoku' relations derived for the sample of >300 long\nKW GRBs with known redshifts (Tsvetkova et al., 2017; Tsvetkova et al., 2021),\nsee http://www.ioffe.ru/LEA/GRBs/GRB241030_T20996/GRB241030A_rest_frame.pdf\n\nAll the quoted errors are at the 90% confidence level.\nAll the quoted values are preliminary.\n","createdOn":1730314859935}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241030B","submitter":"Phil Evans at U of Leicester <pae9@star.le.ac.uk>","submittedHow":"email","subject":"GRB 241030B: Prompt enhanced Swift-XRT position","circularId":37983,"bibcode":"2024GCN.37983....1E","body":"P.A. Abdikamalov (NU) report on behalf of the Energetic Cosmos Laboratory:\n\nThe Nazarbayev University Transient Telescope at Assy-Turgen Astrophysical Observatory (NUTTelA-TAO) observed the field of GRB 241030B observing in Sloan g' and r' bands, with the Burst Simultaneous Three-Channel Imager (BSTI; Grossan, Kumar & Smoot 2019, JHEA, 32, 14).\n\nWe started observations at 20:15:59 UT on 2024-10-30, 1.7 h after the BAT trigger. Observations were made in partly cloudy conditions. No source consistent with the XRT (P.A. Evans 2024, GCN 37983) was detected. We report the following results:\n\nstart time  t-t0(s)  end time    UL g'   UL r'  exposure_time (s)\n-----------------------------------------------------------------\n20:15:59     6100    20:16:59    19.2    19.0     60\n\nstart time is in UT. t-t0(s) gives the time since trigger, in seconds. UL g' and UL r' give the 5 sigma upper limit sensitivity in magnitudes, for images co-added to the given exposure time. R. Tanvir (U. Leicester), C. C. Thoene (ASU-CAS, AbAO), J. P. U. Fynbo (DAWN/NBI), A. de Ugarte Postigo (LAM/OCA, CNRS), L. Izzo (INAF-OACn & DARK/NBI), D. B. Gómez Velarde (GTC) report:\n\nWe observed the optical counterpart (Fu et al., GCN 37985) of GRB 241030B (Fermi GBM team, GCN 37980; Klingler et al., GCN 37981; Zhao et al., GCN 37984) using OSIRIS+ on the 10.4 m GTC telescope, at the Roque de los Muchachos Observatory (La Palma, Spain). The observation consisted of 4 spectra of 1200 s each, obtained with grism R1000B, covering the spectral range between 3650 and 7800 AA, at a resolving power of 600.\n\nThe acquisition image, obtained on 2024-10-31 at 02:42:33 UT, 8.14 hr since the trigger, shows the afterglow at r(AB) = 23.53 +/- 0.12 mag, as compared to Pan-STARRS field stars.\n\nThe spectrum shows a faint continuum over the complete spectral range, though a drop in flux is observed blueward of ~4700 AA, suggesting the onset of the Lyman-alpha forest. No clear DLA trough is visible, but several, low S/N absorption features are present to the red of the drop, which we tentatively interpret as Si II 1526, Si IV 1393, C IV 1548,1550 (blended), Al II 1670, Al III 1854,1862 at z = 2.82, which we propose as the redshift of GRB 241030B.","createdOn":1730375640174}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","eventId":"GRB 241029A","submitter":"Daniele B. Li, H. Lin, S.-S. Li, H.-C. Feng, B.-T. Wang, F.-F. Song, J. Mao and J.-M. Bai (YNAO, CAS) report:\n\nWe observed the optical counterpart of GRB 241030A (Klingler et al., GCN 37956; Watson et al., GCN 37957; Fernández-Rodríguez et al., GCN 37958; Zheng et al., GCN 37959; An et al., GCN 37960; Higuchi et al., GCN 37963; Qiu et al., GCN 37965; Lin et al., GCN 37966; Wu et al., GCN 37970; Breeveld &amp; Klingler, GCN 37974; Méndez-Lapido et al., GCN 37993; Moskvitin et al., GCN 38016; Busmann et al., GCN 38019; Schneider et al., GCN 38021), which was independently detected by Fermi/GBM (Fermi GBM Team, GCN 37955), Swift (Klingler et al., GCN 37956), SVOM/GRM (SVOM/GRM Team, GCN 37972), and Einstein Probe (Wu et al., GCN 37997; Liang et al., GCN 38026) as EP241030a.\n\nThe observation was conducted with the Gao-Mei-Gu (GMG) 2.4m telescope. Grism #3 was used, providing a wavelength coverage of 3400–9100 AA. A single 1-hour spectrum was obtained, with exposure beginning at 13:15:33 UT on 2024-10-30, about 7.46 hours after the Swift trigger.\n\nDespite the low signal-to-noise ratio of the spectrum, we identified a strong absorption line of Al II at 1671 AA, along with weaker absorption lines of Fe II at 2374 AA, 2383 AA, 2587 AA, and 2600 AA, Mg II at 2800 AA, and Mg I at 2852 AA. These metal absorption features consistently indicate a redshift of z ~ 1.4, consistent with the Keck/LRIS result (Zheng et al., GCN 37959).\n\nWe acknowledge the staff at the Lijiang Observatory for conducting the observation.\n","editedOn":1730468099786,"createdOn":1730452237838,"version":2,"circularId":38027}Topic: gcn.circulars, Message: {"$schema":"https://gcn.nasa.gov/schema/v4.1.0/gcn/circulars.schema.json","submitter":"A.
